description: As part of the Carlson Festival of the Arts at the University of Bridgeport, Aaron Copland, the composer, will conduct the school's concert band and choir Sunday. The program will be at 4 P.M. in the Arnold Bernhard Arts and Humanities Center on the campus in Bridgeport, Conn. The public is invited.

title: Pathetic Spectacle...
description: The appalling circus atmsphere surrdunding the case of Gary Mark Gilmore. the convicted murderer who response to his own demand may face a firing squad Utah next Monday, has by now totally obscured the serious questions at issue. Unconscionable commercial exploitation of the convict's wasted and violent life, and of the prospect of his violent death, is tending to make a folk hero of this coldblooded and probably pathological criminal.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: One of the nation's leading business economists, who tracks microeconomic developments in the American economy, has been taking a more optimistic view of the general economic outlook than many of her colleagues in recent weeks. And yet she favors more stimulus, via the tax route, than others are prepared to advocate at present. Norma Pace , senior vice president of the American Paper Institute and a prominent consultant in the business community. said in an interview this week that she was highly encouraged by general economic prospects. Mrs. Pace added, however, that the incoming Carter Administration would be confronted by four serious challenges that would ultimately determine the course of economic activity in this country the next few years.

title: CARTER FAILED IN BID ON STEEL PRICE RISES
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Dec. 2 Jimmy Carter's official spokesman in effect conceded today that the Presidentelect's attempt to dissuade the steel industry from rasing prices had been a failure and strongly indicated that Mr. Carter would make no further efforts to do so until after his inauguration Jan. 20.

title: FreeAgent War: Earlier Fears and Current Realities
description: Four weeks and approximately $21 million after the historic freeagent draft, where does baseball stand? Well, for one thing, it does stand, which puts the sport in a healthier position than its doomsday prophets had darkly predieted. Some owners, of course, continue to warn About that the structure of the Baseball game will crumble under the weight of the dollars that suddenly are flowing into the players pockets, but don't try to convince George Steinhrenner, Gene Autry or Ray Kroc of that dire forecast.

title: A Top Bargain For Theaterlovers
description: From the outside, 321 East 73d Street looks like an apartment building or a tenement. Once the home of the Bohemian Benevolent Society, the building is indistinguishable from its neighbors except for a drab flag identifying the structure as the Manhattan Theater Club. Inside, however, on any weekend is a thriving, theatrical community three stories simmering with plays, workshops, rehearsals, cabaret shows, operas and poetry readings. And it is one of the best theatrical bargains in town.

title: Cash Prices
LAURIE ERSKINE, CREATOR OF RENFREW THE MOUNTIE
description: Laurie York Erskine, the author of the Renfrew of the Royal Mounted series of adventure yarns, died Tuesday at his home in New Hope, Pa. He was 82 years old.

title: Open Interest
MORTIMER ROSENTHAL
description: Mortimer Rosenthal, a vice president of Sidney J. Kreiss, hosiery specialists at 350 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Far Rockaway, after a heart attack. His age was 60.

title: Two Landlords Held for Failure To Provide Heat
description: Two landlords were arrested yesterday on charges of willfully failing to provide heat and hot water to tenants in their three Harlem tenements during the winter months earlier this year.

title: Ellinghaus Leaves Control Board;
description: William M. Ellinghaus resigned yesterday from the Emergency Financial Control Board. which oversees the city's finances, and Governor Carey named Kenneth S. Axelson, formerly Deputy Mayor for Finance, to replace him.

title: New Jersey Soldier Convicted for Refusal To Cut Afro Hairdo
description: FORT ORD, Calif.. Dec. 2 A soldier from Englewood, N.J., was convicted today at an Army court martial of failing to obey an order to get her Afro hairstyle cut to conform to military standards.

title: Where Puppets Strut Their Stuff
description: The puppet show, that delight of childish fancy, is in full seasonal swing this weekend. According to taste, there are hand puppets, stick puppets, marionettes, shadow puppets and even live puppets actors masquerading as lifeless effigies behind masks that would only he found on puppets. You can savor puppets in theaters, museums, libraries, halls and even in the Swedish Cottage, that reproduction lastcentury schnolroom up in Central Park.

title: Optimistic View of Economy
description: A leading business economist, takes a more optimistic view of the economic outlook. Page D9.

title: Art: John. Walker's Collages
description: JOHN WALKER'S new paintings at the Cuningham Ward Gallery, 94 Prince Street, must be categorized as collages, in that they are made of discrete pieces of canvas stuck one on top of the other.

title: Jersey Utility Gets License to Run First Unit of Huge Nuclear Plant
description: HANCOCKS BRIDGE, N.J.. Dec. 2 The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced today that it had received a license to operate the first unit of its Salem generating station here. The unit is the first of four in a nuclear facility that is to become one of the largest in the world.

title: John Scott, an Expert Onthe Soviet Union, Dies of Heart Attack
description: John Scott, an authority on the Soviet Union who was variously a correspondent, editor, lecturer and assistant to the publisher of Time magazine for 30 years, died Wednesday of a heart attack at the Lake Shore Club in Chicago while on a speaking tour. He was 64 years old and lived in Ridgefield. Conn.

title: Music: Undone by Virtuosity
description: Viktor Friedman's recital at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was that of a pianist who seems to go through scores in search of portions he might project in some special way. As he played Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 332), Rachmaninoff's Variations on a Theme of Corelli, Liszt's Mephisto Waltz and Prokofiev's Sonata No. 6 in A, the  listener was moved along from effect to effect, most of them accomplished with preat skill.

title: Castro Assails Some Oil Nations as Assembly Opens
description: HAVANA, Dec. 2 (Reuters) Cuba's recently elected National Assembly opened here today with Prime Minister Fidel Castro accusing some oilexporting countries of making the third world bear the brunt of the world economic crisis.

title: BOOMIS HELD SOURCE OF OTHERS DONATIONS
description: Two $5,000 contributions listed in the 1973 campaign records of Mayor Beame as having come from a relative and business associate of Christopher Boomis actually came from the real estate developer himself, according to friends of Mr. Boomis. It was not clear last night whether such contributions would have been a violation of state election law in 1973.

title: Money Supply Shrinks, Indicating Fed Still Shuns Expansion Policy
description: Despite growing evidence that the nation's economic recovery may he running out of steam, Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, either seems reluctant to adopt the more expansionary monetary policy that many Democratic economists and Congressmen are urging on him or is having difficulty doing so.

title: Poetry Readers Salute Rilke at Chumley's
description: Chumley's bar and restaurant in Greenwich Village is one of the coziest and one of the most inviting of its kind in the city, if" in the words of its manager, Tom Graziano "you can find it. That proviso is not rhetoric. Chumley's is not a place a stranger wil: casually stumble into. It is at 86 Radford Street on the corner of Bedford and Barrow. But there are no signs; a customer must first push through a v,ndeit gate marked private. He or shy is then in a flagstone courtyard on which three or four doors open, no one entrance different from the others. Only by catching a glint of bottles through a closed door will the bar be found. Its huggermugger location is Pxplained by its origin. Chumley's used to he a speakeasy, and the place dates back 50 years.

title: News Summary
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev has given what seems to be an indication of a desire in Moscow to cooperate with the Carter Administration. A spokesman for Mr. Carter said that the Communist Party leader had said that Moscow would go out of its way to avoid any crisis with the United States at the outset of the new Administration. The message was said to have been relayed through Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, who recently was in Moscow. I Page I, Column 1.1

title: In a Nutshell
description: The basic groups of cultivated peanuts are Virginia, Valencia, Spanish and Runner. As yet there is no Georgia; down there they grow mostly Runners.

title: ... New Jersey Penalty
description: They voted for the electric chair in the New Jersey State Assembly the other day. The vote was 42 to 35 in a session that has been described as charged with emotion.

title: Mother of Gilmore Appeals for Supreme Court Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The mother of Gary Mark Gilmore asked the Supreme Court today to block the execution of her son long enough to give her a chance to seek a full review by the Court of Mr. Gilmore's conviction and sentence. The execution is scheduled for sunrise Monday in Utah.

title: Cards, Seeking a Playoff Spot, Face Spirited Colts
description: With the college football season largely completed, the professionals move some of their action to Saturday, and tomorrow will bring two games, one of them special. There is little to choose between the Baltimore Colts, who have clinched a playoff position, and the St. Louis Cardinals, who have not. They are to kick off in St. Louis and Channel will televise the game here beginning at 1 P.M. The second game is Atlanta at Los Angeles, on Channel 2 at 3:30.

title: Albany Investigates. Violent Deaths At Psychiatric Center in the Bronx
description: At the request of a citizen's watchdog group, the State Commission of Investigation has subpoenaed the hospital records of six patients from the Bronx State Psychiatric Center who committed suicide, were victims of assaults or who died under unclear circumstances.

title: Holiday Is Early For the Students In Putnam, Conn.
description: PUTNAM, Conn., Dec. 2 Four children were iceskating today on a pond. Two more were in Pat's General Store, buying bubhlegum. A small hoy was with his mother in her classes at the University of Connecticut.

title: Judge in CarterArtis Trial Allows Testimony Hinting at Racial Motive
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 2 The prosecution in the triplemurder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Anis won a victory today, when Judge Brno L. Leopizzi ruled that it could offer testimony suggesting a racial motive for the killings here 10 years ago.

title: Society's Future: A Liberal Zoo
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y. We all know about the liberals and crime. But as far as I can tell, nobody has projected the trends of the 60's and 70's off into the fearful future. Let's take a deep breath and try it.

title: CARTER GETS PLEDGE BREDINEV WILL SHUN CRISIS TO TEST HIM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter has been advised by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, that the Soviet Union will go out of its way to avoid any crisis with the United States early in the new administration. a Carter sookesman said today.

title: Cape Town Police End Black Riots; Scores Arrested
description: CAPE TOWN, Dec. 2 (UPI) A force of 600 policemen sealed off the black township of Guguletu in armored cars today an darrested scores of blacks to end three days of arson and rioting.

title: Amid an Uncertain Detente, the Russians Wait for Carter
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 When Leonid I. Brezhnev arrived in Rumania last week, he was taken along a receiving line of foreign diplomats, among them an American. Oh, the Soviet Communist Party leader is reported to have remarked, the country with two Presidents one in office and one in action. The comment suggested the degree of concern with which the Soviet leadership views the time of transition in Washington. As word of the quip drifted back to Moscow, Russians assigned to study American affairs were still trying to assemble a picture of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, whose unknown qualities have raised questions here about future contacts between the two great powers.

title: Brascan Reports Offer for Subsidiary
description: Brascan Ltd., of Toronto, a public utility holding company, said yesterday that a group of private investors in Brazil was interested in purchasing Brascan's 83 percent interest in LightServicos de Electricidade S. A., the electric public utility that serves Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.

title: Mrs. Court Injures Leg After Victory in Singles
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 2 (AP)  Margaret Court, who has returned to the tennis circuit after a year's voluntary absence, may be sidelined again  unwillingly and temporarily. She pulled a leg muscle during a doubles match today in a $100,000 women's international tournament.

title: Publishing: A Flaw in the Golden Spike
description: ACENTURY after the railroad magnates carved an iron swath through the Western wilderness to the Pacific Coast, an attempt has been made by the Association of American Railroads to challenge the contents of a forthcoming rail history by Dee Brown, the author of Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Outbreak of Skin Rash in N.H.L. Causing Lots of Head Scratching
description: An outbreak of a mysterious type of contact dermatitis has struck scores of players in the National Hockey League, according to Dr. William F. Schorr, a dermatologist attached to the Marshfield (Wis.) Clinic who is investigating the skin disease.

title: CARTER IS EXPECTED TO APPOINT VANCE SECRETARY OF STATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Cyrus R. Vance, former Deputy Secretary of Defense under President Johnson, is virtually certain to be named by Presidentelect Jimmy Carter as his Secretary of State, according to sources in contact with Mr. Carter, Vice Presidentelect Walter F. Mondale and their aides.

title: Danny Murtaugh Is Dead at 59; Won 2 Series as Pirate Manager
description: CHESTER. Pa., Dec. 2 (AP) Danny Murtaugh, who as the Pittsburgh Pirates manager led the team to two World Series championships, died today, two days after having suffered a stroke and two months after having relinquished the manager's post.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS GAIN ON THE SWISS FRANC
description: LONDON, Dec. 2 (UPI) The dollar closed mixed on European money markets today with a substantial gain against the Swiss franc. The British pound fell marginally after gaining more than a cent the day before.

title: Imagination Express On Track At Jersey ModelRailroad Show
description: Six years ago, as he was approaching 50, Bob Hewison of Cranford, N.J., set out to recapture and preserve his fondest boyhood memory: watching the unloading at dawn of a circus train at a siding in the old freight yard in Westfield, N.J. With some pieces of hard basswood, a razor, glue, paint, patience and recall, he built a 1925vintage, miniature 10car circus train and stocked it with horses, elephants and camels, and tigers and lions in their cages.

title: China's U.N. Delegate, Huang Hua, Promoted to Foreign Minister Post
description: HONG KONG. Friday, Dec. 3 China's Foreign Minister has been dismissed and has been replaced by the delegate to the United Nations, Huang Hua, the Chinese  press agency, lisinhua, said today.

title: Kerouac Translated From Page to Stage
description: Long ago before Watergate, before Vietnam, before civil rights there was Jack Kerouac, the rebel who epitomized, if not invented, the Beat Generation. But there was perhaps another Kerouac: a sensitive man trapped in a macho age, unable to relate to people who mattered to him. It is the trapped and tortured man who is the subject of Martin Duberman's new play, Visions of Kerouac, which opens Off Off Broadway tonight at the Lion Theater Company.

title: Money Supply Drop Sends Bonds To 76 Highs and Spurs Trading
description: The $2.9 billion drop in the nation's money supply reported by the Federal Reserve yesterday afternoon came as major surprise to the credit markets. Trading activity expanded after the announcement and bond prices. which had risen moderately earlier in the day, surged upward to set highs for the year. New bond issues also sold more rapidly.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Rhodesian Bridge Bombed Again
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 2 (UPI)  Black nationalist guerrillas have blown up a railway bridge over the Matetsi River near the border with Zambia and Botswana for the second time in two months, Rhodesian military sources said today. No casualties were reported. On Oct. 6, an explosion at the bridge sent 11 railroad cars crashing into the river.

title: Buffalo, Buried in 3 Feet of Snow, Declared in State of Emergency
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 2 After three days of blinding snow, this buried city peeked out today to see what had happened. It was something like looking out the window of an Arciic igloo.

title: Probation at Minnesota Struck Down by Court
description: ST. PAUL. Dec. 2 (UP1) A fedleral judge granted today the request of the University of Minnesota for a temporary injunction against a probation on the school's teams imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. Inc probation, stemming from alleged infractions by three basketball players, had barred all men's teams from postseason play and from N.C.A.A.sponsored television appearances.

title: 4 Representatives Considering Race for New York City Mayor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  It is New York political tradition for several members of its Congressional delegation to run for Mayor, and this year appears to be no exception. Four of the 16 members whose districts are entire

title: The Price of Steel
description: Having already announced price increases averaging 6 percent on flatrolled products, the heads of major steel companies now would like to meet with Presidentelect Carter to review in detail the reasons the increases are necessary.

title: Art: The Modern's New Masterworks
description: MAKING ADDITIONS to the permanent collection of, painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art especially to the collection of the great European masters is a delicate business. The collection already boasts many of the finest works these artists are known to have produced. There is little point in adding to such a collection, which is generally regarded as the finest in the world, simply to increase its size. New acquisitions, besides having to meet the obvious criterion of outstanding esthetic quality, must also extend our knowledge of the artists.

title: There Was Room To Bow and Curtsy, But Not to Tango
description: The stag line, in the school blazers of St. David's, Trinity and St. Bernard's eyed the girls warily. Take partners, the instructor called out. A 9yearold girl in a floorlength taffeta skirt reached for a wellscrubbed boy in a dark suit. dragged him out of his chair and led him into a fox trot. Carefully watching his feet, the boy went through the motions of dancing. As soon as the music stopped, he ran off and left his partner in the middle of the floor.

title: OUTPUT OF HEATING OILS TOPS CONSUMPTION LEVEL
description: The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that production of home heating oil set a fiveyear record last week, reflecting the nation's continuing cold weather.

title: Auto Layoffs of 14,000 Set in U.S., Canada
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2 More than 14,000 auto workers at six car and truck plants in the United States and Canada will be laid off for one week beginning Monday as all four domestic auto companies cut back some production to control inventories.

title: About Real Estate
description: GLEN COVE. L.I. Out of the ashes of a fire on School Street in this North Shore community Nathan Zausrner's answer to suburban shopping malls is moving toward a March completion date.

title: Article 7 No Title
TeenAgers Held in Slaying
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa.. Dec. 2 (UPI) Two teenagers are being held in Montgomery County Prison for allegedly robbing a  Pottstown man of $8 and then beating him to death. The suspects, PrestonSutton, 16 years old, of Pottstown, and Phillip Allen, 18, of Newark, have been charged with murder in the slaying of Keith Wesley, 45, who was found Oct 23 on the Reading Railroad concourse in Pottstown.

title: White House Criticizes Steel Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 2 The Ford Administration hammered hard today at the latest steel price increase, implying that it was unjustified and encouraging companies that buy steel to bargain for discounts.

title: Notes on People
description: The Americanborn wife of Donald MacLean, the British diplomat turned Soviet spy and defector, is in the United States visiting her mother, it was reported in Moscow and London yesterday. Melinda Marling MacLean, now a Soviet citizen, and their three children joined her husband in the Soviet Union in 1953, two years after he and another Briton. Guy Burgess, fled to Moscow to avoid arrest. Mr. Burgess died in 1963. Moscow sources said that Mrs. MacLean had left the Soviet Union last summer for a prolonged visit with her ailing, 85yearold mother, Melinda Dunbar, who was last reported living in Chicago. The London Daily Telegraph quoted Mr. MacLean as saying, There is no date for her return, but I can assure you she will be coming back to us.

title: BOOMIS HELD SOURCE OF OTHERS DONATIONS
description: Two $5,000 contributions listed in the 1973 campaign records of Mayor Beame as having come from a relative and business associate of Christopher Boomis actually came from the real estate developer himself, according to friends of Mr. Boomis. It was not clear last night whether such contributions would have been a violation of state election law in 1973.

title: For International Traders In Stocks, It's 21Hour Day
description: The sun seldom sets on the world of international securities trading. Virtually around the clock, in some corner of the globe, a stock exchange is open and the securities of giant multinational corporations are being traded.

title: S.E.C. Bars Delay on Estimates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Securities and Exchange Commission, resisting strong pressures, said today that it would not delay or modify its plan to require companies with nonfinancial assets exceeding $100 million to calculate the cost of replacing their physical plants.

title: Gibson Backs National Health Care
description: NEWARK, Dec. I Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson pledged today to press for a national health program that would provide essential medical care to individuals regardless of their financial needs and inI surance coverage.

title: Dachowitz, Bergnan s Accountant, Gets Year in Medicaid Fraud Plot
description: Samuel A. Dachowitz, an accountant who was closely associated with Bernard Bergman in the nursinghome industry, was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of a year and a day for his part in a scheme to defraud the government of Medicaid funds.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Parents tend to entrust their children to Sesame Street as if it were an ideal baby sitter: resourceful, instructional and reliable.

title: G.E. Sets Consortium To Make Electric Auto
description: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 2 (UPI)  The General Electric Company announced today that it had formed a consortium to compete in the Federal Government's program to produce a practical electric automobile.

title: Magic's the Special on Lunch Menu For SleightofHand Group
description: Why am I sitting here? asked Sam Schwartz. He got up. I'm not sitting, I'm standing. Why am I standing? Because I'm a card man and I have to stand for this trick.

title: Two Landlords Held for Failure To Provide Heat
description: Two landlords were arrested yesterday on charges of willfully failing to provide heat and hot water to tenants in their three Harlem tenements during the winter months earlier this year.

title: Kunstler and the Courts in a Battle On Right to Discuss Pending Trial
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dcc. 2 The state c.c,crt system of New Jersey and William M. Kunstler, the New York trial lawyer, l:?ined battle today over what an attorney, under court rules, may say about a.pending trial. The issue also has other implications.

title: Moon Church Plans New York Daily
description: Plans are being made for a new daily newspaper in New York City, supporting the causes of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and his Unification Church of America.

title: Judge Denies Mandel a Mistrial After Bribery Report
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 2 Federal District Judge John H. Pratt refused today to declare a mistrial in Gov. Marvin Mandel's lederal corruption trial after reports that a juror had been offered a $10,000 bribe to vote for acquittal.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Article 6 No Title
Canada's Parliament Opens Inquiry On Payments to Aid Reactor Sales
description: OTTAWA, DEC. 2 A parliamentary committee is investigating the propriety of multimilliondollar payments to foreign agents by Canadian Government corporations to promote the sale of nuclear reactors in South Korea and Argentina and chemical products in Europe.

title: Spanish Opposition Will Name 10, Including a Red, to Meet Suarez
description: MADRID, Dec. 2 Spain's main opposition groups agreed late last night to form a 10member committee, including a representative of the Communist Party, to negotiate with the Government the terms of the parliamentary elections scheduled for next year.

title: Moynihan Names Chief Aide
description: Senatorelect Daniel P. Moynihan anounced yesterday that he would appoint Stuart J. Gordon, a Manhattan lawyer, as his administrative assistant, the top aide to a senator.

title: Doing the Sidewalks of New York
description: Unlike so many other American cities, New York is best relished on foot. For the knowledgeable stroller or even the walker with an inquisitive mind, there are even surprises almost on a doortodoor basis. True, there are the dull reaches, the bedroom regions, where one house looks like another, where history and character have given way to bland uniformity, but even in such parts there is usually bedrock of history: Ebbets Field stood here, George Washington stood there, this was an Indian settlement, and that was a pioneering housing development.

title: Article 4 No Title
World News Briefs
description: VIENTIANE. Laos, Dec. 2 Virtually the entire population of the Laotian capital turned out today to watch or take part in a parade to mark the first anniversary of the Communist takeover of Laos.

title: Market Place
description: The Deseret Pharmaceutical company, a small concern on the Big Board in the disposable surgicalproducts field, was a standout In Tuesday's market, setting a new high of 30 and closing at 30, up 3.

title: FINANCIER, A MAGAZINE, TO BE ISSUED MONTHLY
description: Willard C. Rappleye Jr., former editor of The American Banker, announced yesterday the establishment of a new monthly magazine, Financier The Journal of Financial Affairs.

title: How to Get There
description: Tlie easiest and quickest way to get to Cobble Hill is by subway  Take the IND A train or either the Lexington or Seventh Avenue IRT express to Borough Hall in Brooklyn. On the BMT, it's the RR local to Court Street in Brooklyn. Walk south several blocks to Atlantic Avenue and Court Street to begin your tour. If you drive, take the Brooklyn Bridge to Joralemon Street, and turn right. Make a left turn at Court Street to Atlantic Avenue and look for a parking space. There's a municipal lot on Court Street, before you reach Atlantic.

title: Ford's Half Brother Killed in Tennessee Car Accident
description: LEBANON, Tenn., Dec. 2 (AP) Leslie Henry King, President Ford's half brother, was legally drunk when he was killed today in a headon collision of his car and a truck, state officials said.

title: Islanders Set Back By Penguins, 4 to 2
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 2 Thanks to 18 Penguins, one of them named Herron, the Islanders recession continued tonight at Nassau Coliseum. A 42 loss to Pittburgh stretched the New Yorkers homegame losing streak to four, and lengthened their slump to five defeats in six games.

title: South Africa Court Clears 5 Whites Accused of Aiding Banned Groups
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 2 A long and controversial trial ended here today in the acquittal of four student leaders and a university lecturer all white accused of conspiring to promote the aims of two banned groups, the Communist Party and the African National Congress.

title: RETAIL SALES GAINS LOWER IN NOVEMBER, BIG CHAINS REPORT
description: The big retail sales lift in October abated in November as the nation's consumers scaled down their buying despite cold, seasonal weather and the onset of the Christmas shopping season.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec 2 State Senator Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville became today the first Republican to enter next year's race for Governor by filing with the State Election Law Commission.

title: Formidable Chinese Diplomat
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2  The, short, stockily built man with graying hair who has been named the Foreign Minister of China has demonstrated throughout his five years here that he can sit for hours at a conterence table, chain SMOKing but otherwise motionless. A barrage of angry Soviet words aimed in his direction has had little visible effect, though the smoke has tended to curl heavier. When the diplomat, Huang Hua the name is pronounced hwong hwa has spoken he has proved a formidable match for his Soviet antagonists. He is also a diplomat who knows the United States and has proved equally at ease with officials from the third world as well as the West.

title: Management
description: Will a good big man whip a good little man every time?

title: Pentagon Backs Production of B1; Carter Given 5 Months for Review
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 2 The Defense Department approved today initial production of the BI strategic bomber, but under a contractual arrangement that will give the Carter administration five months to review the future of the $22.8 billion program.

title: Weekend Gardening: For Peanuts
description: Move over, avocado, the in growit fromseed houseplant this year will, in all probability and for obvious reasons, by a peanut. Although the avocado offers the gardening gourmet a plurality of benefits, letting one eat the fruit and grow the plant, too, sparing a nut or two from a fistful of peanuts for planting is not too much of a deprivation. And the peanut plant is easy to grow. Just be sure you start out with raw peanuts. Roasted nuts will produce not even wilted leaves.

title: Dole Aide Describes Visit by GateCrasher
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) The day before Steven Williams of Santa Fe, N. M., crashed his pickup truck into a White House gate, he visited the office of Senator Robert J. Dole, describing himself as an anrgy citizen, Mr. Dole's staff members said today. And in New Orleans, a campaign coordinator of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter said he recognized Mr. Williams as the man hanging around Mr. Carter's campaign visit to New Orleans Oct. 30. He said that the man had seen making antiCarter remarks but wasn't really abusive.

title: Lines From Rilke
description: Put out my eyes, and 1 can see you still; slam my ears to, and I can hear you yet; and without any feet can go to you: and tongueless, 1 can conjure you at will. Rreah off my arms, I shall take hold of you and grasp you with my heart as with a hand. arrest my heart, my brain will heat as true; and if you set this brain of mine afire, then on nay bloodstream I will carry you.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THOMAS WOLFE was one of the more renowned chroniclers of Brooklyn. On the whole he was fascinated with the borough, remarking in the words of one his characters that it would take a lifetime to necome truly familiar with the pint which is why only the dead could know it

title: Stocks Off as Drug Issues Set Lows; A.T. &T. at a Peak Before Slipping
description: Leading drug issues set yearly lows yesterday, while the general stock market drifted down slightly to erase Wednesday's mild advance.

title: Panama Presses for Commitment By Carter on Canal Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Panamanian Government is seeking an early commitment from Presidentelect Jimmy Carter to complete negotiations on a new Panama Canal treaty giving Panama full sovereignty over the waterway.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 Avco Financial Services Inc., a consumer loan company owned by the Avco Corporation, disclosed in an amended registration statement made available at the Securities and Exchange Commission today, that net earnings for the fourth quarter ended Nov. 30, would be reduced by about $25 million because of foreign currency losses.

title: Robustelli Agrees to Retain Giants Post
description: PLILASANTVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 2  Andy Robustelli, who was hired three years ago to rebuild the Giants, but whn says he doesn't want to make my life's work, has agreed to return to the National Football League team m":t season.

title: St. Jan of the Torch Song
description: It's as if Joan of Arc had decided to take a vacation from politics and the military life and go barnstorming around the French provinces with a troupe of jongleurs. Jan de Gaetani, the mezzosoprano who has long been regarded as the St. Jan of modern music, is taking a fling with Cole Porter. It's not just one of those things, either: Miss de Gaetani is serious, and she has made a record whose point is that Porter was, too.

title: From France to 57th St., That Faded Sportswear
description: Fans of Lothar's sportswear no longer need go abroad to replenish their wardrobes. The French company that popularized the streaky washedout blue look has opened its eighth store, at 4 West 57th Street, Here, in a setting of natural wood, glass and mirrors like the forerunners in Europe, are displayed the classic shirts, pants and jackets that now come in some 12 colors and in solid as well as washedout fabrics.

title: People in Sports
description: Football players are not the only athletes going in for knee surgery this lime of year. Elliott Maddox of the Yankees had several hone chips removed from his right knee this week, it. was learned yesterday.

title: Wherein a Tax Cut Is Termed Obscene
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. In the weeks following the election, quite a number of my economist friends of distinguished reputation expressed themselves promptly and decisively on behalf of a tax reduction to stimulate the economy. No partisanship was involved; the same action was also proposed and taken early in the Ford Administration.

title: Clark Leads U.S. Tonight Against Soviet Fighters
description: The Soviet Union's 10man heavyweight boxing team, headed by Igor Vysotsky, meets the United States squad, led by Jimmy Clark, John fate. Marvin Stinson and Gregor Page, at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: IntegrityNot Jive
description: IT IS CURTAIN TIME Sunday at the Theater de Lys in Greenwich Village. Act 1. Total darkness. The sound of rifle fire erupts throughout the theater. The Brownsville Raid begins, and the Negro Ensemble Company has started its 10th anniversary season.

title: FORUM TO AID INQUIRY INTO YOUTH'S SLAYING
description: Mayor Beanie said yesterday that he would appoint a task force made up of persons outside the Police Department to help disseminates information developed n the investigation of the slaying by a police officer ci a 13yearold Brooklyn youth.

title: Columbia Five Stuns Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. N.J., Dec. 2  The resurgence of Columbia University's varsity basketball program began for real tonight in the Rutgers Gymnasium as Columbia's youngsters upset the host team, 8575, before a stunned crowd of Rutgers rooters that saw two streaks broken.

title: Celebrating St. Nick Old Dutch Style
description: CHRISTMAS IS COMING, but St. Nicholas Day is coming even sooner, and there will he a special celebration of it this weekend in the northern Bronx.

title: A PATHOLOGIST TESTIFIES AT DR. FRIEDGOOD'S TRIAL
description: MINEOLA. L.L. Dec. 2 A pathologist for the defense in the murder trial of Dr. Charles E. Friedgood testified today that Sophie Friedgood died at least seven hours after the prosecution said she had been killed by her husband.

title: Dancing Brings the Balkans Together
description: The piercing reed sound of a zummare, the stomp of Polish mountain dancers and the strong, focused voices of a Bulgarian women's quartet will fill Hunter College's Assembly Hall tomorrow night, when the Balkan Arts Center offers its ninth and annual Winter Folk Festival. Spectators caught up in the concert's exuberance are then invited to dance themselves at a party in the evmnasium upstairs.

title: History With Strings Attached
description: I always hold up the wooden actors as instructive :bjectlessons to our flesh and blood players, wrote George Bernard Shaw to Vittorio Podrecca, director of the Tentro dei Piccoli in Rome. The puppet is the actor in his primitive form. Its symbolic costumes, from which all realistic and historical ly correct. impertinences are banished, its unchanging stare, petrified (or rattier signitiecp in a grimace expressive to the highest degree attainable by the carver's art, the mimicry by which it suggests human gesture in unearthly caricature these give to its performance an intensity to which few actors can pretend, an intensity which imposes on our imagination like those images in immovable hieratic attitudes on the stained glass of Chartres Cathedral, in which the ganing tourists seem like little lifeless dolls moving jerkily in the draft from the doors, reduced to sawdust insignificance by the contrast with the gigantic vitality in the windows overhead.

title: Pop Music: Cryer and Ford
description: When Alan Jay Lerner, who was scheduled for this week at the Broadway at the Ballroom series at the Ballroom, 458 West Broadway, postponed his appearance for the second time, Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford not only came to the Ballroom's rescue to keep the series going, but brought a fresh point of view to it.

title: Verity of Armco Says Increase Is Justified by Costs and Demand
description: William Verity, chairman of the Armco Steel Corporation, the nation's sixth largest steel maker, said yesterday that the industry's recent price increase on sheet steel was justified on the basis of both cost of production and market demand.

title: EXMAYOR GANGEMI OF JERSEY CITY DIES
description: Thomas Gangemi, former Mayor of Jersey City and a prominent figure in Hudson County Democratic politics, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday at his Jersey City home. He was 73 years old.

title: Brad Ragan Inc. and 5 Officers Charged With Frauds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 In a major enforcement action, the Securities and Exchange Commission today charged Brad Ragan Inc. and five officers of the large tireretreading company with a host of fraudulent practices, including bribing about 280 of the company's customers to send business its way.

title: Article 3 No Title
Jewelry Is Stolen From Suite. Of Former Venezuelan President
description: Jewelry and a coin collection with an estimated value of $15,000 were re, ported stolen last night from the mid1 town hotel room of former Venezuelan President Romulo Betancourt and his wife, while they were out shopping, the police said.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (UPI) With the nation on the threshhold of the usual start of its influenza season, the national Center for Disease Control reported today that less than onefourth of the adult Americans eligible for swine flu shots had been vaccinated.

title: Article 5 No Title
Rhodesian Government Rules Out Black PropOsals on Interim Regime
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2 The four black nationalist delegations to the conference on the future of Rhodesia presented proposals today on the structure of an interim government to replace white minority rule, but the representatives of the white government in Salisbury termed them strange and esoteric.

title: Poland Shuffles Cabinet Members; Shifts Priority to Consumer Needs
description: WARSAW, Dec. 2 (AP) Poland's Communist Government today raised the priority on production of consumer goods and shuffled the Cabinet of Prime Minister Piotr Jaroszewicz.

title: Japanese Appear to Be Building Their Own Brand of Democracy
description: TOKYO. Dec. 2 Kazuvuki Kori is a pharmacist who, like many Japanese, feels a strong sense of obligation to vote in Sunday's elections for Japan's powerful lower house of Parliament.

title: Public TV Officials Ease Programming Rift
description: Officials of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service, meeting yesterday to resolve a dispute over which body had jurisdiction over the national programming for public television, agreed to set aside the issue of sovereignty and to try again to work in partnership.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 4.6%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 13.5 billion tonmiles, 4.6 percent above the yearearlier level. Both weeks included the Thanksgiving holiday. The A.A.R. also reported that carloadings in the same week totaled 390,065 cars, off 0.4 percent from last year. Americart Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was up 4.4 percent from last year.

title: Advertising
description: Nina Ricci Fragrances, which carved out a respectable market share by appealing only to women, has tripled its advertising budget and is adding the giftgiving male to its target list.

title: Closing the Courts
description: Amid all the speculation about Presidentelect Carter's forthcoming appointments, nothing is being said about his prospective nominees to the Supreme Court, since there aren't any openings. In the long run, however, the number and character of Mr. Carter's choices for the high court might form one of his most important Presidential actions.

title: Blacks Stage Boycott in S. Carolina County
description: ST. MATTHEWS, S.C., Dec. 2 The civil rights movement took longer than usual to reach St. Matthews and the surrounding cotton plantations and soybean fields of Calhoun County.

title: Study Finds Energy Projects Off Jersey and Delaware Pose Serious Ecological and Technological Problems
description: The proposed development of huge energy systems off the coasts of New Jersey and Delaware to produce oil, gas and electricity will pose serious ecological, technological and political problems that state and Federal agencies are not equipped to handle, a Congressional study indicates.

title: Accounting Body Sets New Rules on Leasing Deals
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, in a move to resolve more than a decade of controversy, established yesterday major new standards of financial accounting and reporting for lease transactions. They become effective on or after next Jan. 1, except on lease transactions arranged before then.

title: E.E.C. Pledges Fairer Trade Terms to the Yugoslavs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 The European Economic Community pledged today to seek more equitable terms of trade for Communist Yugoslavia.

title: The Pop Life
description: SOME POP MUSIC artists everybody knows about. There can hardly be a sentient American who hasn't at least heard of Bob Dylan or the Rolling Stones. But other acts lead curious secret lives. They may be beloved by their multitudes of screaming fans, who buy millions their records and fill huge stadiums to adore them. But they are still unknown to the mass of Americans or, if known, then known vaguely and only be dismissed.

title: ADM. ANGELO JACHINO
description: ROME, Dec. 3 (UPI)Adm. Angelo Jachino, who commanded Italy's naval forces in the early years of World War II, died yesterday, relatives announced today. He was 87 years old.

title: Girl Clinically Dies; Murder Is Charged
description: A 27yearold Long island man was charged yesterday with seconddegree murder in the death of an Islip girl he allegedly attacked and robbed Monday. The victim, Karen Pomroy, was certified as neurologically and clinically dead Thursday and was then removed from lifesustaining apparatus in Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, where she had been taken following the attack.

title: English Relics Falling Victim To Modern Ills
description: There is, it appears, no end to Britain's travail this year.

title: Mondale Again Promises to Try To Prevent Closing of Arsenal
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) Vice Presidentelect Walter F. Mondale has repeated his pledge that he will do his best to keep open the Frankford Arsenal in Philadelphia after Jimmy Carter becomes President.

title: Soybean Futures Prices Rise 12 Cents a Bushel; Wheat and Corn Advance
description: CHICAGO, Dec.3 (AP) Soybean futures gained 12 cents a bushel today and strongly influenced higher prices in other pits on the floor.

title: Open Interest
Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Books of The Times
description: Who does not know the marvelous story of Capt. John Smith of the Jamestown Colony, how he was captured by the Indians and how he was saved at the very last second from having his brains bashed in on that January day in 1608 by the comely Pocahontas, the favorite daughter of the Powhatan chieftain, who flung herself on Smith as the bludgeons were about to descend upon him? The story is recounted with various degrees of acceptance in all the history books; and for those who learn their history from fiction, it was brilliantly and wickedly satirized in John Barth's The SotWeed Factor.

title: Untapped Revenues
description: Despite New York's desperate need for new revenues to pay off noteholders and help eliminate a $500 million (or more) deficit in next year's budget, city officials once again have adamantly turned down a longstanding proposal to impose tolls on the East and Harlem River Bridges.

title: Johnson to Replace Foreman
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 3 (UPI) Sammy Johnson will start as running back in place of Chuck Foreman in the Minnesota Vikings game against the Green Bay Packers Sunday. Foreman, who already has gained more than 1,000 yards rushing this season, suffered charley horse last Monday against the San Francisco 49ers. The Vikings said today he was ready to play and probably would play.

title: Cyrus Vance for State...
description: In announcing his choice for Secretary of State, Presidentelect Carter said he had received almost unanimous recommendations from around the country and even some endorsements from abroad for Cyrus Roberts Vance. This is an extraordinary and welldeserved tribute to one of New York's most distinguished citizens.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A settlement of 5500,000 was awarded to a $140aweek laborer who plunged 30 feet when planking gave way as he was working on the construction of the World Trade Center. The laborer, Domenico Dellicarpini, who was 30 years old when the accident occurred on May 15, 1969, has been incapacitated since. According to his attorney, he will never be able to work again. Mr. Delicarpini landed on his head, injured his spinal cord and fractured his neck. The settlement in State Supreme Court in the Bronx involved the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Tishman Construction Company and two subcontractors. Mr. Dellicarpini is married and the father of four children.

title: Large Number of Crime Suspects Knew Their Victims, Study Shows
description: A startling percentage of persons arrested for serious crimes in New York City had prior, often close relations with their victims, according to a study that the Vera Institute of Justice will publish shortly.

title: Iran Tops Soviet Union in Wrestling Tournament
description: TEHRAN. Iran, Dec. 3 (UPI)Iran won the 10th Aryamhr international freestyle wrestling championships today for the 10th time, with the Soviet Union finishing second, also for the 10th time.

title: People and Business
description: A former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a retired New York banker were elected to the board of GambleSkogmo Inc. yesterday at a special meeting in Minneapolis in which another director resianed. the fifth to do so in a month.

title: Many at Geneva Say That Only U.S. Can Break Rhodesian Deadlock
description: GENEVA. Dec. 3A feeling is growing among black nationalist delegates to the conference on majority rule in Rhodesia and interested parties not sitting at the conference table that only the United States can turn the present talks into a genuine negotiation.

title: California Congressman Convicted of Theft
description: SANTA ANA, Calif.. Dec. 3 (AP)Pepresentative Andrew Hinshaw, Republion of California, was convicted today of misappropriation and petty theft of public funds while serving as Orange county assessor in 1972.

title: Long Shots Bring 3 Cheers at the Big A
description: Longshot players enjoyed a little Christmas cheer at Aqueduct yesterday when lightly regarded horses accounted for a $906.60 daily double, a $698.60 exacta and a $3,188 triple. The price of the ticket in each case was $2.

title: CARTER WON'T ASK POWER OF CONGRESS FOR PRICE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, openly expressing a. fear that businesses were raising prices now because of a threat of price and wage controls under his administration, announced today that he would not ask Congress for the authority to impose any such controls.

title: British Laborites Lose Another Seat
description: CAMBRIDGE, England. Dec. 3 (Reuters)  Britain's opposition Conservative Party o on a byelection here today, reducing the Labor Government's effective majority in the House of Commons to one.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Earnings of Major Airlines Gain, But Analysts Are Split on Outlook
description: The nation's major airlines will end 1976 with considerably higher earnings than projected earlier this year. In a striking turnaround from last year's combined loss of $106 million, industry officials and analysts are looking for profits totaling $300 million to $350 million on revenues of $15 billion.

title: Jury Told Rubin Carter and Artis Stories Conflicted
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 3 Rubin (Hurricane) Carter's statement to the police about his whereabouts on the night of triple murder in a bar here 10 years ago conflicted with the statement of his codefendant, John Artis, a chief of detectives testified today during their second trial in the crime.

title: Ford Agrees on Stimulus
description: PALM BEACH, Dec. 3 The Ford Administration has now decided that stimulus for the economy through a tax cut is necessary, a leading Administration economist disclosed tonight.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY WARNED ON PAY RISE
description: The New York State Emergency Financial Control Board warned yesterday that Transit Authority employees would be denied cost  of  living adjustments scheduled to take effect on Jan. 1 if the authority failed to provide proof of new savings from increased productivity.

title: Bouchard, Flames Top Bruins, 31,
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 3 (AP) Eric Vail shoved a rebound past the Boston goalie, Gilles Gilbert, late in the third period tonight, gaining a 31 victory for the Atlanta Flames in a National Hockey League game. Atlanta now has lost only two of its last 14 games.

title: 'Serail' a Film Without Point
description: "Srail" was shown at the last New York Film Festival. The following is Richard Eder's review, which appeared Oct. 8. The film begins today at the Fine Arts Theater.There are a number of good names involved in "Srail" but the movie doesn't so much use them as drop them.Eduardo de Gregorio, who has done a number of screenplays for Jacques Rivette, and who wrote Bernardo Bertolucci's "The Spider's Strategem," makes his debut as a director with "Srail," and was one of the screenwriters. He uses two of Europe's best young actresses, Bulle Ogier and Marie-France Pisier. And nothing much happens beyond a certain stylish sifting. You can't make an omelette without lighting a fire."Srail" is a hazy story about an English writer who buys a big old French country house and acquires, in the bargain, two strange and beautiful residentsMisses Ogier and Pisierand a strange and sinister housekeeper, played by Leslie Caron.Some of them are ghosts, and it isn't clear which. They undo him thoroughly by the time the film is over and it isn't clear how. Nor do we particularly care. None of the characters are interesting in any way except in terms of their plight; and since we aren't told just what the plight is, there's not much point.

title: City's Retail Volume in November Up Only 1.9% After October Surge
description: Sales of New York City's largest retailers were virtually flat in November, rising an average 1.9 percent from the yearearlier levels after having achieved their best monthly increase of the year in October.

title: High Court Delays Gilmore's Death
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Supreme Court indefinitely postponed today the execution of Gary Mark Gilmore to give itself more time to consider his case. Mr. Gilmore was to have died before a firing squad in Utah at sunrise on Monday.

title: REACTION ON VANCE IS POSITIVE ABROAD
description: PARIS, Dec.  3 The first European reaction to the designation of Cyrus R. Vance to be Secretary of State in the Carter administation was one of warm satisfaction. Word reached here after offices were closed, but officials available for comment expressed considerable relief to hear that they would be dealing with a man they knew who had a solid background in European affairs.

title: Peter Schickele, an Antidote to Bicentennial
description: Rossini gave up composing when he felt he had nothing to say. and so did Sibelius. The precedent is there, all right. And just because Peter Schickele, the biographer of P.D.Q. Bach who has for years been regarded as the world's most courageous composer, has not yet abandoned the musical scene, that is no reason to stop hoping.

title: ACCORD IS ANNOUNCED IN PARCEL WALKOUT
description: A tentative settlement in the 74day strike against United Parcel Service was announced yesterday in Washington, but the 18,000 warehousemen and drivers were not expected to return to their jobs for at least another week, pending ratification.

title: Norin Agrees to Sell Its Insurance Business To the Farmers Union for $21.5 Million
description: The Norin Corporation of Miami, which earlier this year expanded its business to include food processing, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its insurance business to the Farmers Educational and Cooperative Union of America for $21.5 million in cash. Last February, Norin acquired 74 percent of Maple Leaf Mills Ltd., one of Canada's largest agricultural and food processors. Maple Mills accounted for about 93 percent of Norin's $429.5 million of revenues in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1976.

title: Auto Union Delays Decision on Return To the Federation
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 3Leaders of the United Automobile Workers reached no decision on whether to return to the American Federation of Labor and Conass of Industrial Organizations after meeting today with George Meany, president of the federation.

title: JACQUES CARLU, ARCHITECT, IS DEAD IN PARIS AT 86
description: PARIS, Dec. 3 (AP) Jacques Carlu, the architect, who designed famous buildings in several countries, died today. He was 86.

title: Vocal Arts Sings Russian Works
description: The New York Vocal Arts Ensemble, a quartet of singers that is presenting three concerts at Alice Tully Hall this season, offered music by Russian composers in their second event, which was given on Thursday night. Those represented were Tchaikovsky, Gretchaninov, Glinka. Dargomizhsky, RimskyKorsakov and Arensky, and the program ended with three folk songs.

title: Girl Clinically Dies; Murder Is Charged
description: A 27yearold Long Island man was charged with second degree murder yesterday after a girl he allegedly attacked and robbed was declared neurologically and clinically dead, leading to her removal from lifesustaining apparatus.

title: China's Hesitant Hierarchy
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 3The close yesterday of the meeting of the Standing Committee of China's National People's Congress without any public action on several key unresolved questions seems to indicate that Peking's new leaders are not yet prepared to deal with some of the most difficult problems facing them. The threeday session of the committee of the congress, China's nominal legislature, did not name a new prime minister to replace the current one, Hua Kuofeng,feng, who was elevated to Communist Party Chairman in October. Nor did it appoint a new chairman of the congress itself, a position left vacant by the death of Marshal Chu Teh in July. It also apparently did not hear any report on the economy or the delayed fifth fiveyear plan, as might be expected at a Standing Committee session.

title: In Memoriam
description: BUCHSBAUMMurray December 4,1975. Alwars in our thoughts, lorever In our hears.

title: Park Dismisses Korean C.I.A. Chief
description: SEOUL. South Korea, Saturday, Dec. 4President Park Chung Fee abruptly dismissed the head of the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency today. Replacing Shin Jik Soo as the head of the politically powerful agency is Construction Minister Kim Jae Kyu, a moderate confidant of the President.

title: DEMOLITION BIDS SET FOR WEST SIDE ROAD
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame announced yesterday that bids would he ought this month for the tearing down of a dilapidated section of the old elevated West Side Highway between Jane and 14th Streets in Greenwich Village.

title: Court Weighing Move On Patriot Stock Fight
description: BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP) A move by minority stockholders to block a proposed change in the ownership of the New England Patriots has been taken under advisement by a Federal judge.

title: Seattle Woman Heads the National League of Cities
description: DENVER, Dec. 2 Phyllis Lamphere was first elected to the Seattle City Council in 1967, by a landslide. Two years later, largely because of the troubles of the Boeing Company, Seattle slid into the worst recession of its history. Thousands of engineers and scientists joined the unemployment lines, along with other workers, as the city's most prominent employer cut back in line with its dwindling aerospace business.

title: VICE ADM. SIR MICHAEL FELL
description: LONDON, Dec. 3 (Reuters) Vice Adm. Sir Michael Fell, one of the Royal Navy's most distinguished fighter pilots, died last night at his home in the south of England. He was 58 years old.

title: Retreat From Learning
description: The State Education Department reports that enrollment in New York's colleges and universities this fall has declined by a substantial 6.1 percent. Since high schools are still graduating students in growing numbers, the decline is obviously not yet caused by a shrinking birth rate but by a retreat from collegegoing.

title: SALES OF NEW CARS SHOW STRONG GAINS IN NOV. 2130 PERIOD
description: DETROIT, Dec. 3Newcar sales improved 20.8 percent in the final third or November from the same period last year.

title: Utah Law Is Overridden
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 3The Supreme Court's action in the Gilmore case serves to override a Utah law requiring that execution take place within 30 to 60 days after sentence is imposed, according to legal scholars in the state. That period expire9 Sunday for Mr. Gilmore.

title: Watson's 66 Paces U.S. To Golf Lead Over Japan
description: HARIMA, Japan, Dec. 3 (AP) Tom Watson shot a 66, a Harima Club course record, and led the Americans to a ninestroke lead today after two rounds of the sixth annual United StatesJapan golf tourney.

title: Learning From the Vietnameseand Giving
description: In February 1970, seven months before he was accidentally crushed to death in Saigon by a 16wheel American military vehicle, Minh the Cripple (nicknamed for his deformity by the other dust of life street children) smiled and whispered into my ear from atop his perch on my back where he often rode:

title: Stenmark Wins Again In Ski Race
description: BORMIO, Italy, Dec.3 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won the men's World Series giant slalom today for his fourth straight triumph in one week. The 20yearold holder of the World Cup triumphed by more than two seconds over Phil Mahre of White Pass. Wash., the runnerup.

title: Great South Bay Patrols Pursue the Clam Pirates
description: BABYLON, L.I.With clam prices expected to rise after their usual autumn slump, the clam pirates of the Great South Bay are coming out in force.

title: Overtures of Reassurance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3With his first two Cabinetlevel appointments, Presidentelect Jimmy Carter has offered reassurance to the worlds of business and diplomacy and signaled to politicians that he will dominate policymaking in the crucial areas of foreign affairs and the budget. He has underscored the urgency he feels to move quickly in both fields by announcing ahead of all other Cabinet appointments his choice of Cyrus R. Vance as Secretary of State and Bert Lance as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: Both Fordham Centers Out of Michigan Contest
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 3 A possible cracked patella in his right knee will keep Paul Smith. Fordham's starting center, out of tomorrow's basketball game with topranked Michigan. Smith has been the leading rebounder in both of the Rams victories this season.

title: DR. HERMANN POERZGEN
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (Reuters) Dr. Hermann Poerzgen, West German dean of the Iforeign press corps in Moscowwho first reported from the Soviet Union in 1937died today at the age of 71.

title: Article 2  No Title
Buffalo's Hot 2d Half Decisive, 135112
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 3Besides being undermanned, the Knicks were overgenerous tonight at Memorial Auditorium and their largesse was a critical factor in a 135112 drubbing at the hands of the Buffalo Braves.

title: Article 1  No Title
Dollar Drops Slightly On European Markets; Gold Prices Are Mixed
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 3 (UPI)The dollar closed slightly lower yesterday on all European money markets except Paris and London, where it gained marginally against the pound.

title: 5 Held in Meat Theft
description: NEWARK, Dec. 3 (AP) Five men have been indicted on Federal charges of stealing 900 cartons of meat, valued at $50,000, from a trailer here. John Bowens, an assistant United States attorney, said the five had been charged with stealing the meat on Feb. 8, 1974, from Roger's Transfer, a Newark shipping company. Named in the indictment were Norman Kahn, 49 years old, of Hillside; Stephen Rizzo, 47, of Mountainside; Thomas Catanzaro, 28, of Montville; James Monica, 34, of Livingston, and James Taylor, 29, of Lake Hiawatha.

title: Most Stores in Malls Will Stay Closed on PreChristmas Sundays
description: NEWARK, Dec. 3Most stores at North Jersey shopping malls in counties that prohibit Sunday sales will remain closed on the three remaining preChristmas Sundays despite the challenge by three major retail establishments of the constitutionality of a 1959 state law that limits Sunday sales, officials at four shopping centers and one in Passaic County said today.

title: Gunman Kills a Traffic Warden At School in Town Near Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Dec. 3 (AP) A young gunman killed a traffic warden today at a school crossing in Dungannon, 40 miles west of Belfast, the police reported.

title: Personal Investing
description: The mutual fund industry may have come up with the ultimate weapon in its battle to keep disenchanted stockholders from cashing in their shares at the chronically high levels of the last 15 monthsa guarantee that investors cannot lose money.

title: What Blacks Want From Carter
description: Around 2 A.M., Wednesday, Nov. 3, a television commentator speculated, along with millions of others, where Jimmy Carter would pick up the remaining few electoral votes he needed to give him the necessary 270: Watch Mississippi. Indeed, that state finally went to Mr. Carter, as did Hawaii, and he was projected the winner.

title: Miss Goolagong Beaten by Miss Stove At Sydney by 76, 64
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 3 (UPI)Betty Stove, playing some of the best tennis of her career, upset Evonne Goolagong, 76, 64, in the quarter finals of the $100.000 Sydney international tennis tournament today. The tall Dutchwoman won the tiebreaker, 13 points to 11.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Transcript of News Conference by PresidentElect Carter and Two Nominees
description: Following is a transcript of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's news conference yesterday in Plains, Ga., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: US. Boxers Lose by 73 To Russians
description: Last night's allheavyweight boxing card at Madison Square Garden between the Soviet Union and the United. States was a dismal affair for most of the American boxers, and it was not a happy occasion for the 7,292 fans who had paid $58,114 for seats.

title: CARTER WON'T ASK POWER OF CONGRESS FOR PRICE CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, openly expressing a fear that businesses were raising prices now because of a threat of price and wage controls under his administration, announced today that he would not ask Congress for the authority to impose any such controls.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec. 3  New Jersey fudges, through the acting administrative director of the court system, renewed today their plea for a $6,000ayear raise.

title: 3 Stars Absence From Masters Points to a Rift in Tennis World
description: It is billed as the Masters, the endofseason showdown to determine the year's No. 1 male tennis player. Yet, when the first hall is struck in Houston tomorrow, the world's top three professionals for 1976 will be absent.

title: Occupation of Land by Peasants Is Said to Have Ended in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3Some 3.500 landless peasants, who brought agricultural work to a standstill yesterday by occupying or threatening to occupy 106,000 acres of private farmland in the northwest Mexican state of Sinaloa, were persuaded to withdraw today, according to representatives a the landowners.

title: ARABS TO NEGOTIATE A WEST BANK STATE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3 Arab negotiators intend to start talks on a Middle East settlement next year with a proposal for a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, territories occupied by Israel since the war of 1967.

title: Lee Konitz, Group Cut Wide Jazz Swath
description: Lee Konitz, one of the definitive cool saxophonists of the late 1940's, when he played with Lennie Tristano's group and with the Miles Davis ninepiece group that has become identified as the source of cool jazz, is leading a nonet at Stryker's, 103 West 86th Street, on Wednesdays and Thursdays, that cuts across a wide swath of jazz sources.

title: People in Sports
description: Fred Carter, whose gunner style of playing basketball became redundant to the Philadelphia 76ers after the team acquired Julius Erving, was traded yesterday to Milwaukee in exchange for the Bucks secondround choices in 1977 and 1978.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: JOBLESS RATE IS HIGHEST OF THE YEAR
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 3The national unemployment rate rose from 7.9 percent to S.1 percent in November. its highest level this year, despite an apparent strong gain in the number of persons with jobs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Hartwick Counting on Its Defense
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3Two teams with stingy defenses that have allowed a total of only 24 goals in 39 games will go against two highscoring offenses tomorrow in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: NursingHome Owner Given Term
description: A Westchester County owner yesterday was given the most severe sentence yet for a nursinghome operator convicted of Medicaid fraud.

title: Lolich of Mets Is Expected to Retire
description: The New York Mets said yesterday that they were more convinced than before that Mickey Lolich would skip the final year of his twoyear contract and retire from baseball.

title: This Heisman Winner Didn't Turn Pro
description: With the understandable confidence befitting a Heisman Trophy winner, Tony Dorsett is looking ahead to a National Football League career. Quarterbacks need more time to learn the plays and the defenses, he was saying the other day. But being a running back, you do things by instinct. I could see myself as rookie of the year next season. Pro football has always been a dream of mine. Its a dream for every good college football player now, a dream often shattered by the reality of not being drafted or not being retained. But for Dick Kazmaier of Princeton in 1951, it was not a dream. Dick Kazmaier is the last Heisman Trophy winner to spurn pro football, except for Pete Dawkins of Army in 1958, who chose remain in the military. Col. Peter Dawkins of Fort Ord, Calif., once confessed, It would've been fun to have joined the Baltimore Colts, the then N.F.L. champions who drafted him. But a quarter of a century ago, Dick Kazmaier did not think of the N.F.L. as fun.

title: ARABS TO NEGOTIATE A WEST BANK STATE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 3Arab negotiators intend to start talks on a Middle East settlement next year with a proposal for a Palestinian state on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip, territories occupied by Israel since the war of 1967.

title: S.E.C. SETTLES CHARGES OF INSURANCE DIVERSIONI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced to:day a settlement nf charges it brought in September that the National American Life Insurance Company and several other companies and individuals had en gaged in a complex scheme to misappropriate more than $3 million of corporate assets.

title: 9Degree Chill Dec. 3 Record For New York
description: The following article was published in The New York Times on Dec. 4,1940:

title: Lisbon Panel Accuses Leftists in Military of Torture
description: LISBON, Dec. 3A presidential commission accused former leftist military authorities today of having committed acts of systematic torture and arbitrary arrests as well as generally cruel treatment of prisoners.

title: Vance Is Selected By Carter to Run State Department
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 3 Presidentelect Jimmy Carter announced today that he had chosen Cyrus R. Vance to be Secretary of State and an old Georgia politicalally, Bert Lance, to be director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: About New York
description: One of the ugliest terms in the police officer's vernacular is the reference to the Bow and Arrow Squad, or the Rubber Gun Squada pejorative description of the groups of police officers who have been relieved of their guns because of some sign of instability, or protectively transferred from the streets to paperwork.

title: El Al joining Charter Run to U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 3El Al, the Israeli national airline, will begin lowbudget charter flightsits firstfrom Boston to Jerusalem next September.

title: A Fresh Look at Europe'?
description: BRUSSELSJimmy Carter's designation of Cyrus Vance as the next United States Secretary of State is taken as an excellent sign by Western Europe. Although it has been successively dazzled, amused and occasionally bewildered by Henry Kissinger's diplomatic brilliance, it has not always been thoroughly convinced of the good doctor's benevolent intentions to the cause of European unity.

title: Bonn to Pay Millions to East for Prisoner Releases
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 3West Germany has reportedly agreed to pay millions of dollars to East Germany to obtain freedom for several hundred political prisoners by Christmas.

title: Wake Forest Wins No. 4
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Dec. 3 (AP)  Rod Griffin and Skip Brown combined for 45 points and Frank Johnson added 20 tonight as undefeated Wake Forest beat Washington, 9275, for the Deacons fourth basketball victory.

title: ExPoliceman Shoots Gunman in a Holdup
description: With a robber's shotgun pointed at his head, a 41yearold iormer policeman feigned compliance with an order to remove his pants, but drew a revolver from an ankle holster and shot the gunman twice in the head early yesterday during a holdup in a Bronx bar.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled that Raritan Township could not use its planning code to block conversion of a television repair shop into an adult bookstore. The court said the township code requirement that a site had to be approved each time a building changed uses was unduly burdensome.

title: English Relics Falling Victim To Modern Ills
description: There is, it appears, no end to Britain's travail this year.

title: Carradine Plays Woody Like Me
description: MUNICHDavid Carradine sits barefoot on a sofa covered with movie scripts, gulping apple juice out of a bottle. He points to the poster, barely clinging to a wall, of Bound for Glory, the film based on the autobiography of Woody Guthrie, the folksinger.

title: The Doomed DayCare Center That Just Won't Roll Over and Die
description: Our Children's Center at New York City Community College in Brooklyn has refused to close its doors although the Agency for Child Development announced last winter that the daycare center was among the 28 it would no longer fund.

title: Court Papers Confirm Apparent Effort to Bribe Jurors in Mandel Trial
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 3Two apparent attempts to prevent a guilty verdict by trying to bribe one or more jurors in the political corruption trial of Gov. Martin Mandel of Maryland and four of his lriends and business associates were conlirmed today by the partial release of sealed court papers. Two men have been ??rrested; one of them was later released.

title: Herzl to Continue Run
description: Announced to close tomorrow, Herzl, the play about the founder of modernday Zionism, will continue at the Palace Theater because of increased business since the opening last Tuesday. Paul Hecht plays the title role in the Dore ScharyAmos Elon drama, which was directed by J Ranelli.

title: 9Degree Chill Is a Dec. 3 Record
description: The following article was published in The New York Times on Dec, 4, 1940:

title: Notes on People
description: A former country doctor, Patrick Hillery, was sworn in yesterday as the sixth President of the Irish Republic in a colorful ceremony at Dublin Castle. In Ireland's ancient Gaelic language,

title: Newly Ordained in Catskills Seek Tax Cut
description: HARDENBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 3 The residents of this small community in the Catskill Mountains who became ordained clergymen to protest rising property taxes are planning to take the final step toward tax exemption tomorrow by presenting formal applications to the Town Assessor.

title: SUSPECT IS INDICTED IN WESTCHESTER RAPE
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 3 Alexander J. Verrone, the 27yearold nursing student who was seized Tuesday as a suspect in sexual crimes against young girls in Westchester County, was indicted today by a grand jury on 16 counts of rape, sodomy and assault.

title: OBSERVER
description: Mr. Bean wanted a fuller description of President Ford. He's easy to recognize, I said. Until his sudden disappearance, he couldn't resist turning up every day all over the newspapers and every night all over the television screen. Find the man who fits that description and you've got him.

title: New Orleans Bank Is Ordered Closed
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 7 The International City Bank & Trust Company, which reported about 6162 million in deposits as of June 30, was closed today by Louisiana banking officials because of a capital deficiency and placed under the receivership of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Dr. Erwin Schwenk Dies; Headed Early Research On the Steroid Hormones
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 3 Dr. Erwin Schwenk, former research director of the Schering Corporation of Bloomfield, N.J., and a contributor to early chemical research on steroid hormones, died Wednesday at the Princeton Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: GOING OUT
description: DOWN TO SEA An art show depicting nautical scenes is the first presentation at the newly reopened Fulton Ferry Museum in Brooklyn, operated by the National Maritime Historical Society on lease from New York City's Department of Ports and Terminals. Thirtysix watercolors by Harold Radgiff, a local painter specializing in scenes of life on New York's harbor and waterfront, comprise the exhibition, which will probably remain on view through the winter.

title: Marines Transfer Leader of Klan To Ease Tension at Camp Pendleton
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3Moving swiftly in an attempt to ease a tense racial situation at its Camp Pendleton base south of here, the Marine Corps last night arrested the leader of the Ku Klux Klan at the base and today flew him to a new base on the East Coast.

title: Nassau Man Given DraftEvasion Term Despite Carter Vow
description: A 29yearold insurance broker was sentenced to three years in jail yesterday for draft evasion despite the defense's reminder that President  elect Jimmy Carter had promised he would pardon all violators of Selective Service laws.

title: CONCETTA SCOGNAMILLO
description: Concetta Mauro Scognamillo, the founder and owner of ratsy's Italian Restaurant, at 236 West 56th Street, died yesterday at her home in Forest Hills, Queens. She was 73 years old.

title: Liquor Companies Guilty of Kickbacks Facing Suspension
description: The chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority said yesterday that he would see the suspension of licenses rather than fines for liquor distillers, wholesalers and retailers charged as a result of an ongoing Federal and state investigation of bribes and kickbacks in the industry.

title: I Have a Dream Closing
description: I Have a Dream, the play about the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will close tomorrow afternoon at the Ambassador Theater after 80 performances. The production originally starred Billy Dee Williams; he was replaced last Tuesday by Moses Gunn.

title: Tonna Stops U.S. Boxer
