title: Marijuana Valued at $3 Million Is Seized on Boat off Florid
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Dec. 4 (UPI)The authorities seized an estimated 10,000 pounds of marijuana with a street value of at least $3 million and arrested seven persons last night after boarding a 37foot boat in the Gulf of Mexico near Fort Myers.

title: Miss Morerod Takes Slalom In Ski Series
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 4 (AP)LiseMarie Morerod found the mountains of her native Switzerland to her liking today as whe won the St. Moritz parallel slalom of the World Series of skiing.

title: NursingHome Talks on in Earnest
description: Negotiations between New York City's private nursing homes and the union that represents most of their employees have begun in earnest with both sides anticipating grave problems In reaching a settlement in light of recent state reductions in Medicaid reimbursement rates.

title: In Summary
description: Rhodesia: Both Fighting and Talking Go On

title: Putting Our Best Heads Together
description: THERE is virtually no disagreement among economists, geopoliticians and planners that the Island's growing malaise threatens our longrange life styles. Along with the Island's obviously unacceptable transportation facilities, there are these other negative factors:

title: Islanders Shut Out Sabres; Rangers Trounce Stars,114
description: UNIONDALE, Li., Dec. 4How do you spell relief?

title: Questions/Answers
description: AMARYLLIS CARE

title: Ministers Given Tax Exemptions In Upstate Town
description: HARDENBURGH. N. Y., Dec. 4The town assessor in this Catskill Mountain community ruled today that he would approve tax exemption applications from all residents who had become ordained ministers of the Universal Life Church.

title: Build (and fly) it yourself; Thousands of hobbyists are putting together funnylooking airplanes in their garagesand some of them will actually get off the ground.
description: In the waning light of a Wisconsin summer afternoon, about 20,000 people stood beside a strip of Tarmac and watched a speck of white race towards them. Here it came, the airplane of the future, the next great advance in aviation, the craft you could build in your garage and then fly to Florida in five hours. Slim and confident against a dark horizon, the plane whizzed towards the crowd with the determined whine of a blender turned up to liquefy. At last it flashed byheads jerked aroundevery inch of its fiberglass and Styrofoam body glistening in the late sun. But somewhere in the crowd a chance visitor turned to his neighbor and, in the confused ignorance of the little boy watching the parade of a naked emperor, whispered a question: Why is it going backward?

title: Bonnie Johnson Is Engaged to Gary See
description: The engagement of Bonnie Ann Johnson to Gary Richard See has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William Richard Johnson of Locust Valley, LI, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Richard See of South Yarmouth, Mass.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Congress Party Takes Over Control Of Bombay Union Run by Jailed Foe
description: BOMBAY, India, Dec. 4 (Reuters) The governing Congress Party has taken over control of the taxi drivers union, ousting its president, George Fernandes, Socialist Party leader, who is facing charges of conspiracy to overthrow the Government.

title: GARDENING
description: IT was a bright, crisp Sunday morning in midautumn. The flowering dogwood outside the diningroom window had reached its peak of fall perfection. The leaves were a deep crimson red, and the bright red fruits were shining in the sunlight. With a sudden flurry of wings, a dozen or so bronze grackles descended upon the tree. In their activity, they were too busy to notice that they were being watched from the window a few inches away. In less than five minutes, they had stripped the fruits from the tree and had retreated to a nearby telephone line to digest their breakfast.

title: No Way Without Will
description: BRUSSELSThe North Atlantic Alliance likes to comfort itself during grim moments by recalling that during 27 years it has managed to deter any thoughts of Soviet aggression against Western Europe and also that its mere existence has probably helped to stave off holocausts which might otherwise have exploded from the Cuban or Middle East crises.

title: Notes: Will Casinos Spread in Northeast?
description: The voters approval of a referendum to permit casino gambling in Atlantic City has inspired the Catskills and the Poconos to seek ways and means of meeting the expected highpowered competition from the New Jersey resort. Both areas have scheduled meetings next month to look into the possibility of getting legislative authority to establish their own gambling operations, and both are pushing other projects as well.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Just two weeks ago, Marine Midland Banks Inc. held a lunch to introduce John R. Petty, its new president, chief operating officer and potential savior, to the press.

title: Tree Growers Put Sales at 200,000
description: AS MODERN technology perfects the childproof, flameproof, foldforeasystorage artificial Christmas tree, families infinitely contraryincreasingly turn to choosing, cutting or digging their own live trees.

title: Clifton House Tied To State's Heritage
description: CLIFTON

title: The Sump Pump Nobody Knows
description: CHICAGOBliss in the executive suite is never having a major strike against the company. And making a profit, year after year, in good times and bad, selling a competitor's products to your own customers. And being loved by the securities analysts who follow the stock of the company you founded.

title: Illegal Entrants Plague Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 4Every day hundreds of men, women and children cross into Venezuela from Colombia walking along the paths and back roach that pierce the sparsely guarded border.

title: New York's Port, the Erie Canal And Hudson Readied for Winter
description: The port is beginning to get ready for winter. Last week, its back door, the Barge Canal System, closed down the Erie Canal between Waterford, N.Y., and Buffalo, and its only active segment, the Champlain Canal, is to be shut down on Wednesday. The be shut down on Wednesday. The Coast Guard is starting next Monday to remove all aids to navigation in the Hudson River from the George Washington Bridge to Albany.

title: In Central Africa the Sun Sets on a Republic and Comes Up on an Empire
description: NDIAMENA, Chad, Dec. 4 (AP)Salah Eddine Ahmed Bokassa, president for life of the Central African Republic, has renamed his country the Central African Empire and made himself Emperor Bokassa I, the Government radio announced today.

title: Lorelei Lois Zenk Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Zenk have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lorelei Lois Zenk, to W. Neil Hauptmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hauptmann. Both families live in Yorktown Heights, N. Y. The future bride is a graduate of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N. Y., and her fiance of Western Connecticut State College in Danbury.

title: Hnuriling
description: GREENWALDBessle S. Wife of the late Leo, mother of Benjamin and Herbert. Beth David Cemetery, Denmark Assn. Plot, Block One, Section 1, Dec. 12, 12:30 P.M. No Postponement.

title: Vocal Music's Modern Master
description: On the whole, musical development in the 20th century cannot be said to have favored the writing of operas, songs and choral works, but Benjamin Britten managed to be both a thoroughly 20thcentury composer and one of the most sensitive and successful creators of vocal music of the era.Instend of taking masters of realtively recent times as his guides for vocal writing, he looked back in English history to composers such as Purcell and Dowland, illustrious figures of the 17th century. He found grace, vitality and expressive force in their settings of English, and the examples they and other composers provided seemed to liberate him from the foursquare prosodic conventions deriving from England's turnofthecentury practices.

title: Gardening
description: Judging from my reading of this year's books on house plants, it seems authors of garden books believe that just about everyone by now must own at least a philodendron. Generally speaking, those who are new at gardening tend to gravitate toward the all abouts, while those who have polished their thumbs green reach for the specifics.

title: Woman Found Dead in Bronx
description: The police have listed as a possible homocide the death of a 33yearold Bronx woman who was found dead on the sidewalk in front of 530 St. Paul's Place, in the Morrisania section, at 7 A.M. Friday. The woman was identified as Orabelle Bryant of 1481 Washington Avenue, and a police spokesman said she had a large gash in her head.

title: Photography
description: Judging from books on photography published this year, some basic truths are becoming recognized at last. Photographs are made by artists, and it is not the illustrative value of photography which is the measure of its brilliance, but the individuals who have used photography to reveal their vision and values.

title: Indiana and San Francisco Gain N.C.A.A. Soccer Final
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4Indiana, rather unconvincingly, and the University of San Francisco, the depending champion, triumphed today in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer playoffs.

title: Rams Rout Falcons, 590
2d Cup Yacht Is Christened
description: With cheers and a splash of champagne, the second new 12Meter yacht for the America's Cup defense was christened in ceremonies yesterday at the Minneford Yacht Yard on City Island the Bronx.

title: POLITICS
description: BEFORE they begin their reelection campaigns next year, members of the State Assembly must take care of a special election of their own. The Assembly speaker, Joseph A. LeFante. Democrat of Bayonne, created the problem when he won the right to succeed Dominic V. Daniels as Hudson County's representative in Congress.

title: IOWA?? RAIN AND WIND DEPLETE FARMLANDS; Topsoil Is Lost at Rate of a Twelfth of an Inch a Year, Conservation Chief Says
description: DES MOINES, Dec. 2The state of Iowa, which contains some of the richest corn and soybean land in the world, is losing about a twelfth of art inch of its Priceless topsoil every year.

title: Carole E. Steadman, Stockbroker, Is Bride Of Jerome Kinney 3d
description: Carole Elaine Steadman, daughter of Charles W. Steadman of West Palm Beach, Fla., board chairman and president of the Steadman Security Corporation in Washington, an investment company, was married in Washington yesterday afternoon to Jerome Frank Kinney 3d of Bethesda, Md., board chairman and president of the Jerome F. Kinney Company, a property management, land development and construction firm in Montgomery County, Md.

title: Christina Algiere Is Wed To Dr. Duke O. Kasprisin
description: Christina L. Algiere and Dr. Duke O. Kasprisin were married yesterday afternoon in St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Plainview, L.I., by the Rev. Matthew Fitzgerald.

title: Collector's Item?
description: The efforts of a French Marquis to celebrate the tercentenary of his chateau with a commemorative wine bottle have resulted in the unintentional creation of a collector's item available at retail here in the United States.

title: CONNECTICUT IS APPLYING FOR $30 MILLION IN GRANTS
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 4 (AP)Connecticut is seeking nearly $30 million in Federal grants for 16 projects across the state, most of them involving schools or youth facillties.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE new RoweManse Emporium in Clifton is like Disney World, the kingdom of Oz and the North Pole all wrapped up in one. Glittering angels, shimmering stars and sleighs filled with gifts are everywhere. Upstairs, there is a winding brick road, only this one is green instead of yellow, the better to harmonize with the mauve walls and palm fronds in pink latticed boxes.

title: Water Suppliers Plan to Sell Land Stirs Connecticut
description: Connecticut, which has remained relatively green in the face of the sprawl of development, is in danger now of losing thousands of acres of open space because private water supply companies plan to sell land they say is no longer needed to preserve the purity of their watersheds.

title: POLITICS
description: NOVEMBER wasn't a good month for Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman. First there was the election, in which he predicted a 1,000vote plurality in the county for President Ford. The President would have needed that edge to win the state, but won the county by only about a third of that amount.

title: Poll Finds 54% Favor Changes In the Way Campaigns Are Run
description: Fiftyfour percent of the American public would like to see changes in the way political campaigns are conducted, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: As one who is fascinated by recordings of pianists of the past. I have spent the last few days rooted in front of the hifi, listening to the latest batch of International Piano Archives disks, which are now being nationally distributed by Desmar. There are examples of the playing of Josef Hofmann, Mischa Levitzki, Wanda Landowska and Arthur Loesser, and I'll try to get around to those in a future column. But the disk that has stopped me dead among those in this particular issue is one named The Catalan Piano Tradition.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNEMPLOYMENT RATE ROSE to 8.1 percent In November from 7.9 percent in October, hitting its highest level since December 1975.. . . Higher unemployment was indicated by the Labor Department's factory layoff rate which indicated 1.7 per 100 employees were laid off in October as against 1.5 workers per 100 in September and 1.3 in August. .. The wholesale price index rose 0.6 percent in November to 185.6 percent of the 1967 average. The increase matched that of October.... Prices of farm products dropped 3 percent in the month to Nov. 15, the Agriculture Department reported, Indicating stable retail food prices this winter. . . .Consumers began paying an average of 6.5 percent more for industrial and cooking gas.

title: In Vienna, EastWest OnceaWeek Talks on Reduction of Forces Still Drag Along After More Than 3 Years
description: VIENNA, Dec. 4An American, introduced to a Chinese diplomat at a recent cocktail party here, identified himself as a participant in the longstanding M.B.F.R. talks.

title: NEW YORK AIDE HEADS CARTER'S H.E.W. TEAM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4If grappling with big problems was required for the job, it is easy to see why June Jackson Christmas was selected for Jimmy Carter's transition team.

title: In Search of Relief,
description: A GROUP of Suffolk artists and craftsmen, insisting that they are among the longterm unemployed and therefore eligible for aid, have started a drive to participate in a countyadministered program that uses Federal funds to provide jobs and job training in the public sector.

title: Few Patients Taking Advantage Of Law on Surgery Consultation
description: Few New Yorkers have taken advantage thus far of a state law passed last summer that entitles them to obtain at their insurance company's expense a second physician's opinion when their doctor recommends a nonemergency operation.

title: Body of Missing Coast Woman Found Near Pasadena Golf Course
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 4 (UPI)  The bludgeoned body of a pregnant woman was found near a golf course in Pasadena today and identified as that of Mrs. Renee Kane, the 26yearold wife of an Arcadia attorney who was reported missing after the couple's home was burglarized Thursday night.

title: WITNESS ON CARTER FOUND OTHER SHELLS
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 4The detective who allegedly discovered a bullet and a shotgun shell in Rubin (Hurricane) Carter's car on the morning of the Lafayette Grill murders, had confiscated a number of varied shotgun shells at the scene of an earlier murder, according to court testimony today.

title: Leafs 2, Black Hawks 2
description: TORONTO, Dec. 4 (AP)Dick Redmond's shot from the blue line weaved through a maze of players and beat Mike Palmateer with 8 minutes 43 seconds left in the game tonight, giving the Chicago Black Hawks a 22 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: The Suburbs Also Are Feeling The PinchAt a Different Level
description: In the suburbs, long regarded as the province of the affluent where such things as unemployment, welfare and credit are not supposed to exist, people are being squeezed by many of the same economic woes plaguing the cities. Whether in Bergen County, N.J., Fairfield County, Conn., or Westchester County, N.Y., financial pressures are great.

title: Janet Grainger Sets Wedding for Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Grainger Jr. of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Virginia Grainger, to Steven Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Thompson of Pelham Manor. N. Y.

title: SOUREN M. ALLALEMDJIAN
description: Souren M. Allalemdjian, a fur exporter who was president of Allalemdjian Fur Corporation and an associate in Allalemdjian & Poser, both of New York City, died of cancer Friday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn L.I. He was 65 years old and lived in Munsey Park, Manhasset, L.I.

title: Dance:Spaniards WithIntentions
description: The National Festival Ballet of Spain, which made its New York debut at the Felt Forum on Friday night, was. apparently established three years ago, and seems to be intended to be some kind of Spanish national dance company. It has a long way to go. At the moment it is mediocre at its best, and its seemingly interminable program lacks taste, imagination and talent.

title: Hungary Is Still Seeking Return of the Crown of St. Stephen, in Safekeeping at Fort Knox
description: BUDAPEST, Dec. 4  Any American visitor of some standing is told by his host here that Hungary wants the speedy return of the Crown of St. Stephen. The relic has been in United States safekeeping since the end of World War II.

title: AUSTRALIA ASSESSES POLICIES ON ENERGY
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 4As the only country to occupy an entire continent rich in coal and sunlight, Australia has laid aside any nuclear energy development and is looking toward the possibility by the end of this century of deriving from solar energy half the fuel needed to drive its air and surface vehicles.

title: The Ivory Pages of Whaling History
description: BEING unimaginative by its very nature, my dictionary defines scrimshaw as a folk art wherein scrimshanders decorate whale ivory with little squiggles. It further says something about walrus tusks, panbone and baleen as materials that Yankee Down East whalemen filled with intricate carvings or designs, meticulously executed. Nowadays such work is widely valued by private collectors, and is on display In at least three Long Island whaling museums.

title: Crooke of St. Anthony's Wins Run
description: John Crooke, a 16yearold St. Anthony's high junior, won the twomile run yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Relay Carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory in Washinaton Heights.

title: Architecture
description: The experience of being in a building cannot be conveyed by any artificial means, but publishers continue to bring us books that try valiantly to do so. Each year, it seems, there are more of them, bigger if not better, with more and more pretty pictures of buildings at sunset, buildings glimmering in their own reflecting pools, buildings photographed from angles perceptible only to visitors who arrive on stilts. Such books are sometimes products of the narcissistic impulses of architects themselves, who encourage (often with financial assistance) publishers to devote entire volumes to their own work; at other times they emerge from publishers own beliefs that the American coffee table cannot go on much longer without the adornment of a book of color photographs of the latest and best cabooses that have been turned into boutiques.

title: Culture Is Togetherness at
description: POMONA

title: Mr. Carter's Economic Approach
description: The Presidential campaign was fought out largely on economic issues, and it has become even clearer since the election that the most urgent problem facing Presidentelect Carte; is how to deal with the faltering economy. Unemploym ent, on the rise since last May, increased again in November to 8.1 percent, reaching its highest level of the year. The jobless rolls have lengthened to 7.8 million workers, nearly a million more than last spring.

title: Resumption of Talks With Moscow Is Only a Start at Easing Tensions
description: The resumption of talks between the Soviet Union and China on their border dispute is a sign, admittedly faint, of less strained relations between the grimly contentious Communist powers. But the meeting, presumably held at Russian initiative, seems unlikely to signify final resolution of the complex territorial, political and ideological questions that form the basis of the confrontation.

title: Democratic Leadership ShakeUp Costs Beatty No. 2 Spot in Senate
description: Manfred H. Ohrenstein. minority leader of the New York State Senate, organized the leadership of his Democratic cadres last week and dumped the threetiered structure of deputy minority leaders that reflected the tenuous coalition that elected hint to the post three years ago.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHEN you hear talk about community theater, resident theater, what is usually meant is that a company is jobbed in for a while as actors in residence, W. T. Martin was saying the other day. Uswell, we're here. We ore in residence. For us, being here is a life investment.

title: A Lack of Commitments Ends RoadRace Series
description: The Sports Car Club of America (SCCA) dropped its Formula 5000 series because only four roadracing circuits were willing to make firm commitments to 1977 events. The track owners and promoters were unwillinn to commit to 1977 dates becauseaccording to an SCCA official who asked not to be identifiedthey were unhappy over low attendance and high costs.

title: GEORGE H. DAVIS
description: Capt. George H. Davis, head of the department of naval science at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., died on Wednesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 49 years old.

title: Drive Is Set to Enroll Residents Eligible for FoodStamp Program
description: Plans have been announced to enroll persons in the foodstamp program who are not aware they are eligible.

title: Indications of Deterioration Abound in New York Crisis
description: The signs of crippled services, physical deterioration, and general government retrenchment in New York City are everywhere.

title: They Also Serve
description: ANYONE for tennis? Too cold, you say? But that excuse is out of date. Indoor tennis is the thing these days, with courts from Manhasset to Montauk crowded with players 5 to 75 years of age. And at many centers, as much action goes on off the court as on it, what with parties, socials and kibbitzing in waltowallcarpeted lounges and Scandinaviantype saunas.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONSeveral time bombs in the foreign trade field are ticking quietly away, timed to explode during or shortly after the transition to a new Administration.

title: Home Style
description: Among all the special types of history that have proliferated over the years, there is a very modest one that is both interesting and accessible to almost anyone: house history.

title: Two Canadians Held in Smuggling
description: DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP)  Two truck drivers were in Federal custody today on charges of smuggling counterfeit American $20 bills into Detroit from Windsor, Ont. They are Antonio Brum, 25 years old, and Gil Silva, 24, both of Toronto. The arrest resulted from a tip supplied by the Ontario Provincial Police, who had the pair under surveillance for several months.

title: E.R.A. and Abortion Face Senate Tests
description: IF HELL hath no fury like a woman scorned, the New Jersey State Senate may be in for some difficult times. When it returns from a monthlong holiday on Dec. 13, it will find itself face to face with women's rights. Pending on the Senate calendar will be a proposal to repeal New Jersey's approval in 1972 of the Equal Rights Amendment to the Federal Constitution. And standing in the wings ready to react, if the Senate votes to repeal this approval, will be numerous groups of angry women.

title: John Hoy Is Fiance of Katherine Minsch Antoinette Geyelin Engaged to William Hoar
description: Katherine Arden Minsch and John Wallerius Hoy, graduates of Southampton College, plan to be married May 21. Mr. and Mrs. William J. Minsch Jr. of Potomac, Md., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Fletcher Hoy 3d of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Serious Music's Ambassador To the Home Screen
description: David Griffiths 19 a man much in demand these days, for be knows how to prepare and present classical music programs on television, a medium that seems only lately to have discovered what riches there are to be mined in this field:The publicTV channels are now telecasting Karajan and Ozawa. Rubinstein and Pavarotti. the renowned orchestras of Berlin, Boston, Philadelphia and a dozen other cities, all doing their joint and several thing, and doing it with increasing frequency. The musicians are sometimes bemused with the size of their new audience. A conductor would have to live 70 years, Sir Georg Solti recently said, and conduct every night of his life, to reach the live audience he can reach in one night on television.

title: Bomb Kills 3 Arabs in Hebron
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 4 (AP)Three young Arabs in the West Bank town of Hebron were killed by an explosion today when a bomb they were assembling exploded, an Israeli military spokesman said. The explosion occurred near the market in Hebron during the morning. A spokesman said the three. all between 19 and 25 years old. were preparing the bomb in a room above a barber shop.

title: 1,000 STUDENTS FLEE COLUMBIA DORM FIRE
description: Nearly 1,000 students, some of whom hung from windows to seek relief from smoke, were evacuated early yesterday morning from a Columbia University dormitory in what the authorities said was the latest in a series of suspicious fires at the institution.

title: Tokyo Rose: Traitor
description: For most servicemen, the worst of modern warfare is the boredom of it. Oa my World War II ship, the U.S.S. Elden, that boredom was as vast as the Pacific itselfday after day, same watches and drills, same food and smells, same heat and shipmates. That is why the Elden's crew, and the rest of the two million young Americans in the Pacific theater during World War II, made so much of the woman they referred to as Tokyo Rose.

title: 1976: A Selection of Noteworthy Titles
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 7, 1975. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Boohs are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.

title: Northern Marianas Vote Charter Aimed at U.S. Commonwealth Role
description: AGANA, Guam, Dec. 3 (Reuters)Nearly 35 years to the day after Japanese bombers took off from the nearby island of Saipan to attack American military installations here, Saipan and its neighbors today came closer to becoming a fullyfledged United States commonwealth.

title: The Battle of North Hills
description: A PUBLIC hearing was held earlier this month in the Village of North Hills concerning the new zoning ordinance and master plan. There were various statements and implications that this rezoning would give substantial gain to members of the board who own large estates in North Hills and would be benefited by this legislation. This is probably correct, but it is the inevitable result of progress in the development of suburban areas. The best illustration is Lev?? where the initial purchases were at the rate of $400 an acre and the prices ultimately reached $40,000 an acre, a 10,000 percent increase.

description: Sally Bloodgood Bachelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Frederick Bachelder of Garden City, and Fort Salonga, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Charles Thompson Stanley, son of Mrs. Henry Phelan of Port Washington, L.I., and the late Robert Francis Stanley.

description: Of course I stole the title for this talk, from George Orwell. One reason I stole it was that I like the sound of the words: Why I Write Continued from Page 2. There you have three short unambiguous words that share a sound, and the sound they share is this:

description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., Dec. 3 (UPI)Paul Farthing, who served on the Illinois Supreme Court from 1933 to 1942 and had a long legal career despite being blinded at the age of 12, died yesterday. He was 89 years old.

title: PEOPLE

John Toll is the president of the State University at Stony Brook, and Kenneth LaValle is a state senator, but they both turned up as honorary coaches at the annual Stony Brook RedWhite intrasquad game, which serves to introduce this season's varsity squad. When it all over, the Tollcoached White squad had won it. 9287.

Coburn of Massachusetts and the Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy performed the ceremony. The bride's marriage to Gail Kubik, a composer, ended in divorce. Mr. Grant, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Albert Grant of Bridgeville, Nova Scotia, is a graduate In arts and law of Dalhousie University.

title: In Greece For Men Only
description: From the peak of the Holy Mountain in northern Greece an ancient monk claimed to he able to see Constantinople on a clear day. Even if the sky were not quite clear enough to see that far, one could, by gazing northward from the summit of Mount Athos, see a landscape unique in the world today,: a hilly forested peninsula dotted with ancient fortresses. The unpaved roads of its interior are walked by men in black leading donkey trains that wind slowly past chapels containing icons from the 10th century. No cars, no electricity, no telephone poles. On the western coast o'er a pebble beach washed by a bluegreen sea stands the monastery of Xenofontos, founded in 520, and just below the horizon are the glistening contours of Macedonia, battleground of Greek history.

title: 3 Jersey College Students Killed, One Injured in CarTruck Crash
description: WINSLOW TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 4 (AP)Three Glassboro State College students were killed yesterday when their car and a tractor trailer collided on Route 73 about 20 miles southeast of Camden, the police said.

description: It is past 5 o'clock and the search continues for special hatch sealing tape to be air freighted to a ship in Korea.

This listener has heard a good many of them, but none in recent years has been so interesting and brilliant as Eliot Fisk, who made his New York debut Tuesday night in Alice Tully Hall.

I will settle in the town where they build my theater, Richard Wagner's granddaughter was saying, but maybe I speak too soon. Probably not; the family has a way of getting things done.

description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5  Arthur E. Braun, a banker, newspaper publisher and philanthropist, died today at his home here. He was 100 years old on Nov. 23.

description: And they talk about rockandroll fans. The girls who used to fling jellybeans at Paul McCartney, the worshipers who scavenged Bob Dylan's garbage cans tor crumbs from his breakfast plate, the ones who wept when Mick Jagger married Biamcaall may have been outdone yesterday. If layinging out cash is a measure of love, there can be few fans more devoted and passionate than opera lovers, who turned out in great numbers yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera's fundraising bazaar.

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) Joseph Charles Fusco, an associate of Al Capone, the late crime syndicate leader, died today in his Conrad Hilton Hotel suite. He was 74 years old.

(Ace) Gutowsky, former halfback and coach at Oklahoma City University and a professional player with the Detroit Lions and New York Giants, died yesterday at the age of 67. He was a standout on the Lions 1935 National Football League championship team.

description: SYRACUSE, Dec. 6 (AP)New York's economic stagnation has cost the state and local governments more than $6 billion in potential tax revenues since 1973, a Syracuse University political scientist reports.

title: JAPAN RULING PARTY LOSES ITS MAJORITY IN THE LOWER HOUSE
Film: Kafkaesque:Schaaf's 'Dream City' Has Fuzzy Quality in Its Plot
description: "Dream City," which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is Johannes Schaaf's German-language screen adaptation of "The Other Side," the only novel ever written by the Austrian graphic artist Alfred Kubin(1877-1959), who has been variously described as an Expressionist, a Symbolist, a proto-Surrealist and a latter-day Romantic of the German school.I have not read the novel, which was published in Austria in 1909 and here in 1968. Yet I would suspect that Mr. Schaaf, by updating it, may have disconnected the logic that compelled Kubin to create his fantasy about a dream city, an allegorical place that probably owes more to conditions in the middle Europe that Kubin shared with Kafka than it does to those in today's world.Mr. Schaaf's movie is an interior decorator's dream, full of bizarre sets, costumes and make-up, about a Munich artist (Per Oscarsson) and his wife (Rosemarie Fendel) who, for reasons they never know, are invited to take up residence in a mysterious city where everything is allowed as long as other individuals are respected. Actually this is a rather large, dampening qualification for life in any real dream city, but the movie is so profoundly fuzzy that it doesn't make too much difference.The film is a vaguely Kafkaesque nightmare that can't make up its mind whether its interests are psychological or political, though it seems to be certain that utopia would drive most people mad. Much of the film was photographed in the old Czechoslovak town of Krumlov, which is very picturesque, maybe just a bit too much so.The only other detail about the film that remains clear is that to get to the dream city of the title, one goes to Munich and books a flight to the Near East on Lufthansa. At least that's how the people in the movie do it.

title: Seriously Now, a Brokers Convention Is Not All Partying
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 4'It's far different now from what it was in my father's day. They used to come down here for a week and party all the time. Now it's for three days and there's a lot of work. The speaker was Alan C. Arnold. a vice president of the New Orleansbased brokerage firm of Howard, Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs Inc. And his remarks. made casually here one evening, indicate how the annual conventions of the Securities Industry Association and one of its predecessor organizations, the Investment Bankers Associationhave changed over the years.

Women's Speed Mark Set
description: FIELDS. Ore., Dec. 5 (UPI)  Kitty O'Neil, a 28yearold Hollywood stuntwoman, established a world landspeed record for women yesterday on the Alvord Desert in southeast Oregon, averaging 321 miles per hour on the five eights mile course in two runs. She drove the SMI Motivator. a threewheeled, rocketlike vehicle which burns hydrogen peroxide.

title: In Memoriam
description: DICKERGusslo. Mother, your love and courage still sustain me. You., are always In my thoughts, forever in my heart. ROSALIND.

title: Europe and Carter
description: PARIS, Dec. 5The major Western European leaders have come out publicly for an early summit meeting with Presidentelect Carter. This slight breach of protocol, in advance of the inauguration, reflects the intensity of the Europeans sense of need to know Washington's intentions, and indeed of their dependence on the plans and policies of the United States. It is a rather drastic reversal of European attitudes from only two or three years ago. It showed clearly at the recent Common Market meeting at The Hague: Instead of talking about establishment of European policieswhich implies decisions made before consultation with the United Statesand European power in the world, as they did in their winter meetings of 1972, 1973 and 1974, the Europeans decided in effect that they could not do anything until they heard from the United States.

title: 200 Rally in Bronx To Demand a Drive To Protect the Aged
description: More than 200 Bronx residents, mostly elderly, crowded into the auditorium of the St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon to hear emotional indictments of the State Legislature, the judicial system and lawenforcement officials for failure to protect them from crime.

title: Commodities
description: Cocoa futures. whose record prices have been alarming many traders recently, declined a little most of last Week and then jumped the daily limit again Friday.

title: Double Trouble
description: Council members Theodore Weiss and Carol Greitzer have offered an interestingbut inappropriatesolution to a parking problem that has been becoming increasingly annoying in some sections of Manhattan. They would double the fine for double parkingfrom $25 to $50for those doubleparkers who neglect to leave a telephone number or address where they can be reached.

title: 11 Injured in Chicago Fire
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UPI)Fire destroyed a threestory apartment building on the city's West Side today, injuring at least 11 persons.

title: Supreme Court and Death Penalty: Uncertainty Heightened by New Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Five months after the Supreme Court upheld the death penalty as a permissible punishment for murder, the nation and the Court itself are entangled in new and rapidly increasing confusion and controversy over the law on capital punishment. To a great extent, this is the in evitable and, in part, expected aftermath of the Court's decision. last July.. In part, however. the Justices are adding new notes of uncertainty for reasons that were, at most, only hinted at in the July cases.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was erroneously reported in The Times Saturday that requests for stays of execution for two Texas convicts, James Livingston and Robert Excell White, were pending before the Supreme Court. In fact, only the request of Mr. White is still pending. A stay was granted in the Livingston case last week.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has charged the Consolidated Edison Company with proposing a slanted and meaningless plan that would undercut the entire concept of timeofday metering for electricity. The utility has proposed an experiment in which selected volunteers would get reduced rates for electricity used between 10 P.M. and 10 A.M., while peak rates would apply the rest of the day.

title: Young to Coach at Purdue
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 5 (AP) Jim Young was named today as head football coach at Purdue University. He succeeds Alex Agase, who was released two weeks ago. Terms of the contract were not announced, but it was reported that Young, who has been head coach at the University of Arizona for the last four years, received a fiveyear pact at $35,000 a year.

title: Police Gather Data on Sunday Store Opening
description: NEWARK, Dec. 5 Newark police officers went Christmas shopping here today to gather evidence for complaints against stores that were open or selling items in violation of socalled Blue Laws, which prohibit certain sales on Sundays.

title: Love for Three Oranges Revived by Chicago Opera
A Detailed Study Charges Redlining By Major Savings Banks in Brooklyn
description: A leading public interest group made public yesterday a detailed study charging that the major savings banks of Brooklyn have redlined the whole borough by systematically refusing to grant mortgages there.

title: Free Democrats and Opposition In Alliance in Lower Saxony
description: BONN, Dec. 5 (Reuters)West Germany's small Free Democratic Party agreed today to join the Christian Democrats to form a coalition government in Lower Saxony.

title: The Cards, Raiders and All That jazz
description: OAKLAND, Calif.. Dec. 5Good football is like good jazz. rile tempo's the thing. In the National Football League, the good teams are like good bands. They play at a faster tempo than had teams or bad bands do. To a refugee accustomed to the waltz of the Giants and the Jets, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Baltimore Colts played a jazz concert in Busch Stadium on Saturday afternoon. They hurried en to the field faster, they broke from the huddle faster, they got off the ball faster. And they scored faster. The Cardinals won, 2417. after having taken a 147 lead in the first quarter. In a more significant setting, such as a Super Bowl, those first 15 minutes might be remembered as the greatest quarter ever played. The teams accumulated a total of 463 yards on rushes, passes and returns, virtually all from execution rather than breakdowns. That's 463 yards in 15 minutes. That's pro football at its best tempo. That's the jazz that the Giants and the Jets seldom play.

title: Promise and Power
description: WASHINGTONUnhappy precedent makes one wary of writing about the freshness; and promise of new people in Washington. The place has seen so many hopes curdle. But anyone who visits the amable chaos of the Carter transition office is likely to come away thinking that its young men and women are fresh, uncynical, and modest.

title: Televising 7 Pro Football Games Is a Complex Task
description: For the approximately 500 persons involved with the televising of seven National Football League games around the nation by CBSTV yesterday afternoon. the operation was typically precise. intricate and nervewracking.

title: Uruguayan Minister Resigns
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 5 (Reuters)Agriculture and Fisheries Minister Julio Aznrez has resigned from the Cabinet for undisclosed reasons. He is the first minister to resign since President Aparicio Mndez was sworn into office on Sept. 1.

title: Ford at Cathedral Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI)President Ford went to services at washington National Cathedral today with W. Clement Stone, an insurance executive, and then relaxed at the White House. Mr. Stone, a Chicagoan, gave more than $2 million to Richard M. Nixon's election campaigns.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Socialist Party Opens Madrid Congress, the First in Spain in 44 Years
description: MADRID, Dec. 5 Officially emerging from a past of exile, persecution and clandestine existence, the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, once the most powerful party in the nation, today legally opened its first congress in Spain in 44 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STRATEGY AGREED ON IN CITY FISCAL CRISIS
description: New York City officials, union executives and Municipal Assistance Corporation aides agreed at a meeting in Gracie Mansion yesterday that there should be one single approach on the $1 billion in shortterm debt that the city is under court order to repay.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Beirut Extends Deadline on Arms
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, Dec. 5 President Elias Sarkis has extended the deadline for the collection of heavy weapons from rival Lebanese factions and Palestinian guerrillas, to avoid having to use force, while giving the opposing groups time to moderate their positions, according to informed sources here.

title: World News Briefs
description: MSCOW, Dec. 5 (Reuters) A silent vigil by political dissidents ended in a violent melee on one of Moscow's main streets tonight. Andrei D. Sakharov, one of the demonstrators, blamed the security police for what happened.

title: ...And These Families Left
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.Corporate kinship, Southernstyle, is bringing the displaced persons of TimeLife Books Inc. into greater social and family contacts here than would have been thinkable two months ago back in New York.

title: Seekers of Loch Ness Monster Disappointed, Not Discouraged
description: The 1976 search for the socalled Loch Ness monster has come to an end with results that werewell, in a worddisappointing, but, the searchers hasten to add, not discouraging.

title: Giants Subdue Lions
Seeking House Leadership Post Press Claims in the Election Today
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5Representative Phillip Burton. legs crossed in a placid pose, puffed slowly on a cigarette and paused for effect before telling a Capitol Hill visitor, I am cooperative by nature.

title: Plan Approved For Olympic Training Sites
description: Heeding a plea for progress. the United Stgtes Olympic committee unanimously has approved the establishment of yearround national training centers to assist American athletes on the road to the 1980 Moscow Olympics.

title: New York Opposes Paying in Advance For Alaskan Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5  New York State has told the Federal Power Commission that consumers should not be required to pay years in advance for natural gas from Alaska's North Slope.

title: Hall and Oates, Classy Pop
description: When Daryl Hall, John Oates and their fiveman band kicked into their first number at the Palladium Saturday night, it was difficult not to feel a certain annoyance. Their appropnalion of many of the devices of soul music of the 1970's is so calculated that all the old shibboleths about whites ripping off blacks resurface. But white rockers have been borrowing from rhythm and blues for years. so why single out Hall and Oates (as they are known as a unit)? Furthermore. Hall and Oates hardly confine their borrowings to Gamble and Huff and other presentday Blacks; they are busy ripping off everybody, of whatever color, into a happy melange of 60's and 70's rock, pop and soul.

title: Yugoslavia Vows Support of Arafat
MacLeish Scores 3 in Flyer Triumph
Search Is Continued For Mrs. Garment
description: The whereabouts of Grace Garment remained unknown yesterday after a 13state missingperson alarm was issued for the television writer and the wife of Leonard Garment.

description: PARIS, Dec. 5Jacques Chirac dissolved the Gaullist party today and transformed it into a new mass movement of personal support.

Orthwein in St. Louis, the former president, moving up to chairman and chief executive, titles previously held by Ernest A. Jones in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Mr. Jones, 61 years old, becomes chairman of D.M.M. International.

description: GENEVA, Dec. 5Black nationalists at the conference on the future of Rhodesia are mostly displaying studied indifference today to Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's decision to resume the leadership of his delegation.

description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2Stroking his shoulderlength blond hair, Kevin Hammond, 14 years old, was saying that he once was a packandahalfaday when he was younger. Now he is down to about onehalf pack daily.

Jacob Bleibtreu, Former Governor Of New York Stock Exchange, 90
description: Jacob Bleibtreu, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange and partner in the firm of Abraham and Company, died Saturday at his home, 262 Central Park West. He was 90 years old.

description: TRENTON, Dec. 5The State Assembly has scheduled 46 bills for a vote tomorrow, including proposals to require banks and other lending institutions to finance mortgages in slum areas, to set up a state agency to promote the filming of motion pictures in New Jersey, and a package of measures that would make sweeping changes in drunkendriving laws and make it harder to get a driver's license.

description: WASHINGTONFor eight months earlier this year, candidate Carter and the men around him grimly refused to admit the existence of a list of contrihutors to the Carter 1970 campaign for Governor.

title: NEGLIGENCE ALLEGED IN FIRE AT COLUMBIA
description: Columbia University  officials, who toured a dormitory yesterday where a fire forced the evacuation of nearly 1,000 students early Saturday, received dozens of complaints about poor living conditions and negligent maintenance in university housing.

title: Some MuchRecruited Freshmen Excel
description: Seven much recruited basketball players, whose names appeared prominently on the various high school allAmerica teams last March, played key roles in the fortunes of their college teams this weekend. All but Darryl Griffith of Louisville were on winning squads Saturday night.

title: BigBand Jazz Back and Booming at Princeton University
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 5Three years ago, when the first notes of the Princeton University Jazz Ensemble drifted across the Princeton campus, some students and faculty members doubted that there was enough interest to sustain bigband jazz at a college where the students almost universally followed rock music.

title: Lead Poison Kills Snow Geese
description: LAKE CHARLES, La.. Dec. 5 (AP)About 200 snow geese have been found dead at the Lacassine Wild Life Refuge, apparently poisoned by lead shotgun pellets eaten on their southward migration, wildlife authorities said. The refuge is 30 miles southeast of here. Laboratory tests on 20 of the dead birds showed 18 of them died of lead poisoning, one died of old age and one of gout.

title: How to Become a Pariah in Today's China: just Hail From Shanghai
Books of the Times
description: Near the end of this appalling book, someone says: What an education this has been for all of us. For us, and for our kids.I can't watch Petrocelli anymore. Petrocelli is a big fairy tale.

description: MADRID, Dec. 5 (UPI) The Mayor of Madrid attended a reception held by international Jewish leaders today, taking the edge off an official boycott of a Jewish conference.

description: CALDWELL, Dec. 5 Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, a nuclear scientist and professor of chemistry at Harvard University, told several hundred people today that those who favored expanded nuclear power and technology had far more money than those who wanted military funds diverted to social and environmental programs.

title: New York State Weighing a Pullout From Summer Lunch Program
description: New York State education officials are debating whether to withdraw from the Federal Government's summer program to feed needy children, and have held up publication of their 1977 management plans until a decision can be made by the Board of Regents.

title: Nuggets Turn Back Jazz, 117105
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 5 (AP)Dan Issel and David Thompson combined for 55 points tonight and paced the Denver Nuggets to a 117105 victory over the New Orleans Jazz in the National Basketball Association.

title: Special Class Offer To Drunken Drivers Gains in New York
description: ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP)More than half of the drunken drivers convicted in New York State during the last year chose to take special classes rather than give up their license for a year, the State Motor Vehicle Department reported over the weekend.

title: Around the Nation
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 (AP)Striking bus drivers agreed today to obey a court order and return to work, ending a fiveday mass transit strike in Allegheny County.

title: Envoy in Moscow Dies
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5 (UPI)H. Adrian Lowe, West. Germany's secondranking diplomat in the Soviet Union, plunged to his death tonight from his apartment in a foreigners compound, his embassy said. Mr. Lowe, a minister in the embassy, was married and had three young children.

title: Cancer Report Made By Educational Trust
description: A research affiliate of the New Jersey Hospital Association published yesterday the first of a series of analytical reports on cancer in the state. The Hospital Research and Educational Trust said the reports were based on records of more than 55 percent Of the one million patients admitted to hospitals in the state each year. Most similar studies are based on a 1 percent sample; the research group said.

title: 4 Children Killed in Brooklyn Fire
description: Fire swept through a threestory Bedford Stuyvesant apartment building early this morning, killing four small children, according to the police. The father of one of them had thrown his son and another boy out of a secondfloor window in an attempt to save them.

title: Five Killed as Light Plane Crashes Into a Church After Hitting Tower
description: A twinengine plane carrying five persons struck a radio tower in Forked River, N.J., Saturday night. sheared off its left wing and then crashed into a church, killing all aboard.

title: 29 Persons With Gastroenteritis Are Hospitalized in Australia
description: SYDNEY. Australia, Dec. 5 (AP)At least 29 persons were hospitalized with severe gastroenteritis today after arriving in Australia on a British Airways flight from Hong Kong, hospital officials said.

title: The Labor Scene
description: Has a new militancy gripped the labor movements of Western democracies or is 'the end of ideology in postindustrial society causing the strike to wither away as an economic weapon? Each of these contradictory appraisals has had persuasive champions among analysts of industrial conftct in the last two decades. Now both are rejected as wide of the mark in a study by a Massachusetts Institute of Technology political scientist.

title: 4 Die in Mobile Home Fire

They were John DeVerney, 30 years old, his wife Joyce, 27, and sons John Jr., 4, and .Jay, 2. There are indications the fire may have been started by an overheated wood stove. a sheriff's spokesman said.

Even then, some skeptics suggested that the oil would eventually be sent to Japan, but that charge was scathingly denied.

title: Carter Sends Rabin Cable

description: ST. MORITZ. Switzerland, Dec. 5. (AP)Walter Tresch of Switzerland beat Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden today in the final of the men's parallel slalom in the closing program of the World Series of Skiing. Stenmark missed a gate in the first run and took a 1.5second penalty. Trying to make up in the second run, he fell after the halfway mark of the 26gate course while he was slightly ahead.

If layinging out cash is a measure of love, there can be few fans more devoted and passionate than opera lovers, who turned out in great numbers yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera's fundraising bazaar.

title: 2 Named to Assassination Study
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP)  Two members of the staff of the New York County District Attorney were named today to oversee a special House committee's inquiry into the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Robert Karl Tanenbaum will be deputy chief counsel for the group investigating the Kennedy assassination and Robert Joseph Lehner will be deputy chief counsel for the King assassination investigation. Richard A. Sprague, chief counsel of the House inquiry, announced the appointments.

title: Spanish Village, City Folks Haven, Is Slow to Accept Recent Trends
description: ROBLEDO DE CHAVELA, Spain, Dec. 1Not far from E1 Escrial, the melancholy edifice begun by Philip II four centuries ago, lies this whitewashed village where wealthy people from Madrid come in the summer. Its inhabitants, inhibited by generations under the heel of what they call the bosses, are afraid to speak out.

title: 80% OF WORK FORCE HELD MISEMPLOYED
description: PRINCETON, Dec. 6A marketing research company that has been screening job applicants for companies for 16 years has concluded that people are hired for the wrong reasons and that 80 percent of the work force is misemployed.

title: Miss Hearst Scheduled to Appear In Los Angeles Court Thursday
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (AP)Patricia Hearst's first court appearance since she was released on bail two weeks ago has been scheduled for Thursday.

title: The U.N. Today
Supereme Court Puts Off Execution Of Texas Killer Who Wants to Die
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 6 The Supreme Court temporarily postponed today the execution of a Texas murderer who had told the Court he wanted to die on schedule. The Court acted to give lawyers for the man a chance to seek full high court review of his case.

title: O'NEILL IS SPEAKER; REP. WRIGHT OF TEXAS WINS MAJORITY POST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Democrats in the House of Representatives today elected Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts to be Speaker of the House in the next Congress and Jim Wright of Texas to be majority leader.

title: Iowa Corn and Soybeans to Suffer From State's Driest Six Months
description: AMES, IowaUp to three inches of snow is covering Iowa's corn and soybean fields, but the snowfall was too small and It came too late to prevent this from being the driest six months in Iowa's history.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge experts in general hate to lose matches, but if they do lose they would rather lose by 20 or 30 international match points, a not undignified number, than by one or two. A tiny margin always means a sleepless night worrying about all the possible ways in which a few points might have been saved.

title: Program to Be Tried To Fight Child Abuse
description: TRENTON, Dec. 6 (AP)  A new program to combat child abuse and neglect, using paraprofessionals who will go into homes and offer outside guidance, will be tried in 40 to 50 Passaic County homes, Commissioner Ann Klein of the State Department of Human Services said today.

title: The Challenge to Giscard
description: PARIS, Dec. 6 A new period has begun in French politics with the metamorphosis of the Gaullist bloc into a mass movement behind the former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac. French commentators have speculated widely and excitedly about where it will lead, and the conclusion is that anything can happen. It is as though a tremor had revealed a deep new earth fault. The devastating quake has not come yet, and may never come. But it can no longer be considered impossible or even unlikely.

title: RULING ON TEXAS BIAS VOIDED BY JUSTICES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 The Supreme Court vacated by vote of 7 to 2 today a lower Federal appeals court ruling that found illegal discrimination against both blacks and MexicanAmericans in the Austin, Tex.. public schools and that ordered the preparation of a broad school desegregation plan.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Despite present economic uncertainty, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation intends to continue with its previously announced $1.8 billion program of capital expenditure, David Adams 4th, vice president in charge of finance, said in a presentation to the New York Steel Analysts Group.

title: Dollar Dips Except Against Pound; Gold Climbs on a Strong Demand
description: BRUSSELS. Belgium. Dec. 6 (UPI)The dollar lost ground slightly against all European currencies except the pound today. The price of gold rose sharply.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Philip Heller, 65, Dies; Former Labor Official Was in Foreign Service
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Philip A. Heller, a longtime New York labor union official and a retired Foreign Service officer, died today at the Georgetown University hospital of kidney failure. He was 65 years old.

title: Ideas for a Solution to South Africa's Crisis Percolate as Leaders Break for Vacations
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Dec. 6At least 14 blacks were injured by police gunfire today in a fresh flareup in a black township near Cape Town. But here in the capital all was calm as Prime Minister John Vorster and his ministers, their year's work completed, headed off for their annual beach vacations.

title: Open Interest
Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Oct. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on ting New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Sipa Exchange anD (o) over the counter.

title: FRANK W. HALL, HEAD OF AD AGENCY, DIES
description: Frank W. Hall, president since 1970 of Albert FrankGuenther Law, a leading financial advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday at his home, 121 Meadowbrook Road, Garden,City, L.I., of complications following brain surgery several months ago. He was 56 years old.

title: Three More in Ohio Town Killed
description: CELINA, Ohio, Dec. 6 (UPI) A car struck a power pole and a tree yesterday, killing three Minster teenagers, including one who survived an accident last March 7 that took the lives of eight Minster High School students. The authorities said that James Quinlan, 16, one of those killed yesterday, had been uninsured last March when eight students in a group he was with were struck by a car. The other victims yesterday were identified as Jeffrey Bruns, 17, and Thomas Meiring, 16.

title: VIRGINIA DEMOCRATS ASK CAUCUS TO REMOVE BYRD
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 6 (UPI)The State Democratic Central Committee of Virginia has overwhelmingly ratified a resolution calling for the removal of Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., an independent, from the Senate Democratic Caucus.

title: ExPolice Official Backs Beame Son On Boomis Meeting
description: A former highranking police official who served in Mayor Beame's 1973 election campaign last night supported the contention of the Mayor's son, Bernard Beame, that the younger Beame neve promised Christopher Boomis a lucrative building project in exchange for secret campaign contributions during an October 1973 meeting.

title: A MODERATE BUSING PLAN IS ADOPTED IN KANSAS CITY
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 6 (UPI)The Board of Education has chosen the most moderate of three options for school desegregation next year, a plan that would bus 7,800 more students but would leave some high schools all black.

title: Seven Months With New Baby, Parent Leave Is Hit in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLMKurt: If you don't achieve contact with children in the early months, you can't catch up. Once you start, it's easy to continue.

title: CAREY SEES A BUDGET WITH $1 BILLION GAP; LOCAL AID TO SUFFER
description: ALBANY, Dec. 6Governor Carey announced today that New York State faced a budget deficit next year of $1 billion, which he said he would seek to close by drastic restructuring of the formulas that channel aid to localities, including New York City.

title: Five Feared Missing in Crash
description: CLEWISTON, Fla., Dec. 6 (UPI)The Hendry County Sheriff's Department said today that a twinengine Piper Aztec plane reportedly carrying five persons from Pensacola to Fort Lauderdale had crashed into Lake Okeechobee and that there were no survivors.

title: CALIFORNIA STUDIES 2TIER PROPERTY TAX
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec.6The California Legislature opened consideration today of a proposal whose fate may be watched by businessmen across the countrya plan to establish different tax rates for incomeproducing property and for private homes.

title: Turkish Quake Toll Put at 3,790
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 6 (AP) The earthquake that rocked the eastern province of Van 10 days ago claimed 3,790 lives, the Housing and Reconstruction Minister, Nurettin Ok, announced today. Officials had expressed fear the toll would reach 5,000. Mr. Ok said the quake left 50,000 homeless.

title: Military Pension System Is Called More Costly Than the B1 Bomber
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)The military pension system will be far more costly than such major weapons systems as the B1 bomber, according to Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: WILLIAM CASEY, ENGINEER IN CONSTRUCTION WORK, 58
description: William H. Casey, who with his wife, the former Mary Jane Maher, was killed in a collision of two light airplanes over the Hudson River Saturday near Nyack, N.Y., was a wellknown construction engineer. They were each 58 years old and residents of Baltimore.

title: Defecting From the Virgin Mary
description: LONDONAt the age of 16 I solemnly promised that I would imitate the Virgin Mary all my life. In return, I received a stiff blue ribbon with a medallion that proclaimed Mary Queen, Advocate and Mother. I had become a member of the Sodality of Our Lady, a Child of Mary.

title: JOSEPH T. SCARRY
description: Joseph T. Scarry, a retired newspaperman, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J. He was 83 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: U.S. Ties With Manila Strained By a Public Dispute Over Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 Relations between Washington and Manila appeared severely strained today after an unusual public dispute over what caused the breakdown in negotiations for a new agreement permitting continued United States use of military bases in the Philippines.

title: CLOSED PRIMARIES ALLOWED TO STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) The Supreme Court today refused to hear arguments challenging the exclusion from primary elections of voters not affiliated With either major political party.

title: Boarder Babies
description: The problem of the socalled boarder babieschildren stuck in hospitals for months and sometimes years after the medical reasons for their hospitalization have disappearedis said by municipal administrators to have resulted from a bureaucratic morass. Even a superficial penetration of that morass provides an instructive lesson into how and why governments so often work badly or fail to work at all.

title: Tentative Plan Is Outlined By Beame for Redeeming Billion in New York Notes
description: A tentative plan to redeem, under court order, almost $1 billion in New York City notes was outlined yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: F.B.I. Opens Inquiry Into Charges Of Police Corruption in Stamford
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents began an inquiry here today into charges of widespread corruption in the Stamford Police Department.

title: 2 Composers Lead Their Own Works
description: Irwin Bazelon and Claire Polin presided over performances of their own music in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night, and in some respects the two composers made a complementary pair.

title: DUNNING POWELL
description: Dunning Powell, a portrait painter whose works include the portrait of former Gov. Malcolm Wilson in the State Capitol in Albany, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Old Chatham, N.Y. He was 56 years old.

title: Bengals Beaten by Raiders, 3520; Steelers Playoff Chances Improve
Jersey Bars Auto Insurance Rise
description: TRENTON. Dec. 6James J. Sheeran, New Jersey's Insurance Commissioner, rejected today all auto insurance rateincreast applications pending since July and said the companies would probably have to wait at least six months more for any rate increases.

description: BASKETBALL

title: ROCK GUITARIST BOLIN IS FOUND DEAD IN HOTEL
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 6 (UPI) Tommy Bolin, a rock guitarist, was found dead in his Miami Beach hotel room Saturday following a reported drinking bout.

title: Two Giants in the Hospital Enjoy Their Football Sunday Vicariously
description: In room 622 of the Hospital for Special Surgery, Larry Csonka and Tom Mullen were having as good a time as could be expected. Their Giant teammates were defeating the Detroit Lions, 2410. On the little bedside television screens, it looked more like this Sunday: The Giants defeated the Detroit Lions, 24.10

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (UPI)The new Thai military Government dropped all charges today against three military rulers whose regime was overthrown in a bloody revolt by students in 1973, calling the evidence against them very, very weak.

title: Rangers Revival Tightens Battle For Top Honors in Patrick Division
description: Lester Patrick, for whom the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League was named, would have been proud that the fiercest rivalry in the league was taking place in his division. The Silver Fox, who managed and coached the Rangers in their glamorous early years, would have been doubly proud that this season's edition of the Rangers, once given up for dead, has come back to challenge their division rivals in a most spectacular manner.

title: Spacecraft Maps Structure of Sun's Magnetic Field
description: The structure of the sun's magnetic field has been determined for the first time from data returned by the Pioneer 11 spacecraft, scientists reported yesterday.

title: 3 Parties Challenge Grenada Leader
description: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada, Dec. 6 (ReuIters) A threeparty alliance could provide an unexpectedly powerful challenge tomorrow to Prime Minister Eric Gairy in Grenada's first general election since it became independent two years ago.

title: Farmers in Suffolk Find New Potato Bitter
description: ALBANYFor 20 years, Long Island potato farmers dreamed of the perfect potato, a strain that would prove resistant to a cropmunching pest known as the golden nematode and that also would preserve the region's reputation for plump, tasty potatoes.

title: Crosby on the Road to Broadway
description: Bing Crosby is, by his own description, older and slower, and his voice is lower  I can't make those high notes, but he has no intention of retiring. A healthy, vigorous 72, he opens tonight at the Uris Theater in Bing Crosby on Broadway. This is almost three hours at home on stage with the Crosby family  Bing and Kathryn Grant Crosby and their three children, Harry Lillis 3d, Mary Frances and Nathaniel, with help from such family friends as Rosemary Clooney and Joe Bushkin.

BUSINESS PLANNING NO RISE IN SPENDING IN FIRST HALF OF 77
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6Business plans no increase in real terms in investment in plant and equipment in the first half of next year over the final half of 1976, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Pitt Picks Sherrill
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6Jackie Sherrill, a former assistant coach under Johnny Majors at Iowa State and Pittsburgh, was named today to succeed Majors as head coach at Pittsburgh. The 34yearold Sherrill left Pittsburgh early this year to become head coach at Washington State, where his team won three games and lost eight.

title: CARTER TRANSITION STAFF FINDS BOMB IN ITS OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP)Members of Presidentelect Carter's transition staff found a bomb in their offices today. It was successfully defused by District of Columbia police.

title: Bergman Aide Sentenced To 3Month Prison Term In NursingHome Fraud
description: Mark Loren. a top aide to Bernard Bergman, the promoter who last year became the first to plead guilty in the nursinghome scandals, wag sentenced yesterday to three months in prison and fined $7,500 for conspiracy to defraud the Government.

title: Seymour Net Victor
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP)Russell Seymour, a South African now teaching tennis in Austin, Tex., won the national senior hard court tennis championship yesterday by defeating Vladimir Petrovic, 75, 62. Barbara Weigandt of Vista beat Helen Perez of Los Angeles, 61, 61, in the women's final.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Sued by Labs

title: Notes on People
description: Anybody who knows what he's worth isn't worth very much, is the rather grand, standard answer given by John MacArthur, said to be the nalion's sole surviving billionaire, to inquiries about the size of his personal fortune. Now, however, It appears a court order involving a damage suit may lift some of the secrecy surrounding Mr. MacArthur's finances. In Palm Beach, Fla., Adeline K. Moffet, widow of James Moffett, former chairman of the Standard Oil Company, is suing Mr. MacArthur for $200 million tor having allegedly ousted her from an apartment he owned for nonpayment of rent in 1973. A judge has ordered Mr. MacArthur to produce a statement of this net worth, in connection with Mrs. Moffett's suit. Mr. MacArthur has appealed, maintaining that it would require many weeks of intense work by accountants and expert assistants to formulate such a figure. Mrs. Moffett indicated she's willing to wait.

title: U.S. Hearing Out Andreotti Aid Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today after a meeting with Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti that the United States was ready to discuss Italy's request for financial aid.

description: More than $250,000 in motor vehicle registration fees nas been embezzled over the last three years from the Staten Island branch office of the State Department of Motor Vehicles, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

title: The Reformed House ...
description: When Representative Thomas P. O'Neill, Massachusetts Democrat, takes over as Speaker or the House of Representatives in January, he will preside over a body that differs considerably from the one in which his friend and former Massachusetts colleague, John W. McCormack, relinquished the Speakership at the beginning of 1971. Reforms adopted during the intervening six years have transformed the House.

title: Going Out Guide
description: IS AND WAS If for no other reason than to hear that stunning Rodgers and Hart score of The Boys From Syracuse, musical comedy fans can attend a revival through Dec. 19 at the uptown Equity Library Theater (8699266).

description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Nicholas Scoppetta, the Investigation Commissioner, as deputy mayor for criminal justice, a new post mandated by the revised City Charter.

title: Gilmore Asks Mother to Drop Plea
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 6 (UPI) Gary Mark Gilmore pleaded with his mother today to drop her appeal to the United States Supreme Court on his death senfence, saying that dying Ain't, no big deal.

title: Signaling A GoSlow Approach
description: With all due respect to the 16 economists and businessmen who are said to have recommended it to him, Presidentelect Carter may come to regret his renunciation of wageprice controls. This country's economic problems are so complex and demanding that its chief economic manager needs every weapon available.
