description: The Sun Company of Philadelphia said yesterday that a subsidiary of its Sun Oil Company Ltd. unit, Global Arctic Islands Ltd., and a fourcompany group had signed an agreement for an $80 million oil exploration program in the Canadian Arctic Islands.

title: Nader Says Carter Seems Ready To Pick Aides With Business Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7RaIph Nader asserted today that Presidentelect Jimmy Carter had reneged on his pledge of consultation before making appointments and appeared ready to hand the Cabinetlevel jobs to corporate interests.

title: Rockefeller's Home In Capital on Sale; Priced at $8 Million
description: Vice President Rockefeller is placing his rambling, whiteframe house and 25acre estate on Foxhall Road in northwest Washington up for sale, with a reported asking price of $8 million.

title: Using Mondale in the Cabinet
description: SILVER SPRING. Md. When Jimmy Carter chose Walter Mondale to be his running mate, he said that the Vice President would play an important role in the Carter Administration That, of course, is what all Presidential candidates say: yet, invariably, Vice Presidents wind up doing little of substance.

title: U.S. Court Rules Corporations Are Immune to Double Jeopardy
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held yesterday that corporations, as well as individuals, were entitled to guarantees against double jeopardy.

title: P. L. O. SAID TO WEIGH JOINING OTHER ARABS IN PEACE DELEGATION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7Palestinian leaders, are moving toward acceptance of an, Egyptian proposal for their inclusion in a single Arab delegation to a reconvened Geneva conference on the Middle East, informed Arab diplomats said today.

title: Mary Nash Dead; Character Actress Of Stage and Film
description: Mary Nash, whose 40year career as an actress included stardom on Broadway and success in motion pictures and vaudeville, died Friday at her home in Brentwood, Calif. She was 92 years old.

title: Music: Beethoven Cycle
description: NOT THAT AN EXCUSE WAS NEEDED, hut the 150th anniversary of Beethoven's death, provided the impetus last night in Carnegie Hall for the beginning of a short Beethoven cycle. Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra, with Rudolf Serkin as piano soloist, are going through some of the symphonies and concertos, and on this occasion there were the Fifth Symphony and the Second and Fourth Piano Concertos.

title: Personal Finance: Fire Insurance
description: ABSTRACTIONS such as building costs and inflation were the last things that. Mr. and Mrs. James McDonald had in mind as they fled the fire that wrecked the downstairs of their twostory home in Bergenfield, N.J., not long ago.

title: SWINE FLU IS FOUND IN WISCONSIN MAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7Scientists have apparently isolated swine flu virus from a human for the first time since the outbreak of the disease at Fort Dix, N.J., early this year.

title: Motor Vehicles Chief Vows Action To Halt Fraud in License Bureaus
description: ALBANY. Dec. 7The State Motor Vehicles Commissioner, James P. Melton, today promised new, tough procedures in his department, after disclosing that state and county employees working in auto licensing offices throughout the state had allegedly stolen millions of dollars in license and registration fees.

title: In Defense of Eating Rich Food...
description: PARANOIA, thy name is the American diet. Butter, eggs and creamthe absolute foundations of haute cuisinehave become the dreaded Gorgons, the absolute nonos, the menace foods of the century.

title: A Refusal to Become Black Russians Or African Cubans
description: The present predicament that faces Western influence in Africa is aggravated by the outcome of the civil war in Angola. The development of events now, and in the future, clearly indicates that Soviet influence will grow steadily to the detriment of the Western countries and China.

title: Dr. John Scudder, 76, a Pioneer In Establishing Blood Banks, Dies
description: Dr. John Scudder, an early developer of the blood bank, died Monday at his Kane at 560 Riverside Drive. He was 76 Years old.

title: Waldheim a Skilled Diplomatic Technician
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7In his first term as Secretary General of the United Nations, Kurst Waldheim of Austria strived to perfect the technical machinery of diplomacy. This, rather than any singular policy initiatives, has been his contribution in world affairs. There is no Waldheim doctrine on any subject; the tail and convivial Viennese diplomat is often unnoticed by the general public, as he discovers to his dismay sometimes when he waits in line for an airliner during some diplomatic mission.

title: Navy Missile, in First Test From Air, Goes 188 Miles to Find Target
P.L.O. Meeting Reported Set Sunday
description: BEIRUT. Dec. 7 (UPI)The Damascus radio, monitored here, said today that Khaled alFahoum, president of the Palestine Liberation Organization's central committee, had called an important meeting of the committee in Damascus Sunday night.

title: CARTER AIDE SCORES DECISION ON AIR BAGS
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 7Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's issues director said today he was disturbed that the Ford Administration had issued a decision on airbag automobile safety devices without giving the incoming administration a chance to influence the decision.

title: Biggest Eastern Tourney Coming Up
description: Skippy Hartman, a New Yorker who grew restless wit b being a lawyer and went into the tennis business, has come up with a grandiose ideaa revamping of the Eastern indoor men's championship, which he has been running for several years, into a combined sixevent tournament with prize money.

title: Higher Price for American Steel Seen as Opportunity for Imports
description: The higher the prices Aincrica.n steelmakers charge for their products, the greater the opportunity for foreign steel producers to sell here, Charles Stern, president of the American Institute for Imported Steel, said yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
Giants Have Cardinals Fretting
description: The Giants final practice session at Pleasantville, N.Y., was called off yesterday by Coach John McVay because of the rain and mud. It was just a looseningup day anyway, said the coach. The team will practice the rest of the week at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., for its final game, Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals. . . . The Cardinals have to beat the Giants and then have the Cowboys beat the Washington Redskins at Dallas in order to gain the National Football League playoffs. There's nothing we can do about the Dallas game, said Don Coryell, the Cards coach. Our big concern is the great improvement of the Giants under Coach John Mc. Vay. . . . The Cards beat the Giants, 2721, earlier in the season, but Coryell said, I think we'd really have a better chance of beating the Redskins than the Giants the way the Giants have been playing lately. Pause. 'But that's kind of stupid since Washington beat us twice. . . . The GiantCardinal game will not be televised locally because CBS has opted lo show the Redskin Cowboy game at 4 P.M. The Cards will not delay their flight back to St. Louis to watch the Redskins. We might as well be flying, said a team spokesman. We'll try and get the pilot to get the game for us on the radio. . . Larry Csonka and Tom Mullen were released from the Hospital for Special Surgery and showed off their casts to their teammates at Pleasantville.

title: Melba Moore Makes the Met Pop
description: More and more these days the Metropolitan Opera has become the ultimate prestiae symbol among New York concert hairs for popular artists. So far only a few pop stars have been able so play therepartly because the Met itself fills up every night but Sundays daring the season, and partly because the company is a bit choosy about whom it will rent to.

title: WALDHEIM IS BACKED BY SECURITY COUNCIL FOR FIVE YEARS MORE
More Stores Join Move To Open On Sunday
description: Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and B. Altman three of New York's largest retailers, announced yesterday that they would open their doors on the next two Sundays in the metropolitan area.

title: Velasquez Wins Twice, Gains 3,000th Victory
description: Jorge Velasquez rode Razzle Dazzle Rey to a sevenlength victory in the seventh race at Aqueduct yesterday for the 3.000th winner of his career. Velasquez, who also won the fourth race, joined Sandy Hawley, Laffit Pincay Jr. and Angel Cordero as riders to reach the 3,000winner plateau this year. Altogether 22 jockeys have ridden at winners in the recorded history of thoroughbred racing.

title: Article 1  No Title
A Good Desk...uh,Table...Near the Water Cooler
description: The debate over the virtues of lunching at the desk has been muted, and no one's suggesting that pressure has been brought to bear by takeout interests, but a practice considered acidulous and pernicious by some is hotly defended as virtuous and nonfattening by others.

title: Kadar Says He Sees No AntiSoviet Stand Among. Reds in West
description: VIENNA, Dec. 7The Hungarian Communist leader, Janos Kadar, said here today that he did not agree with the notion that autonomous West European Communist movements were hostile to the Soviet Union.

title: Fashion Is Back in Fashion
description: The psychedelic fashions of the 1960's have passed into history. They were followed, as explosive styles often are, by a quiet period. Women retreated into shirtwaist dresses or sweaters and shirts with pants.

title: Faust Bedevils the Met
description: Of all the new productions that came to the Metropolitan Opera during Rudolf Bing's regime as general manager, perhaps none proved less successful than two produced by JeanLouis Barrault. His tastles Carmen has been replaced, hut his ludicrous Faust hangs on, and on Monday night returned to the repertory for the first time in four seasons.

title: Women Playing Important Role In Rights Struggle in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Women, who are sometimes believed to hold a subservient position in Asian societies, are playing an increasingly prominent role in the struggle for human rights in South Korea.

title: WagePrice Standards.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 In promising not to promulgate wageprice guideposts unilaterally, the way President John F. Kennedy did, Presidentelect Jimmy Carter appears to have closed the door to specific, numerical standards against which Congress and tlie public can evaluate wage and price rises. Some of the economists who advise the Presidentelect, businessmen and labor leaders regard numerical guideposts as likely to do more harm than good. One view is that they lead to confrontation, just the opposite of the cooperative pulling together that Mr. Carter spoke of hopefully at last Friday's news conference.

title: COAST COURT UPSETS DEATHPENALTY LAW
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7The California State Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the state's threeyearold death penalty statute is unconstitutional under recent decisions of the United States Supreme Court.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: IF EVER there was a dish tailormade for quick cookingand pare enjoymentit is of the sort known in French as an minc, a word for which there is no exact English equivalent. An minc consists of any sort of meat cut into shreds and cooked quickly with liquids and seasonings added to make a sauce. Next to an omelet, perhaps, there are few dishes to be cooked in such a hurry.

title: Anonymous Donors Contribute $4,500 To Aid the Neediest
description: An anonymous donor from upstate New York has sent a check for $2.500 to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, while two other contributors, also wishing to be anonymous, gave gifts of $1,000 each.

title: Minter Knocks Out Seales In Fifth Round in London
description: LONDON. Dec. 7 (AP)Alan Minter, British middleweight boxing champion, battered Ray Seales of Seattle to defeat in the fifth round of a scheduled 10round middleweight fight at Royal Albert Hall tonight.

title: Market Place
description: The longdelayed offer by Monogram Industries to buy 3.2 million shares, or 55 per cent, of the common stock of Royal Industries has finally become effective to the relief of arbitragers who reportedly hold about 20 per cent of Royal's shares.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am never happy with the toast that pops out of my toaster. What do you recommend?

title: Seoul Asks Washington to Release Agent for Korean C.I.A. Who Reportedly Sought Asylum
People in Sports
description: Marvin Barnes, the Detroit Pistons forward who had been sentenced to a oneyear term in prison, got a temporary reprieve yesterday. Attorneys for the basketball player were given until Jan. 15 to present a specific program that would serve as an alternative to the prison term. Barnes was convicted Nov. 30 for having violated his probation stemming from a 1974 assault in Providence, R. I.

title: North Koreans in Moscow Linked to the Black Market
Child's World
description: Ski Clothes: The BlueLips Problem

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Dec. 7A wealthy Dutch art dealer is accused of being responsible for the deaths of 120 Jews at the hands of the Nazis during the wartime occupation of Poland.

title: PAUL W. JOHNSTON, 84, HEADED ERIE RAILWAY
description: Paul W. Johnston. a former head of the old Erie Railroad and a pioneer in the use of diesel engines, died yesterday at the Judson Park nursing home in Cleveland. He was 84 years old and had been retired as the railroad's chief executive officer since 1957.

title: Anger in Verse and Dance
description: John Park's celebration of black women, You and the Ladies, in his Monday evening program at the Bijou Theater was not the mistyeyed evocation of Mothers Day but a series of works in verse and dance that drew a sharply etched portrait that embodied a considerable amount of anger. Mr. Parks choreographed most of the works, hut allowed the women to tell their own stories.

title: C.A.B. Told It Erred in Rejecting Charter Airline Route Application
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)The Civil Aeronautics Board acted too hastily in rejecting an application for regularly scheduled, coasttocoast airline service by World Airways that would cost $89 for a oneway ticket, a Federal appellate court ruled today.

title: Plastic Balloons Are Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)Blobo Plastic BubbALoons are being recalled because they contain a hazardous chemical. The toys are plastic balloons sold nationally in separate metal tubes and in packages of tubes. They are made by a Taiwan manufacturer, The Imperial Toy Corporation, which has agreed to repurchase them, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said yesterday.

title: Carter's Agenda: Justice
description: WASHINGTONA new law that becomes fully effective on Jan. I, 1978, will require agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to retire by age 55. It means that 650 men will have to leave the bureau during the next yearnearly one agent out of 12, among them some in senior positions.

title: Jersey Man With Knife Is Killed
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 8 (UPI)  A knifewielding man, Eugene Whaley of Atlantic City, was shot to death yesterday in a struggle with a liquor dealer, the police said. Leon Jackson, 60, the liquor store owner, was charged with homicide and released on his own recognizance. The police said that Mr. Whaley, 23 years old, had asked Mr. Jackson's wife, Ethel, to exchange a bottle of wine, that she refused and that Mr. Whaley cut l'er on the hand. Mrs. Jackson ran to the back room to get her husband, Mr. Whaley chased her and Mr. Jackson shot him, the police said.

title: MARKO DUROVIC DIES; FIGURE IN 1966 TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI)Marko Durovic, one of four men acquitted in the 1966 Krebiozen trial, died Sunday at Michael Reese Hospital, apparently of natural causes. Funeral services were held yesterday in Winnetka, the Chicago suburb where he lived. He was 75 years old.

title: Kim Hughes, a Shooter Most Foul
description: Kim Hughes set himself behind the line, bounced the ball once, adjusted it in his left hand, then flicked it softly at the basket.

title: A Burn Center Is, Opening in New York City It's a First
description: New York City's first burn center opens tomorrow at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center as the first step toward developing a regional network for burn care and building the nation's largest burn facility.

title: Chirac's Challenge
description: How can you have a oneparty system in a country with 256 varieties of cheese? Charles de Gaulle once responded to allegations that he had dictatorial ambitions. His Ironic quip was confirmed by the fact, that, though he ruled as a monarch, he left office with France's basic democratic processes preserved.

title: G. P. PUTNAM'S IS ORDERED TO RECOGNIZE A UNION
description: G. P. Putnam's Sons and two subsidiaries, Berkley Publishing Corporation and Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, have been ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to recognize Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employes International Union as bargaining agent.

title: Pupils Get Painterson Nonsmoking Benefits
description: RIDGEWOOD. Dec. 8Janet Stemwedel. 8 years old, grimaced as she said that her father smoked for 10 years in the Navy and got a terrible disease.

title: Swiss Elect New President
description: BERN, Dec. 8 The two houses of parliament today elected Minister of Justice Kurt Furgler as President of Switzerland for 1977. The election Is a formality because the purely ceremonial office is rotated annually.

title: W. R. Grace and Channel Set Pact in Principle
description: W. R. Grace & Company announced an agreement in principle to acquire Channel Companies Inc., a specialty retailer of home improvements, for about $19.4 million.

title: Card of Thanks
description: MIGNOCCHIThe family of the late Serge Mignocchi wishes to thank ?? fives, friends and neighbors for. The kindnesses shown them during their recent bereavement. Also for the beautiful floral tributes, mass..cards, sympathy cards and contributions to The Heart Fund.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., said yesterday in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission that questionable payments of about $854,225 were made by certain discontinued operations of the company over a fiveyear period ended Dec. 31, 1975. The operations were not identified.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Caution has become the byword of the incoming Carter Administration. During the election campaign, Jimmy Carter made high unemployment the main focus of his attack on Mr. Ford. After the election, Mr. Carter said his aim was to reduce the unemployment rate by 1.5 percentage points by the end of 1977considered a Scene fairly modest objective. , at the time he specified that goal two weeks ago, the last known jobless ratefor Octoberwas 7.9 percent, that implied an unemployment rate of 6.4 or 6.5 percent by the ..nd of next year.

title: Justice Dept. Says It Won't Prosecute Former Rep. Hays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI)The Justice Department has officially closed its investigation of the Capitol Hill sex scandal in which former Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio was accused of putting his mistress on his Congressional payroll, a spokesman said today.

title: Finley Attacks Owners And Kuhn's Leadership
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 Charles O. Finley, complaining that his Oakland A's had been destroyed by the commissioner of baseball, called for Federal action today to rescue the sport from chaos, lack of leadership and the stupidity of the owners.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Students in Seoul Protest Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 8Charges that the South Korean Government had tried to bribe United States Congressmen into supporting it were made here in the open today for the first time. They were included in a manifesto distributed by university students during an unsuccessful attempt to stage an antiGovernment rally.

title: Gulf & Western Gives New York A Culture Center
description: The New York Cultural Center of Columbus Circle, empty since fiscal troubles closed it in September 1975, has been bought by Gulf & Western Industries as a gift to New York City. It will serve as headquarters for the new Department of Cultural Affairs and as an exhibition and tourist center.

title: Article 3  No Title
2Piano Team Performs at Hopper's
description: Twopiano teams are a rarity in jazz. Occasionally they may form for a special performance, but the only pair who played together for any considerable length of time was Albert Ammons and Meade Lux Lewis, the boogiewoogie pianists who appeared for several years at Cafe Society in the 1940's (where they also performed as a trio with Pete Johnson).

title: Heliskiing Provides Touch Of the Exotic on High Slopes
description: BANFF, Alberta, Dec. 7 Skimpy snow conditions, unusual even this early in the season for the Canadian Rockies, have drastically reduced the skiable terrain at the regular recreation areas. But operators of the helicopteroriented Canadian Mountain Holidays plan to open their season on schedule Sunday. The only thing that can stop us, Bruce Harding, the company's general manager, said today, is weather that might sock in our craft. Otherwise, come Sunday our skiers will enjoy 2,500 to 3,500 feet of vertical drops for each of their descents. And it will be on untracked snow.

title: Top Exchanges, N.A.S.D. in Plan On Limit Orders
description: The nation's six major securities exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers approved yesterday a plan to create a communications system that would link them for the purpose of better executing limit orders.

title: Stars Have Reunion On Atkinson Stage To Mark 50 Years
description: There was a sneak retrospective yesterday for the matinee audience at Same Time, Next Year at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street,

title: Congressional Caucus Is Formed To Speak for Hispanic Population
description: Four Democratic members of Congress and the resident commissionerelect of Puerto Rico announced yesterday the formation of the first Congressional Hispanic Caucus.

title: Advertising
description: Never has so much been known about so many peopletheir wants, possessions, habits, opinions, motivations and the way they liveas the United States Government and business establishment know about us.

title: A Doctor of Bovinity
description: On this page on Sept. 14, 1974, the British writer Roald Dahl revealed a hidden truth to a largely innocent world that catapulted a farmer he named Rummins into the tiny ranks of the worldshakers (Copernicus, Newton, Freud).

title: Medicaid Treatment Of Children in South Is Called a Disgrace
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)The Southern Regional Council, headed by a member of the Jimmy Carter transition team, today called Medicaid treatment of poor children in the South a national disgrace and an inexcusable waste of human resources.

title: People and Business
description: Edward F. Gibbons, 57, who joined the F. W. Woolworth Company in 1973 as vice president for finance and who was named president two years later, will become chief executive officer of the retail chain on Feb. 1.

title: Carey Budget: A Tough Nut
description: While Albany's annual budget game got under way this week with a bigger opening play than usual, Governor Carey's assertion that the state faced a $1 billion deficit for its next fiscal year struck most of his audience as the kind of instant replay they could do without. What was accomplished, dispirited Albany watchers asked, by the fiscal agonies of the last yearwhich saw a $1.6 bililon state deficit erased through a painful combination of cuts, taxes and budgetary bandagesif the whole experience now has to be lived through all over again?

title: Era of Good Feelings
description: ATLANTAThe Era of Good Feelings, a phrase coined in 1817 by The Columbian Centinel to describe the oneparty euphoria of the James Monroe Administration, turned out to be a time marked by petty factionalism and stagnation. Not until party partisanship reared its divisive head, under the banner of Andrew Jackson, did a vigorous twoparty system get the nation moving again.

title: Florida Man Slain in ShootOut
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 8 (UPI) A rush hour shootout on a busy street resulted in the death of an auto mechanic and caused a massive 15block traffic jam late yesterday. George Raymond Galbin. 39 years old, of Fort Lauderdale, died of a gunshot wound in the chest, fired by Willie Lee Lindsay, a former Broward County deputy sheriff now employed as a security guard. Mr. Galbin's two COMpanions, Jackit Wayne Hammer and Thomas Calvin Young, were charged with aggravated assault. Witnesses said that Mr. Galbin had a knife in his hand and lunged at Mr. Lindsay, who dodged and drew his 38caliber revolver and shot Mr. Galbin in the chest when he lunged a second time.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. DEC. 8The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company filed notice in Superior Court here today that the company would appeal last month's rejection by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners of a $150.2 million rate increase.

title: A.M.C. and the Auto Union Reach Accord on Holidays and Time Off
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 8 (UPI)Representatives for the American Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers reached agreement yesterday on holiday pay and time off for the period between Christmas and New Year's Day.

title: Next Attorney General
description: In his statement to the Democratic Party Platform Committee last June, Governor Carter stated:

title: Aqueduct Shifts Races, Cancels Exotic Bets
description: Aqueduct's stewards shortened the distance of yesterday's seventh and ninth races and moved both from the main track to the inner winterized one. The track's parimutuel department made refunds to fans on exacta and triple wagering prior to the two contests.

title: Illinois Community Prepares for a Monetary Collapse in 771
description: STELLE, Ill., Dec. 8 (AP)This community was established to plan for doomsday, which is expected in the year 2000. But the residents are more concerned now with surviving the world monetary collapse they see coming next year.

title: Suspect Held in Assault on Aged
description: Elsworth Berkley, 26 years old, of 240 Second Avenue was arrested yesterday by officers of the Manhattan North Senior Citizens Robbery Unit and accused of assaulting and robbing two elderly met recently in their Upper West Side apartments.

title: Ramirez Disqualified, Reinstated and Then Loses
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8 If you thought you saw everything in the way of tennis controversy during the Ilie NastaseHans Pohman match at Forest Hills last September, what happened here tonight might change your mind.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Eulalie Ashmore Hilts Is Wed to Theodore C. Scull
description: Eulalie Ashmore Hilts of New York and Nantucket, Mass., widow of Erwin R. Hilts, was married yesterday afternoon to Theodore C. Scull, a widower. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Nantucket. The Rev. Dr. James S. Stewart performed the ceremony in the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: I.M.F G old Sold at $137 an Ounce, Highest Price for Auction Series
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The International Monetary Fund sold 780,000 ounces more of its gold at auction today and received the highest price to date.

title: EXXON DETAILS ITS PLANS ON 4YEAR CAPITAL OUTLAY
description: Howard C. Kauffmann, president o f the Exxon Corporation, detailed the company's previously reported $20 bi lion fouryear capital and exploration spending program in a presentation to security analysts in Atlanta.

title: Stimulating Program of 14thCentury Music
description: The alumni of the late New York Pro Musica are many, and they tend to group and regroup themselves into new earlymusic ensembles as if they were dancing a sarabande. One such ensemble, the Elizabethan Enterprise, made its official debut on Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, although it has been performing in this area for a couple years. This latest appearance is a result of its winning the Concert Artists Guild's annual auditions.

title: Nadler &
description: Nadler & Larimer Advertising, which will bill about $30 million this year, is acquiring Koehl, Landis & Landan Advertising, specialists in travel advertising and billing around $7 million. As of Jan. 1 it will become the Landis & Landan division of Nadler & Larimer and will share the parent company's office space at 1350 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Dr. Earl Gil, 74, Originated 12th Man With Texas Aggies
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Dec. 8 (AP) Dr. Earl King Gil, who originated the 12th man tradition at Texas A. & M. University, died last night at his Rockport home of a possible heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: The EmploymentUnemployment TradeOff
description: Soon the Carter Administration will decide whether, and iF so how, to stimulate the economy to create more jobs and, hence, reduce unemployment. The direct effect of a stimulus, whether by way of reduced taxes, increased Government spending, easier credit, removal of costraising regulations, or all of these, will be on employment rather than unemployment. The effect on unemployment is largely indirect. It is illusory to think there is a onetoone relation between increased employment and reduced unemployment.

title: Barbara B. Godfrey, 42, Dies; Civic Leader in Suffolk County
description: A mass of the resurrection will be 01fared today for Barbara Barnes ?? a community and civic leader in ?? County, at SS. Phillip and James Roman Catholic Church in St. James, L. 1. Mrs. Godfrey died Sunday at her home in ?? James after a brief illness. She was 42 years old.

title: Article 8  No Title
P.L.O. IS CONSIDERING GOVERNMENT IN EXILE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization is considering the formation of a government in exile before the start of expected negotiations in Geneva for a Middle East settlement, Palestinian sources said today.

title: Playground for Disabled Designed
description: If the New York City Planning Commission has its way, handicapped children in the city will soon be playing a game involving nets, brooms, a ball and wheelchairs, riding on a modified version of a 19thcentury railroad handcar or playing on air mattresses.

title: BENDIX BID TO ADD EXCELL0 IS HALTED
description: The Bendix Corporation and the ExCellO Corporation announced yesterday that they had called off their merger agreement because they could not get together on the terms of the final deal. The cancellation of the $236 million agreement follows by a day disclosure that the Federal Trade Commission was cornpiling information toward a study of Bendix's proposed acquisition of ExCell0 on. the ground of violation of the antitrust laws.

title: Beame Announces an 8Point Plan To Back New Community Boards
description: Mayor Beame announced an eightpoint program to support the city's newly constituted community boards yesterday and drew immediate criticism from the chairman of the State Charter Revision Commission, who said it amounted to an unneeded bureaucratic overlay.

title: Soviet to Sell India Heavy Water for Use In Nuclear Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The Soviet Union will sell India 200 tons of heavy water for use in the Indian nuclear energy program, according to a submission to the International Atomic Energy Agency, United States officials said today.

title: Three on School Board Sentenced To 6 Months in Jail for Extortion
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) Three members of the Pittston School Board were sentenced today to six months in jail and fined $3,000 each for extortion.

title: Raab to Testify at Paterson Trial
description: A reporter for The New York Times has agreed to testify in the second murder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis that is now under way in Paterson, N.J.

title: City U. and City Hall Are Steering Collision Course on Further Cuts
GOING OUT Guide
description: AT HOME ABROAD The Dutch Republic in the Days of John Adams, 1775 to 1795 is a new exhibition of art and artifacts from museums and private collectors in the Netherlands, organized by that country's government and circulated by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service. Centering on our second President's years as Ambassador to Holland, the Bicentennial show offers special interest for television viewers of The Adams Chronicles.

title: State Drops Talks With Touro on Use Of Three Buildings
description: New York State authorities have ended negotiations for a leasepurchase arrangement with Touro College that would have enabled the institution to obtain three stateheld buildings on the East Side that formerly housed the now defunct Finch College.

title: Second Wife of Mao Hailed at China Rally
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 8 (UPI)The Peking daily Jenmin Jih Pao said today that a rally had been held in Hunan Province to praise the revolutionary spirit of Mao Tsetung's second wife and criticize his last and fourth wife, Chiang Ching.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Byrne Is Displeased by a Report On Housing Quotas in the Suburbs
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8A new housing report detailing the responsibilities of suburban towns to accommodate lowincome and moderateincome families was released today, but Governor Byrne promptly expressed dissatisfaction and Ordered the report redone.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDYING TREMORS IN MORRIS
description: LONG VALLEY, Dec. 8Seismologists from Columbia University's LamontDoherty Geological Observatory were seeking today the cause of a series of minor earth tremors that shook sections of this Morris County community earlier in the week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Laws on Environment Stir a Debate
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, Dec. 8An official of the Meadowlands Chamber of Commerce and State Assemblyman Robert P. Hollenbeck, Democrat of Carlstadt, clashed today over charges that state environmental protection laws discouraged business investment in New Jersey.

title: Knicks Hopes of Getting McAdoo Fade
description: The Knicks pursuit of Bob McAdoo has evidently ended in failure. After six days of negotiations between Mike Burke and Paul Snyder and after three separate oral agreements between the two on the trade that was to have brought the Buffalo Braves sharpshooter to the KnicksBurke is now convinced that the deal is off.

title: DR. BORIS PREGEL, EXHEAD OF ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
description: Dr. Boris Pregel, president of the New York Academy of Sciences in 1958 and the holder of patents involving radioactive materials, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He lived at 1 West 67th Street and was 83 years old.

title: Liggett Sets Tentative Accord for Tetley Inc.
description: Liggett Group Inc., of Durham, N. C., announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Tetley Inc., a Delaware corporation, owned by J. Lyons & Company of London, for cash and assumption of debt aggregating $27 million.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONAmid all the emphasis on a tax cut for individuals to stimulate the economy, are additional tax incentives for business investment going to be forgotten?

title: Boomis Says Regan Wasn't There For Talk of Beame Campaign Aid
description: Christopher Boomis has told friends that Cyril R. Regan, a former police official, was not present, as Mr. Regan has asserted, during discussions at which Mr. Boomis was allegedly asked for secret contributions to Mayor Beame's 1973 campaign.

title: Berkeley's Council Ends Effort to Study Feasibility Of Charging Drivers Fees
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP)Faced with strong opposition, the City Council has backed out of a plan to study what would happen if motorists were charged for using city streets.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday:

title: East German, Hurt, Cries for Aid in Vain
description: HELMSTEDT, West Germany, Dec. 8 (AP)A West German customs patrol near here listened helplessly late yesterday to the screams of a wounded man who failed in an attempt to escape from East Germany.

title: After Mastectomy: The Options for Breast Reconstruction
description: In an operation that is stirring debate in the medical profession, plastic surgeons are reconstructing the breasts of women who have had mastectomies.

title: Winston Paul, 89; Helped in Changing Jersey Cosntitution
description: Winston Paul, an industrialist and civic leader who was active in helping develop a new, and later revised, constitution for the State of New Jersey, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J., after a short illness. He lived in Montclair and was 89 years old.

title: Guy Clark Is Singing Progressive Country
description: The problem of expressing complex themes in what has traditionally been a simple, popular musical idiom is itself a Complex one. Either songwriters freight the music with a pretentious verbal opacity, or they distort the musical idiom, or they are forced to reduce clever ideas to clichs, hoping that they can substitute a mythic simplicity for the loss of subtlety.

title: DR. JOHN J. BOTTONE
description: Dr. John J. Bottone, an attending urologist on the staff at Long Island College Hospital In Brooklyn since 1932, died Tuesday in the hospital of heart disease. He lived at 19 Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn and was 72 years old.

title: Hunters of France TurnOut in Full Cry
description: LA FERTEST. AUBIN, France, Dec. 5Gunshots cracked all over the French countryside this weekend as more than two million hunters took to the woods, bent on shootingfor dinner or amusementvirtually anything that rustled, loped or fluttered.

title: Norris Industries to Bid $23 a Share for McIntosh
description: Norris Industries of Los Angeles announced that it proposes to offer $23 a share for not less than 80 percent of the 2,359,464 shares outstanding of the McIntosh Corporation of Chicago. If all shares are tendered, the total purchase price would be in excess of $56 million.

title: 2 Seats on Big Board Are Sold
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced the sale of two member seats yesterday. The first was sold for $60,000, down $10,000 from the preceding sale on Dec. 1 and the second seat went for $58,000. Seats are now quoted at $50,000 bid and $68,000 asked.

title: Guardians Association Asks Blacks In P. B. A. to Quit Union in Protest
description: A meeting of the Guardians Association, a black fraternal group of New York City policemen, voted late Tuesday night to urge its members to withdraw from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: New York State Sells $91.9 Million in Bonds at 6.31%
description: New York State sold a $91.9 million bond issue yesterday morning at an interest cost of 6.31 percent, well below the 7.54 percent rate it accepted in July in its preceding public offering of longterm securities. The bonds were then priced to give investors yields ranging from 3.25 percent up to 6.70 percent, depending on their maturities, and they sold so quickly that only about $6 million were still left in underwriters hands at the end of the day. Like the other two bond issues sold to Wall Street underwriting groups earlier this year, the issue attracted only one bid. All three issues have been awarded to syndicates managed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Knicks Conquer Nets,. Monroe, Shelton Star
New Jersey Briefs
description: The attorney for Lee Morgenstein, who is serving a life sentence in the death of a model, plans to seek his client's release pending an appeal of his conviction. The announcement followed a report by the state police on Tuesday that they had filed charges against two inmates accused of sexually attacking the 18yearold Teaneck man at the Yardville Youth Reception and Correction Center. Mr. Morgenstein has been in jail since his conviction in June in the. shooting death in July 1975 of Kimberly McIntosh, 22, of Teaneck after she rejected his advances.

title: WOMEN VOW FIGHT FOR PREGNANCY PAY
description: The Supreme Court decision on disability benefits outraged women's rights advocates and immediately spurred moves yesterday for both national and state legislation to insure pay for women on leave because of pregnancy.

title: In Memoriam
description: MARINicholas. 1st Anniversary. you are always In my heart and parents Your Daddy

title: INSIDE
description: Warning in South Africa

title: Giscard to Ask Leaders Parley
description: PARIS, Dec. 8 (AP)  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing plans to send a letter soon to the heads of major industrialized nations calling for a toplevel meeting, an official spokesman said today. There was no indication of the site or date he would ?? Obseryers considered it unlikely that such a meeting would be held before Jimmy Carter tis inaugurated Jan. 20 and his admistration has had a shakedown period

title: CARTERWIDENS FIELD FOR 2 TOP POSITIONSI
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Prospective Cabinet members continued to see Presidentelect Jimmy Carter in Atlanta today amid reports that Mr. Carter is taking a second look at his first choices for Secretary of Defense and National Security adviser.

title: Gold and Silver Bullion Futures Up
description: Prices of gold and silver bullion futures bounded upward on New York and Chicago commodity exchanges yesterday in expectation of higher bids at the International Monetary Fund's latest auction of gold.

title: Fees and Coverage
description: Dr. John Goin, chairman of the public information committee of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgeons, said that not enough operations had been performed to establish fees for breast reconstruction.

title: Jury in Bronfman Case Studies 2 Tape Recordings Made by Alleged Kidnapping Victim and Sent to Father
description: WHITE PLAINS Dec. S The jury that received the Bronfman kidnapping case ?? night listened intently today to two ape recordings that, in the view of the defense lawyers tended to implicate SamBronfman 2d as a partner in his alaged abduction in August 1975.

title: Deaths
description: Agar, Grace H.

title: Market Place
description: This week, the RapidAmerican Corporation won dismissal of an action by minority shareholders of Schenley Industries charging that RapidAmerican issued false and misleading proxy information in connection with its 1971 acquisition of Schenley.

title: TV: Richard Rodgers Tribute Dazzles and BBC War Film Shocks
description: On paper, the master plan for tonight's twohour tribute to the music of Richard Rodgers, on CBS at 9 o'clock, is not particularly promising The mix of studio performers is somewhat curious: Diahann Carroll, Vic Damone. Sammy Davis Jr., Sandy Duncan, Lena Horne, Cloris Leachman, Peggy Lee and John Wayne. Then there is the old dramatic context of Gene Kelly and Henry (The Fonz) Winkler, playing Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Lorenz Hart, reminiscing about their collaborations with the composer.

title: THAILAND SAYS VIETNAMESE PLAN A FEBRUARY INVASION
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 8 (Reuters) Thailand today accused Vietnam of planning to invade Thailand on three fronts next February.

title: NATO DEFERS BUYING U.S. WARNING SYSTEM
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8An American effort to win final allied approval of a $2.44 billion airborne earlywarning and control system ran into financial objections from hardpressed European countries today and a decision was deferred until next year.

title: ExSoviet Scientist, Now in Israel, Tells Of Nuclear Disaster
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 8A former Soviet physicist, who came to Israel in 1972. said today that a nucloar disaster occurred in the Soviet Union in the late 1950's as a result of careless storage of nuclear wastes.

title: Brooklyn Man Found Slain
description: The body of a 31yearold Brooklyn man who had been shot five times was found in the trunk of his burning automobile on a quiet residential street in West Hempstead, L.I. The man was identified through fingerprints by the Nassau County police as Lucio Parisi of 2154 East 69th Street. He was reported to be a part owner of two bakeries, one of which was described as a hangout for mobsters, and part owner of a race horse.

description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP)  The speed of Butch Lee and a tenacious defene helped Marquette register a 6461 basketball victory tonight over Florida.

About New York
description: There is an 87yearold nag in the Bronx named William Birscher who seems to scream to life every morning, first with a cold shower, then with a brisk round of dispensing his own hand printed traffic citations to offending motorists who block the curbside path Of the city's mechanical brooms on 161st Street.

title: CARTER WIDENS FIELD FOR 2 TOP POSITIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Prospective Cabinet members continued to see Presidentelect Jimmy Carter in Atlanta today amid reports that Mr. Carter is taking a second look at his first choices for Secretary of Defense and National Security adviser.

title: Folger Lifts Price Of Coffee 10th Time For Current Year
description: In what may set the stage for a new round of price increases throughout the coffee industry, the Folger Coffee Company. the nation's second largest coffee processor, announced yesterday that it was raising its wholesale prices for the 10th time this year.

title: 'Silver Streak' Tarnishes on a Tiring Film Trip
description: "Silver Streak" is the sort of comedy that leaves you exhausted, though not from laughing.The film, which is set mostly aboard a Los Angeles-to-Chicago train and has to do with art forgers, cops and innocent bystanders, works its cast so relentessly, with so little real good humor and at such apparent expense and trouble, that it wears you out with the tension that comes from watching good people make idiots of themselves.Among these are a skinny-looking Gene Wilder, who plays a more or less straight romantic role that suits him not at all, and Jill Clayburgh, an actress of too much intelligence to be able to fake identification with a role that is essentially that of a liberated ingenue.Richard Pryor, a very funny man, who turns up in the last third of the film, has some genial moments that are immediately undercut by what appears to be either thoughtless editing or direction. I don't think I've ever before seen an actor at the end of a movie scene adopt that slightly desperate look we have come to associate with television performers when the camera stays on them too long after they've finished their schtiks.This sort of sloppiness is a measure of "Silver Streak," which appears to be looking for a dominant style as it lumbers along over mountains, deserts and prairies. Colin Higgins's screenplay is not witty or rambunctious or mysterious, nor does it have the courage to parody a disaster film like "Airport 1975," an idea that seems to pass through its mind from time to time, though it's never acted upon. Bring back "The Big Bus.""Silver Streak" was directed by Arthur Hiller, a man whose work defies generalization. He's made good films ("The Hospital"), dreadful ones ("Plaza Suite") and one gold mine ("Love Story"). "Silver Streak" is one he may want to forget as quickly as possible."Silver Streak," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly racy dialogue and one love scene that is made vulgar more as a result of the leering behavior of the actors than because of anything that's shown on the screen.

title: NATO DEFERS BUYING U.S. WARNING SYSTEM
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8An American effort to win final allied approval of a $2.44 billion airborne earlywarning and control system ran into financial objections from hardpressed European countries today and a decision was deferred until next year.

title: Jail for Helstoski's ExAide
description: NEWARK, Dec. 8 (UPI)A former aide to Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of New Jersey, has begun serving a sixyear prison sentence for shaking down illegal aliens. The former aide, Albert DeFalco. 50 years old, of Lodi, N. J., surrendered here yesterday for transfer to a Federal prison. Mr. DeFalco was convicted of receiving payments from illegal aliens in exchange for promises that Mr. Helstoski would introduce permanent residency bills for them in Congress. The Representative, who was indicted in a similar alleged scheme, and who recently lost a bid for reelection is scheduled to go on trial early next year.

title: Gulf &
description: The New York Cultural Center of Columbus Circle, empty since fiscal troubles closed it in September 1975, has been bought by Gulf & Western Industries as a gift to New York City. It will serve as headquarters for the new Department of Cultural Affairs and as an exhibition and tourist center.

title: 6 Hold a 2Month Vigil Over a Body
description: The decomposed body of a 29yearold map who reportedly died of cancer two months ago today was found by the police yesterday in his Riverside Drive apartment where six religious zealots had maintained a roundtheclock Convinced that he would rise from the dead.

The protests seemed to he losing momentum as shopkeepers in almost all West Bank towns except Hebron and Nablus ended a business strike.

description: QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 8 (Reuters) Ecuador's military Government said today that it had uncovered a plot led by a former government minister and two unidentified Roman Catholic priests to overthrow the regime.

title: Notes on People

The university has offered a visiting professorship in political science,  said Maj. Robert Barrett, who is banclling Mr. Ford's personal affairs during the transition. Consistent with past statements by the President, all such offers are being held for review, with no decisions planned until atter Jan. 20. Major Barrett declined to go into detail about any of the offers.

title: Mexican Peons Vow to Hold Land

When the peasants know there is no more land, then perhaps they won't demand it. But now a few families own everything.

title: Winter Simplicity
description: There is little subtlety about weather, especially in December. It is winter in the making and basic realities are emphasized, even in a world of machines and complex organization. The landscape is reduced to winter simplicity. Ice, a primal element, is now obvious as morning hoarfrost or a glaze on the pond or snowflakes in the air. And life itself faces two primal necessities, shelter and food.

description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 George Scott, who was all set to go home again, may not get there after all.

Turnesa, winner of two United States Amateur championships and one British Amateur, received the Distinguished Service Award of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

description: LA FERTEST. AUBIN, France, Dec. 5Gunshots cracked all over the French countryside this weekend as more than two million hunters took to the woods, bent on shootingfor dinner or amusementvirtually anything that rustled, loped or fluttered.

description: There's more than a trace of the old?? preacher in George Faison and it is slyly mixed with a highlytheatrical sense. His Hobo Sapiens, a new solo for Dudley Williams, is a rich seriocomic work that sugarcoats its message with the performing glitter that Mr. Williams brings to tarnished but tenacious characters. The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater showed it for the first time Tuesday evening at the City Center 5th Street Theater.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (AP)  Topseeded Dianne Fromholtz of Australia fought back to victory and Margaret Court, continuing her comeback, gained the third round of a $50,000 women's international tennis tournament today.

description: The GiantsCardinals football game Sunday, from Giants Stadium, will be televised by Channel 2, starting at 1 p.m., CBS said yesterday. The game between the Washington Redskins and Cowboys in Dallas will not be shown locally, the network said.

title: Snow Heightens Difficulties of Turkish Quake Relief
description: ANKARA, Turkey. Dec. 8The snows of winter are starting to sweep across eastern Turkey, and government officials face an extremely difficult job in providing shelter for more than 50,000 people left homeless by the earthquake that devastated the region almost two weeks ago.

title: Cost in U.S. of 5% Oil Rise Placed at $1 Billion a Year
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The State Department cabled to American embassies today an analysis that said a 5 percent increase in the world price of oil would strip nearly $4 billion a year from the big seven industrial countries, more than SI billion from smaller developed countries and more than $1 billion from developing countries that don't produce oil.

title: Carter Reported Studying Plan for Reorganizing White House Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Presidentelect Jimmy Carter is reported to be deferring key White House appointments while his aides analyze and debate a reorganization study that recommends abolishing the National Security Council and Domestic Council and replacing them with a new Executive Cabinet Committee.

title: 2 Plead Not Guilty in Bombings
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)Two Portland, Me., men have pleaded not guilty to two bombings here July 2. Edward P. Gullion and Richard J. Picariello, both 28 years old, entered the pleas yesterday in Suffolk Superior Court and were ordered held on $200,000 bail. They were charged at their arraignment with bombing an unoccupied Eastern Airlines plane at Logan International Airport and two National Guard trucks. Judge Arthur Mason continued the case to Feb. 7. A third defendant, Everett Carlson, 38, of Portland, was arraigned on the same charges July 30 and held on $100,000 bail.

title: BRADEMAS APPOINTED TO HOUSE WHIP POST
MAURICE R. BRANN

It is a neighborhood of one and two family wooden houses, worn by time, but kept up by solid, IrishAmerican working people. Down the block is a side driveway into the Parking lot of Salvi Ford.

description: KENT, Conn., Dec. 8Charles Wilkins, a 51yearold publicrelations consultant, was held in $200,000 bail today at the Litchfield Correctional Center awaiting a hearing in Superior Court on charges of having murdered his wife and their 19yearold son.

In Albany, the State Public Service Commission announced that it had granted the Brooklyn Union Gas Company a 7.8 percent increase in gas rates to its 11.2 million customers in Brooklyn, Staten Island and parts of Queens.

description: The New York State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, James L. Melton, proposed yesterday that the Legtslature transfer 93 motorvehicle offices now under county clerks and put them under his office.

description: A Queens grand jury, which has handed up indictments against 54 persons, charging that they defrauded the city of hundreds of thousands of dollars of welfare funds, has recommended two major changes in the current welfare payment system that the jury said encourages cheating.

title: Dean's Office Is Strangely Quiet
description: The dean of students at Queens College is E. Richard Covert. His office, a comfortable, paneled, booklined room in the social sciences building on the Flushing, Queens, campus, is a quiet place these days.

description: HONG KONG, Dec. 8Members of the Chinese General Staff said today that Chiang Ching and three other disgraced members of the Politburo had blocked attempts to modernize the armed forces, placed politics ahead of professionalism and tried to oust career officers.

title: NEW DEVICES ENHANCE RESEARCH IN DEEP SEA

description: Brooklynesethe language spoken by millions of New Yorkers and chronicled and parodied for generations  doesn't exist. Technically. that is.

Harry arrived in the United States on Aug. 2 and made his show debut the following month at Tuxedo. As the spirited Harry bounded from class victories to best of breed, then on to take the terrier group and best in show, ringsiders not only cOntinued to applaud the 2yearold import but came back for a second look at the crates.

title: German Toymakers, Facing a Shortage of Children, Now Aim at Adults
description: GIENGEN, West GermanyThe venerable German toymaking industry, which survived two world wars, a depression and a recession, is now threatened by a critical shortage of children. The pill did it, and the changing, more hedonistic way of life of millions of young West German couples. The birth rate has fallen sharply and so have toy sales.

title: Marshall to Take Denver Helm
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP) Jim Marshall, recently dismissed as manager of the Chicago Cubs, today was named manager of the Montreal Expos Denver farm club of the American Association. Marshall previously managed six years in the minors.

title: Rival Ivy Coaches Welcome League Return of Blackman
description: Bob Blackman's return to the Ivy League as the new head football coach at Cornell is seen as bene??cial for the league by other Ivy coaches, who also view his return as a definite challenge. But Jake Crouthamel, a former player and assistant coach under Blackman at Dartmouth, refused yesterday to consider Blackman a miracle worker. Crouthamel, who succeeded his boss as Dartmouth's head coach in 1971 when Blackman took the coaching job at Illinois, said: Remember what Bear Bryant always says, If you're going to make chicken salad you have to start with chickens. You win with football players and if he gets football players he will win at Cornell.

title: F.B.I. Is Investigating 2 Indian Deaths in Fire
description: ALBANY. Dec. 8 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating the deaths last summer of two Indians in a fire on Oneida Indian Territory to which the local fire department refused to respond.

title: News Summary
description: A more effective United Nations was urged by Kurt Waldheim in a speech in the General Assembly accepting a second fiveyear term as Secretary General. He asked for concentration on essentials that could be achieved and pledged a lean administration that would carry out overdue changes. In an interview, he said he planned an energetic effort to reconvene the Middle East conference at Geneva, seeing the best chance yet for a comprehensive ArabIsraeli settlement. [1:5.]

title: JOHN HORVATH
description: John Horvath. a senior planner at the McCannErickson advertising agency, died Monday at his home at 6530 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 52 years old.

description: An article in The Times yesterday on possible appointments to the Carter administration incorrectly identified Arley Miller, a former Ford Motor Company executive, as president of Stanford University. Mr. Miller Is dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business,

title: EXTEAMSTER FUND AIDE PLEADS INNOCENT TO FRAUD
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI)Alvin Baron, a Las Vegas, Nev., lawyer, pleaded not guilty today to charges that he took a $200,000 kickback to arrange a $1.3 million loan made by the principal pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to a California cemetery operator. The case was continued until Jan. 3.

title: Lawyer Seeks Gilmore's Freedom, Cites the Stay in Killer's Execution
description: PROVO, Utah, Dec. 8The attorney for Gary Mark Gilmore, the convicted slayer, asked today that a writ of habeas corpus be issued for his client on the ground that the state did not execute him within 60 days of sentencing, as appeared to be required by law.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 12%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were an estimated $13.08 billion, up about 12 percent from the yearearlier level of $11.52 billion. Department store sales were about $2.09 billion, up about 13 percent from last year's $1.84 billion.

title: Market Place
description: There was almost no trading in $250 million worth of New York City Housing Authority bonds yesterday while dealers attempted to determine which bonds are in effect, guaranteed by the Federal Government.

title: ISRAELI GENERAL OFFERS GRADUAL STEPS TO PEACE
description: TEL AVIV, Dec 9 Maj. Gen. Ariel Sharon, the hero of the war of 1973 who organized a new party for the Israeli parliamentary elections in November, made public a program for Middle East peace today.

title: Flyers Beat Bruins, 31, Ending Jinx
description: BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Gary Dornhoefer's powerplay goal put Philadelphia in front to stay in the first period as the Flyers ended an old Boston jinx tonight with a 31 victory over the Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

title: A Window Wonderland
description: FIFTH AVENUE, a windowshopper's winter wonderland in holiday trappings as festive as a Christmas tree candy cane, will hold an open house for all of New York this Sunday when motor traffic will be removed to make way for pedestrian frolics.

title: SHARES OF A.T.&H. REACH 10YEAR HICK LEADING MARKET UP
description: Stock prices pushed higher across broad front yesterday as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company traded at its highest price in a decade.

title: FORD SEES CONNALLY, REAGAN, ROCKEFELLER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 President Ford met at the White House today with his old rival, Ronald Reagan, and with Vice President Rockefeller and John B. Connally. The four Republican leaders called for the creation or a national coordinating committee to help rebuild their party.

title: Government of Quebec Busily Wooing Industry
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 9Quebec's new separatist government has begun a series of talks with local, national and foreign business leaders in an effort to persuade them that it is a businesslike nononsense cabinet of experts whose main interest is developing the economy with outside help.

title: Solo Flight For Arroyo On Sunday
description: When Martina Arroyo gives her recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M., she will be on her own, with the exception, of course, of her pianist, Donald Hassard. It will be a novelty of sorts for the soprano, who is a leading singer at the Metropolitan Opera but who has not given a solo recital in Manhattan for a number of years.

title: About Real Estate
description: Jack Rosenthal acts fast. He heard on a Tuesday in August that a group of six buildings west of First Avenue between 64th and 65th Streets were for sale, and he signed a purchase contract on Thursday.

title: A Burst of Handel
description: FOR music lovers, the Christmas season begins in earnest this weekend. All at once, it seems, Handel's Messiah is upon us. David Randolph and his Masterwork Chorus and Chamber Ensemble will offer four performancestonight in South Orange, N.J., and tomorrow night and Sunday, afternoon and evening in Carnegie Hall. There also will be performances this weekend by the Queens Choral Society, the Brooklyn Philharmonia, the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, St. Batholomew's Church, the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church (part 1 only), the Abyssinian Baptist Church and the Church of the Holy Trinity. And there will be many more in the days to come, including further efforts by Mr. Randolph and his forces, Richard Westenburg's Musica Sacra at Avery Fisher Hall On Dec. 20 and the annual Messiah singin at Fisher Hall on Dec. 23.

title: 90,000 PROPERTY OWNERS GET WARNING ON TAXES
description: Nearly 90,000 New York City property owners who have been delinquent in their taxes totaling close to $50 million for more than one year were warned yesterday by the Finance Administration that if they did not pay by Jan. 1, they faced foreclosure.

title: Ripping Off an Old Lady
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Two days after my 66yearold mother arrived in this country from Trinidad this fall, she was relieved of her entire life savings of over $4,000 in a con game by three brothers in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: BOND PRICES CLIMB WITH MONEY SUPPLY
description: Tiv credit markets drifted downward in light trading yesterday and then bond prices recovered late in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve disclosed substantial $2.7 billion increase in the nation's money supply. The net result was little change from Wednesday's level. The market's response to the money supply differed from a week ago, when the money stock dropped sharply and bond prices soared in hectic lateafternoon trading.

title: Wish for Return to College Football CitedWill Leave for Arkansas to Accept Post
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 9Lou Holtz, the rookie coach of the New York Jets, resigned today and walked away from a fiveyear contract believed to be worth more than 80,000 a year.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: Britain Says Aged Are Better Off
description: London, Dec. 9 (Reuter) Most Britons are worse off but living standards for the elderly are improving according to a report released by the British Treasury. Comparing present living standards with those of 1970, the report said that retirees were 30 percent better off. Most British workers, however, have experienced only a 9 percent increase in liv

title: Policemen Battle With Squatters In Another North Mexican State
description: TORREON, Mexico, Dec. 9 (AP) Mexican policemen raided a shantytown in this northern Mexican city today and set fire to some shacks in an effort. to force about 4,000 squatters out of the area.

title: 618 Got Welfare While Concealing Public Jobs From New York Agency
description: The latest computer crosschecks in the New York City welfare system have found 618 Federal, state and city government employees who have been collecting welfare payments while concealing their public jobs from welfare authorities.

title: Freshman Quits Indiana Five
description: BLOOMINGTON. Ind., Dec. 9 (UPI) Mike Miday, a 6foot8inch freshman on Coach Bobby Knight's Indiana University basketball team, has dropped out of school. A spokesman said Miday told Knight he felt he made a mistake in his choice of school. Miday averaged 6 points and 14 minutes in Indiana's first three games.

title: Opera: Utopia Limited
description: UTOPIA Limited, the next to the last comic opera created by Gilbert and Sullivan, has never had any staying power despite its considerable success at its premiere in 1893. It has just been given one of its rare revivals by the Village Light Opera Group, at the Fashion Institute Theater. Despite an inventiveperhaps too inventiveproduction and a musically splendid performance, the work itself, heard Wednesday evening, makes clear why it has been neglected.

title: 33 Bids Accepted by I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (Reuters) The International Monetary Fund said today that it had accepted a total of 33 bids from 13 successful bidders at its auction yesterday of 780,000 ounces of gold.

title: Police in New York Name First Woman As a Precinct Head
description: The first woman to head a police precinct in New York City was named yesterday by Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd.

title: Carter Meets With Ribicoff
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (Reuters)  Presidentelect Jimmy Carter . discussed Middle East peace prospects today with Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, the Connecticut Deocrat who recently toured the area. The Senator said he had told Mr. Carter he believed new efforts for peace should be made early next year and repeated a suggestion that Secretary of State Henry A.Kissinger should be assigned as a special envoy in the Middle East. Mr. Carter indicated interest in the proposal but did not commit himself on it, Mr. Ribicoff added.

title: Staging a 42d St. Transformation
description: PoSted on the door of Robert Moss's office at Playwrights Horizon is part of a tabloid headline reading Mob Boss. There is aptness in the spoonerism. Bob Moss is an agitated activist, a visionary who is often taking umbrage and doing something about it.

title: Earthquake Shakes Ocean Floor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) A moderate earthquake shook the Pacific Ocean floor today about 350 miles west of the central Oregon coast. the United States Geological Survey reported.

title: South Korea Seeks Japan's Aid
description: SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 9 (UPI) Japan and South Korea opened an eightday meeting today to discuss Korea's request for Japanese financial cooperation in its !fourth fiveyear economic development program to begin next year.

title: Issue and Debate
description: The future of capital punishment in this country has been left in an uncertain limbo, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger wrote in June 1972. And so it has been.

title: Article 3 No Title
Charge of Bias Made Against Coop City Is Withdrawn
description: The New York Urban League has withdrawn allegations it made in September that a new tenantmanagement group at Coop City had instituted blatant discriminatory practices against black applicants in filling vacant apartments at the huge Bronx project.

title: Antiques
description: THE MEDUSA and Tutankhamen images fashioned by the jewelers and craftsmen of the early 20th century, represent brisk business these days to at least four Madison Avenue shops.

title: Notes on People
description: Andrei A. Amairik, the Soviet dissident freed this year from exile in Siberia, came here from his home in The Netherlands to receive last night the Human Rights Award of the international League for Human Rights. Mr. Amalrik and his wife, Gyuzel, left the Soviet Union last July after more than a decade of participation in a movement on behalf of broader freedom for Soviet citizens. For his efforts he received two terms in Siberia, including exile and detention in a labor camp. Mr. Amalrik, who will give lectures at Columbia, Harvard, Yale and other universities while here, expressed a desire yesterday to meet with Presidentelect Jimmy Carter.

title: Maine 78, City College 50
description: ORONO, Me., Dec. 9 Paul Whaley, a 6foot guard, scored 20 points to lead the University of Maine to a 7850 romp over City College.

title: ROBERT O. BEATTY, 52; FORMER H.E.W. OFFICIAL
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 9 (AP) Robert O. Beatty, a former Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare who was a conservationist, author and publisher died last night of cancer. He was 52 years old.

title: Amusement Park Dummy Turns Out to Be Corpse Of Man Slain by Gunshot
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI) An old man whose body had been on display in an amusement park fun house for years where everyone thought it was a dummy was killed by a gunshot wound in the chest, the Los Angeles County coroner announced today.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney on the Atlantic Richfield Company's development into a diversified national giant. Page D5.

title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR CARTER IN OHIO
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 A Federal judge cleared the way today for Ohio's 25 Presidential electors to vote for Jimmy Carter when the Electoral College meets Monday.

title: Pregnancy Sick Benefits: Call for Action on Court Ruling
description: We bombed out in court, so well have to go to Congress, said athleen Peratis of the American Liberties Union.

title: Theft of SummerYouth Checks Is Charged
description: NEWARK, Dec. 9Eighteen persons. three of them juveniles, were charged today by the Newark Police Department with stealing and cashing $45.000 in checks intended for summer youth workers.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: AUERBACH Joseph and Ida. We ??? biessed by hav.na yeit for pare, YOUR THREE GRACES

title: P.L.O., Set Back in Lebanon, Told by Allies to Compromise
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 9 The Palestine Liberation Organization, which was born in the refugee camps 13 years ago, nurtured into a military power, then devastated by defeats in Jordan in 1971 and in Lebanon this year, is now under severe pressure from Arab allies to scale down its political objectives.

title: Where and When
description: Following is a list of some of the productions or Messiah in and around New York City during the holiday season.

title: Ohio Mother Kills Her Husband, Two Children and Then Herself
description: UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) Patricia Bolin, a 40yearold mother of three, used a .22caliber gun to kill her husband and two of her children before shooting herself to death, the police said.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: People and Business
description: President Ford was urged yesterday by five incoming Democratic Senators not to approve a lastminute decontrol of gasoline prices. Asserting that such a move would result in higher consumer prices and gerater profits to oil companies, the five Senators, in letter to the President, declared: We believe strongly that such a lastminute act on your part would contribute to a further loss of confidence by that great body of the American public that is so skeptical of their political leaders.

title: Hearst Trial Delayed for 3 Months
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (UPI) Patricia Hearst appeared briefly in Superior Court today and was granted a threemonth delay in her trial on 11 counts of robbery, kidnapping and assault stemming from her actions as a member of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: TELEVISION TODAY
description: Morning

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: ONE OF THE GENTLER pleasures of New Haven is its city green. Except for three graceful old churches on it, this shaded preserve is open to strollers and inviolate to change. Because New Haven was built around it, the green provides a sanctuary that serves as a focal point for the city; it lies at the center of a variety of things one would expect to find only in a much bigger place: good theater, interesting restaurants, concerts, museums and a fair share of the unpredictable.

title: DeObfuscationism
description: WASHINGTON History records that in the earliest days of World War II the following newly promulgated regulation reached the desk of a weary Commander in Chief deliberating the weighty and terrible decisions of that dark time: Such preparations shall be made as will completely obscure all federal buildings occupied by the federal government during an air raid for any period of time from visibility by reason of internal or external illumination. Such obscuration may be obtained either by blackout construction or by terminating illumination.

title: Cabaret: An Eclectic Debut
description: Carleton Carpenter, who made his stab for fame singing Aba Daba Honeymoon with Debbie Reynolds in the film Two Weeks With Love, and since then has been in 15 films, 20 New York plays and musicals, more than 5,000 television shows and has written 6 mystery novels, has found something new to do. He is making his nightclub debut this week at Brothers and Sisters, 355 West 46th Street, singing in a voice that is thin and reedy but strong enough to be projected without a micronhone.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Commissioners Satisfied So Far But Apprehensive on Future
description: Martin Lang, the Commissioner or Parks and Recreation, was considering the other day how his department had dealt with New York City's continuing fiscal crisis.

title: Korean Bank Signs Loan Accord With 32 International Banks
description: SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 9 (UPI) The state run Korea Exchange Bank, representing six other local banks, signed a $100 million loan agreement today with a group of 32 international banks including Citibank and the Chase Manhattan Bank of the United States.

title: Fibak Holds Off Vilas, Gains Final in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 9Overcoming nerves and the exhausting effects of a 3hour44minute match, Wojtek Fibak of Poland defeated Guillermo Vilas of Argentina in five sets tonight for a berth in the final round of the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Salaries and Ethics
description: While those who follow politics have been spending recent weeks devouring each new morsel about the shape of the new Cabinet, a Presidential commission has been concluding some quieter work on a more fundamental task of equal urgency. The Presidential Commission on Executive, Legislative and Judicial Salaries made a sweeping report to President Ford last week. The governmental response to its recommendations may well determine the quality of the people who make the wheels of government turn.

title: TryBeforeBuy Selling Arranged on Ski Slopes
description: Skiers interested in purchasing new equipment will be able to make decisions close to their sport next Friday, Saturday and Sundayon the slopes of Mount Snow. The southern Vermont resort will be the site of a marketing promotion called Consumers Demonstration Days. More than 23 mantaacturers and suppliers of skis, boots, poles and gloves will have representatives there to present a try before you buy operation. The arrangement will enable skiers, after paying deposits, to try out equipment on the trails before purchasing or rejecting it.

title: PreElection Blast In Lisbon Worsens Tense Atmosphere
description: LISBON, Dec. 9 A powerful bomb explosion early today disrupted Lisbon's water supply and heightened the atmospere of tension three days before municipal elections.

title: Commodity Price Index Increases 2.9 From the WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 200.2 from 197.3 last week.

title: 305 Racing Days Listed For 1977, but No Sundays
description: Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga will combine for 305 days of thoroughbred racing in 1977, none of them on Sundays. The New York State Racing and Wagering Board approved the Jan. 3Dec. 23 schedule submitted by the New York Racing Association.

title: On the Right Trak
description: Amtrak, the national rail passenger service, has issued a host of dull statistics that could add up to an exciting discovery for anyone who hasn't taken a train trip lately.

title: WESLEY FERRELL, 68, DIES; MAJOR LEAGUE PITCHER
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) Wesley Cheek Ferrell, a 29game winner twice in his 15year major league baseball pitching career, died today at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Syracuse 87, Biscayne 63
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP)  Syracuse University's 20thranked team rolled to an 8763 victory over Biscayne College here last night behind the scoring of Roosevelt Bouie and Larry Kelley.

title: Jurors Reexamine Defense Contention Of Bronfman Hoax
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 9 (AP) Jurors now deliberating in the trial of two men accused of having kidnapped Samuel Bronfman 2d reexamined more evidence today, apparently trying to analyze a defense contention that the abduction was a hoax.

title: 2 Young Brothers. Killed As a Fire Sweeps Through Queens House
