title: Met Increases Hours Of Egyptian Galleries
description: To facilitate public viewing of its new Egyptian galleries and the new exhibition The Glory of Russian Costume, both of which are drawing crowds, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, at Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, will keep the galleries open until 7:45 P.M. from today through Jan. 2.

title: Soviet Inefficiency and the Lesson for American Priorities
description: WASHINGTON"How can the Soviet Union have been the first country to launch a sputnik, testfly an I.C.B.M. and deploy an A.B.M. defense? This question comes naturally to a Westerner looking for a bobby pin, a BandAid, or even good tennis shoes in Moscow (where they would be much easier to find than in the provinces).

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Agnew Denies He Ever Asked Ford To Pardon Him in Income Tax Case
description: Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew denied yesterday that he had ever sought a pardon from President Ford on his conviction of income tax evasion.

title: Keep the Faith, Rep. Abzug T ells Women in Adieu
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The women of Capitol Hill said farewell to a tearful Bella Abzug today.

title: Suns 107, Celtics 103
description: BOSTON. Dec. 10 (AP)Rickey Sobers scored 25 points and his backcourt mate, Paul Westphal, added 21 tonight as the Phoenix Suns gained a 107103 victory over the Boston Celtics in an N.B.A. game.

title: Matisse, Gaudi Church Works At Modern Art
description: In their time, Henri Matisse and Antoni Gaudi proved dramatically that the architecture, stainedglass windows, pews and vestments of the Roman Catholic Church could be updated without violating ancient church traditions.

title: Aide Says Carter Has Selected Team for Top Security Positions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Presidentelect Jimmy Carter has selected the team of persons fpr the top national security positions in his Administration but is still sorting out which candidate will fill which job, a top aide said today.

title: Embarrassing Riches'. . .
description: City officials are properly embarrassed by the disclosure that they are anticipating a $320 million cash surplus for the current fiscal year ending June 30, 1977 a prediction that conjures up visions of municipal affluence totally at odds with New York's fiscal reality.

title: West Point Cadets, by Close Vote, Bar Flexible HonorCode Penalty
description: WEST POINT. N.Y. Dec. 10The Corps of Cadets has voted to retain expulsion as the single and automatic penalty for violation of the honor code of the United Stales Military Academy here.

title: Article 1 No Title
U.N. Assembly Approves Treaty On Manipulation of Environment
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 10 The General Assembly tonight approved a treaty that aims at outlawing the manipulation of the environment for military or hostile purposes.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions on Page 21.

title: FREDERICK T. ALLEN
description: Frederick T. Allen, a retired partner of Barr Brothers & Company, a law firm specializing in municipal bonds, died Thursday at his home at 200 East 66th Street. He was 83 years old.

title: In Memoriam
description: CAMPBELLMagdalene Whyte, In ing memory of a beloved wife, devoted mother, loving, and adored grandmother who passed away on Dec. 11, 1963. You're always In our thoughts and hearts.

title: E.P.A. Faults 208,000 Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Environmental Protection Agency ordered the Chrysler Corporation today to recall 208.000 of its 1975 model automobiles because of what the agency said were faulty design and maintenance problems producing excessive air pollution.

title: Natalie Ann Smith Calkin Is Wed to Charles Hazard
description: Natalie Ann Smith Calkin of Brooklyn, daughter of Clinton H. Smith of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Sybil C. Smith, also of Brooklyn. was married yes.trday to Charles Do hazard. son of C. Howard Hazard of Burlington, N. J., and the rate Maron Moon Hazard.

title: Act at Cabaret Based on Blues
description: A Man, a Woman and the Blues, is the accurately descriptive title of a modest, unpretentious attempt at a cabaret production at Upstairs at Cecil's, 161 East 54th Street. The man is Larry O'Leno, the woman is Nancy Harrow and they both sing the blues.

title: In a Mill They Share a Busy Life, With Pottery Wheel as Focal Point
description: EAST KILLINGLY, Conn.When not hip deep in paint remover or plumbing parts or polystyrene insulationbasics in the gradual renovation of their mill home hereRichard and Sandra Farrell are earning their living by making pottery.

title: Steve Cady
description: Let the TV go first, a publicity man was shouting as camera crews dragged cables and lights across an orange carpet toward Bob McAdoo.

title: White Sox Acquire Zisk from Pirates
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 Richie Zisk, Pittsburgh's slugging left fielder, became tonight the second righthanded power hitter to get away from the Yankees this week when the Pirates traded him to the Chicago White Sox three hours before the midnight interleague trading deadline.

title: Donald McKayle's Latest Dance in Premiere
description: Donald McKayle's latest dance, Blood Memories, which had its world premiere at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Thursday night, is ambitious, exciting and long. It is one of the longest ballets the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has ever produced, lasting about 50 minutes. Its scope and its range are also considerable.

title: Angola,With Cuban Help, Said to Clear Wide Strip Along Border in South
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 10 (AP)Officials in SouthWest Africa said today that Cuban and Angolan troops had cleared a stria of land along the southern border of Anaola.

title: When Competition Loses Logic
description: BRUSSELSNot only does the NATO alliance find itself in a financial disarray of duplication and rivalry in the arms production of its various member countries (as cited in a column last month) but the great civilian airlines, staggering under the mounting cost of aviation fuel and the uncertainty of traffic loads, seem on the verge of facing the need to stop buying differing types of planes from differing manufacturers.

title: PROGRAMS PROPOSED TO IMPROVE HOUSING
description: NEWARK, Dec. 10With hopes that the incoming Carter Administration will keep its promise and not forget the nation's urban areas, housing officials and mortgage bankers offered today a series of programs and ideas to stop the decline of New Jersey cities and help preserire existing neighborhoods.

title: Officials of Seagram Appeal 9Day Suspension of License
description: Officials of Joseph R. Seagram & Son Inc., the nation's largest distiller, appeared yesterday before the director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to appeal a nineday suspension of the company's Federal operating license. The suspension has not taken effect, pending appeals.

title: The Basic Problem Is 14,000 Tons of Waste Each Day
description: New York is a dirty thy and, according to people who should know, it is getting dirtier. The indifference of many residents and the almostchronic problems of the financially beleaguered Department of Sanitation have combined to make the job of disposing of the city's 14,000 tons of daily waste more difficult than ever.

title: Navy's Desertion Rate Hits Peak; Study Group Formed to Find Cause
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 10 (AP)The Navy suffered its highest desertion rate on record during the 1976 fiscal year and Navy officials say they do not know why.

title: Price of Gold Bullion Up in Europe
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP)The price of gold bullion continued to move higher in Europe today. The dollar was little changed.

title: New Burlington Chief Gives Direction in a Cyclical Field
description: The new boss at Burlington Industries, harddriving 55yearold William A. Klopman is respected by many and disliked by some, but he has indisputably put his stamp on the world's largest textile manufacturer.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Soviet Extends Its Fisheries Limit
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 10The Soviet Union today joined a growing list of countries in extending the offshore fishing limit to 200 nautical miles.

title: Hofstra 76, Duquesne 70
description: PITTSBURGH, Richie Laurel scored 29 points to lead Hofstra to a 7670 victory over Duquesne tonight, its fourth in five outings.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Dec. 10 (UPI)An antipornography campaigner, Mary Whitehouse, has invoked the Blasphemy Act of 1697 to force prosecution of a magazine that published a poem, by a professor teaching in Massachusetts, for alleged blashphemous libel of the life of Jesus.

title: SouthWest Africa Talks Stall As Guerrilla War Continues
description: PRETORIA. South Africa, Dec. 10While efforts to resolve the Rhodesian dispute grind on inconclusively in Geneva, a less publicized dispute with many of the same elementsa guerrilla war, an entrenched white minority and a factionridden black majoritysmolders on in the huge. mineralrich territory of SouthWest Afrira.

title: WILLIAM C. FRENCH JR.
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (UPI) William C. French Jr., president of United States Steel Corporation's products division, died yesterday at his home in suburban Fox Chapel. He was 61 years old.

title: Irrepressible, Prolific Taylor Caldwell
description: BUFFALOTaylor Caldwell is prodigious.

title: Opera: A Fine Merry Widow
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan operates in the small 299seat Eastside Playhouse. There it has been reviving sundry light operas along with its regular Gilbert and Sullivan repertory. The announcement that it would do The Merry Widow aroused misgivings in some minds, however, because the Lehar work has in recent years been given fairly sumptuous productions in large theaters, in one case by the New York City Opera.

title: . . . Economizers Guide
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, the J. C. Penney executive who performed distinguished emergency service for the city as Deputy Mayor for Finance, recently described New York as a city that went too far in providing services its citizens could not afford.

title: PETER LISAGOR DEAD; NOTED JOURNALIST,61
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)Peter Lisagor, Washington bureau manager of The Chicago Daily News and one of the nation's bestknown journalists, who appeared frequently on television, died today at Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital. Mr. Lisagor, who was 61 years old, had been fighting cancer since February.

title: Mieuli and 49ers End Talks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP)Discussions concerning the sale of the San Francisco 49ers to Franklin Mieuli, owner of Basketball's Golden State Warriors, have been terminated by mutual agreement, the 49ers announced today. A team spokesman said, however, that the collapse of negotiations does not mean that the club is no longer for sale.

title: Nyquist Drafts a New Food Plan
description: The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, outlined yesterday series of administrative and fiscal recommendations intended to improve the scandalridden Summer Food Service Program for children.

title: Mexican Administration And Big Business Sign $5 Billion Investing Pact
description: MEXICO CITY. Dec. 10Mexico's new administration and the country's powerful private sector today signed a $5 billion joint investment pact marking the beginning of closer relations between government and big business.

title: Meadowlands Drivers
Seoul's Intelligence Chief in Washington to Go Home
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The South Korean Government has won a struggle for the loyalty of Maj. Gen. Kim Yung liwan, the Washington station chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, who has been persuaded to return to Seoul, authoritative Korean sources said today.

title: Education Without Longing for CookieCutterism
description: Again there is hue and cry in the search for a relevant general education. Along with a modicum of wisdom are large portions of naive speculation, false and deceptive measurements, meaningless statistics, and exceedingly bad history.

title: Engraving by Durer Is Stolen From Philadelphia Art Museum
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (UPI) A 16thcentury engraving by the German artist Albrecht Dilrer has been stolen from the Philadelphia Art Museum.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions arc based on news report ed in The Times in the last weep.

title: Study Criticizes Hospital Agency And Asks Reform
description: A report drafted for the May or's Task Force on the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is sharply critical of the corporation's leadership and the failings that have exacerbated the corporation's current fiscal crisis.

title: Progress on Terrorism
description: Any progress toward effective international action against any aspect of terrorism, however it be called, deserves commendation. The unusual coming together of Western nations, the third world and the Soviet bloc behind a United Nations proposal for an international treaty against the taking of hostages is a cause for celebration. The adoption by consensus in the General Assembly's legal committee of the resolution advanced by West Germany and 37 other nations assures passage by the Assembly itself.

title: Mexican Troops Surround Land Occupied by Peasant Squatters
description: TORREON, Mexico, Dec. 10 (UPI)Army reinforcements today surrounded farms awaiting orders for a possible second attack to drive out thousands of peasant squatters who refused to leave the cottongrowing lands they seized near the Texas border.

title: Books of The Times
description: The blues as such are synonymous with low spirits. Blues music is not. . . . Not only is its express purpose to make people feel good, which is to say in high spirits, but in the process of doing so it is actually expected to generate a disposition that is both elegantly playful and heroic in its nonchalance. So says Albert Murray in Stomping the Blues. And in this frolicsome paean to blues music, the artists who play and sing it, and the spirit that invigorates it, Mr. Murray cuts through many prevailing cliches and ossified assumptions to present a picture of a musical tradition steeped in affirmation.

title: Michigan Votes to Ban Some Aerosol Sprays
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 10 (AP) Michigan has become the nation's third state to bast aerosol sprays that contain fluorocarbons. By 1978, one year before the ban takes effect, all spray cans containing fluorocarbon propellants such as Freon will have to be labeled as such.

title: 2 IN BRONFMAN TRIAL GUILTY OF EXTORTION BUT NOT KIDNAPPING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 10Mel Patrick Lynch and Dominic P. Byrne were acquitted today of charges of kidnapping Samuel Bronfman 2d in August 1975, but were convicted of grand larceny for extorting a $2.3 million ransom from Mr. Bronfman's father, Edgar, who is chairman of the Seagram Company Ltd.

title: S.E.C. Adopts Rules Requiring Reporting of Lost Securities
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules today requiring all lost, stolen or counterfeit securities to be reported to the Government, as of March 1, 1977.

title: Fiat's Libyan Deal Held Aid to Soviet; Moscow Role Seen
description: ROME, Dec. 10The Soviet Union emerged today as a potential beneficiary from the agreement by Libya to take a 10 percent holding in Fiat, the giant Italian automobile company.

title: DUDLEY HARMON, 90, DIES; NEW ENGLAND CRUSADER
description: HARWICHPORT, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP)Dudley Harmon, a former newspaperman who began crusading 50 years ago for joint action by New England states on their common problems, died Wednesday at his home here after several months illness. He was 90 years old. Private services were held yesterday at his home.

title: Camden Mayor Seeks to Win 4 Elections in a Year
description: CAMDEN, Dec. 10Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti has set out to win four elections within a year to improve his chances of rebuilding his blighted hometown.

title: Radical Infiltrators Vex British Laborites
description: LONDON, Dec. 10PrimeMinisterJames Callaghan, his predecessor, Sir Harold Wilson, and the general secretary of the governing Labor Party have joined some of this country's newspapers in warning against a party takeover by extremist infiltrators, mainly youthful Trotskyists. Judging by the headlines given these warnings, the average British reader could easily conclude that the party is ripe for takeover, if not already in bondage. In fact, the militants are few in number, and only about a dozen seats in Parliament are being seriously challenged.

title: Canadian Pianist in Return
description: Ronald Turini is so obviously a superior pianist that the mystery is why he does not impress one consistently as an important artistThe Canadian musician, who made his Carnegie Hall debut 15 years ago, but has been an infrequent performer in New York since then, returned on Thursday night after a sixyear absence to give a recital at the 92d Street YMYWHA.

title: Equality Sometimes
description: The Supreme Court, overturning the judgments of six United States Courts of Appeal, ruled this week that an employer's refusal to pay disability benefits to employees who become pregnant did not constitute unlawful sex discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Excerpts From the Kissinger News Conference at NATO Headquarters
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 10 Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's news conference today at NATO headquarters as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Volvo to Cut Output in 1977
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10 Volvo announced today that its stockpile of unsold cars was so great that the company would he forced to reduce production during the first half of 1977 by 15,000 to 20,000 cars, a move that will affect some 15,000 workers.

title: U.S. Estimate Puts Wheat Crop At Record 2.147 Billion Bushels
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 Wheat growers have produced a record harvest of 2.147 billion bushels this year. the Agriculture Department estimated today in its final production report on the crop.

title: UNITED BRANDS BRIBE CALLED ABERRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 A 1974 agreement by the United Brands Company to pay the Honduran Economics Minister a $2.5million bribe to obtain a reduction in banana taxes was a unique aberration rather than part of a pattern of company behavior, a special investigating committee reported today.

title: Cup Activity For Intrepid Is Expected
description: Intrepid, the gallant 12Meter yacht that defended the America's Cup in 1967 and 1970 and just missed filling that role again in 1974, is expected to be back for this summer's cup activity. George Hinman, chairman of the America's Cup committee for the New York Yacht Club, said yesterday that negotiations were under way to purchase or charter Intrepid, which is in the Hawaiian islands and a pawn in complex financial dealings.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA portable ladder, put up in sections, makes it feasible for women as well as men to climb telephone poles. Instead of climbing a pole or mast by sticking the points of legirons into the wood, workers will be able to attach the light frames and walk up a series of steps.

title: Blazers 103, Braves 102
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (UPI)The Buffalo Braves, playing their first game since Bob McAdoo was traded, staged a gallant fourthquarter drive tonight before losing, 103102, to the Pacific Divisionleading Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Golf
description: WORLD CUP

title: Bridge:
description: Almost all the top New York experts will be in action at 1:30 P.M. today at the New York Hilton Hotel, hoping they are headed for grand national honors next summer.

title: HUGHES CONCERN PICKED TO DEVELOP HELICOPTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10The Army today selected Hughes Helicopter to develop a new attack helicopter for use against tanks and ground troops.

title: Kissinger, in a Farewell to Allies, Appeals for Vigilance and Detente
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 10Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger made a farewell appeal to America's allies today to maintain strong defenses while pursuing mutual restraint with the Russians to avoid an unimaginable catastrophe.

title: Orantes Stops Solomon, Gains Final
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 10You remember Manuel Orantes, Forest Hills hero in 1975 and forgotten sorearm competitor for most of this season?

title: Alden H. Maclntyre, ExBanker And Descendant of John Alden
description: Alden H. MacIntyre, a retired Boston banker and a direct descendant of John Alden of the Mayflower settlers in Plymouth, Mass., died Thursday in his home in Cambridge, Mass. His age was 77.

title: Rhodesian Says He Was Misled
description: GENEVA, Dec. 10Prime Minister Ian D. Smith charged today that he was brought to the conference here on a pretense that the black nationalists were ready to accept the proposals on Rhodesian majority rule that he had agreed to with Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Tight Postseason Slate Is Proposed
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10A new schedule for postseason games, a real possibility of splitting each major league into three divisions in 1978, and the National League's continued resistance to the designatedhitter rule were the main items of direct fan interest to emerge from the annual baseball winter meetings that ended here last night.

title: Barons 7, Capitals 1
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 (AP) The Cleveland Barons snapped an 11game losing streak when they exploded for five firstperiod goals and skated to a 71 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: State Police Looking Into the Arrest of Utica's Mayor
description: UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 10 (UPI)A State Police observer was ordered today to look into the dispute between Mayor Edward Hanna and local police officials that led to the Mayor's arrest and the sofar ignored suspensions of the Police Chief and three other officers.

title: UNION AIDE INDICTED IN DOCKSIDE PAYOFFS
description: A top official of the International Longshoremen's Association was indicted yesterday on Federal charges of accepting nearly $90.000 in cash payments from the United Brands Company when the company's cargo was tied up in longshoremen's strikes in 196869 and 1971.

title: CARTER VIEWS JOBS AS THE TOP PRIORITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Presidentelect Jimmy Carter said today that his first priority in stimulating the economy would be to channel Government money into programs to create jobs and that any tax reduction he proposed would be a supplement to that effort.

title: Ottinger Names New Aide
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 10Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Westchester, announced today the appointment of Martin Rogowsky, a 27yearold attorney, as his administrative assistant. Mr. Rogowsky, a Democrat who lives in White Plains and practices law in New Rochelle, lost to Assemblyman Peter M, Sullivan, RepublicanConservative, by 272 votes in the November election in the 92d Assembly District. Mr. Sullivan defeated him by 373 votes in 1974. Mr. Rogowsky succeeds Oren Teicher who will supervise Mr. Ottinger's district offices in Westchester.

title: Harvard Defeats C.C.N.Y., 5949, As Trion and Hooft Pace Attack
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 10 (AP)Steve Irion scored 15 of his 17 points in the first half to give Harvard a big edge, then Bob Hooft netted 6 of his 16 in the final eight minutes to nail clown a 5949 victory over City College in college basketball tonight.

title: New Precinct Commander
description: When Capt. John Waters took over command of the 13th Precinct in Manhattan a few years ago, he was faced with an immediate discipline problem. Two officers had just committed minor infractions, and he had to decide how they should be punished. The officers came to see him on his first day at the precinct. They suggested he consult the precinct's executive officer.

title: High School Gymnast Unmasked As 24YearOld Seeking Youth
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 10 (UPI)For nearly a year Patrick Lajko lived a Peter Pan fantasy of youth eternal. The 24yearold college graduate posed as a high school student and became a star gymnast.

title: Bergdorf Will Open One Store Sundays
description: It's never on Sunday at Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue, but White Plains is another matter.

title: CHINATOWN PRECINCT GETS A TOUGHER COP
description: The police commander of the Chinatown precinct was transferred to administrative duties to make way for a tougher cop, a highranking police official said yesterday.

title: Keep the Faith, Rep. Abzug Tells Women in Adieu
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 10The women of Capitol Hill said farewell to a tearful Bella Abzug today.

title: A Changing of the Guards
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 10 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers today put a rookie guard, Mo Howard, on waivers and activated another firstyear backcourt man, Chuckie Williams. Williams, Cleveland's No. 1 drat choice out of Kansas State University, had been on the injured list. He has not played a game for the Cavaliers.

title: World Is Looking Rosier For Rising U. S. Ski Team
description: VAL D'ISERE, France  It is all happening at once for the United States Ski Team, which is way ahead of schedule, with a victory and television cameras to show off the good results back home. There is even a little money in the bank. Times have changed.

title: Woman in Ohio Heads National Guard Unit
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 11 (UPI) Capt. Sandra Campbell today assumed command of Headquarters Company of the Ohio Army National Guard's 16th Engineer Brigade, becoming the first woman to head a guard unit in Ohio.

title: Acting for Kids Isn't Child's Play
description: There's an old showbusiness adage that warns actors to avoid, at all costs, playing opposite either children or animals. As an actor currently employed doing children's theater, which always booms at this time of year, trust me when I say that acting with children is duck soup compared to acting for children. (I have never acted for animals, although one particularly rowdy audience in Chicago came awfully close.)

title: Las Vegas Calm About Atlantic City Competition
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 10  Atiantic City?

title: HOUSING IN HARLEM GAINS IN VITALITY
description: After three years of inactivily because of a housing moratorium in the early 1970's, the first sign of relics for local housing groups in Harlem has appeared.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in the Arts and Leisure Section:

title: Fugitive Seized in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 10 (UPI)  Charles E: Crawford, 25 years old, of Camden, N. J., was arrested in Hawaii yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the slaying earlier this year of Betty Jo Mosely of Camden. The F.B.I. had been searching for him since last March 28 under a fugitive warrant.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Acting of any kind is difficult enough to judge rationally but film acting is the most illusive, being so dependent on things that have nothing to do with the talent or the craft or the intelligent options exercised by the actor. good performance on the stage or screen can be shaped as much by what God gave the actor for a nose, a voice or a general physique as by the things the actor does with those original resources. The screen performance is at the further mercy of the director, the lighting cameraman and the editor, all or any of whom can ruin a good performance  as well as they can create a great performance out of what is virtually found material.

title: Parley Urges Aid to Region In Adirondacks
description: ALBANY  A new regional economic development agency has been proposed for the 13 counties in and around the Adirondack Mountains. one of the most depressed areas of the state.

title: A Gift That Never Forgets
description: COLOMBO. SRI LANKA, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Sri Lanka announced today it would give a yearold orphaned elephant called Shanti (Peace) to the United States to mark the Bicentennial.

title: Justice Dept. Studies Surveillance by C .1 .A On Micronesia Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The Department of Justice is tstudying the legality! of Central Intelligence Agency electronic surveillance conducted during the last: four years in Micronesia, a group of Pacific islands governed by the United States under a United Nations trusteeship, a department spokesman said today.

title: Richard Fuller, 79, Philanthropist; Founded Seattle Art Museum
description: Richard E. Fuller, a philanthropist and leading patron of the arts on the West Coast died in his home in Seattle Friday of apparent heart failure. He was 79 years old.

title: In Summary
description: Ever since 1969, when the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration first proposed that air bags that would deploy automatically in an accident should be made compulsory in 1972 automobiles, Government officials have postponed the actual decision that would mandate the devices.

title: Latest Jets Era Ending With Namath as Starter
description: Still another Jets era (Randy Rasmussen says he has been through four in his 10 years) ends at Shea Stadium today when the New Yorkers how out of the 1976 football season against the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Bob Sheppard: The Clear and Cool Stadium Voice
Yolande Canavaggio To Marry in Panama
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jean Canavaggio of Parvu have announced the engagement of their daughter, Yolanda Maud Canavaggio, to Thomas Kellogg Hadlock.

title: New York Budget Division Ordered by Court to Give Access to Information
description: ALBANY, Dec. 11  The New York State Budget Division, a part of Governor Carey's executive departments, is required under the state's Freedom of Information Law to supply work sheets and other statistical information when the material is requested, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Third Department, has ruled.

title: Article 2  No Title
STAGE VIEW
description: Charles Fuller's The Brownsville Raid has point of honor to make, and by the time reaches its final fadeout at the Theater de Lys  with eight disgraced black soldiers standing in rigid military silence, stonily accepting the justice that has been accorded them  the point is made with considerable dignity and force. With some subtlety, too, rather more than you'd expect from a semidocumentary detailing a notorious instance bigotry and the wanton damage it did before hate could be satisfied.

title: Carol Forsyth Fiancee of Paul F. Mickey Jr.
description: Carol Lynne Forsyth, a member of the editorial staff of TimeLife Books in Alexandria, Va., and Paul F. Mickey Jr., a lawyer in the Legal Adviser's Office of the Department of State, will be married March 19 in Washington.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the story on Bermuda inn.., Bermuda Option: Away From the Hotels (Travel Section, Nov. 28), the telrphone number for the Visitors Service Bureau was incorrect. It is 809.2951480, The rates for South Capers should have read $21$24, for Rosemont. $19.$23, and for the White Heron( $24 (European Plan).

title: US. TO BACK CHILEANS 11 ON WORLD BANK AID
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The United States intends to vote favorably Tuesday on two World Bank loans to Chile despite strong pressure from Congress to cast a negative vote based on considerations of human riehts.

title: Vatican Paper Publishes A 1975 Condemnation Of Direct Sterilization
description: ROME, Dec. 11 (AP)  Sterilization to prevent pregnancy is absolutely forbidden for Roman Catholics, even in cases where pregnancy would result in physical or psychic evil, the Vatican said in a statement issued today.

title: State Tennis to Start
description: Entries for t he New York State men's and women's indoor tennis championships at the Cote Racquet Club in Glen Cove. LI, close on Tuesday. The women begin play on Friday and the men Dec. 20.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: The next time your buddy pulls you aside after a night of league howling and tells you to be a hit more straightforward in your game, the odds are that he is not impugning your integrity but has detected a flaw in your delivery.

title: Amateur Opera With Professional Heart
description: MICHAEL BLANEY drives cab. Alison Corr is a secretary. Ric French sells lime. Arlene Garguilo is a dental assistant, Salvatore Davi makes ballet slippers. Jennifer Herring teaches music.

title: TV VIEW
A Question and
description: On what basis should the public judge your performance?

title: Morristown Salutes Nast
description: Morrisrown IF IT were not for Thomas Nast, who knows what Santa Claus might look likr? Thanks to Nast., a 19thcentury ????? cartoon1st, and his famous iliusIration, the modern world knows Santa as a cherrynosed butterball in a furtrimmed outfit and hoots.

title: The P.T.A. Is Not What It Was Happily, Some Say
description: Last month in Rochester, the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers approved a resolution at its 79th annual convention calling for the decriminalization of marijuana. The vote underscored the fact that changes are due in the traditional image of the P.T.A. as a social group whose activities used to be limited to gathering at monthly school meetings for coffee or tea.

title: Roiling the Fishermen's World
description: THE timing, say the Island's commercial and partyboat fishermen, couldn't have been worse. The National Marine Fisheries Service has released preliminary plans for allocating fishing rights for surplus fish stocks in the northwestern Atlantic Ocean to foreign fleets. The plans are to go into efect March 1 along with the extension of the country's territorialwaters limit to 200 miles to protect fishermen.

title: School Bonanza Creates a Quandary
KISSINGER ACCUSES MARITIME CERNIAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has accused the chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission of signing an agreement with the Soviet Union without informing the State Department.

title: Mozambique Says Rhodesians Attack Border Village by Planes
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, Dec. 11 (Reuters)  Rhodesian planes today attacked Mozambique village near the Rhodesian border, the Mozambique press agency reported.

title: Pastore to Leave Senate Dec. 28 To Let Chain Obtain Seniority
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Dec. 11 (AP)  LJnited States Senator John D. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, said today that he would resign Dec. 28 to allow his successor, Republican John H. Chafee, to be appointed to serve out the term and gain seniority benefits.

title: Mixed Results
description: WASHINGTON When Presidentelect Jimmy Carter got a briefing from members of his transition staff on Thursday about the problems he will soon face the Treasury Department's area of economic policy, four of the six economists who briefed him were women. It seemed to be a sign of real progress for the women's movement

title: Nina Stone Reeves Plans To Marry Peter C. Gable
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stone Reeves of Oldwick, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Stone Reeves, to Peter Crane Gable, son of Mrs. Louis L. Lorillard of Monte Carlo, Monaco, and the late Lewis Martin Gable of New York, where he was an independent industrial relations consultant.

title: There Are No Islands Left In the World's Economy
description: Jimmy ,Carter's victory In the 1976 Presidential contest was based in part on domestic economic concerns over inflation, unemployment and the pause in the economic recovery.

title: Simon Asks to Keep Foreign Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today that over the last two years he has kept several gifts from foreign officials pending a resolution of his request to the State Department that he be allowed to purchase the items.

title: Giant Restaurant Union Is Accused 101 Intimidating New York Members

title: The Wallpaper Fox
description: At first, The Wallpaper Fox threatens to be merely a routine chastisement of morally flaccid, uppermiddle class America. Soon, however, this solid and serious novel emerges as not just an expos of what really goes on behind the wellgroomed facades of the affluent, but a thoughtful exploration of character and the efficacy of moral action in forming and reforming it.

title: Austin Peay Hires Coach

title: Sober Piano Recital Is Given by Jahoda
description: Fritz Jahoda, who has been playing, conducting and teaching locally for more than 30 years, is a sober, selfeffacing musician. There is never anything forced or exaggerated about his pianism. if the range of color and dynamics is relatively narrow, chances are he prefers it that way. of the five Works on Mr. Jahoda's program Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, Brahms's Six Piano Pieces (Op. 118) benefited the most from the Viennaborn pianist's approach. These ripe miniatures from the composer's last years, which can sound sentimental in more personalized readings, were on this occasion eloquently dignified.

title: NEW TRUCE REACHED IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 11  A ceasefire has been worked out between rival Moslem and Christian factions in the district of Bint Jbail in southern Lebanon near the border with Israel.

title: CORRECTION

title: Rangers Unbeaten String Ends in 41 Loss to Leafs
description: TORONTO, Dec. 11  Toronto is pleasant place to visit, but not for the New York Rangers. For them it is Jinx City..

title: 13 Cubans Arrested in Florida Unloading 12 Tons of Marijuana
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 11 (UPI)Federal, state and local police, alerted by phone call from an informer, arrested 13 Cuban refugees today and confiscated nearly 12 tons of marijuana while it was being unloaded on Ramrod Key, about 30 miles northeast of Key West.

title: How to take on OPEC
description: When the Arab embargo and the subsequent oilprice increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries launched the energy crisis in October 1973, Washington's initial response was little more than a display to placate the public, queued and short  tempered at filling stations. President Nixon, ever the car dealer, pledged 'that by 1980 we shall be able to meet America's energy needs from America's own energy resources. To launch the conservation Vittlit, the first family would fly commercial and cut back on Christmastree lights. Congress held hearings to decide whom to blame, while for immediate, if symptomatic, relief, it reduced highway speeds and expanded daylightsaving time. New agencies and councils were set up, and existing bureaus were given new names. Energy czars were turned over like losing baseball managers.

title: Joni Mitchell Recaptures Her Gift
description: It's easy to get testy about Joni Mitchell. Originally yet another strumming folkie from the Village, she moved out to Southern ralifornia and steatily transformed herself into a mythological, icy glamour princess. Her album covers were testimonials to grandiose narcissism, and her poety and her music evolved inexorably into nervously selfabsorbed introspection. Not that she didn't produce great recent work to go along with her.haunting earlier albums"Court and Spark from 1974 in particular.

title: Miss Zurhellen Plans Wedding To Biochemist
description: J. Owen Zurhellen Jr., Ambassador to Surinam, and Mrs. Zurb2llen, of Paramaribo, Surinam; Washingtm, and Putnam Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement cf their daughter, Stephanie Jo Zurhellen, to Dr. Angus Girdwood Hcphurn, who is doing research in molecular biochemistry at the University of Bristol Medical School in England.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Ore of the favorite games of opera buffs is IfI. WereManager. Everybody has his favorites. If you or I were running a major opera house, what operas would we put on to supplement the standard Mozart through Strauss repertory? Take New York, with its two major organizations  the Metropolitan and the New York City Opera. And here are you and I, the ultimate musical tsars of the city, able to dictate repertory. What, in our infinite wisdom, would we produce?

title: Susan Read Plans Katmandu Wedding
description: Susan Read and Edward W, Cronin Jr.. Williams College graduates, will be married Dec. 20 in Katmandu. Nepal. The future bride's parents are Mr. and Nrs. Alexander D. Read of Peru, Vt. Her father is an artist and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Siderowf Discusses the Gentleman's Side fo Golf
description: A casual glance at the amateur golf scene would suggest the field consists entirely of handsome giants with long blond hair, frayed jeans and shirt tails hanging out. They attend college on lucrative golf scholarships, a circumstance that makes the campus a prep school for the professional golf tour. They are so impatient to turn pro that they don't even try to earn a diploma.

description: Carl E. Burckhardt, an engineering executive of PepsiCo Inc. of Purchase, N. Y., died Tuesday in Glen Cove (L. I.) Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 12 Duke Place, Glen Cove and was 62 years old.

description: W HEREVER America's cities are going, Newark will get there first."Motto of the administration of Mayor Kenneth A.

title: In Summary

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: LINES are peculiar things. Nobody plans them. Usually selfgenerating and almost always consisting of people who say they wouldn't dream of being part of them, they form where it might naturally be expected they wouldat the Lincoln and Holland Tunnel toll booths in the rush hours, at doityourself hardware counters in Wayne and for standingroomonly at the latest fad restaurants in Fort Lee.

title: Getting Santa to Montclair
description: INELL, he came to town all right, but it wasn't all that easy. I mean even Santa Claus just doesn't come into town, any town, these days without prior planning. And before he made it to Montclair that Saturday, months of preparation were necessary.

title: Suffolk Police Job: Sweepstakes On
description: THE Suffolk Legislature is not scheduled to act until next March on the question of a new County Police Commissioner, but already there is spirited speculation and scrambling concerning the $44,240ayear position. And although the 18member Legislature will appoint the police commissioner, there is emerging agreement that the key to its decision will ultimately lie with Dominic J. Baran ello, the Suffolk Democratic chairman.

title: Contemplative man of action
description: Andr Mairaux died on November 23 shortly after completing his 75th year. He was still actively writing: the final volume of his vast The Metamorphoses of the Gods had come out, a short book on the same theme in literature was planned, the AntiMemoirs were being extended, and Picasso's Mask bad just been published in this country. An engaged intellectual from the 19zws to the present, Malraux tried to encourage in all his writings a dialogue between the active and contemplative life, and particularly between the politician and the cultural thinker. He had no illusions, however, about politics: he knew it forced the thinker to give up some individuality and even to become, in extreme situations, a shadow or mask of his former self. But it was precisely this dehumanizing aspect of public life that his later philosophy of art sought to counter by representing the masterpieces of all ages as an antidestiny": austere triumphs wrested by the artist from a seductive and monstrous world.

title: Delaware Stops Football Lottery, Cites Reports of Wrong Bet Line
description: WILMINGTON. Del., Dec. 11 (API) Pete Simmons, Delaware lottery director, said tonight he was canceling all wagers on the state's football lotPrV.

J., Dec. 10 (AP)  Joseph Schott, 15 years old, of West Milford, who was hunting deer in a wooded area off Clinton Road here, was killed yesterday when a shotgun accidentally fired after it fell to the ground, the police said. After the accident, the youth's hunting companion, a 15yearold whose name was not released, ran one and a quarter miles to the nearest house to summon help, the police said.

title: Con Edison Seeks Extension on Deadline for Indian Point Changes

title: City Council Units Set Hearings for the Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: 7 INJURED AS 5 INMATES FLEE PRISON IN CAROLINA
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Dec. 11 (UPI)  Five inmates escaped from the Oaklawn prison camp toniht, wounding at seven persons with guns and knives in the breakout.

title: 10Year Loss in Jobs
description: NEW JERSEY has lost 142,000 manufacturing jobs in the last 10 years, with the big decline 88,000 jobshaving occurred since 1974. The loss since 1966 amounts to one of every six manufacturing jobs in the state.

title: False Distress Call Brings Prison Term
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 11 (UP)  A 26yearold man who pleaded guilty to calling in a false distress call on a citizen's band radio has been sentenced to one year in prison.

title: Notes: Are Robots Wave of the Future?
description: An airport robot that dispenses passengers tickets, enabling them to avoid waiting on line, has passed its first test with flying colors and could be a portent of the style of travel in the future. Travelers in a hurry, mostly business travelers, have been making such good use of the device, a selfticketing machine introduced by United Airlines at Cleveland's Hopkins Airport, that the carrier has installed three moreat the Chicago, San Francisco and Los Angeles Airports.

title: Scientists Drill in Antarctic Shelf To Unlock Secrets of Ancient Ice
description: McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica  An oceanic lost world cut off from the sun, as well as from human scrutiny, for thousands and perhaps millions of years is being probed by a team of scientists who are drilling through the Ross Ice Shelf of Antarctica.

title: Tremor on IranianIraqi Border
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 11 (UPI )  earthquake measuring 4.8 on the Richer . scale was recorded today near the bordre between Iran and Iraq about 310 southwest of Teheran. There were no re, ports of injuries or damage.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The U.S. Mint's San Francisco mail  order address  55 Mint Street  has become familiar over the years to countless thousands of collectors who have ordered the Mint's special coin and medal offerings. Although may be only a postal address, 55 Mint Street's numismatic service facilities are real enough, and they are housed in a building that still stands at Fifth and Mission Streets as one of the few survivors of the terrible earthquake and fire of 1906. Today the Old San Francisco Mint, a secure National Landmark, gives every indication of becoming one of that city's premier historic attractions.

title: Dropping of Sheriff's Jury Urged
description: The State Commission of Investigation yesterday called on the Legislature to abolish the sheriffs jury. in Manhattan.

title: The MillionDollar Man on the Lam
description: ST. GEORGE'S. Grenada  There are no horses on this sunny little isle, at least none bred to separate gambling man from his hardearned cash. This is a land of nutmeg, enough to make an eggnog for every Christmas celebrant around the world, and a rum punch topped with spice that would excite the most languid palate, but Sports these are hardly the of kinds of tourist attracThe Times tions to lure a ded cated horse racing fanatic.

title: PEOPLE
description: On the local literary scene, the latest collaboration to find its way into print is that of Cecile Shapiro and Lauds Mason, who have combined interests, talents and determination to produce Fine Prints: Collecting, Buying and selling (Harper & Row, $10.95). Lauris Mason Brookville is a former teacher and interior designer whose hobby of collecting prints led her to become an art dealer. Her clients questions led to the next stepwriting about prints and print collecting. Cecile Shapiro of Great Neck is a former finearts major who became a teacher and then a writer. Along with guidance for collectors and wouldhe collectors at all income levels, their book offers anecdotes that collectors love to hearstbries about bargainhunters who pay $4 at an auction for a 15thcentury print.

title: Meetings With Malraux
description: Last winter, he had just published Lazarus (to be published here in 1977), his conscious meeting with death, and had come back bearing the signs of resurrection. The eyes were brighter than ever, the hands more nervous, the face tense as a hawk's, the body hunched and absent as an owl's. A cold midday sun tried to shine over Paris while we lunched at the home of the Gaullist Deputy Raymond Offroy. I said hello and he called me my accomplice.

title: Higgins Stars For Scanlan In 4Mile Relay
description: The schoolboy track season has barely started, but 13oh Higgins has already served notice that he's re;.dy. Higgins, a senior at Monsignor scanlan High in the Bronx, turned in his third impressive performance when he ran the anchor mile leg of the fourmile relay yesterday in 4 minutes I S.G seconds at the Mount St. Michael Polar Bear Meet in the Bronx.

title: To Delight of Collectors, Mint Accidentally Makes More UpsideDown Bills
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Much to the delight of the world's numismatists, the Bureau of Printing and Engraving in Washington has made another blunder.

title: FILM MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: If last week's sudden jolt of frigid weather was not enough to convince gardeners that rough times are ahead for plants, then take a look at the rhododendrons. On cold frosty mornings, their leaves are curled up into tiny cigarlike strips. Just looking at them is enough to make anyone shiver. Pachysandra does the same thing.

title: The Fragile Writer
description: Suddenly there are a number of firstrate women writers aroundso many that one doesn't envy them the competition if they are drawing anger and insight from the same well. It's an illustration again of how fragile a matter artistic fecundity is. Some sort of sea change occurs in the climate of opinionan idea's time comes dueand almost immediately a group of writers materializes who had not made themselves available before. The circumstances are different in this case, however. Writers, like other artists, have generally originated in the middle class since anybody started noticing origins at all, and so in America when a particular ethnic minority has stopped being either cops or robbers, commonly and quite abruptly its children have begun to publish novels, as in the postWorld War II surge of Jewish, Irish, Negro, ItalianAmerican writing. But womenconstituting half the countryhad been going to college and enjoying the advantages of a good Protestant bank account, foreign travel, a polite neighborhood, a room of one's own, leisure in the evening and what not for very much longer than they had exercised their prerogative to publish their opinions on any proportionate scale. They had been editors, for instance, but from some arcane. vital failure of nerve had not stepped forward in numbers to speak for themselves until freed only recently by one of those fascinating tippingofthescales in the process that produces art.

title: CAMERA VIEW
Shavers Stops Williams in 14th; Rossman Wins
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 11 (AP) Earnie Shavers staggered on the verge of a knockout in the 10th and final round today before staging a comeback that knocked out Roy Williams 14 seconds before the end of their fight.

title: Slayer of Man Who Tried to Aid A Policeman Gets 2 Life Terms
description: A 21yearold former mental patient convicted of killing a man and wounding a policeman inside St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City in January 1975 was sentenced Friday to two consecutive terms of life in prison. He will be eligible for parole after 25 years.

title: Giants Finale a Must for Cardinals
description: The 280pound tackle doesn't think it would help the St. Louis Cardinals chances of making the National Football League playoffs.

title: POLITICS
description: NEW JERSEY Democratic hopefuls have a unique lovehate relationship with Hudson County. They want the Democratic plurality that the area represents, but they fear the county's reputation for raising public corruption to the level of high art.

title: Olympics Still a Source of Feuds in Quebec Politics
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 11  The 1976 Olympic Games are part of history, but the host city of Montreal and the province of Quebec are embroiled in increasingly bitter controversy over the decision that brought the Olympics here and over the money spent to make them possible.

title: New York Board of Education Asks Aid in Dealing With Bias Charges
description: The New York City Board of Education asked the public last week for suggestions on how to deal with Federal charges that the school system discriminates against women and minoritygroup members in teacher hiring, promotions and salaries.

title: CRIME, POLITICS AND FINGER
description: OSAKA. He's the selfstyled mayor of the night of a seedy neighborhood near the city's gaudiest nightclub district. His youthful followers are under strict orders not to drink in the bars near the highwalled confines of his spacious headquarters complex or otherwise harass the ordinary citizenry. The police come here and say Hello to me; we are like relatives. says Hideomi Oda, a director of the Yamaguchigumi, Japan's largest crime syndicate. Portly, bespectacled, fond of fancy silk shirts, diamondstudded tie pins and whitegold cuff links, Oda is expansive in the security of a study filled with stuffed birds and animals. A couple of nervously attentive assistants slip quietly in and out with iced coffee and tea. The police have their own roles; we have ours, Oda elaborates. In the daytime the police protect the citizens, and at night I protect them.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox:
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Opposition Mounts
description: THERE comes a time in the tide of governmental affairs when an overdue idea suddenly pops up and seemingly is unstoppable. The proposed sunset law one of these ideas and the time is now. But it may not be unstoppable. There is considerable opposition to it.

title: Blermann Optimistic About Return
description: ROME, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Wolf Biermann, the folk singer who was stripped of his East German citizenship for his liberal views, said today that he hoped to he able to return home sooner than his enemies would like.

title: PHONE COMPANY TAPS ARE CHARGED IN TRIAL
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 11  A former highranking executive of the Southwestprn Bell Telephone Company has testified that the company frequently wiretapped its employees and customers.

title: Republicans Are Trying to Regroup on Middle Ground
description: WASHINGTON  Crawling out of the rubble of the 1976 electoral blitz, the Republican Party has reckoned the number of its surviving officeholders at a deeply disturbing few. But, given the lack of a rallying leader like Winston Churchill, G.O.P. morale six weeks after the onslaught seems remarkably, almost unreasonably high.

title: LEADING SPANISH AIDE KIDNAPPED IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Dec. 11  Gunmen believed to be Basque militants today kidnapped Antonio Maria de Oriol y Urquijo, the staunchly conservative president of the advisory Council of State, taking him from his downtown Madrid office to an unknown location.

title: CONNECTICUT ACTION ON ETHICS IS LIKELY
description: HARTFORD. Dec, 10Bipartisan support of a proposed strict code of ethics now holds promise of sufficient support in the newly elected General Assembly to insure its adoption, although resistance is expected.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THOMAS B. LANCE, Presidentelect Carter's choice to head the Office of Management and Budget, said he favors a $15 billion stimulatory package for the economy, consisting of tax cuts and Federal spending. Earlier, he said he believed a oneyear tax rebate would be preferable to a permanent tax cut. . . . Meanwhile top corporate executives who met with Mr. Carter proposed a broader package$15 billion in tax cuts for individuals and an increase tax credits to 13 percent from 10 percent and a $5 billion job creation package. . Mr. Carter has under consideration a proposal to increase mortgage subsidies by $2 billion to a total of $5 billion to aid the housing industry. . . . Consumer credit in October rose $1.56 billion, the largest increase in three years.

title: Qatar, Site of Oil Ministers Conference This Week, Bolsters Its Border Guard to Block Any Terrorists
description: DOHA, Qatar, Dec. 11  This remote Arabian sheikdom has been taking stern security measures in recent days to guard against any terrorist assaults or incidents during a meeting next week of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, more commonly known as OPEC.

title: QUEBEC HALTS TRIAL OF ABORTION DOCTOR
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 11  Quebec's new Government has decided to halt all further prosecution of Dr. Henry Morgentaler, a Montreal physician who has been tried and acquitted three tunes in the past three years for performing illegal abortions.

description: Nothing has yet appeared this year to equal the monster volume of some Christmases ago that opened up to a spread of 3 feet. But this season's coffeetable literature covers as wide a range of subjects as ever, which can help to fill the blanks in the annual gift listprovided you're ready to put out the money.

title: Californians Get High Marks With German Shepherds
description: Mary Roberts, a 108pound ownerhandler from Covina. Calif., outweighs her dogs by just a few pounds yet manages to make her ring performances look effortless in the midst of tall professionals. And her claim that

title: Book Ends
description: Gilmore. Having as your lawyer in a capital case the writer who is wheeling and dealing your life story is about the same as hiring the Boston Strangler as a masseur, but Gary Gilmore's employment of Dennis Boaz as his lawyerbiographer was just one of many bizarre aspects of the case. Well, the rule these days is where there is notoriety the book and movie money moves in, so it's no surprise that the Dennis Boazes are not far behind. People's lives (or deaths) or other people's confidences become properties; notoriety pays and increasing competition for celebrity turns the ordinarily grave events of life into a carnival of commerce. Since it appears that capital punishment will become commonplace, however, future deathrow inmates won't be such hot properties. Still out of fairness, we think a rider should be added to the Miranda Rule lest criminals be deprived of their literary rights. In the future, interrogators should advise as follows: You have a right to remain silent. You have a right to a lawyer. You have a right to retain a writer and confess to the highest bidder.

title: Tennis Unity Is Getting Entangled in Web of Conflicts
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 11  Capping the sport's busiest and richest year ever, Manuel Orontes of Spain will play Wojtek Fibak of Poland tomorrow afternoon for the $40,000 top prize in the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament.

title: Segovia

title: Answers/Questions
description: This year I put my Christmas cactus in darkness at least 12 hours each day from Oct. 1 and now the plant has 20 buds. I am pleased. However, although watering is done when the soil is dry. I find some of the outer leaves withering. What am I doing wrong? Miss D.B., Brooklyn

description: Steve Cauthen, the 16yearold jockey who looks like he would seem more at home in a highschool classroom than on a race track, stole the spotlight at Aqueduct yesterday.

description: PARIS, Dec. 14  More than half of the Soviet Jewish emigrants, all of whom ostensibly leave the Soviet Union bound for Israel, are going elsewhere, mainly to the United States.

title: Thais Report Four Rebels Slain
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec. 11 (AP)  A border patrol in southern Thailand killed four Communist guerrillas and wounded several more yesterday in a clash 25 miles from the Malaysian border with a group belonging to the banned Communist Party of Malaya, Thal security officials said here today.

description: LIHUE, Hawaii, Dec. 11 (UPI)  Dr. Renee Richards advanced to the final of a 520,000 women's tennis tournament today when Karen Krantzcke of Australia had to default.

description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 11  The United States team of Jerry Pate and Dave Stockton caught and passed the Spanish team of Severiano Ballesteros and Manuel Pinero on the back nine today and tuok a onestroke lead into the final round of the 24th World Cup golf championship at the Mission Hills Country Club.

title: ART
Jail for Corporate Price Fixers?
description: The decision of Federal Judge James B. Parsons in Chicago to impose prison sentences on 15 of the 47 executives in the billiondollar folding carton industry charged with price fixing marks the culmination of an extraordinary effort by the Justice Department to seek incarceration of corporate criminals. wage Parsons, in a marathon sentencng proceeding on Nov. 29, refused to ncarcerate 33 defendants, imposed ientences of 10 days or less on 10 defendants, sentenced tour individuals to terms ranging from 30 to 60 days  and then stayed execution of all sentences until Jan. 10 to consider defense motions to reduce sentences. Hearings on the motions began last week.

title: NEW HOUSE LEADERS LIST CAMPAIGN GIFTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  The pervasive influence of money from special interest groups upon the 1976 Congressional elections and the lawmakers they produced is illuminated by the campaign records of the six men who were chosen this week as major House leaders for the next two years.

description: Dr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Austin Morris, to Richard Warren Blossdm, an assistant product manager with the General Foods Corporation.

description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 11  Mary Schneider's Sign of the Times, one of the more consistent fox chasers in the metropolitan area, scored 13 points and won the local working hunter championship today at the Boulder Brook indoor horse show.

title: The ExWife as Angry Victim
description: A RE you a victim, too? the visitor was asked as she entered the house. They had assembled, out of bitterness and despair, to promote enforcement of courtordered support and to seek new divorce legislation.

title: HOUSING FOR ACTORS UNDER FINAL STUDY
description: The plan to turn Manhattan Plaza, $951 million development west of Times Square into subsidized housing for performing artists is now in the final stases of consideration by the City Planning Commission, with a decision expected early next month.

title: A Master's Design Sails Again
description: DURING the last quarter of the last century the south shore of Suffolk was dotted with the summer estates of the wealthy. There were the Nicolls and Cuttings in Great River, the Vanderbilts in Oakdale, the Bournes in West Sayville and the Roosevelts in Sayville. Many of these families were yachting enthusiasts, and many of them bought their yachts from the same man Gil Smith of Patchogue.

title: Letters
description: Hooray for Roger Starr's article in praise of Making New York smaller (Nov. 14)! We loved our years in New York but yielded to a very amenable suburban area after realizing that a city that unrealistically allots most of its resources to welfare, housing and medical care for the poor has no hope of being decent for the middleclass resident. In the longrun, it would be kinder for New York to press on with family planning for the poor, to remove old, blighted housing so as not to attract more people it can house only poorly but not employ or educate, and to gradually increase its green areas. A smaller dependent population is the first step to building a healthier city.

description: CAMP KADUM, Israeli  Occupied West Bank, Dec. 8 A year ago today the Israeli Government told a zealous group of Israeli squatters that they could remain in their illegal settlement here for only three months while the Cabinet decided on the future of its West Bank settlement policy.

description: City Hall surrendered to a resolute band of Brooklynites yesterday and agreed to reopen a little firehouse in Greenpoint that has been occupied by community residents around the clock since its shutdown in the fiscal crisis year ago.

title: Government and Private Backers Face Huge Losses on New Towns
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 5  One of the Federal Government's most innovative approaches to housing, the new Communities program, has turned into multimilliondollar nightmare. governments that participated in building the experimental projects could lose an equal amount. Federal housing .officials have already begun to take steps to reduce future losses and are preparing paper recommending major changes the scope of the program and of Federal involvement in it.

title: Helene Bullard Rousseau, Bennett Alumna, Married in Southport to Stephen Epifano
description: In Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Helene Bullard Rousseau, daughter of Mrs. Henry Harwood Rousseau and the late Mr. Rousseau, was married to Stephen Barry Epifano, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Philip Epifano. Both families live in Fairfield, Conn.

title: GARDENING

title: Archeology, Medicine
description: ATHENSAccording to Greek legend, a man named Palecidets practiced medicine in the region at Nafplion during prehistoric times. Last year, while archeologists were exploring a fortress in that area they accidentally discovered a tomb from Mycenaean times, the Greek bronze age. Inside, they found set of medical instruments.

title: The State and Death
description: NEAR the gas chamber in the State Penitentiary in Canon City is a cabinet with a small brass tag for each person whose life was snuffed out by the State of Colorado. Almost 10 years have passed since Luis Jose Monge was gassed to death there on June 2, 1967, and his tag is so tarnished with age that it is difficult to make out that he was prisoner No. 35563.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 11 (AP) Housewives should exchange services and pay each other salaries so they can !cash in on employment benefits like Social Security and tax deductions, an economist suggests.

title: ATTEMPTS TO ABORT MANDEL TRIAL SHOWN
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 11  When the chief prosecutor in the aborted political corruption trial of Gov. Marvin Mandel was losing his argument in court earlier this week against defense demands for mistrial, he characterized the Government's case as besieged by sinister forces.

title: Poor and Hungry Haitians Sell Food Provided by an American Church
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 11 (AP) Thousands of cans of beef chunks destined for drought victims ended up on store shelves in PortauPrince earlier this year. But it wasn't because the poor didn't get the food.

title: PEOPLE
description: What's a biomedical ethicist? That's a good question, and the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has an answer for it, Russell L, McIntyre has just been appointed to the college faculty, and he's one of the few biomedical ethicists teaching in medical schools. Dr. Stanley S. Bergen Jr., president of the college, said that bringing in Dr. McIntyre represented an attempt to introduce students to the humanistic imIs curing enough or should the physician, for example, actively encourage better health practices? How far should go to try to change the destructive life style of a patient? Dr. McIntyre, trained as a theologian, described his role the medical school as a catalyst of all the humanities, such as ethics. sociology, psychology, religion, philosophy and the law. He and his wife, the former Christine Coats, and their two children live in Morristown.

title: Aides Say Beanie Still Seeks to Oust Hospital Corporation's Chief
description: Top Beame administration officials said last week that the Mayor was still actively seeking to oust Dr. John L. S. Holloman Jr. as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and to find a successor who, like Dr. Holloman. is black.

title: Article 7  No Title

For a long while, that was the high point of the season.

title: A Conciliator and a Good Listener With Few Enemies

title: Remembering Josephine

title: New For Home Handyman
description: Homeowners can cut down dramatically on the amount of water used for flushing toilets by installing a small gadget that fits into any standard flush tank. Called the Dual Flush, and manufactured by the Savway Company, 930 Clarkson Drive, Brooklyn N.Y. 11203, the device can be installed on the top edge of the tank with a screwdriver. What it does is create a twopart or dualflushing system in a standard flush tank For liquid waste or when a small child uses the toilet, the handle is depressed briefly in the normal way and released. This releases only half a tank of water instead of the full tankmore than enough to take care of liquid waste. When solid waste is to be disposed of the handle Is still depressed in the normal way, but this time it is held down a few seconds longer. This overrides the device and a full tank of water is released for full flushing. Priced at $4.98, the Dual Flush not only saves water (estimated savings are 1,500 gallons per month for a family of four), it also reduces the amount of cesspool cleaning required in houses that have cesspools.

title: What's Doing in the MIDHUDSON VALLEY
description: THE RIVER"Since Henry came up the river is a favorite method of dating time in the Hudson Valley. But the explorer probably gets more credit than he deserves. The captain of the Half Moon lost interest in the river that was to be named for him when his voyage, in 1609, proved that it was not the Northeast Passage to the Orient. It was left to later travel. ers to appreciate the beauty of the Hudson as it flows between the Catskills, to the west, and the rolling foothills of the Taconic and Berkshire ranges to the east; many have compared it to the great rivers of Europe. Despite the dep. redations of man and machine, the midHudson Valley is still striking. In winter especially, when the roads are less crowded, the woodlands somber and the stonefenced fields barren and austere, the valley makes quiet but strong impressions.

The designers who set these tables recommend combining shapes, materials and texturesmixing traditional silver and crystal with contemporary flatware, rattan and wood, for instance. And for centerpieces they strayed from formal floral arrangements, choosing instead a bush of heather, tied into the shape of a Christmas tree, a silver bowl set with a cluster of tiny pineapples, a lacquered Oriental box filled with blooming kalanchoe plants and a spruce tree, with roots intact.

title: Teaching the help a lesson
description: On Dec. 15, 1811, in Livingston County, Ky., two nephews of Thomas Jefferson committed one of the most grisly murders in the annals of American crime. Angered because an illgrown, ill  thrived slave named George had broken a pitcher, Lilburne and Isham Lewis decided to teach all their servants a lesson in obedience. Herding them into the kitchen cabin, which stood apart from the main plantation house, and bolting the door so that none could escape, Lilburne Lewis seized an axe and sank it deep into George's neck. The brothers then compelled one of the other slaves to complete the dismemberment of George's body, and as the pieces were whacked off, they tossed them onto the roaring fire so as to destroy all evidence of the crime. During the several hours required for this cremation, Lilburne lectured his horrorstriken slaves on their duties to their master and warned that if any one of them so much as whispered about George's murder he would receive the same punishment.

title: Killer Buried With Her Victims
description: UPPER ARLINGTON, Ohio, Dec, 11 (AP)A 40yearold woman who killed three members of her family before fatally shooting herself was buried with them today, Patricia Bolin shot her husband, Ronald, 43 years old, and two of her three childien, Todd, 9, and Tamela, 12, Wednesday night, the police said. title: Headliners
description: The trial of Maryland Gov. Marvin Mandel, who is accused of fraud and racketeering, has become a mistrial, on the ground that jurors were exposed to prejudicial publicity, after the proceedings had produced a substantial amount prosecution testimony damaging to the Governor. The prosecutors contend that the Governor used his influence to increase the value of a racetrack secretly owned by five friends, who are codefendants. In return, the prosecutors maintain, the friends gave Mr. Mandel expensive gifts and a valuable interest in other ventures. at almost no cost to him. A crucial point in the prosecution case is its allegation, supported by witnesses at the trial, that Mr. Mandel vetoed a bill to increase the number of racing days at the track but then arranged for an override by the State Senate when his friends, a short time after the veto, obtained their interest in the track. Other witnesses testified that Mr. Mandel had been financially rewarded for his efforts. The mistrial was declared because the judge believed that the jurors may have been influenced by news reports of alleged attempts to bribe one of them to vote for acquittal. No evidence linking the alleged bribery attempts to Mr. Mandel or his codefendants has been found, Federal authorities said. The incident apparently will complicate the prosecution's task in the Mandel case by making more difficult the selection of for trial.

title: Crowd pleasers

title: Georgia O'Keeffe
description: As this beautiful book makes clear, the career of Georgia O'Keeffe is unlike almost any other in the history of modern art in America. It is a career that embraces not one or another phase of that history, but virtually the whole of itfrom the early years of the century, when Alfred Stieglitz (whom she married in 1924) mounted the first shocking exhibitions of the new art to be seen in New York, to the present day when modern art is firmly established as both a glory and a commonplace of our culture. For some 60 yearssince her first solo exhibition at Stieglitz's 291 gallery in 1916she has been recognized, first by a small circle of modernist acolytes and eventually by the world at large, as an artist of special distinction. Today, at the age of 89, she remains a vital figure, first of all as a painter of remarkable originality and power but also as a precious link with the first generation of American modernists.

title: Daylight
description: Almost any way you look at it. December is the year's shortest month. Anyone who insists that February shorter is simply niggling. True, December has thirtyone days, but can you honestly call those frantic little spans of daylight that come zipping past between Thanksgiving and Christmas days? Pause long enough to check them off on the calendar and you have no time to keep track. The turkey vanishes and right in front of you is the tree, waiting to be decorated. Then someone shouts, Happy New Year! and that is the end of December.
