title: Soybean Futures Prices Close at $6.77 a Bushel, Posting a Sharp Decline
description: Soybean prices dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, where the January contract closed at $6.77 a bushel, down from $6.91. Prices of soybean oil were also lower, with the January delivery ending at 20.70 cents a pound down from 21.12.

title: PENN CENTRAL FILES ITS REORGANIZATION WITH FEDERAL COURT
description: The bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company filed yesterday a reorganization plan with proposals for settling close to $1 billion in government and individual claims against the company.

title: HELEN NESSA COHEN, 92, A PAINTER AND SCULPTOR
description: Helen Nessa Cohen, an artist, died Thursday at the ColumbusItalian Hospital division of the Cabrini Health Care Center. She was 92 years old and lived at 208 West 23d Street.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Paralysis of 7 Latest Problem For Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 17This has been, as one Pittsburgher said, the Year of the Strange Disease in western Pennsylvania.

title: ABC's Exclusive Olympic Rights Apparently Over
description: ABC's exclusive televised coverage of the summer Olympics, which began in 1968 with the games in Mexico City, is at an apparent end.

title: WORLD OIL BUSINESS THROWN INTO CHAOS
description: The international oil business was thrown into chaos yesterday by the announcement from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries of a twotiered pricing system that is expected to cost the world $10 billion more a year for crude oil.

title: No Sign That Britain Will Coalesce
description: LONDONDespite the damp reaction to Chancellor Denis Healey's deal with world bankers and muted British financial optimism, the chances are this Labor ministry will stagger well into 1977 at the very least, hoping for an upward turn. One sure thing, whatever happens, is that this country will not resort to peacetime coalition government again.

title: Charles Douglas Is Dead at 75, Retired Fiat Chemicals President
description: Charles V. Douglas, founder and retired president of Fiat Chemicals Inc. of Great Neck, L. I., died Thursday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He lived at 217 Ridge Road, Douglaston, Queens, and was 75 years old.

title: American Can Gets Rights To Conveyor System
description: The American Can Company announced that its machine technology division had obtained proprietary rights to a recently patented selfaccumulating conveyer system from Phillips & Roberts Ltd., a British company. It described the system as being less complex and more reliable than conventional industrial conveyors.

title: Kaiser Steel Spending
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation of Oakland, Calif., said it was prepared to spend an additional $7.8 million over the next two years for coke oven emission control. The company said that if the commitment was approved it would bring the company's total estimated future costs for air quality control at its Fontana, Calif., coke works to $46.6 million.

title: Stocks Decline After Advance On OPEC News
description: The stock market finished slightly lower yesterday after an early show of strength that greeted the news of a pricing split within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1976

title: Fed Acts Again to Expand Available Credit Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The Federal Reserve Board announced today a further small step toward making more credit available in the economy. The central bank said that it was reducing by about $550 million the volume of reserves that banks are required to retain against the checking account deposits that they hold.

title: HERBERT JOHN BURGSTAHLER
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 17Herbert John Burgstahler, an educator and theologian, who was president of Cornell College in Mount Vernon, Iowa, and president and later chancellor of Ohio Wesleyan in Delaware, Ohio, died here yesterday. He was 90 years old.

title: Soviet to Free Leading Dissident In Trade for Chilean Communist
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17The Soviet Union's most prominent imprisoned dissident, Vladimir K. Bukovsky, is being freed in exchange for the release by Chile of the jailed chief of the Chilean Communist Party, Mr. Bukovsky's mother reported today.

title: Death Penalty Seen as Way to Die For Suicidal Type Without Nerve
description: The annals of psychiatry contain many cases in which persons who led tormented, and often demented, lives murdered others with the intention of invoking a death penalty that would bring them surcease. Many are clearly suicidal and believe that they deserve to die but admit they lack the nerve to kill themselves.

title: Gasoline to Cost About a Penny a Gallon More; Slight Rises Due for Utility Bills and Air Fares
description: Consumers across the nation are expected to pay more for gasoline, utilities and air fares as a result of the crudeoil price increases agreed to late Thursday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

description: For periods ended Oct. 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) Over the Counter.

title: Ashe, Tanner Give U.S. A 20 Lead Over Mexico
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 17He didn't sleep well last night, was more nervous than for the semifinals at Wimbledon or Forest Hills and lost five of the first six games today.

title: Turning Back To the Campus
description: I am writing to solicit your support for an entirely new kind of American institution. I propose to call it uncollege. Its tasks will be diseducation and detraining. The need for such an institution is desperate. Its contributions to American life will be immense. Please bear with me while I outline the case.

title: Florida Cabinet Votes to Abandon Army Corps Barge Canal Project
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 17Governor Reubin Askew and the Florida Cabinet voted 6 to 1 today to recommend a halt to the partly completed CrossFlorida Barge Canal, a $425 million project begun nearly 40 years ago and never finished because of the environmental and economic controversy it generated in the Sunshine State.

title: Pope to Celebrate New Year's Mass
description: ROME, Dec. 17 (UPI)Pope Paul VI will celebrate mass on New Year's Day in the Church of Mary, Queen of the Apostles, in a southern suburb of Rome, the Vatican said today.

title: Why Not Send the Best as Ambassadors?
description: WASHINGTONPublicly lecturing the incoming Carter Administration on what it should do has become a national pastime. With respect to ambassadorial appointments, several commentators have urged the Presidentelect to confine his nominations to career officers. On the other side, one New York Times columnist has characterized the call by the American Foreign Service Association to stress professionalism in ambassadorial appointments as a power grab.

title: Calder Stabile Takes Shape As His Monument for Jerusalem
description: TOURS, FranceThe creative genius of Alexander Calder, who died last Nov. 11 in New York, still inspires work here on what could become his most monumental achievement, a sculpture for Jerusalem.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)Reversing an earlier decision, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it was willing to hear a proposal to fly passengers coast to coast for $89, about half the present commercial airline fare.

title: Simon Can't Keep Gifts From Foreign Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon may not pay for and keep some gifts he received from foreign governments, the State Department informed him today.

title: Brezhnev at 70
description: In the rituals of the Soviet Communist Party, the 70th birthday of a top leader is a very special occasion. Just how very special was revealed in 1949, when celebration of Stalin's birthday was made one of the most elaborate propaganda occasions in all Soviet history, beginning months before the event and continuing for months afterward. Nikita Khrushchev's 70th birthday party in 1964 wasin contrasta relatively quiet affair, but he could hardly have expected more, given his personal drive against selfaggrandizement and the cult of personality.

title: Congressional Freshmen Return to School
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 17 Trooping across the snowcovered Harvard Yard in their blue jeans, sweaters and duffle coats, some of them looked like graduate students in the tow of an amiable professor.

title: Tremont Temple Quits the Bronx
description: SCARSDALE, Dec. 17Tremont Temple, for more than half a century the most prominent Reform synagogue in the Bronx and one of the best known in the city, moved to Scarsdale tonight.

title: Jersey Bill Would Require Brides To Be Tested for Rubella Immunity
description: A blood test to determine whether women of childbearing age are susceptible to rubellaGerman measlesis likely to be established as a prerequisite to marriage in New Jersey.

title: Chorus Line, With a New Cast, Still Hottest Ticket for a Reason
description: The sheer expectations aroused by a hit show are really unfair. Take A Chorus Line, still at the Shubert Theater after more than a year and more than 18 months since it started downtown with Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival. It is, even now, still the hottest ticket in town.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A Surprise Bouquet Delivered to Door Fresh Each Week for Less Than $10
description: Almost every Tuesday Dorothea Elkon receives a bouquet of flowers. It arrives early in the morning and is placed outside the door of her Park Avenue apartment. She never knows what kind of flowers will be there, not even what color.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article in The Times Friday the Ideal Corporation was incorrectly identified as the Ideal Toy Corporation.

title: Hull, Though Ailing, Is Favorite at Soviet Tourney
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17In the dank, bare hallways outside the rink where Soviet hockey fans drink their watery beer and munch on sandwiches of curling cheese, they still line up for souvenir post cards of Bobby Hull. Next to the other black and white cards with the flat look of 1940's photography picturing such Soviet stars as Aleksandr Maltsev, Aleksandr Yakushev and Vladislav Tretiak, there is Hull's generous smile and the face that always seems to be squinting into the sun.

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended Dec. 17, 1976

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Dec. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)A wellinformed Chinese source said today that a kind of big public trial, where the accused is expected to be Chiao Kuanhua, dismissed as Foreign Minister on Dec. 2, is likely to be held here tomorrow afternoon.

title: Seoul Said to Act to End Dispute Over Charges of Bribing Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The South Korean Government has begun negotiations with American diplomats in an effort to settle the scandal generated by allegations of Korean bribery of American Congressmen, according to Korean sources here.

title: Meadowlands
description: Aqueduct Jockeys

title: Aid for Chile's Junta?
description: Unless the Ford Administration has a lastminute change of mind, the United States next week will support two World Bank loans totaling $60 million for Chile's military dictatorship.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONAn automatic electronic device, invented by a New York pathologist, can, he says, measure and record a patient's blood pressure, temperature, pulse and breathing rate in one minute.

title: CARTER TO APPOINT IDAHO'S GOV. ANDRUS INTERIOR SECRETARY
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 17Presidentelect Jimmy Carter will name Gov. Cecil D. Andrus of Idaho as his Secretary of the Interior tomorrow and has all but decided to ask Congress to create a new Cabinetlevel energy department, to be headed by James R. Schlesinger.

title: OPEC Rise to Add To Consumer Costs
description: Consumers across the nation are expected to pay more for gasoline, utilities and air fares as a result of the oil price increases set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: WatsonMiss Post Team Leads Mixed Golf
description: MIAMI, Dec. 17Tom Watson and Chi Chi Rodriguez have quickly become convinced men and women have a place together in professional golf, and, generally, the partners playing here in the PepsiCola mixed team championship are developing a deep respect for one another.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Fiftyseven years ago, New York City lent City College an original folio of John James Audubon's Birds of America. Yesterday, the 435 prints of the double elephant folio as it is known because of the size of the prints, was returned to the city in a brief ceremony at City Hall. A spokesman for City College said the rare, fourvolume, first edition was originally purchased by the city in 1850 for $1,000 and now had an estimated value of $300,000. City College agreed to return the books earlier this year because it learned that the Municipal Research and Reference Center was searching for the missing set. While the books will not be kept at the reference center, they will remain available to the college when it wants to display them.

title: Article 4  No Title
The Reborn Redskin Blocks Punts
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 17In his dreams, the retired pro football player knows the phone will ring. His coach will be'calling. His coach needs him again. His coach knows he'll make a big play in a big game. His coach will persuade his boss to grant him a leave of absence through the Super Bowl because his coach always assumes his team will win. In reality, the phone never rings for most retired pro football players. But for Bill Malinchak, the phone rang. Bill Malinchak will be playing for the Washington Redskins tomorrow against the Minnesota Vikings in the National Football League playoffs. It's like being reborn, he says. When the Redskins' coach, George Allen, cut Bill Malinchak in training camp before the 1975 season, Bill Malinchak sold real estate in Florida for several months, then moved to New York as a trainee at the Commodity Exchange on Broad Street where about $300 million in gold, silver and copper is traded daily. But on Tuesday night before Thanksgiving, with only three weekends remaining in the N.F.L'chedule, Bill Malinchak was in his East Side bachelor apartment when the phone rang. Tim Temerario, the Redskins' personnel director, was calling.

title: GEORGE EASTMENT, TRACK COACH, DIES
description: George Eastment, probably the most successful track coach ever in the metropolitan area, died yesterday afternoon at his home in Riverdale. He was 72 years old.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1976

title: Dance: ChoreoMutation Company
description: ChoreoMutationis a company that doesn't strike out in new paths, but experiments with changes in wellworn paths. It is an energetic and brightly talented group of performers driven to do their own thing but not far from their creative roots. The program presented at American Theater Laboratory Friday evening was engaging without in any way being daring.

title: WADE WOODWARD
description: Wade Woodward, a retired book publisher and father of Joanne Woodward, the actress, died Thursday at his home in Decatur, Ga. He was 75 years old.

title: Experts Call Suspension of Shots Last Blow to Swine Flu Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Even if investigation completely vindicates the swine flu vaccine, many public health experts and others believe the muchtroubled national immunization program is dead as a result of the current suspension imposed because of a possible link to another malady.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Officials Get More Reports Of Rare Paralytic Syndrome in U.S.
description: Federal health officials received more reports of a rare paralytic syndrome yesterday, one day after they suspended the nationwide swine influenza program as epidemiologists throughout the country prepared to begin an exhaustive search for every case of the condition.

title: For Some Opera Singers, Cooking Can Be a Tranquilizer
description: Food is quite important to opera singers, and even those who manage to stay slim still have to keep their vocal equipment well fueled if they are to produce tones that soar over a full orchestra.

title: NEW YORK DROPPING SUIT AGAINST S. E. C.
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that New York City was dropping its lawsuit challenging the right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate allegations of fraud in past and present city fiscal practices.

title: For South Africa Whites, It's Still Paradise
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 17By the measures an outsider uses, it's been a frightful year. The economy, already on the decline for two years, is still heading down. The racial issue, always a menace to the country's future, exploded at midyear with the most violent disturbances ever to wrack the black community. But out in the lush northern suburbs of this sundrenched city, scarcely 15 miles from the black township of Soweto, the life of comfort continues much as before.

title: Article 1  No Title
Judge Halts East Rutherford Tax on Track Patrons
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 17East Rutherford's new law to impose a 5cent admission tax on each patron at the Meadowlands Race Track was temporarily blocked in Superior Court today, pending a ruling on the legality of the levy.

title: Seminary Finds Success Isn't Just an Academic Issue
description: Bill Webber rushes in where angels probably never thought to tread.

title: Music:
description: Last night's program by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center started. slowly enough, and then built to a wonderful evening. The first two pieces were a Cherubini Sonata for Horn and a Mozart Divertimento. But then came the American premiere of the Shostakovich Viola Sonata and Schubert's B flat Trio.

title: Singer Agrees to Sell Tufting Unit's Assets
description: The Singer Company announced that it had agreed in principle to sell substantially all the assets of its tufting division to Spencer Wright Industries Inc., a new corporation. Singer announced earlier this month that it was terminating a variety of its business operations, including knitting, tufting, mailing equipment, venture capital and traffic control.

title: Article 3  No Title
PRELATE'S OUSTER URGED FOR ALLEGED AID TO NAZIS
description: Four of the top leaders of American Judaism joined more than 300 young Jews Thursday in a demonstration calling upon the governing board of he National Council of Churches to oust Archbishop Valerian Trifa for allegedly murdering thousands of Jews and Christians in Rumania in 1941.

title: George Eastment Dies
description: George Eastment, who coached track and field at Bishop Loughlin High School and Manhattan College, died yesterday. His obituary appears on Page 26.

title: Undefeated St. John's Vanquishes S.M.U., 87 to
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 17 (AP)Glen Williams and George Johnson scored 23 points each tonight in leading unbeaten St. John's to 8771 victory over Southern Methodist in the opening game of the Volunteer Classic basketball tournament. Cecil Rellford added 22 points to the Redmen's total as they won their sixth game.

title: Counsel for Players Union Tells Of Early Plans to Join Finley Suit
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UPI)Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's voiding of the sale of three players by the Oakland A's caused concern in the players association that he would assume powers to interfere with players' rights, an attorney for the association testified today in United States District Court.

title: People and Business
description: All Nippin Airways, Japan's largest airline passenger carrier, approved the appointment yesterday of a new president, Nasami Chi Anzai. He replaces Tokuji Wakasa, who is now under indictment in connection with the multimilliondollar Lockheed payoff scandal.

title: Perjury Indictment of De Sapio Dismissed for Lack of Evidence
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesteday dismissed a perjury indictment against Carmine G. De Sapio, the former leader of Tammany Hall.

title: Gasoline Price Drops
description: The average retail price of regular gasoline in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area dropped 0.3 percent between September and October to 60.7 cents a gallon, the United States Department of Labor reported yesterday. The average price of premium gasoline dropped 0.2 percent to 66.4 cents a gallon.

title: SAUDIS WARN THE WEST TO SHOW APPRECIATION OF OILPRICE RESTRAINT
description: DOHA, Qatar, Dec. 17Saudia Arabia warned today that it was prepared to increase production to hold down the world price of oil, which other producers decided to raise to 15 percent in two stages next year. But it also warned the West, and especially the United States, that it expected a show of appreciation with responsive measures in both the ArabIsraeli conflict and the northsouth negotiations between industrialized and developing countries.

title: Spain Rejects Abductors' Demands
description: MADRID, Dec. 17The Government tonight made a dramatic televised rejection of increased demands by the kidnappers of the rightwing president of the advisory Council of State.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.

title: Saudis Linking Oil and Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17The diplomatic consequences of Saudi Arabia's decision to hold down an increase in the price of oil seem at least to equal, if not outweigh, the economic importance of the move. The Saudis have now publicly linked the oil issue with the need for the United States to bring about an. overall ArabIsraeli settlement. This has added a dramatic new element in the complicated diplomacy of the Middle East. It has raised all sorts of possi, bilities for future American diplomacy, but it also carries with it the possibility of tragic misunderstandings if the anti. cipated moves by the Carter administration next year fail to produce significant results.

title: Aerosmith's HighEnergy Rock Executed With Clarity, Humor
description: Three years ago, this reporter ventured up to the Bronx to cover the Kinks at a college date. The opening act was an outfit called Aerosmith, and they were not very impressive. The lead singer was the baldest imitation of Mick Jagger that one could ever hope to encounter, and the band cranked out loud, crude, not very vital rockandroll.

title: Role of South Vietnam Detailed at Party Congress
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 17Communist leaders from the southern part of Vietnam spoke at the party congress today in support of the northerners who have dominated the four days of meetings.

title: Elizabeth B. Cowles Dies at 76; Founded Planned Parenthood
description: Elizabeth Bates Cowles, wife of John Cowles Sr., former president and chairman of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, died yesterday in Minneapolis at the age of 76.

title: For the HardtoPlease Someone
description: Pretzel sales outside H. Stern jewelers, at 645 Fifth Avenue yesterday appeared brisk, but diamonds were moving slowly. With seven shopping days left to Christmas, though, there was still the hope that business might pick up. Anyway, it was only the first day the merchandise was on display.

title: Public Controversy Helps Carter In Selecting Cabinet, Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17One of Presidentelect Jimmy Carter's top assistants asserted today that Mr. Carter was deliberately subjecting his prospective Cabinet members to public controversy as a means of narrowing his choices.

title: Luis Corvalan Lepe
description: Longtime leader of the Communist Party in Chile . . . A dominant figure in the Marxist policies of President Salvador Allende Gossens . . . Short, 60yearold former Senator in Chile with manner of a provincial teacher . . . jailed soon after the military overthrow and death of President Allende in 1973 . . . Moscow has pressed a persistent international campaign for his release.

title: United Files New Service
description: United Airlines announced the filing of an application with the Civil Aeronautics Board for a nonstop route between Cleveland and San Diego. The airline, which currently holds onestop authority between the two cities, estimated that on the basis of proposed service in 1978 the nonstop route would bring revenue of $8,466,000 and an operating profit of $1,433,000.

title: Aides Follow Coach to Pitt
description: PULLMAN, Wash., Dec. 17 (AP)Two Washington State assistant football coaches have resigned to join the staff of Jackie Sherrill, the former Cougar coach, at topranked Pittsburgh. Bob Leahy, offensive coordinator, and Rod Kirby, linebacker coach, left for Pittsburgh this week.

title: Key Figures in Move by OPEC
description: Saudi Arabia's powerful Minister of Petroleum and Mineral Resources was appointed to his post in 1962 by the late King Faisal, who considered him a son.... He is a commoner by backgrounddescended from desert tribesmen but his father was Chief Justice or Saudi Arabia. . . . Reputed to have less power now than under the reign of King Faisal as the royal family seems to make the final decisions on Saudi oil policy.... The 46yearold oil minister spearheaded the drive to wrest control of his country's oil resources from foreignowned companies and has a degree from the Harvard Law School.... Dress ranges from long white Arab robes to Pierre Cardin suits. . . . Frequently toys with worry beads although never looks worried and writes poetry in Arabic in his spare time.... Married to his second wife, 24 year  old Tamam Mohammed alAnbar.... First wife lives in Switzerland with two children.

title: Simon Halts Bid to Collect Tax On Employee Fringe Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Treasury Secretary, William E. Simon, halted today a Government move to collect taxes on fringe benefits provided to employees, sources said.

title: For Brezhnev on 70th Birthday, Praise, Medals, Films and a Bust
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 17Leonid L Brezhnev will celebrate his 70th birthday on Sunday at the end of a long drumroll of honors, medals and Personal tributes.

title: Warriors Top 76ers, 117114; Barry Excels
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 (AP)Golden State's Rick Barry, the game's high scorer with 34 points, dropped in two free throws with two seconds remaining to clinch the Warriors' 117114 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: Books of The Times
description: At the age of 48, five years into a happy second marriage. 12 years and two books after he had quit The Atlanta Journal because they wouldn't let him write columns about the Southern civilrights movement of the 1960's, Pat Watters lost his job. He was laid off by the Southern Regional Council, a domod organization in financial trouble. The council had to cut back on staff, and Mr. Watters, who is white, was one of the first to go. Members of the executive committee felt that the directorship of a project on investigative journalism in which he was interested should be given, instead, to a black person.

title: Talks in Ballet Strike Reported at Standstill
description: No progress was reported toward settling the musicians' strike against the New York City Ballet, which began last Monday. The company's performances of The Nutcracker remained indefinitely canceled.

title: Site Sought for the Battleship New Jersey
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 17A state commission toured Liberty Park here today while city officials sought to persuade it that this was the ideal spot to berth the battleship New Jersey, the most decorated combat vessel in United States history, as a museum.

title: Rapaport Resigns As Head of Sucrest In Inventory Inquiry
description: Robert M. Rapaport, president and a director of the Sucrest Corporation, one of the country's largest sugar refiners, resigned Wednesday as a result of a continuing investigation by the company into certain rawsugar inventory transactions and other matters.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Tanker Explodes in Los Angeles Harbor; At Least 2 Crewmen Killed and 22 Hurt
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17An oil tanker exploded and burned tonight in Los Angeles harbor, killing at least two crewmen and injuring 22 others.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Scranton Wrote Young on Worth of U.N. Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17With some of the hesitation natural to a Republican politician addressing a Democratic politician in the postelection season, William W. Scranton wrote Andrew Young a month ago hoping to whet his appetite for the job of American representative at the United Nations.

title: Bojangles!, Charming Stage Tribute
description: Bojangles is a tribute without the complacency of most tributes. It isin spirita oneman show, without the grandiloquent monomania of most oneman shows. It is a series of vignettes from the life and work of the black tapdancer Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, and it is a delight.

title: Triumph for the Slow Break
description: CATAWBA, N.C., Dec. 17 (AP)A basketball rarity, a shutout, was registered by the NewtonConover High School's junior varsity girls' team when it defeated Bandys, 90, last night. Just as rare was Crystal Sweet's performance. She scored all 9 points as NewtonConover shot 4 for 7 from the floor.

title: CHONG RYULSONG
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 18 (AP)Chong Ryulsong, composer of the anthem of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, died Dec. 7 in Peking, the official Hsinhua press agency reported today. He was 58 years old.

title: Missing Baby Found Unharmed
description: HAWTHORNE, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI)Jason Timothy Bustillos, a 6monthold baby reported stolen from his crib last Monday, was returned unharmed to his parents last night. The child was found by San Bernardino County sheriff's deputies lying in a cardboard box in the back of a bar in Ontario, 45 miles northeast of this Los Angeles suburb.

title: Experts Call Suspension of Shots Last Blow to Swine Flu Program
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Even if investigation completely vindicates the swine flu vaccine, many public health experts and others believe the muchtroubled national immunization program is dead as a result of the current suspension imposed because of a possible link to another malady.

title: First Road Victory for Milwaukee
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 17The homeless masses of the National Basketball Association have found as friendly a landmark in the Nassau Coliseum as European immigrants found in the Statue of Liberty. Tonight the Milwaukee Bucks breathed free and won for the first time on the road this season as they trounced the New York Nets, 126110.

title: Seminary Finds Success Isn't Just an Academic Issue
description: Bill Webber rushes in where angels probably never thought to tread.

title: Times Widens Top News Team As Part of Its Expansion Program
description: An expansion of the news management group of The New York Times, involving the promotion of several senior editors, was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times.

title: Art in Metal and Wood
description: The current exhibition and sale of jewelry and boxes at the Florence Duhl Gallery, embraces the work of four metalsmiths and four woodworkers to provide a study in contrasts.

title: ExRep. Hastings Guilty in Kickback Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)Former Representative James F. Hastings, an Allegany, N.Y., Republican, was convicted by a Federal District Court jury here tonight on charges that he accepted salary kickbacks from two parttime employees in his Congressional district.

title: Juvenile Crime Laws
description: The flight of Ronald Timmons coupled with a rash of fellpublicized crimes against old people has begun to stir the kind of legislative interest that makes for fat headlines, if not good legislation. At a recent hearing of the United States House of Representatives Committee on the Aging, New York State Senator Ralph J. Marino, chairman of the Senate crime committee, said that he intended to introduce a bill next session that would send juveniles as young as 13, who have been charged with attacking the elderly, to the adult criminal courts.

title: Abortion Conviction of Boston Doctor Upset
description: BOSTON, Dec. 17The manslaughter conviction of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin in one of the nation's most famous abortion cases was overturned unanimously today by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT WASHINGTON

title: Miki's Resignation Follows 2 Years Of Bickering, Scandal and Inaction
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17Prime Minister Takeo Miki's announced decision today to resign the leadership of Japan's governing LiberalDemocratic Party effectively ends a twoyear political rule dominated by intense power struggles within the party, scandal and little legislative action.

title: CarterArtis Trial Is Expected to Go To Jury Tuesday
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 17On the last of 30 days of testimony in the triplemurder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis, the prosecution attacked the credibility of a television reporter who said he had heard two former prosecution witnesses recant testimony that they gave in the defendants' first trial, in 1967.

title: Rhodesian Troops and Warplanes Again Strike Into Mozambique
description: UMTALI, Rhodesia, Dec. 17 (Reuters)Rhodesian troops backed by jet fighters and light bombers struck into neighboring Mozambique today in pursuit of a group of black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Saudis Bar Old Ships To Unclog Main Ports
description: An official notification to shipping and trade concerns that cargo vessels more than 15 years old will be barred from discharging cargo at Saudi Arabian ports was explained by the Saudi Consulate General here yesterday as a major move aimed at easing increasing non congestion.

title: Hugh Stewart Johnson Jr., a Good Ol' Boy
description: VERY AFTERNOON when the legislature wasn't in session, Hugh Stewart Johnson Jr., Democrat of Rose Hill, Duplin County, North Carolina, put on his red hunter's cap, packed up scraps for his dogs, and took off in his babyblue Chevrolet pickup truck to the deer camp.

title: 13 Are Indicted in BloodTest Fraud
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17A Federal grand jury today returned an indictment against 13 defendants, including 10 San Diego doctors, accusing them of a criminal conspiracy to defraud the Government of more than $500,000 in excessive Medicare charges.

title: Frenchmen Score Upset In Sunshine Cup Tennis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP)Unseeded Gilles Morreton and Yannich Noah of France upset Secondseeded Fernando Dallas Fontana and Alex Gattiker of Argentina in today's quarterfinals of the Sunshine Cup Matches Between tennis tournament.

title: The Complexities of Rearing an Adopted Child
description: ARDSLEY, N. Y.When we adopted our son ten years ago, we saw him one day, then had to wait 24 hours before we could take him home. Why? we asked. The caseworker explained: Sometimes people discover at the last moment that adoption isn't for them. They say, The baby isn't what we expected. Or, He's too tiny. Then we know they will never adopt a child.

title: Events Today
description: BUGS BUNNY FOLLIES, Madison Square Garden, through Jan. 2, 10:30 A.M. and 2.

title: Kitchen Electrics Ringing Register In Holiday Buying
description: What's hot for Christmas? Retailers across the nation size up today's customers as just about the most selective and practicalbut comfortlovingshoppers in years. At least, that seems to be reflected in the kind of gifts they are buying this holiday season.

title: Music
description: Because Handel's Messian is so crusted over with tradition, good and bad, and entangled so hopelessly in its own performance history, there can be no such thing as an authentic version of this inescapably great and, at this season, greatly inescapable, oratorio. The version presented at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, for example, by the Oratorio Society of New York, could be attacked on most historical counts, and defended on many.

title: GERMANS HOLD A SUSPECT IN $8 MILLION KIDNAPPING
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Dec. 17 (UPI)Police arrested one man and sought others today in the kidnapping of a mulitmillionaire's son who suffered a broken leg and vertebra and was tortured with electric shocks by his abductors. None of the $8.77 million ransom was recovered.

title: Oil Decision Lifts London Stocks; Increase Is Sharpest in 18 Months
description: LONDON, Dec. 17 (Reuters)  Stock prices in London showed their sharpest rise in 18 months today following the splitprice oil decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Text of Oil Ministers' Statement
description: The 48th meeting of the conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was held in Doha, Qatar, from the 15th to the 17th December 1976. His highness, Khalifa bin Hamad alThani, emir of the state of Qatar, addressed and formally opened the conference. The conference unanimously elected as its president H. E. Abdul Aziz bin Khalifa alThani, Minister of Finance and Petroleum of Qatar and head of its delegation; H. E. Col. Mohammed Buhari, Commissioner for Petroleum Reources of Nigeria and head of its delegation, was reelected alternate president.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: FOR a man leaving Congress after 18 years, Representative Dominick V. Daniels, Democrat of Union City, sure didn't act like a man about to retire. Although he had been a lame duck since last May, he still scheduled district office hours on his 68th birthday anniversary in October.

title: Bukovsky and Corvalan Exchanged at Zurich Airport
description: ZURICH, Dec. 18 (AP) Vladimir K. Bukovsky, a leading Soviet dissident, and Luis Corvaln Lepe, the Chilean Communist leader, have been freed from prisons in their homelands and flown here for an exchange today that was mediated by the United States.

title: Paul Terence Schubert Marries Gail Campbell
description: Gail Meurlin Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Campbell Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Terence Schubert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Schubert of Freeport, L.I. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Design
description: The Village of Loon Mountain, a resort community on the Kancamagus Highway in Lincoln, N.H., was launched at the worst possible momentthe summer preceding the oil embargo in 1973, which kept Americans off the roads temporarily and delayed their plans to buy or build a second home. Two mild winters in succession also plagued the ski communities of the Northeast and further discouraged the sale of recreational properties. That the Village of Loon Mountain survived and even prospered seems to prove that enlightened site planning, fine architecture and good management do make difference.

title: BRIDGE
description: Many systems that might seem to be of interest only to bridge historians nevertheless leave their mark on bidding theory. Harold Vanderbilt's original Strong Club system, which followed closely on his invention of contract scoring in 1925, received no attention at all from the public; but the idea was revived with great success by the Italians in the fifties and now has many descendants. The authorities who banded together to produce The Official System in the early thirties were completely defeated by Ely Culbertson in their battle for public support, but history has given them the last laugh. Everyone nowadays uses the 4321 point count that they advocated, while honor tricks have totally vanished, and tournament players today overwhelmingly prefer their strong artificial twoclub opening to Culbertson's Strong Twos. And although the Four Aces in the thirties could win with their system but not sell it, their idea of making prepared openings in a threecard minstandard practice.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: COMMITTEES abound. Governments delay decision by creating them. Cities give municipal recognition to deserving citizens by concocting committees and putting these citizens on them. But, then, lest the committees begin to think they should function usefully, the city or town or boroughwhatever the political divisionignores the committee, except to praise it when it dissolves.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: Children's Games: A Lesson for Adults
description: A store selling auto parts formed one arm of the L, a wooden house and a body shop the other. In the angle, that sultry afternoon, I counted 10 children, all busy. Though the temperature was climbing through the 90's, they were running races.

title: California Aide Says Blacks Plan To Finance University in Grenada
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Dec. 18 (AP) A group of black Americans is planning to finance establishment of a university on the Caribbean island of Grenada, Lieut. Gov. Mervyn M. Dymally of California said yesterday.

title: OTTO BRODNITZ
description: Otto Brodnitz, a retired stockbroker, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 450 East 63d Street.

title: Oil And Politics
description: OPEC has spoken, but for the first time the oil producers have spoken with a divided voice: The different economic and political wishes of its members transcended the need of any cartel to act unanimously. As a result, all that is certain is that when the new year starts, the price of oil will be higher by at least 5 percentbut how much more, and who will pay what price, is a matter for the future.

title: Human Toll Is Exacted By City Budget Slashes
description: In his Tale of Two Cities, Charles Dickens might have been alluding to the climate of recent times in New York City when he wrote: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, we had everything before us, we had nothing before us.

title: Shirley Day Fiancee Of Robert W.Harrell
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Day of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., of the engagement of their daughter, Shirley Susan Day, to Robert W. Harrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harrell of Portsmouth, Va.

title: CrimeData Rule Is Eased by Police
description: TORN between upholding the constitutional rights of prospective defendants and complying with the public's right to know, the New Jersey state police have begun a program aimed at satisfying both demands when disseminating news about crime and traffic accidents.

title: Liberty ParkShaping a Dream
description: AFTER lying in disgrace for decades, Liberty Park, the anteroom of New York Harbor, is being redecorated under an ambitious statesponsored plan that will eventually provide residents of the Carden State with a majestic place from which to make a grand entrance into New York City.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Furry Nuisances

title: Eric Langslet Plans to Marry Miss Patterson
description: Elizabeth Burwell Patterson of New York, a computer project manager for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, and Eric Bjarne Langslet of Hillsdale, N.J., president of the Telson Corporation, a Dumont, N.J., distributor of industrial adhesive tape products, will be married in April.

title: Meadowlands
description: Time 2:03.

title: Quebec's Government Plans to Revise Law to Reinforce Position of French as Key Language in Province
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 18Quebec's new government has begun efforts to reinforce the position of French as the only official working language of this province.

title: Dorsett Reaps Records As He Leads Pitt to Top
description: The University of Pittsburgh and its outstanding tailback, Tony Dorsett, were the No. 1 team and No. 1 player in the nation. The Panthers won all of their games and Dorsett won the Heisman Trophy. Then Johnny Majors, the Pitt coach, walked out on the Panthers. Never before had a coach resigned from the most successful team in a college season. But Majors wanted to go home and coach at his alma mater. Tennessee, rather than try to keep Pittsburgh at the top without the graduating Dorsett. Majors, Dorsett and the other Panthers will be together one more timeagainst Georgia in the Sugar Bowl Jan. 1 at New Orleans.

title: East Side Temple Hoping for a Hanukkah Miracle
description: Hanukkah, the eightday Jewish holiday that began Thursday at sundown, recalls the victory of Judah the Maccabee over the Syrians in 165 B.C. when the Maccabees reclaimed and rededicated the temple of Jerusalem. Legend has it that there was only enough oil in the temple lamp to keep it burning for one day, but miraculously it burned for eight.

title: Headliners
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court has overturned the manslaughter conviction of Dr. Kenneth C. Edelin, the physician accused in the death of a fetus during a legal abortion. The prosecution had contended that Dr. Edelin's removal of the 2024weekold fetus constituted manslaughter on the theory that the fetus was actually alive within the woman's body. But the court ruled that a doctor only commits manslaughter if he ends the life of a fetus that is definitely alive outside of a woman's body. Dr. Edelin's conviction occurred two years after the United States Supreme Court ruled that state courts cannot interfere with a woman's right to an abortion, but before Massachusetts passed a liberalized abortion law ?? its own.

title: Sabres' 3dPeriod Goals Overwhelm Islanders, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 18The Islanders, who thought they owned the Buffalo Sabres by virtue of seven straight triumphs over them, had to take inventory tonight after losing, 42, to their upstate visitors.

title: Scarcity of Snow in West Costs Ski Resorts Millions in Losses
description: DENVER, Dec. 18A dearth of snow at every major Ski resort west of Michigan is costing the winter tourism industry millions of dollars a day and threatens to damage the economies of some states if no appreciable snow falls before Christmas.

title: Gail O'Leary Bride Of J. D. Macdonald
description: Gail Susan O'Leary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. O'Leary of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon in New York to James D. Macdonald, executive vice president of Hydron Europe in Wokingham, England, a division of the National Patent Development Corporation of New York.

title: Fire Destroys U.S. Army Building
description: BAD HERSFELD, West Germany, Dec18 (UPI)A fire in the noncommissioned officers' club of a United States Army barracks here last night caused damage estimated at $1.04 million, a police spokesman said today. No one was injured but the building was destroyed.

title: The heist of the century
description: NICE, France. The bank couldn't function. It was Monday morning, July 19, 1976, and the main vault door wouldn't open. The bank had no cash. Crowds of depositors waited with increasing impatience. The mechanism had stuck before, harried bank officials explained, and would be cleared in a moment. But it wasn't.

title: Emily Wheeler Wed To James LeMoyne
description: Emily Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Warren Wheeler of Bronxvine, N.Y., and Concord, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to James G. LeMoyne in Trinity Episcopal Church in Concord. The Rev. Nigel L. Andrews performed the ceremony.

title: Roster of Champions in 1976 Olympic Games at Montreal and Innsbruck
description: Archery

title: LETTERS
description: In the article A $1,000Lunchbox Made of Ostrich Leather (Dec. 5) a survey was quoted which found that women carry such items as needlepoint, makeup and their best shoes (whatever that means) in briefcases. Did the survey also find what men carry in their attach cases?

title: U.S. Judge Is Told Black Children Do Not Get Fair Chance at Adoption
description: A Federal judge presiding at a racediscrimination trial in Manhattan was told last week that many black children eligible for adoption were routinely continued in foster care. We were told, said Judith Mendell, testifying as an expert witness for the New York Civil Liberties Union, which is bringing the suit, that at no time would more than 5 percent of black children ever be adopted.

title: What's Doing in the VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: BACKGROUNDSt. Thomas, St. Croix and St. John are the prin cipal and only inhabited islands of the United States Virgin Islands (the British Virgin Islands are next door). Although smallSt. Thomas, for example, with its 32 square miles, is about the same size as Manhattanthe three islands are no boondocks backwater. Most of the action is on St. Thomas; St. Croix, although larger, is more subdued; St. John, the smallest, is really for those who want no action at all (many St. Thomas residents spend weekends in St. John for just that reason). There are about 100,000 inhabitants, split almost equally between St. Thomas and St. Croix, other than about 2,500 on St. John. The population is cosmopolitan: blacks (in the majority), Puerto Ricans, some East Indians and a growing white (and black) group, called Continentals, from the American mainland. The United States bought the Virgin Islands from Denmark in 1917 for $25 million. They are an unincorporated territory under the American flag.

title: Anniversaries
description: Steinfeld

title: Long to Meet With Carter
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 18 (UPI)Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was scheduled to meet with Mr. Carter this afternoon at the Presidentelect's home here. The purpose of the meeting was not disclosed.

title: Fiat Chairman Under Criticism For Libya Deal
description: ROME, Dec. 18Giovanni Agnelli, who is one of Italy's bestknown personalities and runs its most famous company, is once again dominating the headlines, the covers of the weekly picture magazines and the conversation here.

title: Spain for Democracy
description: It was a foregone conclusion that Spanish voters would endorse overwhelmingly the Government's plan to hold free elections for a new democratic Parliament next spring. There was, nonetheless, something exhilarating about the 75 percent turnout in Wednesday's referendum and the 94 percent approval for the program advanced by King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez for dismantling the authoritarian system of Francisco Franco.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IN the Bicentennial boom there's gold in them thar brass marketsand that goes for the custommade new item as well as the authentic antique. This helps to explain why an ingenious shop called The Brass Menageries is flourishing at 369 North Central Avenue in Valley Stream.

title: Answers/Questions
description: REFRIGERATED BULBS

title: New York City Is Turning to Sale of Mortgages for MuchNeeded Cash
description: As New York City scrambles to acquire some cash, one of its chief sources is the impending sale of $1.231 billion worth of MitchellLama mortgages. The sale is expected to net the city approximately $429 million.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Based on our experience with more than 350 widows during the last four years, I most certainly agree with Sylvia Orans [Not the Same as Single, Opinion Page, Nov. 28] that the emotional responses to the death of a spouse differ from the problems of those who have chosen to become single by divorce or who have never left the single state. However, her remarks leave the impression that there are no programs, as she puts it, designed to help the widowed cope with their grief and facilitate their reentry into society.

title: Have They Saved the Best Movies for Last? Christmas Week Will Tell
description: THE ENFORCERIt takes more than a windshield to stop Clint Eastwood as the triggerhappy Dirty Harry. The thriller opens Wednesday at neighborhood theaters.

title: Notes: Doubts Over DutyFree Bargains
description: Ireland's Shannon Airport is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year as the site of the world's first dutyfree airport shopbut it's holding the birthday party amid mounting suspicion that airport dutyfree shops are not what they used to be.

title: Pop: Disciples Show Assurance
description: Mongo Santamaria's Latinjazz combo was used as bait Friday evening at Town Hall for a talent showcase that brought together a mixture of new acts and established performers.

title: Soviet Team Finds a Mountain of Iron in Antarctica
description: McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Dec. 15 In the Prince Charles Mountains, near the coast of Antarctica facing the Indian Ocean, Soviet explorers have found what one American geologist here described today as a mountain of iron.

title: A Money Machine Named Nuveen
description: In this era of retrenchment in Wall Street, a thriving investment house is exceptional, and one that earns a steady25 percent or more on its capital is as scarce as a stockbroker without a buy recommendation.

title: Oilcan Eddie takes on the old guard
description: Fellow workers at the United States Steel plant on Lake Michigan in South Chicago called him Oilcan Eddiea happygolucky young fellow, a strong union man, a good companion to down a couple of beers with after a hard day in the mills. Today, 12 years out of the mills and into union business, Eddie can be seen more often on the stump, from Pittsburgh to Los Angeles, asking steelworkers for their votes and throwing fear into the union old guard and the captains of the steel industry.

title: INVESTING.
description: The price of gold, that perverse metal, has reversed a sharp decline to show signs of strength lately. In the battered market for gold stocks, which tend to follow bullion's fortunes fairly directly, the big question now becomes: Is it just a respite or is gold headed solidly higher?

title: CHINA SAYS 4 CHANGED A KEY MAO QUOTATION
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 18China today confirmed reports from unofficial Chinese sources that a major charge against Chiang Ching and three other disgraced members of the Communist Party Politburo is that they reworded a critical quotation by Mao Tsetung to make it appear they alone were to be left in control after his death.

title: Two Choirs Record A Christmas Gift
description: ORADELL AGIFT of music for Christmas has been presented by the choirs of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in this Bergen County community in the form of a stereophonic recording containing 13 religious songs performed by the choirs during the year.

title: The Missing in Action
description: Representative G. V. Montgomery has delivered the painful but inescapable message that all the remaining Americans still listed as missing in Vietnam must be considered dead. The Pentagon carried the names of 728 men as missing and 33 as prisoners. But the Mississippi Democrat who headed the House of Representatives' Select Committee on Missing Persons in Southeast Asia put it simply: The sad conclusion is that there is no evidence that any of these missing Americans are still alive.

title: N.C.A.A. Weighs Unity In Talks With N.A.I.A.
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 18 (AP)The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics and the National Collegiate Athletic Association, sometimes bitter rivals in the past, are talking over conflicting dates, playing rules and international competition.

title: Big Gains, Bigger Hopes Spurring Women Athletes
description: This year has brought many concrete gains to women's sports and spurred hopes for further advances. Increased sponsorship has meant the richest tournaments ever in golf, tennis and bowling. Women's squash racquets found its first sponsor, enabling women to compete for prize money for the first time. In both tennis and golf, there were more tournaments with larger purses than ever before, and prize money on the Ladies Professional Golt Association tour soared from $1.2 million in 1975 to a record $2.6 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Bombs Injure 17 in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 18 (UPI)At least 17 persons were injured in two bomb blasts within half an hour today in Dacca's bustling food shopping areas, the police reported. They said they had no suspects in the bombings.

title: Republicans in Westchester Seek Candidate Who Can Beat DelBello
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 18Westchester Republicans, who dominated this county for more than half a century, but whose power has been steadily eroded by the Democrats, have begun a talent search.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: BAM Extra

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Faulty aiming probably causes more unsatisfying golf shots than faulty swinging.

title: Higher Fees for Speeders Voided
description: The State Department of Motor Vehicles has been enjoined from doubling or tripling the licenserenewal fees of drivers convicted of speeding or other moving violationsa measure it adopted last Sept. 1 to pay for driverrehabilitation programs.

title: Mary Ann Muller Is Married to Roney Ebling
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Ann Muller to Roney Hilliard Ebling. The Rev. William Donovan performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien.

title: Winners of Individual and Team Championships During 1976
description: Archery

title: Goldwater Quits Race To Head Senate G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona announced today that he was withdrawing from the race for Senate Republican leader.

title: New & Novel
description: Will Bryant is evidently steeped in the lore of turnofthecentury criminal Americana including gunsmithing, penal institutions, the state of the art of safecracking and miscellaneous flummery. He is also a formidable storyteller. This combination results in a midand farWestern that gallops compellingly along from a Jailbreak in St. Louis to a showdown on the Owlhoot Trail.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The seven rear cars of an 11car MontrealtoWashington Amtrak passenger train derailed about one mile south of New Haven, resulting in minor injuries to one of 220 passengers and crew aboard the train. The first four cars continued their journey while passengers on the derailed cars were returned to New Haven.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN I order dinner in a Hunan or Szechuan restaurant for purposes of a review, I make no special requests about the spiciness. I take it as it comes, regardless of my personal preference. How else could I judge the kitchen's standard and advise the reader? I have come to realize that the common denominator of spiciness in the restaurants I have visited is fairly low. Often, according to the pepper alone, it is difficult to distinguish the dishes listed in red on the menu from those that are not.

title: Margaret Stout Wed in Jersey
description: Margaret Tucker Stout, daughter of former State Senator Richard R. Stout and Mrs. Stout of West Allenhurst, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to John Crawford Pogue 3d. He is a son of Mrs. Justin J. Stevenson of Cincinnati and of Mr. Pogue of Geyserville, Calif.

title: Nile Rowing to Be Held This Week
description: CAIRO, Dec. 18The sixth annual Nile International Rowing Festival will get under way tomorrow with the arrival of the University of Paris, the French entry.

title: Why Does He Play So Hard?. To Survive
description: I was young when I became a father, so young I still went out to play ball with the fellows in the neighborhood. And when my son became 5, we went out together to play with my friends. Alan was already incredibly adept at hitting and catching a ball. My friends were a bit embarrassed but also delighted to have him join their games.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices posted a moderate advance last week as investors were buoyed by hopes that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would increase oil prices only moderately.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: The Region
description: New York City has yet to produce a satisfactory plan to pay off owners of $1 billion of its notes, something it must do by a court order that cannot be appealed, and the noteholders have now returned to court to get the city moving.

title: Inadequate Conditions May Bring Order to Shut Putnam County Jail
description: CARMEL, N.Y., Dec. 18One of the state's oldest county jails, which has been cited as unsafe, inadequate and unsanitary by the State Commission of Correction almost yearly since it was built in 1906, is being threatened with closing for the second time in recent years.

title: Raiders Subdue Patriots, 2421; Vikings Win, 3520, From 'Skins
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Dec. 18The key play was the first play today as the Minnesota Vikings trounced the Washington Redskins, 3520, in the playoff game. What was it? A simple offtackle call on which Francis Tarkenton handed the ball off to Brent McClanahan, Minnesota's other running back, and McClanahan raced downfield for 41 yards to the Redskin 25yard line. That set the mood, the tone, of the onesided contest.

title: Dismissed Organizer Reinstated
description: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 18 (UPI) The U.M.W.'s international executive board today handed another setback to Mr. Miller by voting, 17 to 4, to reinstate Jose Garcia, who was dismissed recently from his job as a union organizer.

title: Corvaln Thanks Brezhnev
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP)Luis Corvaln arrived in Moscow tonight and thanked Mr. Brezhnev for having helped arrange his release.

title: Endpaper
description: id he have a fever? Warm forehead. or at least it seemed to he warm as he tested it with the palm of his right hand in the hack of the cab. And he was weak. jellylimbed and faint. Could you go a little slower? No response from up front as they sped through the park. lie rapped on the glass partition. He pulled at the change box. placing his lips to it. Could you go a little slower?

title: Equestrian Preparation For Olympics Extensive
description: It might be said without too much debate on the subject that the equestrian teams of the world spend three years in preparation for the Olympic Games.

title: N.F.L. Hurt in Court But Not on the Field
description: Pro football's establishment, meanbig the owners and their commissioner, Pete Rozelle, lost ground in the courts but did well in the counting houses and on television during the National Football League's 57th season, which has three more weeks to run. In separate court cases, the annual draft of college players, and the freeagent compensation rule (known as the Rozelle Rule) were declared violations of antitrust laws and therefore illegal.

title: DINING OUT
description: THEME restaurants can be offputting, as anyone who has ever dined in a socalled Polynesian place offering a simulated hurricane every hour can readily confirm. Fortunately, the 50 Yard Line confines its macho orientation to the murals of famous stadiums, a display of assorted gridiron trophies and some silly titles on the menu.

title: Santas for Hire
description: Still wondering where Santa Claus comes from? Relax. He comes from the same agencies that supply secretaries and file clerks on a temporary basis during the rest of the year.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The Revealing Art Of Architectural. Drawings

title: Chilean Envoy in U.S. Says Only One Political Captive, Communist, Now Remains
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Ambassador Manuel Trucco of Chile said today that his country had only one political prisoner left following the release of Luis Corvaln Lepe, the Communist leader. The envoy identified the prisoner as Jorge Montes, another Communist official.

title: William Cahill of The News Is the Fiance of Mary Moore
description: Mrs. Patrick Moore of Dublin has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Moore, to William J. Cahill, son of Edith Cahill of Middle Village, Queens, and the late James E. Cahill Jr.

title: CAREY SEEKS TO CUT MEDICAID EXPENSES
description: As part of his effort to cut $200 million from New York State's $3.4 billion welfare and Medicaid bill, Governor Carey will seek to end Medicaid reimbursement for services such as privateduty nursing and physical therapy and to require Medicaid recipients to pay part of the cost of dental care, eyeglasses and prescription drugs.

title: The New American Establishment Is Called the Community
description: WASHINGTONCyrus R. Vance, Secretary of Statedesignate; Zbigniew Brzezinski, who will be national security affairs adviser; W. Michael Blumenthal, named Secretary of the Treasury; Harold Brown, who may be chosen Defense Secretaryall are part of a small floating group that comes close to monopolizing the top foreign and national security posts in any administration. Known as the foreign policy community, it does not operate as a club of the likeminded or a conspiracy or a governing board. It acts more like an aristocracy of professionals. Its members sometimes actually make the decisions, usually define what is to be debated and invariably manage the resulting policies.

title: CARTER SAYS ACTIONS WON'T BE INFLUENCED BY SAUDI OIL PRICING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Presidentelect Jimmy Carter said today that he would not let Saudi Arabia's decision to hold down oil prices influence his administration's policies on the Middle East and other matters.

title: Engagements
description: BertashRichter

title: Theodore W. Marcy, Gymnast, Is Fiance Of Kimberly Hornung
description: Mr and Mrs. Gerald K. Hornung of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Hornung, to Theodore Wendell Marcy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Marcy 3d of Oak Brook, Ill., and Lake Placid, N. Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Presidentelect Jimmy Carter, the nation and the world won't be getting one big gift they had all been covetingbut not really expectingthis year. But they may well be seeing a different and more important Christmas present under their trees next weekend.

title: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:
description: MondayThe Committee on Parks. Recreation and Cultural Affairs will consider five bills to rename streets and parks. 250 Broadway, 23d Floor, 10 A.M.

title: Elizabeth Lewis Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Lewis of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lewis, to Eric Gershon, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gershon, also of Bayside. The couple plan to be married at the West Hempstead Jewish Center next June.

title: ART
description: Greenvale WE learn from standard texts on William Caxton, the 15thcentury pioneer who printed the first book in English and established the first English printing company, that some historians have not been overly pleased with the literary selections he chose to publish. The celebrated Gibbon, for example, was no ardent admirer of Caxton and scored him for not having published the classics and for his occasional lapses of taste.

title: Hearing Scheduled On Bias Accusation By 2 Choir Singers
description: The Black Caucus of the Episcopal Diocese of New York will hold a hearing Tuesday on charges of racial bias in the dismissal of black members of the adult choirs at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: StudentAid Plans May Be Revamped
description: JOHN JONES is a young South Jerseyan who was in the top 10 of his high school graduating class last June and who showed his capability for college by being accepted at Glassboro State College.

title: New Studies Insist on the Same Treatment for the Same Crimes
description: Criminal sentences handed out by New York State judges are the longest in the country, often up to 15 to 25 years, but in practice most felons in this state spend two or three years in prison and then are released on parole. The sentiment in this state, particularly in [New York City], is that prison sentences are not long enough, Edward R. Hammock, chairman of the State Board of Parole, said recently.

title: A City in Fear of Crime
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18The city by the bay is as beautiful and sunlit as ever but it's in something of a flap these days about crimenot just because there's so much of it, which has been true all along, but also because crime suddenly is seen as striking at the rich, the powerful and the random target.

title: Rylee Routh Fiancee Of David Paul Ruley
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Routh Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mr. Routh's daughter, Rylee Ann Routh, to David Paul Ruley, son of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Ruley of Riverside, Conn. Miss Routh is a daughter also of the late Aleen Rylee Routh. The wedding is planned for May 21.

title: FollowUp on The News
description: When Veniamin G. Levich, a Soviet physical chemist and corresponding member of the Academy of Sciences, applied to emigrate to Israel in 1972, he not only did not get permission, he also lost his posts with an institute, five scientific committees and two editorial boards, and the chair he held at Moscow State University was abolished.

title: News of Realty
description: Barclays Bank International has purchased the 14story office building at 100 Water Street from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for $2.4 million.

title: UNIONS' AIMS FOR '77 STRESS JOB SECURITY
description: In next year's labor negotiations unions representing nearly 5,000,000 workers in some of the nation's biggest industries seem likely to stress greater job security and to seek only moderate pay increases if inflation does not flare up again.

title: Sports in 1976: Jock Lib
description: In professional game sports, 1976 was the Year of Jock Lib, a time of revolt against the feudal structure of baseball, football, basketball and hockey. The revolution was fought mostly in the courts, and it won for athletes, for the first time, some voice in their own future.

title: Law Student Plans to Wed Susan Welsh
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Corbett Welsh of Camp Hill, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Welsh, to William S. Eakins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Eakins of Glen Cove, L.I. A wedding in January is planned.

title: Frazier Shot at Buzzer Sinks Cays in Overtime
description: Walt Frazier's bank shot at the buzzer, after he had snared the rebound on the third of three shots missed in rapid sequence by Bob McAdoo, provided the New York Knicks with a 115113 overtime victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers last night.

title: ISRAEL SEEKING AID FOR ARMS INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Israel, seeking to lessen its military dependence on the United States, has informed the Ford Administration that it would like to use some American aid to build up its own defense industry.

title: Article 10  No Title
Robin Martens Bride Of Richard D. Huss
description: Rebecca Robin Martens, an admission counselor at Centenary College for Women in Hackettstown, N.J., wasmarried yesterday morning to Richard Deas Huss, Centenary's director of admissions.

title: Of 96 Million Workers in the U.S., 7 Million Are PentagonRelated
description: When Presidentelect Jimmy Carter proposes more stimulus for the economy while at the same time endorsing a cut in defense spending, is he contradicting himself? On the face of it, he seems to be proposing that his Administration will deal out more money with one hand and take it away with the other.

title: Article 11  No Title
STAMPS
description: The heritage of the Middle Ages, when every form of artistic endeavor was devoted to the celebration and veneration of Christianity, has been evoked as the dominant theme of many 1976 Christmas stamps from around the world.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: Intangibles Spice Battle In RamsCowboys Playoff
description: IRVING, Tex., Dec. 18Are the Los Angeles Rams ready for the playoffs? And are the Dallas Cowboys? Both teams presented questions here today as they got set for tomorrow's fourth and last National Football League division playoff game in Texas Stadium. This one will have a late start and CBS anticipates a national television audience of perhaps 30 million. The game will be televised in New York on Channel 2 beginning at 5:30 P.M., E.S.T.

title: The Law Firm That Stars in Court
description: Every Friday afternoon, lawyers from Paul, Weiss, Rifkind Wharton & Garrison meet in one of the firm's spacious, paneled conference rooms for a cocktail party. The party on the afternoon of Nov. 19 was like a wake.

title: family/style
Mary M. Wilson, I.B.M. Marketing Aide, Wed to Michael Moore, Medical Student
description: Mary Maud Wilson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Wilson Jr. of Darien. Conn., was married yesterday in Noroton, Conn., to Michael Patrick Moore, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Moore of River Forest, Ill. The Rev. William Donovan, assisted by the Rev. Pierre Botton, performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church. A reception Kvas held at the Shore and Country Club in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Lois Naftulin, R. A. Burstein Are Married in Pennsylvania
description: The marriage of Lois J. Naftulin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George S. Naftulin of Wyncote, Pa., to Robert Alan Burstein of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Burstein of Miami Beach, took place yesterday evening.

title: Class Spinning Over Teachers' Revolving Door
description: The case of Mrs. Dudley taught me a lesson, said Conrad Johnson, a fifth grader. Never get close to a teacher because she always leaves.

title: New York Regents Agree to Let Summer Food Plan Run in 1977
description: ALBANY, Dec. 18New York State education authorities yesterday agreed to administer the Federal Government's $70 million 1977 summer food program for needy children in the state, but called for new controls to eliminate the problems and abuses that marred last summer's program.

title: The Nation
description: A Federal court has ruled that a President may be held personally liable for civil damages for official actions that violate the Constitution. If upheld on appeal, the judgment, against Richard M. Nixon, could set a precedent for other suits claiming damages from chief executives.

title: Turn and Count Takes Roamer by Two Lengths
description: Sigmund Sommer's Turn and Count, a colt who has been raced sparingly because of leg problems, demonstrated again he has legs full of run when they are sound as he gained the first stakes triumph of his career at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Events Today
description: Fifth Avenue Holiday Mall: pedestrian mall and entertainment; 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., Fifth Avenue from 34th to 57th Street.

title: Sacrificed for a Subway: Two Blocks' Repose
description: With each daily blast of dynamite dozens of feet below elegant East 63d Street between Park and Third Avenues, another forward step is taken toward the completion of the controversial $700 million ManhattanQueens subway line. Above ground, a tailor suffers a nervous breakdown, a florist goes broke, a shop clerk is let go for lack of work.

title: Article 8  No Title
Loss of $2.4 Million in U.S. Notes Remains a Mystery After 2 Years
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18In an old house in New Orleans that is laden with vines lives a rich, eccentric inventor 99 years old, who once had in his possession a fortune. But one evening the fortune mysteriously disappeared.

title: CrimeVictim Unit Turned Down Half Of Requests for Aid
description: New York State's Crime Victims Compensation Board rejected more than half the claims it received in the year ended last March 31 because it did not have enough information according to an audit of the board by the Office of the State Comptroller.

title: A Different Cup of Tea Leaves
description: LONDONMore than nine years ago, on a visit to Montevideo, I wrote: Contemporary England... might well take a long southwesterly look at Uruguay while murmuring: There but for the grace of God go I. For Uruguay is the welfare state gone wild...the system maximizes rights of the citizen and minimizes his obligations... pragmatic socialism knows that charity costs moneyand now the bill has been presented.

title: Monica Jacobson Bride of Arnold Bressler
description: In Temple Oheb Shalom in South Orange, N. J., yesterday evening, Monica Ruth Jacobson became the bride of Arnold Nacht Bressler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Bressler of East Orange, N. J. The bride is the daughter of Commissioner and Mrs. Joel R. Jacobson of South Orange.

title: Two composerperformers who are still storm centers
description: What higher glory can there be for any creative artist than still to be controversial generations after his death? Gustav Mahler remains the object of fierce dispute after 65 years in the tomb. No composer since Wagner has been so idolized, as both the most eloquent of musicians and the deepest of intellects. Many musiclovers perceive in him the definitive statement of the dilemmas of modern man, the meaninglessness, the despair at the breakdown of hallowed forms. On the other hand, a considerable number find him tedious and bombastic.

title: Peking Seeks to Convince Maoist Parties Abroad It Has Not Forsaken Leftist Purity
description: PEKING, Dec. 17One of the most active organizations in China these days is the international liaison department of the Chinese Communist Party. It is telling Maoist parties around the world that China did not forsake leftist purity when it threw Mao Tsetung's widow and her associates into jail in October.

title: NEW REGULATIONS COVER PAYMENTS FOR MEDICAID
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 18 (AP)Medicaid payments to nursing homes will be based on the homes' costs instead of a flat rate as a result of regulations approved this week by a Connecticut legislative committee.

title: Two Big Stars of Tennis Are Outshone by a Villain
description: Chris Evert was the heroine.

title: POLITICS
description: THE Island's handful of Democratic Legislators traditionally have been seen but not heard in the State Senate and Assembly chambers. They have been outvoted and outvoiced by the Republican legislative contingent from the Island, one of the most potent blocs in the Legislature not only because of its size but also because of its unitysome would say lockstepunder the leadership of two strong politicians. These are, of course, the Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea of Montauk, who is also one of the leaders of the Suffolk Republican organization, and Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta of Uniondale, who is the sole leader of the Nassau G.O.P. organization.

title: A Return of Confidence
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18The signs of change now dominate the capital. The inauguration stands are going up on Capitol Hill. President Ford is sending his official papers to the National Archives. The book publishers are throwing money at Henry, and the new boys in town are whistling Dixie.

title: Reorganization of Purchase Department Is Urged by Beame Panel
