description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 20The South African Government today freed the first 13 of 81 political detainees whose release was pledged last week by Justice Minister James T. Kruger. At least 350 other peo ple, most of them blacks, remain in detention without trial.

title: Georgetown's Coach Has Had a PressureFilled Year
description: Most college basketball coaches undergo emotional agonies about six months of the year. But the pressures of the job have been dogging John Thompson of Georgetown for the better part of the last 12 monthswith three months more to go.

title: Retail Coffee Prices Seen Going Higher
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)Retail coffee prices will continue rising in 1977 and it may be two years before normal production brings much relief to consumers, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: A PLAN TO REVITALIZE NEW YORK'S ECONOMY IS OFFERED BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame made public yesterday a fiveyear economicrecovery plan for New York City whose key new elements are tax reductions and an aggressive advertising and marketing program.

title: Bridge:
description: A young New England foursome won a convincing victory in the last New York event of the Bicentennial year.

title: Tennis
description: SUNDAY

title: The Arms Talks, and Beyond
description: WASHINGTONThe Russians believe a new agreement in the strategic arms limitation talks is the decisive element in their overall relations with the United States and in reconstructing dtente, a process they say they want to make irreversible.

title: U .S. Bishop Granted Approval as a Saint
description: ROME, Dec. 20A consistory of cardinals today formally approved the canonization, of Bishop John Neumann, who will become the first American male saint.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: OVERHAUL EXPECTED IN INTERIOR AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20President. elect Jimmy Carter's plan to create a unified Federal energy department is seen by two senior Democrats in Congress, Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, as a prelude to a major revamping of the Interior Department that would enlarge it and change its name.

title: Booklet Explains Revised Charter
description: The state Charter Revision Commission for New York City has prepared a 42page manual explaining the revised City Charter for Community Board members, the commission said. State Senator Roy M. Goodman, RepublicanLiberal of Manhattan, chairman of the commission, said the booklet, A Charter Revision Guide for Community Board Members, explains how the revised Charter operates and contains suggestions on the functioning of Community Boards.

title: Mars Operations Resumed By Vikings After Slowdown
description: After more than a month of relative inactivity, the Viking spacecraft on and around Mars have resumed full scientific operations, and one of the vehiclesthe Viking 2 orbiterwas shifted yesterday into a lower orbit to get a clearer view of the planet's polar regions.

title: High Court Bars Difference by Sex In Minimum Age for Buying Beer
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today that a state may not set different age minimums at which men and women may buy 3.2 percent beer.

title: N.B.A.'s Memo Stresses Consistency to Referees
description: All of a sudden National Basketball Association teams are winning more on the road. Why? Maybe Memo N595 from John Nucatola, supervisor of officials, to his staff had something to do with it. His memo react: In any basketball game someone wins and someone loses. However, each player, each coach, each club and each game deserves and demands your very best. Every effort that you put forth on the court, every call you make and every whistle you blow should be done with complete disregard to where it is and on whom it is.

title: BLACK BUSINESSMEN GIVE BUCKLEY AWARD
description: James L. Buckley was honored yesterday by a group of black businessmen during what the United States Senator from New York called his last public appearance before my senatorial coach turns into a pumpkin. He will leave the Senate next month.

title: Antiwar Activists Appeal to Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Daniel Ellsberg, Joan Baez, Daniel and Philip Berrigan and dozens of other antiwar activists of the 1960's and 1970's have protested to the leaders of unified Vietnam about reports of repressive acts carried out since the capture of Saigon last year.

title: Belfast Hotel Plans to Open
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 20 (Reuters)  Northern Ireland's most bombed hotel, the Europa in central Bel fast, plans to reopen next March, its management announced today. The 200room hotel has been bombed 28 times since it was originally opened five years ago at a cost of about $4.59 million. It man aged to stay in business until last year when the hotel's second and third floors were wrecked by a bomb attack.

title: Harris, Bleier Considered Questionable for Sunday
description: It was as if a Hatfield had admitted he liked a McCoy. A Pittsburgh Steeler called the Oakland Raiders a good bunch of guys.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The New Jersey Pharmaceutical Association urged yesterday that elderly people who qualify for rebates under the state's pharmaceutical assistance program must file their claims before Dec. 31 for any prescription medicines purchased in 1975.

title: Hitachi to Build Plant
description: The Hitachi Shipbuilding and Engineering Company said in Tokyo that i had signed a $34.5 million contract to supply a sugar manufacturing plant to Compana Agropecuara Forestal Industrial of Ecuador. The contract was made on a yen basis with deferred payment, but details were not disclosed.

title: Alabama Romps in Liberty Bowl by 366
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 20 (AP)Alabama's canny Bear Bryant taught Terry Donahue, of the University of California, Los Angeles an embarrassing football lesson tonight as Barry Krauss's 44yard scoring interception and a 20yard fleaflicker pass to the quarterback, Jack O'Rear, helped swamp the seventhtanked Bruins, 366, in the Liberty Bowl.

title: Grain Prices Steady
description: Grain prices were virtually unchanged yesterday in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean prices showed only a slight gain.

title: Pilot Was Charged Previously
description: The pilot who crashed in Memorial Stadium in Baltimore Sunday just after the playoff game was free on $2,100 bond on a previous recklessflying charge, authorities said yesterday. Details, Page 20.

title: Chicago National Cuts Its Prime Rate to 6%
description: The First National Bank of Chicago, a $13 billiondeposit bank that is the second largest in Illinois and 10th in the nation, announced yesterday that it was lowering its minimum interest rate on corporate loans to 6 percent, effective today. The rate had been 6 percent.

title: Committee Appointed by Governor Grasso Seeking Sweeping Changes in Connecticut State Government
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 20A committee appointed by Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut proposed today that sweeping changes be made both in the structure of government and in the ways in which the state provided the services expected of it.

title: Speidel Newspapers Agrees in Principle to Join With Gannett in a $173 Million Deal
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Speidel Newspapers Inc. today agreed in principle to merge with the Gannett Company in a $173 million stock transaction that would expand the Gannett chain to 73 newspapers.

title: CENTER FOR ELDERLY OPPOSED IN LEONIA
description: LEONIA, Dec. 20The question of where to establish a federally financed $500,000 health center for the elderly in southeast Bergen County is like asking if we really believe in motherhood, a town official said after an area meeting on the subject.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ideals and Realities
description: Repeatedly during the past year Presidentelect Carter stressed that, if elected, he would scour the nation looking for talented people who would be new to government. For no office did he set a higher standard than that of Attorney General who, he said, should be appointed without respect to political considerations.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Niles Welch, Actor of Broadway And 20's and 30's Motion Pictures
description: Niles Welch, a leading man of many silent and early talking movies who later did wartime foreignlanguage broadcasts for the Voice of America, died Nov. 21 in Laguna Niguel, Calif., where he lived. He was 88 years old.

title: Expanded Politburo in Vietnam, With New Members From the South
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Dec. 20Following is a list of the members of Vietnam's new ruling Politburo. The identifications are from Western sources in Bangkok.

title: 10 Hurt in School Bus Mishap
description: NORTH BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 20 (AP) Three adults and seven retarded children were hurt slightly here today when a school minibus and a car collided. The seven youngsters, who ranged in age from 7 to 9 years old, were on their way to the James E. Allen School for the Retarded in Dix Hills. The accident occurred at 9:15 A.M. at the intersection of Hunters Avenue and Route 231.

title: Talking Book Meets His Listeners
description: Some of George Backman's greatest fans have never seen him act; they know him only as a clear, strong voice that enters their living rooms for hours on end to entertain and inform them, to tell them of foreign and familiar places and of strange situations or intrigue or even of romance.

title: Factories in China Urged to Lift Output
description: HONG KONG, DEC. 20Peking called today for better management, harder work and increased efficiency in China's factories amidst indications that 1976 has generally been a poor year for the country's industry.

title: RUTH DOUGLASS DEFOUW
description: Ruth Douglass Defouw, director of social services at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L. I., died there of cancer on Saturday. She was 67 years old.

title: Argentine Grand Prix Said to Get Ultimatum
description: MILAN, Italy, Dec. 20 (AP)The world's Formula One autoracing manufacturers sent an ultimatum today to the organizers of the Grand Prix of Argentina to accept the manufacturers conditions for a race on Jan. 9 or drop out of the world championship, Italian racing sources said.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONThe Rev. George C., D.D. The Board of Directors on the Insirtutes of Religion and Health (Including the former Academy of Religion and Mental Health) announce with profound sorrow the death of Dr. Anderson on December 19th, in Swarthmore, Pa. As the rounder and Honorary President of the Academy of Religion and Mental health, Dr. Anderson made an international contrloution to the reconciliation of religion with the medical, social and behavioral, sclences. There will be a memorial service on Thursday, December 23d, at Trinity Church, Swarthmore, Pa., at 11:00 A.M. He is survived by his sister, Mrs. Richard Bowman, of 468 Sweetbrier Rd.. Warminster; Pa., 189/4. DONALD E. SMITH, President, CHARLES C. BERGMAN, Exec. V. P.

title: Tale of Two Buildings
description: Something seems awry when the Federal Government will not invest in the city but private business will: one expects the reticent, bardnosed decisions from the private sector. But in the last two weeks, New York has seen the Federal Reserve Bank withdraw plans for a longawaited building in lower Manhattan and the International Business Machines Corporation signal a cautious willingness to go ahead with a major midtown structure.

title: Article 5  No Title
Angolas's Trial of Mercenaries Is Criticized by Jurists' Unit
description: GENEVA, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The Angolan court that sentenced the American Daniel Gearhart and three other mercenaries to death last June often used tenuous legal reasoning, the International Commission of Jurists said here today.

title: People and Business
description: William M. Agee, the 38yearold president and chief operating officer of the Bendix Corporation, was elected yesterday to become the company's chairman and chief executive officer early next year, succeeding W. Michael Blumenthal upon Mr. Blumenthal's confirmation as Secretary of the Treasury. Presidentelect Jimmy Carter announced his choice of Mr. Blumenthal for the Cabinet position last week. Mr. Agee will retain the president's post. The company has not yet designated a new chief operating officer.

title: Article 7  No Title
Gilliam Free on Bail
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 20 (AP)Joe Gilliam, the former Pittsburgh Steeler's quarterback, was sentenced to 45 days in jail today for violating probation. He waived a preliminary hearing on a new drug charge and five hours later was free on $6,000 bond.

title: Nobody Cares About the Horses
description: A few brittle leaves, pushed by a bonechilling wind, scuttled across a path outside a barn at Belmont Park. Imbedded in the path, frozen as solid as archeological fossils, were the deep hoofmarks and shallower pawprints left by a horse and dog in the mud of an earlier day. From the top of a concrete manure pit, a gang of sparrows in search of a stray oat or two pulled and tossed the discarded straw bedding like Christmas shoppers at a discount store. It was barely 9 A.M., but the bundled stablehands had been hard at work for the better part of four hours.

title: The Rev. George C. Anderson; Cleric Active in Mental Health
description: The Rev. Dr. George Christian Anderson, a leader in closing the gap between religion and psychiatry, died Sunday at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 69 years old.

title: WORLD ENERGY BODY SEES CUT IN DEMAND FOR OIL FROM OPEC
description: PARIS, Dec. 20The International Energy Agency, making its first assessment of the impact of last wek's price increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, says that demand for OPEC oil will now be sharply reduced and that this may check any growth of the cartel's revenues.

title: John Cobb Displays Technical Skill on Piano
description: John Cobb tore through a testing collection of piano pieces Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall and none of them presented him with the slightest technical problem. The young pianist from Chicago, a pupil of Claudio Arrau and Rafael de Silva, coolly untangled the densest pages of Ives's First trickiest filigree of Schumann's First Sonata as easily as he tossed off the Faschingsschwank aus Wien.

title: Theater: Music Is Dichotomized
description: The temptation to say that Music Is, the new musical that opened at the St. James Theater last night, is not, should clearly be resisted. But in the circumstances it is difficult to resist, for the show hardly seems one of the more noticeable events of the season. A lot of effort has gone into itso what else is news?

title: Winter Blowing In Today, With Hints of Cold Like the Old Days
description: If winter comes in today like a polar bear, will it go out like a pussycat? Or a Siberian tiger?

title: College Results
description: BASKETBALL

title: A Controversial Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President elect Carter has made his most controversial Cabinet selection so far by asking his longtime friend and political supporter, Griffin B. Bell, to become Attorney General in his administration.

title: BriscoeWarren Bout a Draw
description: NICE, France, Dec. 20 (AP)Benny Briscoe of Philadelphia and Willie Warren, Corpus Christi, Tex., fought to a 10round draw tonight in a middleweight fight billed as an elimination for the right to meet the world champion, Carlos Monzon of Argentina. Briscoe weighed 158 pounds and Warren 159. Warren was down for a mandatory 8 count in the third round.

title: It's Lingerie for Today, but Not Unmindful of Past Beauties
description: Some women are mad for lingerie; others go wild for furs. Fernando Sanchez has for a long time concentrated on both areas of sybaritic luxury.

title: Insolvent Democrats Close Trenton Office
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)The state Democratic Party, unable to get out of debt for the last seven years, has closed its main office in Trenton on the eve of the gubernatorial election year.

title: COURT READY TO KILL SAYPOL'S INDICTMENT
description: A State Supreme Court justice, after hearing an assistant district attorney declare that a key wiretap had been illegally obtained by former Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari, said it was exceedingly probable that he would dismiss a bribery and perjury indictment against Justice Irving H. Saypol of State Supreme Court.

title: Policy for the Americas
description: Presidentelect Carter could ask for no better set of recommendations for United States policies and priorities in Latin America than the one issued yesterday by the distinguished private commission headed by former Ambassador Sol N. Linowitz.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: India's Economy Is Heading From Rags to Riches
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 20After years of scraping by with only the skimpiest of foreign exchange reserves, India suddenly finds itself with an embarassment of riches.

title: JOHN L. MATTHEWS
description: John L. Matthews, a retired retailing executive and brother of Herbert Matthews, formerly on the editorial staff of The New York Times, died yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Greenwich at 91 Brookside Drive.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Court Says Malpractice Panels Can Submit Evidence
description: The Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn held yesterday that the recommendations of state medical malpractice mediation panels, authorized by the Legislature in an effort to reduce lengthy malpractice trials, could be submitted as evidence if the cases actually did go to trial.

title: Reality Of Carter's Cabinet
description: SAN FRANCISCOIt's a wellknown fact of life that things are not always what they seem. But here on the West Coast a momentarily transplanted Easterner may find himself somewhat more than ordinarily, flummoxed by appearance and reality.

title: British Soccer
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Japanese in Plea to Carter
description: TOKYO, Dec. 20 (Reuters)A group of Japanese nuclear scientists and legal experts today appealed to Presidentelect Jimmy Carter to remove immediately all nuclear weapons from South Korea. A similar appeal was also made to the United Nations Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim. The group of 22 scholars who made the appeal included Dr. Yasuo Miyake chairman of the Nuclear Committee of the Science Council of Japan.

title: COURT READY TO KILL SAYPOL'S INDICTMENT
description: A State Supreme Court justice, after hearing an assistant district attorney declare that a key wiretap had been illegally obtained by former Special Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari, said it was exceedingly probable that he would dismiss a bribery and perjury indictment against Justice Irving H. Saypol of State Supreme Court.

title: Griffin Boyette Bell
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 20Somewhere between Americus, where he was born, and Washington, where he is headed, Griffin Boyette Bell concluded that the best way to travel through life was in the middle of the road. That is the way he writes his legal briefs as a top Atlanta lawyer. It is the way he wrote decisions in his 15 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit. It could very well be the way he will run the Justice Department if his nomination to be Attorney General is approved.

title: Technologies Gets Contract
description: The United Technologies Corporation said its subsidiary, United Space Boosters Inc., had been selected as a booster assembly contractor for the pace shuttle by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Negotiations with NASA on the $122 million contract will begin next month and horizontal test flights of the shuttle are to begin in 1977, orbital test flights in 1979 and the complete vehicle is to be operational in 1980, United Technologies said.

title: Juanita Morris Kreps
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Juanita M. Kreps, whose designation as Secretary of Commerce was announced by Presidentelect Jimmy Carter today, is the first woman chosen for the Carter Cabinet, and thus far the only one. So once again finds herself in a role she has long played in business and government. The 55yearold economist and educator is now a vice president of Duke University in Durham, N.C.; a professor of oconomics at the same university, specializing in problems of labor and manpower, the aging and income distribution; a member of the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange, and serves on several corporate boards. She was the first woman appointed to the stock exchange governing board, and is the only woman on several boards of directors.

title: Careful Polishing Keeps Silver Gifts Shiny
description: Silver bells, silver sells. It's Christmas time in the city, and overtime at Tiffany's.

title: U.A.W. Votes to Accept Contract At Caterpillar Tractor Co. Plants
description: PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 20 (AP)Auto workers at seven Caterpillar Tractor Company plants in five states have voted to accept a contract that provides pay and pension rises and higher bonuses for perfect attendance, a company spokesman said.

title: About New York
description: There is a oneroom public school in Brooklyn for 16, pregnant girls, aged 12 to 19, all of whom are unmarried and waiting the long months together to be delivered. Roberta Wilen, a publicschool teacher, runs it by herself on a parttime salary and even keeps after the girls for lesson assignments at night when they like to watch television, sew clothesmostly postnatal outfits for themselves rather than clothes for the babiesand try to relax in the temporary security of the Angel Guardian Home.

title: Two Arms Officials Resign
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Fred C. Ikle, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and his deputy, John F. Lehman Jr., resigned today, effective Jan. 20, the White House announced. Mr. Ikle, 52 years old, had served as the Government s chief arms control official since July 1973. Mr. Lehman, 35, had specialized in troop reduction issues.

title: Tenneco Plans A Gas Pipeline In New England
description: A subsidiary of Tenneco Inc. yesterday formally applied to the Federal Power Commission for permission to build a 498mile pipeline across New England to help deliver new supplies of Algerian natural gas.

title: ALEXANDER GOLDBERG
description: Alexander Goldberg, a retired food retailer and former vice commander of the American Veterans of the Jewish Legion died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 4500 Broadway.

title: Dow Declines by 6.65 to 972.41; Weakness Is Tied to Profit Taking
description: The stock market ignored some favorable economic news yesterday to close lower in less active trading.

title: 5 Brooklyn Rabbis Killed in Car Crash; 6th Seriously Hurt
description: Five Orthodox rabbis from Brooklyn were killed and another seriously injured early this morning when their car skidded into an oncoming tractortrailer about 25 miles west of Philadelphia.

title: Banked Passion
description: The banks of New York are famous for their seductive advertising. One after another they appear on television, undulating suggestively with hints of the delights in store once you surrender to them.

title: Business Records
description: Monday, Dec. 20, 1976

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is donating copies of his personal and official papers to the Library of Congress, but the public can virtually forget about seeing them before the year 2001.

title: Port Will Reduce Its Tonnage Fees In Move to Attract New Business
description: Longshoremen and shippingindustry employers agreed yesterday to a 15 percent reduction in the tonnage assessment levied on almost all oceanborne freight passing through the Port of New York. The assessment is used to pay for dockworkers' benefits such as pensions and guaranteed annual income.

title: East Germany Spurs Athletes to Olympian Heihgts
description: EAST BERLINKornelia Ender is an 18yearold East German citizen who grew up in the smoggy, smelly industrial city of Bitterfeld, which until last summer was known chiefly for the chemicals manufactured there.

title: Real People, Real Need
description: Sociologists are needed to study the weaknesses of social arrangements and governments to relieve the conditions those arrangements breed; but also needed are the warmth and efficiency of an agency which, without red tape or any kind of administrative costs, can bring help some of the city's most stricken individuals and families. That is the function of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, now in its 65th annual appeal for contributions.

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES ADDITIONAL SPENDING
description: TRENTON, Dec. 20The State Assembly gave final legislative passage today to a $36 million supplemental spending bill, but Governor Byrne said that he would veto it and scolded the lawmakers for hanging too many goodies on the Christmas tree.

title: Neumann, a selfEffacing Cleric, Won Esteem for Work With Poor
description: As a young man in his native Bohemia, John Nepomucene Neumann developed an avid interest in chess and spent many hours in matches with classmates. But suddenly he decided he had an inordinate desire to win, and he abruptly abandoned the game.

title: Court Rules Teachers Who Struck Must Pay Tax on Withheld Wages
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the 45,000 teachers who took part in the fiveday New York City public school strike in September 1975 must pay Federal income taxes on the five days gross pay they lost as a penalty.

title: People in Sports
description: Peter Carmichael, who was defensive coordinator the last three years at Columbia, has been signed to a threeyear contract as head football coach at the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I.

title: ExWest Point Cadet Says Most of Ousted Wish to Come Back
description: A West Point cadet ousted in the academy's cheating scandal said yesterday that 88 of 94 former fellow cadets surveyed by telephone Sunday had indicated they would return next month if given the option. A total of 151 cadets were implicated.

title: Suspect Gives Up After Robbery Of $250,000 From His Employer
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. Dec. 20 (UPI)A man robbed an armored car company of $250,000 and a van today but later surrendered voluntarily, the police said.

title: There Was Hardly Room to Admire Stars
description: Is there such a thing as too much success? Possibly, when about 450 men and women crowd into a room meant for 250, the music makes Con Edison drillers pale into insignificance, and the beleaguered waiters have to tackle their way to each table, leaving in their wake elbows and shins in a somewhat more fragile condition than they were at the beginning of the evening.

title: Swine Flu Fiasco
description: The sorry debacle of the swine flu vaccine program provides a fitting end point to the misunderstandings and misconceptions that have marked Government approaches to health care during the last eight years, when Washington power has been shared between a Republican White House and a Democratic Congress.

title: Daley Ruled Chicago With Total Control
description: Mayor Richard J. Daley was the last of a breed, the last of the big city bosses. For better or worse, he ruled the City of Chicago with almost total control for 22 years.

title: 2 HELD FOR HURLING. BOY OUT OF 6THFLOOR WINDOW
description: Two Bronx men were indicted yesterday on charges, of hurling a 9yearold boy from a sixthfloor apartment window and slashing an elderly man during a robbery earlier this year.

title: Qatar Petroleum Order
description: The Qatar Petroleum Company has awarded Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy industries a $169 million contract for construction of offshore gas gathering and transmission facilities for the country's natural gas liquid project. The plant is scheduled to begin production in 1979.

title: Brown and Marshall Reported Set As Defense and Labor Secretaries
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Presidentelect Jimmy Carter will attempt to end two appointment controversies tomorrow by naming Harold Brown to be his Secretary of Defense and F. Ray Marshall to be his Secretary of Labor, according to sources in the Carter camp.

title: A Controversial Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President elect Carter has made his most controversial Cabinet selection so far by asking his longtime friend and political supporter, Griffin B. Bell, to become Attorney General in his administration.

title: Screen: 'Across the Great Divide':Charming Tale of the West Will Delight Youngsters
description: Stewart Raffill, the writer-director, and Arthur R. Dubs, the producer of last year's Christmas bauble, "Adventures of the Wilderness Family," are not the ones to let a simple, profitable formula lie.Like kids ever ready to have a go at a second candy cane, they've tackled another innocents-versus-the-wilds confection in "Across the Great Divide," which arrived yesterday at the Guild and Embassy Theaters. And it's safe to say that their new holiday treat is as harmless, say, as that second candy cane, and it should charm the youngsters and even some indulgent grown-ups.If moviegoers with retentive memories detect similarities between "Wilderness Family" and "Great Divide" it is hardly important. Only an urban misogynist would sneer at the idea that once again the focus is on nave pioneers, the wilderness and such predators as a grizzly and cougars. But the Pacific Northwest and its fauna are still eye-fillingly photogenic and the principals are cheerful and endearing, if amazingly indomitable.A cynic might question this fiction about a youthful, self-reliant, orphaned sister and brother adrift in the forested high country in 1876, who, with the aid of a resourceful young con-man gambler, finally make it to the lush Oregon acres they've inherited.But action, a touch of humor and nonmarauding Indians give the proceedings a fair portion of realism. Our handsome gambler and our wandering pre-teen-agers are always on the run. If the youngsters are slow to accept his blarney, they grudgingly do come to trust him. But there's always that grizzly and the cougars who deprive them of their horses, as well as a snarling wolf pack to threaten them, and a band of dissolute, if comic, frontiersmen to keep them and the film moving at a fast clip.The Indians, led by George (Buck) Flower, are decent, family types who appreciate their help in driving off that man-eating grizzly. If some oddly Dickensian dialogue by a pair of newcomers. Heather Rattray and Mark Hall, can be overlooked, they emerge as natural and attractive kids. Robert Logan (one of the leads in "Wilderness Family") is properly stalwart as their knowledgeable protector. And they all blend well with the spectacular Utah and British Columbia landscapes in which "Great Divide" was shot.

title: FORD AND A.M.C. PLAN AN INCREASE IN LAYOFFS
description: DETROIT, Dec. 20The number of American and Canadian auto workers who will he idled next month because of slumping smallcar sales rose to 38,850 today with the announcement of new layoffs by the Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SURE THINGS There's nothing especially Christmasy about the new exhibition of Iranianmade locks (the key kind) on view through Jan. 12 at New York University. But this display of exotica463 specimens spanning 16 centuriesis perhaps unique to the local scene. The lockmaking show, sent here as a Bicentennial tribute from the Iranian people, is being circulated on a twoyear tour of American museums by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service.

title: 56 College Football Powers Plan New Group to Achieve Objectives
description: DALLAS, Dec. 20Fiftysix of the nation's most powerful football colleges met today to form a new group that will campaign for changes in National Collegiate Athletic Association rules they consider unfavorable to their programs.

Poor Murderer to Close

Directed by Herbert Berghof, it costars Laurence Luckinbill, Kevin McCarthy, Ruth Ford, Larry Gates and Maria Schell. Kermit and John Bloomgarden and Ken Marsolais produced the venture.

description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 (AP)The last oceangoing vessel of the season, a damaged Liberian freighter, made it into the St. Lawrence Seaway today some 40 hours after the system was scheduled to close.

description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 20The jury in the triplemurder trial of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis today heard more than six hours of summations by the two lawyers for the defendants and by the Passaic County Prosecutor.

title: J. Frank Drake, Former Chairman Of Gulf Oil Corporation, Dies at 96
description: J. Frank Drake, former head of the Gulf Oil Corporation and for many years a leader of the nation's oil industry, died yesterday at Concord Hospital in Concord, N.H. He was 96 years old and, until entering the hospital several weeks ago, was living in the same house in which he had been born in Pittsfield, N.H.

title: Carter Jokes of Bell As Stopgap Appointee
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 20 (UPI)Presidentelect Jimmy Carter said jokingly today that he was naming Griffin B. Bell as provisional Attorney General until Mr. Carter's brother, Billy, got his law degree.

description: ROME, Dec. 20A consistory of cardinals today formally approved the canonization of Bishop John Neumann, who will become the first American male saint.

title: Hanna T. Rose, a Retired Curator Of Brooklyn Museum, Dies at 67
description: Hanna T. Rose, who gained international recognition in her 41 years at the Brooklyn Museum for innovative work on the museum's role in education and in the community, died last Tuesday in Rhosneigr, Wales, where she had retired. She was 67 years old.

title: Paper to Publish Sunday
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP)The Johnstown TribuneDemocrat, a sixday daily newspaper, will publish a Sunday paper for the first time beginning March 6. Richard H. Mayer, publisher of the Tribune Publishing Company, said today that the decision was based in part on requests from advertisers.

description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 20Presidentelect Carter today named a longtime friend, Griffin B. Bell, to be Attorney General and selected two other Cabinet officers, including his first woman appointee.

description: BRUSSELS, Tuesday, Dec. 21 (UPI)Foreign ministers of the European Common Market reached a deadlock early today on negotiations for a joint fishing policy beginning in the new year.

description: The third network raidonEntebbe production, a threehour affair, will be televised by NBC next month.

title: An old Paris District, Hemmed In By Modernity, Is Becoming Chic
description: PARIS, Dec. 20It wasn't quite planned and nobody seems to know exactly when it happened, but it did: Another district of Paris has become an in place to live.

title: Alaska Mail Delivery Ends 7Month Lapse
description: NOME, Alaska, Dec. 20 (AP)The mail was delivered during the weekend to the remote Bering Strait island of Little Diomede for the first time in seven months. And villagers sent return mail and ballots from the Nov. 2 election on pIanes back to Nome, 130 miles to the southeast.

title: Pickup in Holiday Shopping Is Reported
description: After a sluggish start, Christmas shopping across the nation has picked up in recent days and retailers are predicting modest sales increases over 1975. However, the gains will still be below those of last year's strong season over 1974, according to a spotcheck a stores in major cities.

title: 26 Reported Slain in Rhodesia Raid
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 20 (Reuters)Security force headquarters said tonight that at least 26 black workers from a Rhodesian tea estate were shot to death by black guerrillas who raided the plantation, near the border with Mozambique, to abduct employees and their families.

title: Pilot in Baltimore Stadium Crash Faced an Earlier Flying Charge
description: The pilot of a light plane who crashed in the top deck of Baltimore's Memorial Stadium after Sunday's playoff football game had been free on $2,100 bond on a previous charge of reckless flying, the authorities said yesterday. For four years before last October, the pilot had been grounded for psychiatric reasons, the authorities said.

title: Madrid Accepts the Use of Catalan
description: MADRID, Dec. 20Prime Minister Adolfo Surez declared this evening in Barcelona that his Government accepted the equality of Spanish and Catalan in the regional bureaucracy of the four provinces of Catalonia.

title: China's Defense Minister Is Becoming Increasingly Prominent Figure
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Dec. 21Yeh Chienying, China's Minister of Defense and its senior military figure, is being given increasing prominence, analysts here believe, apparently as part of the growing role of the country's armed forces in Peking's new leadership.

title: RCA Says Inquiry Finds Conrad Failure on Taxes Is Not Tied to Its Business
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that an independent investigation has found that failure of Anthony L. Conrad, its deposed chairman and president, to file personal income tax returns for five years through 1975 was in no way related to the company's business.

title: Robert Selmer Bergland
description: WASHINGTON, Dec.20  A delegation of Representative Bob Bergland's farm constituents, attending a hearing of the House Agriculture Committee here last year, smiled and nodded assent as they heard a member demand high price supports for ag Manricultural commodities. But Mr. Bergland's ruddy, In the weathered countenance was News creased by a frown. And when his colleagues on the committee had finished, the Minnesota Democrat said that the proposal was unrealistic. Furthermore, he said, his colleague knew that it was unrealistic.

title: Hasidic Jews Protest Housing Plan
description: More than 8.000 Hasidic Jews demonstrated at City Hall for two hours yesterday morning to protest a plan to allow the recently completed Roberto Clemente Plaza housing development in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn to be occupied by a majority of black and Puerto Rican families.

title: Gay, Eagle Lineman, Killed
description: BLACKWOOD, N. J., Dec. 20 (UPI)The wife of a Philadelphia Eagles' defensive lineman, Blenda Gay, has been held in lieu of $100,000 bail for allegedly stabbing her husband to death this morning while the couple's 3yearold daughter slept beside them.

title: Rutgers Rallies And Overtakes Princeton, 5954
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 20There's no team tougher in the nation when they have you 4 points down with less than three minutes to play.

description: Richard A. Stengel and Laura Garwin didn't know each other very well when they were growing up in Scarsdale even though (as Miss Garwin remembered) they both attended the Westchester Reform Temple Sunday School and (as Mr. Stengel had to be reminded) were graduated together with the Scarsdale High School Class of 1973.

title: U.N. Endorses Armed Struggle By Blacks in SouthWest Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 20The General Assembly approved a resolution today that, for the first time, endorsed armed struggle for SouthWest Africa to secure independence from South Africa.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 20The Westchester Board of Legislators approved a county budget of $398.5 million tonight, reducing County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's holdtheline proposal by a further $1.04 million.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP)A fivehorse pileup at Suffolk Downs race track today left two jockeys injured, killed one thoroughbred instantly and forced the destruction of another.

description: MIAMI, Ariz.It has been 31 months since Ralph Bamerio, director of industrial hygiene at the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company complex here, received his first communiqu from the Federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration.

title: CIT Ordered to Divest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)The Federal Reserve Board said today that the CIT Financial Corporation of New York must divest itself of financial and real estate interests acquired after June 30, 1968, in order to continue as a bank holding company. CIT is one of the nation's largest consumerloan companies with more than $3.9 billion in outstanding personal and secondmortgage loans through its 1,000 consumer finance offices in the 50 states, Puerto Rico and Canada.

title: Henry Vose Greenough, Retired From Textile Company, 93
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 20Henry Vose Greenough, a retired textile executive, died yesterday in the Reservoir Nursing Home here after a long illness. He was 93 years old.

title: EDWARD H. CAIN
description: Edward H. Cain, retired president of the Buckley Brothers Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Shell Oil Company in Bridgeport, Conn., died Sunday in a hospital in Clearwater, Fla. His age was 68.

title: Justices Bar Extension Of Deadline for Filing Civil Rights Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled today that the time limit for filing civil rights complaints with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is not extended because an employee chooses to go first through union grievance procedures.

title: Raiders' Atkinson Warns Steelers: Colts Were Intimidated
description: Philip James Villapiano, the aggressive linebacker for the Oakland Raiders, defined playoff football yesterday as the stage began to form for Sunday's game in Oakland between the Raiders and the Pittsburgh Steelers. Villapiano was talking about the style of the Raiders last Saturday, when they beat the New England Patriots, 2421, and established a record for most penalties, 11 in a playoff game. The Steelers broke the mark the next day against Baltimore with 12.

title: Treasury Sells $3 Billion of 2Year Notes at an Average Rate of 5.3% as Markets Ease
description: The Treasury sold $3 billion of twoyear notes yesterday at an average rate of 5.37 percent, almost half a point lower than the rate in a similar sale a month ago. The Government's note sale took place as the credit markets backed down from the sharp gains they had made late Friday afternoon after the Federal Reserve reduced bank reserve requirements. At the close of the credit market yesterday, no overall trend was evident. The taxexempt bond sector held its gains, Government securities kept part of them and corporate bonds ended with small declines.

title: Year's Paper Production Of 61 Million Tons Tops Output in 1975 by 15%
description: Paper and paperboard production this year is expected to reach 61 million tons, a gain of 15 percent over the 52.9 million tons produced last year when the industry was in a recession, the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

title: John Cale Has Debut at CBGB
description: Well, that was easy enough. All John Cale had to do was put together a band and automatically he becomes one of the leading figures on the whole New York artpunkrock scene. His debut performances with his new group Sunday night at CBGB's were triumphant, and he will be back at the Bowery club Thursday through Saturday, as well as part of the Patti Smith and Television bill at the Paladium on New Year's Eve.

title: Holdup Man Killed With His Own Gun
description: A Brooklyn florist, forced into a car by three holdup men late last night, seized the revolver that one of the men was holding and fatally shot one of his assailants, as the two others fled.

title: MAYOR RICHARD DALEY OF CHICAGO DIES AT 74
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20Mayor Richard J. Daley, head of this city's Democratic machine and one of the most powerful Democrats in the country for more than two decades, died today of a heart attack.

title: 25 Die in Indonesia Floods
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 (Reuters) At least 25 people died in floods that swept through villages in Aceh, north Sumatra, following days of torrential rain, officials said today. The Antar?? News Agency reported more than 60,000 people were suffering from food shortages caused by a drought that had hit the rice crop in islands east of the holiday resort of Bali.

title: Tanker Grounded Off Nantucket Reported in 18 Earlier Accidents
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 (AP)The tanker Argo Merchant, grounded since Wednesday on the Nantucket shoals, had been involved in 18 other accidents, including two previous groundings, since 1964, according to the Center for Short Lived Phenomena.

title: Rabin Resigns Post; Vote Is Due by June

description: EAGLE PASS, Tex.Pools of water lay everywhere, and the road in Farias Ranch was a greasy sea of mud.

title: A PLAN TO REVITALIZE NEW YORK'S ECONOMY IS OFFERED BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame made public yesterday a fiveyear economicrecovery plan for New York City whose key new elements are tax reductions and an aggressive advertising and marketing program.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 20Third  world governments today announced their strategy for trying to put pressure on the Carter administration for immediate consideration of longsought reforms in the international economic order.

title: EMERGENCY POWER IS NEAR IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20Lebanon is moving quickly toward proclaiming a state of emergency with the institution of press censorship, suspension of the right of assembly without authorization, and the creation of military tribunals.

description: BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Dec. 16 Among the poorest and most isolated countries in the world, Burundi and its northern neighbor, Rwanda, are nonetheless yielding a rich lode for social theorists who are examining why two lands so alike in their past are so different in their present.

title: GENERAL AMNESTY URGED ON CARTER BY VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)Saying that Jimmy Carter's proposed pardon of Vietnamera draft resisters is too limited, a group of veterans called today for a general amnesty that would include the more than 700,000 men who got less than honorable discharges.

title: Bank Unearths Works of Byron And of Shelley
description: LONDON, Dec. 20A treasure chest of 19thcentury literary papers, including manuscripts, letters and poems by Byron and Shelley, has been discovered in a bank vault in the center of London.

title: Corporation Affairs

description: INDIANAPOLISThere is a sign in the office of the Opera Company of Boston that reads Freedom is the ability to take advantage of the unexpected.

title: G.N.P. Showed Rate Of Increase of 3.9% During Fall Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)The nation's total output of goods and services showed an annual rate of increase of 3.9 percent in the fall quarter, revised Government figures showed today.

title: Court Bars Tampa, Fla., Couple From Discriminating in Rentals
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP)The Department of Justice today obtained a court order requiring the owners of three apartment complexes inthe Tampa, Fla., area to rent to black persons.

title: A Transit Authority Patrolman, Working as Cabby, Shot to Death
description: A 36yearold Transit Authority patrolman, working as a medallioncab driver while on vacation, was found shot to death early yesterday on a quiet street of onefamily homes in Queens Village, Queens, the apparent victim of one or more robbers.

title: City Council Panel Votes to Honor Settler, Policeman and Veteran

For one, the name was to be bestowed on a street, for another on a park and for the third on a plaza.

title: Hartford Aide Criticizes Dropping Of Murder Charge Against Reilly
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 20  Chief State's Attorney Joseph T. Gormley Jr. today sharply criticized the judge for too hastily dismissing the case against Peter Reilly in his second trial on charges of killing his mother, and strongly defended the original trial in which Mr. Reilly was convicted of the crime.

title: NEWYORK HIGH COURT BACKS DISABILITY PAY IN PREGNANCY GASES
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that private employers must pay disability benefits to women who missed work because of pregnancy.

description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 20 (AP)Mike Woodson a freshman, scored 26 points and pulled down 10 rebounds as he led Indiana to a 7971 college basketball victory over Utah State tonight. Indiana, the defending National Collegiate champion, evened its wonlost record at 33.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20To the ranks of those reluctant to come to Washington to join the new Carter government, add the Presidentelect's own daughter, Amy.

title: DOCTOR GIVEN 2 YEARS FOR CHEATING MEDICARE
description: MIAMI, Dec. 20 (AP)A Federal judge sentenced a physician to two years in prison and fined him $45,000 for billing Medicare for services that he did no?? render.

title: Carter and Dr. Kreps Share 2 Verbal Jabs
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 20 (UPI)Dr. Juanita Kreps graciously thanked Jimmy Carter today for naming her Commerce Secretary and then gave him two little verbal jabs that he accepted with a smile.

description: The plight of a needy child or the hardship faced by a lonely elderly person has led many contributors to the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to request that their gifts be allocated to the very young or the aged.

description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP)The Moscow subway system today recorded its 40 billionth passenger in 41 years of operation, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Shellfishing Is Barred by Rupture Of Jersey Sewage Outflow Pipe
description: LONG BEACH TOWNSHIP, N. J., Dec. 20 (AP)The rupture of a sewage plant outflow pipe here has resulted in a ban on all shellfishing along the shores of western Long Beach Island, state authorities said.

title: Notes on People
description: New couple on the Manhattan scene: Governor Carey and Ethel Kennedy. According to some acquaintances, the widowed Governor and the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy have been dating occasionally for the last couple of months, mostly at private parties at the homes of friends, now and then at places like 21 or Le Club. On Friday, they dined at the home of her brotherinlaw, Stephen Smith. The Governor has been seeing less of Anne Ford, his frequent date for the last year or so. Confronted with a request for confirmation of these unofficial doings, the Governor's press office issued the following comment: We do not comment on the Governor's personal schedule. End of social note.

title: CARTER NAMES FRIEND AS ATTORNEY GENERAL AND SELECTS WOMAN

title: Respect and Approval for Carter's Actions
description: At a private luncheon in New York last week, a highlevel corporate executive with close ties to the Ford Administration was asked how he viewed the imminence of a Democratic Administration in Washington and what changes he thought it might mean for the business world. Without hesitation and qualification, he answered: I like very much what I've been seeing in the approach and the philosophy of Jimmy Carter. I think he has been best described as a conservative on economic issues and a liberal in the social fielda pretty good combination. And it looks like his first 100 days won't come until 1980.

The popular American pianist played last night in Carnegie Hall before a nearcapacity audience, and he selected a series of pieces from which most strong pianists would shrink. Schubert, with the posthumous C minor Sonata. Brahms, with both books of Paganini Variations. Prokofiev, with the Sonata No. 3. A Rachmanioff group.

title: Ned Washington, Lyricist, Dead; Songs and Scores Won 3 Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 (UPI)Ned Washington, who won three Academy Awardsfor his film score of Walt Disney's Pinocchio, the best song of the same movie, When You Wish Upon Star, and the theme of High Noon'died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 75 years old.

title: 'Mikey and Nicky,' Film on Amity
description: Elaine May's first two films, "A New Leaf" and "The Heartbreak Kid," were comedies of sometimes inspired and often touching lunacy, mostly about the uncertain progress of romantic love between men and women. Her third film, "Mikey and Nicky," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie, is something else entirely.It's a melodrama about male friendship told in such insistently claustrophobic detail that to watch it is to risk an artificially induced anxiety attack. It's nearly two hours of being locked in a telephone booth with a couple of method actors who won't stop talking, though they have nothing of interest to say, and who won't stop jiggling around, though they plainly aren't going anywhere."Mikey and Nicky," which Miss May wrote as well as directed, takes place in one approximately 12-hour period. It involves a lot of self-conscious exposition that never quite succeeds in telling us all we have a decent right to know.It's about a couple of small-time Los Angeles hoods who've grown up together, joined the same mob and now, on this particular night, find their lifelong relationship passing in front of our eyes in aggressive close-up.Nicky (John Cassavetes), convinced that his bosses have put out a contract on his life, summons Mikey (Peter Falk) to his hideout in a fleabag hotel. Nicky needs help. He's scared out of his wits. He's coming apart at the seams. He's afraid of being murdered but his ulcer is killing him anyway. He isn't sure he can trust Mikey, but if he can't trust Mikey, he can't trust anybody.When Mikey arrives at the hotel, Nicky at first refuses to let him in, but then he relents. The two men embrace. They are in tears. They clutch each other. They laugh. They cry. They argue. They reconcile. Mikey tries to be reasonable with his distraught friend.Mikey: "Who told you [there was a contract out on you]?"Nicky: "Someone I know told me."Mikey: "How do you know it's true?"Nicky: "How do you know it's not true?"Later in the evening, Mikey angrily accuses Nicky of having nicknamed him "the echo" for always saying everything twice. But so do Nicky and everyone else in the film. Miss May used to write that kind of dialogue to be funny. This time she means to be serious but the method isn't good enough."Mikey and Nicky" follows the friends as they wander in aimless desperation around a neon-lit city, and as we learn eventually that Mikey is, in fact, the finger man.By this time, though, it's too late to retrieve the film from the kind of busy banality that Mr. Cassavetes' own films, including his recent "The Killing of a Chinese Bookie," fall into when actors take over from the director, apparently with the director's full approval.Though we are told more than once that the Cassavetes character is a charmer and that he has always treated his friends rottenly, including Mikey, there's no evidence in the performance that Nicky is charming in any way. Nor do we believe that Mikey is a jerk, as he's supposed to be. Both actors are, in fact, as interchangeable in their characters as are their character names. It's significant, I think, that as I write this review I have to keep referring to my notes to remember which actor plays which part.Short portions of the film come to vivid life, especially toward the end. There's a very funny, typically urban confrontation between Mr. Cassavetes and an officious lady on a bus who doesn't want to start up with his "element," and a fine sequence in an all-black bar whose patrons take Mikey and Nicky for white cops. Not so good is a sequence in a neighborhood bar where Miss May's camera keeps panning across the great faces of the real-life (I'm sure) customers as if she were showing us Hindu tempe carvings.Several supporting actors have some good moments, including Ned Beatty, who plays the hired murderer who worries about the cost of the gasoline he's using up, and Carol Grace, who is superb as a slightly dimwitted girlfriend of Mr. Cassavetes. What Mr. Cassavetes and Mr. Falk do, though, exists beyond the fringe of film criticism. They just seem to be carrying onmaking elaborate actorish fussesin front of the camera.Miss May is a witty, gifted, very intelligent director. It took guts for her to attempt a film like this, but she failed.

Another 50,000 were American and European tourists.

title: Notes on People
description: Kenya's new permanent representative to the United Nations will be Margaret Kenyatta, the 48yearold daughter of President Jomo Kenyatta. Mr. Kenyatta announced the appointment of his daughter, who has been Mayor of Nairobi since 1970, in the capital city yesterday. Earlier this year Miss Kenyatta announced she would not seek reelection as Mayor, but she later reversed herself in response to demands from women's groups. That set off a dispute in the city council, and as a result the Government postponed elections indefinitely. Miss Kenyatta's appointment was viewed as a means of moving matters off dead center and opening the way for elections.

At City Hall, he was The Man on Five. They came to him, obeisantly: precinct captains, industrialists. Presidential candidates.

title: GRAINS & FEEDS
11 in Mine Blast Died Quickly
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21 (UPI)The 11 men who died in the second Scotia coal mine explosion, on March 11, were killed almost instantly by the force of the blast, seconds after they had begun a desperate dash to the surface, a pathologist reported today. There is no way they could have survived, said Dr. George Nichols, a Cincinnati, Ohio, forensic pathologist. He was hired by Kentucky health officials to issue a medical report on the disaster.

title: Bell Is `Concerned About Membership In Exclusive Clubs
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney Generaldesignate, said tonight that he was concerned and would do something before going, to Washington about membership he holds in two Atlanta clubs whose rosters list no blacks and few, if any. Jews.

title: Union Wage Increase Found to Average 8.9%
description: At yearend, workers think in terms of their financial outlook for the next 12 months. Will they bring raises, either through their own merit or through collective bargaining?

title: Cuellar and Harper Placed On Waivers by Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles have placed Mike Cuellar and Tommy Harper on waivers, the general manager, Hank Peters, announced today.

title: Celtics' Ard in Hospital
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP)Jimmy Ard, Boston Celtics center, has been hospitalized for at least three days for treatment of an infected elbow, the club said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in The Times yesterday tricotrectly reported that officials of the Roberto Clemente Plaza housing development planned to rent 75 percent of the apartment units to Hasidic families, The officials plan to rent 75 percent to black and Puerto Rican families and 25 percent to whites.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The LTV Corporation and its Jones & Laughlin Industries subsidiary restructured their bank credit arrangements by combining existing bank credits of the two into a new Jones & Laughlin credit that provides for borrowings of as much as $195 million. The agreement provides for a group of banks headed by the Bank of America to provide funds on a revolving basis until Dec. 31, 1978, with the amount outstanding at that date to be repaid over a fiveyear period ending Dec. 31, 1983.

title: Going out Guide
description: ROUNDUP There is quite a musical bill scheduled for 8 o'clock tonight in the Felt Forum at Madison Square Gardena program geared to show the diversity of musicians who perform in New York in various styles of the Latin jazz, folk, rock, blues and rhythm genres. The holiday special is benefit saluting local activities of the United Farm Workers of America.

title: Study of Bell's Rulings as Appellate Judge Shows Mixed Record in Civil Rights Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Griffin B. Bell, Presidentelect Carter's choice as Attorney General, voted as a Federal Appellate court judge to uphold the constitutionality of a critical part of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. As part of that case, he also voted to enjoin the state of Georgia from holding certain elections pursuant to a disputed reapportionment plan.

title: JOSEPH NORTH DIES; COMMUNIST EDITOR
description: Joseph North, a veteran correspondent and editor for The Daily Worker, died Monday of leukemia at a hospital in San Juan, P. R., while on a visit. He was 72 years old and lived at 103 Cambridge Place in Brooklyn.

title: Associated Press HEADING FOR THE SLOPES: Susan Ford, the President's daughter, on her way to a ski lift in Vail, Colo., where her family is vacationing.
Westinghouse Agrees to a Decree After S.E.C. Disclosure Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged the Westinghouse Electric Corporation with failing to make adequate disclosure of its material potential financial exposure In the form of uncovered commitments to deliver uranium.

title: Delay in Mails Costs Many Towns U.S. Aid Expected for Public Works
description: NEWARK, Dec, 21The recent strike against United Parcel Service, compounded by the Christmas mail rush, will apparently cost dozens of New Jersey towns millions of dollars in anticipated Federal public works funds.

title: Bettors Get a Tax Reprieve
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service gave racetrack bettors today a reprieve from a plan to withhold taxes from their winnings.

title: Theater:John Noonan's Hothouse
description: Though John Ford Noonan's material can be strange, even macabre, his approach is goodnatured and amiable. He has an impish, offcenter humorand he also has an unfortunate tendency to be whimsical, amply demonstrated in his new play, GoodBy and Keep Cold at the Ensemble Studio Theater.

title: Coast Gunman Holds Two on Plane
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (UPI)  A gunman who seized two United Airlines maintenance workers as hostages and commandeered an empty jetliner, stabbed one of his captives tonight when the authorities refused to allow the plane to take off.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov Nutcracker
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Half of the American dance world seemed to be gathered at the Kennedy Center here tonight for the world premiere of Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of The Nutcracker, for American Ballet Theater. This was the first time Mr. Baryshnikov has tried his hand at choreography, and, moreover, the entire concept and direction of the production was his alone. Could the 28yearold dancer emerge triumphannt when faced with the entire responsibility for a full evening production?

title: World Bank Votes Loans to Chile Of $60 Million, With U.S. in Favor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The executive directors of the World Bank approved today by a large margin two loans to Chile totaling $60 million despite a negative vote from the director representing the Scandinavian countries and abstentions by five other directors with European constituencies.

title: $475 MILLION SALE OF NOTES ARRANGED
description: Three major bank holding companies announced yesterday that they had completed arrangements to sell a total of $475 million of longterm notes to institutional investors. The implication was clear that some highlevel financial executives at

title: U.S. Networks Lose Soviet Olympic Deal
description: The three commercial American television networks have been finessed out of the competition to get rights to broadcast the 1980 Olympic Games from Moscow to the United States.

title: On Li, Mall's No Longer the In
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I.Now that she is 15 years old an has discovered New York City, Nina Goldman can look back with amusement on the distant time when the shopping centers of suburbia were her world.

title: Marquette Bows Again as Minnesota Triumphs, 6659
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (AP)Minnesota. sparked by Mike Thompson's 23 points, opened a 24point lead early in the second half and held off a furious Marquette rally tonight for a 6659 college basketball victory.

title: Rohatyn Says New York Can't Rely On Credit Markets in Full for Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said today that New York City would almost certainly be unable to reenter the credit markets in full when its Federal loan program expired in mid1978even if the city met the legal deadline to balance its budget by then.

title: Religious Panhandlers Are Provoking Anger at Airports
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21Aggressive religious panhandlers, most notably members of the Hare Krishna sect, are stirring anger at airports and other transportation centers across the country and in the process creating a major constitutional question on the extent to which they can inflict themselves on others in the exercise of religious frAedorrt.

title: Dance: Joffrey's Holiday Season
description: Opening its first Christmas season, the Joffrow Pn.11et came up withpleasant jolt last night at the City Center. The surprise was John Cranico.r. Pineapp!e Poll, not given here for folk years and now as bright as a halfpenny in a new staging by Celia Franca..For a quintessentially British ballet, the _results were jolly good.

title: The President and the Bible
description: The President of the United States stands in the biting wind of Inaugural Day. He is surrounded by crowds, but he stands alone. His vocation causes him to tremble. Pressures from outside are mounting. Today, however, we encourage him to listen to the still voice from within. We encourage him to stay his balance by the presence of God's peace. And we do presume to suggest some of what a President is called upon to do who publicly has stated that he shares the Jewish and Christian understanding of reality found in the Bible.

title: HARLEM HOSPITAL SCORED ON. ALCOHOLISM PROGRAM
description: The New York State Department of Mental Hygiene reported yesterday that it had informed the Hospital for Joint Diseases in Harlem that its alcoholism program might lose its state certification unless serious deficiencies in administration, supervision and operation were corrected.

The U.N. Today
description: Dec. 22, 1976 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Charles William Duncan Jr.
description: The new Deputy Secretary of Deftrise has served as chairman of the Houstonbased Rotan Mosle Financial Corporation, a financial holding concern, since September 1964 . . . Was president of the Duncan Foods Company, at one time familyowned, when it was acquired by the CooaCola Company in 1964 . . . Immediately named a director of CocaCola and assumed its presidency in 1971 ... The 50yearold Houston native is one of the largest holders of CocaCola common stock, with 170,000 shares currently worth $13.4 million . . . Holds a degree in chemical engineering from Rice University and did graduate work in management at the University of Texas ... Now serves as director of CocaCola, the Great Southern Corporation, A.P.S. Inc. and Southern Railway System . . Also is advisory director of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. and is on the advisory council of the Trust Company of Georgia ... Described by friends as softspoken but firm ... An outdoorsman, he relaxes at his ranch in Cody, Wyo., whore he hunts, plays tennis and goes fishing . .. Married to his second wife, the former Anne Smith, and they have two children.

title: U.S. Networks Lose Soviet Olympic Deal
description: The three commercial American television networks have been finessed out of the competition to get exclusive rights to broadcast the 1980 Olympic Games from Moscow to the United States.

title: Ford Urges Restudy of 72 Order Barring Poison to Destroy Coyotes
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 21President Ford, now in the waning days of his Administration, has directed that a 1972 executive order barring the wholesale use of poison to destroy coyotes be reexamined to determine if it is necessary.

title: Flames Players to Help Atlanta Keep Club There
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21 (AP)The Atlanta Flames said today that the team's players would purchase $25,000 worth of tickets in an effort to keep the National Hockey League team in Atlanta.

title: Film: By Lizzie Borden at Whitney
description: Lizzie Borden, who is described as a writer and critic in program notes and obviously is not the late, historic cutup, is indecisive as a film maker in Regrouping, which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Her documentation of a sodality of four, young liberated women seeking mutuality and identity and their eventual disenchantment and breakup, is, despite its pointed honesty, blunted by diffuse filming and narrative techniques.

title: People in Sports
description: Orland Kurtenbach, one of the quietest and most efficient enforcers in the National Hockey League during his playing days, was named coach of the floundering Vancouver Canucks yesterday. Kurtenbach, who brooked no nonsense from opposing players, replaced Phil Maloney, who will devote full time as general manager. I can no longer tolerate the situation, Maloney said of the Canucks 9233 wonlosttied record.

title: Sale of The Nation Magazine to Morgan Called Off, And He Now Plans to Publish New National Journal
description: The publisher of The Nation magazine said yesterday that the previously announced agreement to sell the 111yearold political weekly to Thomas B. Morgan, former editor of The Village Voice, had fallen through, with the principals disagreeing on the reason.

title: TV: 14thCentury Holiday Treat
description: WNET/13's Great Performances series, made possible by support from Exxon Corporation and PBS member stations, has discovered something very special for the holiday season in the program files of the British Broadcasting Corporation. The Christmas Chester Mystery Plays, which can be seen tonight at 9, are eight short dramatizations used to illustrate Biblical stories. The playlets date from the late 14th century and were first performed by craft guilds in the city of Chester. England.

description: There are a lot of unnecessary things in life and perfumed candles are among them. But they are also, for the most part, too small a sybaritic pleasure to be sinful.

title: C.A.B. Requested to Make Airlines Subtract Lobbying Cost From Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)A consumer's group asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to make airlines adopt accounting rules that identify the cost of lobbying and subtract it from passenger fares..

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Newark police have issued 24 more summonses to seven city stores for violations of the Sunday closing laws, Preseculor Joseph P. Lordi of Essex County said. Nine summonses were issued to Bamberger's and Hahne's, along with 15 summonses to five other city stores, he said. Two Guys, which was open on previous Sundays, remained closed last Sunday in response to a contempt conviction last week in Bergen County Superior Court. Vornado Inc:, the parent company of Two Guys, will be fined for allegedly violating a voluntary agreement not to sell banned merchandise until a judge ruled on the concern's legal challenge to the blue laws. A ruling on the suit challengingthe law, which is in effect in 11 of the state's 21 counties, is expected next month.

title: Glen Rock School in FuelConservation Program
description: GLEN ROCK, Dec. 21The Central EICmentary School in this Bergen County community has been selected with nine others in the United States for a $2 million energyconservation program aimed at reducing heating costs in the nation's 1 schools.

description: The Argo Merchant oil spill would rank about 10th in total oil volume spilled from broken tankers, even if all its oil Leaks out, but its potential for ecological and economic damage is far greater than its size might indicate.

description: Handel's Messiah has been used and abused in every conceivable performance fashion during the 234 years of its existence, but at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night it had the glitter and grandeur of a brandnew masteroiece.

title: Grumbles in the Jungle: Some Thumbs Just Aren't Green
description: Suddenly, after years or sweettalking her house plants, Sylvia Nowve is taking a sharper tone. Frankly, the schoolteacher was saying in a voice all too audible to the ivy on the windowsill, I have had it. I have poured energy, time, money and real love into these ungrateful things and I've just been slammed down every time.

title: Landslide in Jamaica
description: Jamaica's fourth general election since independence offered the voters a clearcut choice and they delivered a clearcut verdict: a landslide for Prime Minister Michael Manley's People's National Party (P.N.P.). It was unfortunate that the election was held under a state of emergency and with some Government opponents in detention; but the dimensions of the P.N.P. victory left no doubt that most Jamaicans want Mr. Manley to continue to lead the country toward his own brand of democratic socialism.

title: Freddie Ray Marshall
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Last year, George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., invited F. Ray Marshall, a labor economist at the University of Texas, to Washington to meet Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, the dissident Soviet author. In introducing Professor Marshall to Mr. Solzhenitsyn, Mr. Meany said, I want you to meet one of the few American professors who understands the working people. That, in capsule, is Mr. Marshall's reputation in labor, business and academic circles, and it is a reputation that makes him an acceptable choice as Secretary of Labor to a variety of interests.

title: The Mayor
description: Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago was the last and perhaps the ablest of a vanishing breed of bigcity bosses. New York has not seen a leader in city politics with his unrivaled power since Charles Murphy of Tarnmany Hall died more than half a century ago. Other bigcity mayors or party bosses in the old styleJames M. Curley of Boston, Frank Hague of Jersey City, Toni Pendergast of Kansas Citymet defeat or disgrace at the end of their careers.

description: NEW PROVIDENCE, N. J.When the Coddington property became available, Nat Conte wasted no time. He had had his eye on it ever since he started building the quaint shopping and office center known as Murray Hitl Square in the Murray Hill section of this town west of Summit. With the Coddington land. he could expand.

There may be violinists of greater flash, intensity or musicological conscientiousness. But there can't be many who can match him for beautiful sounds when he is playing at his best.

description: If public television's 260 stations are to succeed in their mission of offering an alternative on the dial to network broadcastingso dominated by the demands of sponsors and the ratings systemthen they must be innovative, courageous and immunized from the pressures of commercialism. Particularly in public TV, you know you're doing something right when you're in trouble.

title: Harold Brown
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Looking back at his career over the past 25 years, it almost seems that Harold Brown, the brilliant young physicist, was being groomed by the scientific component of the militaryindustrial complex to be Secretary of Defense some day. At the age of 23, shortly after receiving his doctorate in physics from Columbia University he was recruited by the Atomic Energy Commission to help design weapons, and became a protege of Dr. Edward Teller, the developer of the hyrogen bomb, at the Livermore Laboratory in California.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  Munro Leaf, the author and illustrator of scores of internationally popular children's books, including The Story of Ferdinand, died today of cancer at his home in suburban Garrett Park, Md. He was 71 years old.

description: After a weak start yesterday, soybean futures prices showed a gain in quiet trading. The January delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade closed at $6.88 a bushel, up from $6.83.
