description: The Board of Estimate was unable early this morning after a 15andonehalfhour session to reach agreement on new lines for community districts in New York City's five boroughs.

title: 'Nickelodeon': Not Much Movie for the Money
description: Peter Bogdanovich knows a great deal about movies, including how they are made. Perhaps he doesn't know why they are made. In any case, knowing how something is made isn't the same as making it. "Nickelodeon" is two hours and two minutes of impersonations.Some of them are very good impersonationsdeft and funnybut they lack a life to string them together. The effect is like a vaudevillian imitating a Frenchman making a speech. The imitation is fine but there is no speech.Despite its length, which is one of its problems, there isn't much movie in "Nickelodeon," which opened yesterday at the Columbia I and II Theaters.Its subject has been pretty heavily treated of late. It is about the early days of movie-making. Slapstick in style and picaresque in form, it is closer to such spoofs as "Hearts of the West" and "Won Ton Ton the Dog Who Saved Hollywood" than to "Day of the Locust" or "The Last Tycoon."It is not really a spoof though. At the end Mr. Bogdanovich has his raggle-taggle band of movie makers, given a contract after many reverses, pass a lighted sound-stage. "They're making a movie," says Ryan O'Neal, as their director, in a near-choked voice.Mr. Bogdanovich mistreats his love for the vitality of American movie-making by proclaiming it so breathily. He mistreats his love for the tricks of the trade, especially the slapstick comic trade, by virtually italicizing each trick as he trots it out.HarriganMr. O'Nealis an incompetent lawyer who meets up with Cobb, a manic film producer who is battling the big companies. Some meaningless remark leads Cobb first to hire him as a writer, then to send him out West to take over a band of actors and technicians whose director has decamped. Harrigan gets entangled with an unskilled hooferplayed by Jane Hitchcockand an unskilled rodeo riderBurt Reynoldsadds them to the company, and begins to make movies.It's easy, the cameraman tells him "These are the actors. This is the camera. You tell me where to place it, and when you have enough you tell me 'cut.' "It is a nice rendering of the casual improvisation of early movie-makingparodied, but only marginally. Mr. Bogdanovich arranges for some good things to happen. There is a fine trolley-car scene where Cobb's film company rides to the set inventing the script along the way. Not only is the idea-man subject to fits, he also produces ideas only when he has them.There are any number of sight gags. Somenotably one involving two monocled Germans who make movies clandestinely at the back of a pastry shopare very funny. Too many, though, are obvious quotes from old slapstick routines. The shock of recognition, such as it is, quite overpowers the impulse to laugh.Mr. Bogdanovich lets his routines run on too long. There is an endless fight between Mr. O'Neal and Mr. Reynolds. It is choreographed as a comic ballet: It is infinitely familiar, infinitely slick and not at all funny. Rather than giving us a sense that the movie is going somewhere, the routines succeed one another endlessly. They are a parade that totally interrupts any traffic that might be around.Mr. Reynolds is appealing, and sometimes quite funny as the cowhand who becomes a reluctant star. Miss Hitchcock, with wide cheeks and a pointed chin, seems to have comic potential but the point is never really proved. Tatum O'Neal plays a sarcastic but useful brat as if she'd been there before and too often.Mr. O'Neal is a major mistake. He has very little talent for comedy. The way to be funny is not to try intensely to be funny. It is to be yourself so single-mindedly as to be funny. If Mr. O'Neal has a self he has left it at home.On opening day "Nickelodeon" was charging a nickel admission. That's underpricing it; 75 cents would be about right.The film has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It's hard to see why any such caution is put in. There is nothing that could conceivably be objectionable in it.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP, BUT RISE IS MODERATE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21consumer prices rose a relatively moderate threetenths of 1 percent last month and food prices dropped, the Labor Department reI ported today.

title: Advertising
description: Most of the top people at the top ad agencies, which are coming to the end of a fabulous year, are projecting 10 percent to 20 percent billings gains for 1977.

title: Cooke Offers a Mass for Bishop. Neumann
description: Hundreds of worshipers gathered at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral yesterday for mass offered by Terence Cardinal Cooke to honor the approval Monday of Bishop John N. Neumann for sainthood by a consistory of Cardinals in Rome. Bishop Neumann had been ordained a priest at that cathedral 140 years ago.

title: Memphis Player Dies
description: MEMPHIS, Dec. 21 (AP)Memphis State basketball player, John Gunn, died today at Baptist Hospital after brief illness. The 20yearold Gunn, junior center averaging 12.3 points, entered the hospital Dec. 11 with an illness diagnosed as StevensJohnson syndrome, a condition that attacks the body's mucous membrane.

title: Explanations, Please
description: The Transit Authority has evaded a direct response so far to a Board of Estimate order that it hold a public hearing on proposed service cuts. A senior officer insisted that the Authority would always comply with legal requirements, but declined to acknowledge that the hearing order is legally binding, as the Board insists.

description: In the opinion of a selfstyled despairing optimist, the 20yearold, multinational drive to harness thermonuclear fusion to create electric power resembles a group of pioneers crossing a river and climbing a milehigh mountainonly to confront a range of mountains 10 miles high.

description: UNIONDALE, L. L, Dec. 21 BillEE! BillEE! BillEE! shouted most of the 14,985 fans, the largest crowd to see a hockey game in Nassau Coliseum history. That was for the 30 shutout Billy Smith posted against the Boston Bruins tonight.

title: Bell Is Concerned About Membership In Exclusive Clubs
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney Generaldesignate, said tonight that he was concerned and would do something before going to Washington about membership he holds in two Atlanta clubs whose rosters list no blacks and few. if any, Jews.

title: Western Schizophrenia
description: LONDONI don't know whether it is more accurate to use schizophrenia or dichotomy to describe the present condition of the West but there is no doubt of a disturbing contrast between its announced goal of drawing closer together and its visible fragmentation.

title: Frozen Track Shuts Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Dec. 21 (AP)Racing was canceled at Laurel Race Course today because the track was frozen. Rain last night was followed by freezing temperatures.

title: Split Tanker Leaves 60Mile Oil Slick Off Nantucket
description: MASHPEE, Mass., Dec. 21A grounded Liberianflag tanker broke in half off Nantucket this morning, spilling some five million gallons of heavy crude oil into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Mrs. Habersatter Posts 2d Ski Victory
description: ZELL AM SEE, Austria, Dec. 21 (UPI) Brigitte Totschnig Habersatter of Austria, taking advantage of a spill by Annemarie Proell Moser, captured her second downhill ski race. in 24 hours today.

title: Toyota to Lift Output
description: TOKYO, Dec. 21 (UPI)Toyotaannounced plans today to produce and sell 2.67 million units in 1977, an increase of 7.7 percent over this year's estimate of 2.48 million units.

title: 400 Evacuated at Chemical Plant
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 21 (AP) About 400 employees of a chemical plant here were evacuated yesterday after paint fumes filled the production area of the plant, causing several employees to complain of dizziness, the police said. One employee of the company, the Fluid Chemical, was admitted to Paul Kimball Hospital and three others were released after emergencyroom treatment, the police said.

title: On L.I., Growing Up Means Leaving the Mall
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I.Now that she is 15 years old and has discovered New York City, Nina Goldman can look back with amusement on the distant time when the shopping centers of suburbia were her world.

title: Vance May Pick Some Outsiders
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Cyrus R. Vance, the Secretary of Statedesignate, has promised to bring a new look to the State Department and has talked of giving some top jobs to prominent outsiders even if they have little or no foreign policy background.

title: Joys and Problems of Christmas On Corporate Headquarters Row
description: Park Avenue from 46th Street to 39th Street is home to one of the biggest concentrations of corporate headquarters in the world. There stand American Brands, Union Carbide, Joseph H. Seagram & Sons, Lever Brothers, Citicorp and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, among others. It is a street of

title: Nat'l Hockey League
OPEC Providing Loans Of $42.7 Million Today To ThirdWorld Nations
description: VIENNA, Dec. 22The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will sign agreements tomorrow to provide interestfree 25year loans totaling $42.7 million to the Central African Republic, Guinea, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, the Sudan and Western Samoa.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONThey were literally imploring us to have faith in them, said a business executive who had attended the closeddoor meeting, and quite frankly, some of us were impressed.

title: Dividends
RamsVikings Analyzed As Even Game Sunday
description: Now there are four and on Sunday night there will be two as the National Football League's version of musical chairs continues. The four surviving playoff teams will play for the National and American Conference championships on Sunday, Los AngeAbout Pro Football les and Minnesota at Bloomington, Minn. (Channel 2, P.M.), followed by Oakland and Pittsburgh at Oakland (Channel 4. 4 P.M.). The winners qualify for the Super Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., on Jan. 9 and the games come in the wake of the controversial division playoffs last weekend. The controversy centered on some questionable officiating that worked against Dallas arid New England and some weak telecasting as to camera alertness and commentary that worked against the public interest.

title: To Jody, Jack . . .
description: WASHINGTON  Once again, the burden of a national election has passed over the country. The results are now felt everywhere. By glimpses, we see the dreams of the winners beginning to take on the hard test of reality, and the defeated dismissed from service almost overnight. For, in the ebb and flow of Washington power struggles, there is barely room for success, and certainly none for failure.

title: Russel Wright, Pioneer Designer In the Modern Mode, Is Dead at 72
description: Russel Wright, the pioneer industrial designer and the first to popularize modern design in America, died in New York Hospital yesterday of a heart attack.

title: About New York
description: It is midday in Manhattan, and new shooter emerges among the group cf businessmen at the craps man with a little checked fedora Wila nervously shifts his cigar from one side of his mouth to the other and ruffles a stack of $25 chios.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: New York Gets PublicWorks Aid
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that the city was about to receive a muchneeded Christmas gift$102.2 million in Federal funds for 51 capitalconstruction projects that are expected to create 2,500 construction jobs.

title: Paramount Pictures to Acquire Assets of Hughes TV Network
description: The Paramount Pictures Corporation has agreed to acquire the assets of the Hughes Television Network division of the Summa Corporation.

title: Why Not The Best?
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22These are hard times for people who believed that Jimmy Carter would give us a government of hope, of fresh ideas and humane concerns. He has chosen all but one of his Cabinet members now, and the list hardly inspires the exhilaration that some of us expected. The feeling, rather, is disappointment verging on dismay.

title: Jersey Mayor Calls Tinsel at City Hall Violation of ChurchState Separation
description: ENGLEWOOD, Dec. 22A watercolor painting of carolers on a glass office door at City Hall and Mayor Sondra J. Greenberg's hiterpretation of it as a violation of the constitutional separation of church and state have somewhat soured the holiday mood here.

title: Daley Eulogized at Funeral Service; Thousands in Chicago Pay Tribute
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22Mayor Richard J. Daley was eulogized today at a mass of the resurrection as a great and powerful man, but humble before God, his family, the city he ruled for more than two decades and the people he loved and who loved him.

title: ARTHUR W. HIGGINS
description: Arthur W. Higgins, a vice president of DCA Food Industries of New York, died yesterday at his home on Midlane South in Syosset. L.I.

title: Cutting African Births
description: WASHINGTONRecently, a number of enlightened voices have urged bigger food programs for underdeveloped countries in order to avoid great suffering. This is the only decent thing to do, and of course food aid is consistent with our finest traditions. However, unless the character of our foreignaid programs is recast, putting more emphasis on population growth rate reduction, any suffering we prevent today will be compounded many times a generation hence.

title: Indictments Charging Cunningham With Selling Judgeship Dismissed
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday dismissed major indictments against Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic County chairman.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Gloria Whitman Is Married to A. Wickes Rossiter 3d
description: Gloria Louise Whitman, daughter of Sybil Cood of Woodburn, Ore., and Walter H. Whitman of Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to A. Wickes Rossiter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rossiter of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington. L.I.

title: Rangers Rally, Tie Flyers, 33, On Goals by Gilbert, Esposito.
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22 (AP)  Willie Plett, a rookie, got into two firstperiod fights, spent 12 minutes in the penalty box and then scored on a 50foot slap shot tonight to lead the Atlanta Flames to a 21 N.H.L. victory over Detroit.

title: A Curator's World: Where Clothing Ends And Fashion Begins
description: Now that the show The Glory of Russian Costume has settled down to a successful run at the Metropolitan Museum of. Art  27,000 people wandered through it in the first weekStella Blum can settle back into her regular routine.

description: A Federal grand jury is hearing allegations that high officials of the Central Intelligence Agency and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were involved in a conspiracy to fabricate and coordinate the statements they made to a 1973 Senate inquiry into I.T.T.'s role in Chile, Justice Department sources said yesterday.

title: Bell Will Quit All Private Clubs
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney Generaldesignate, said today that, because he believed that the Attorney General is a symbol of equality before tree law, he would resign his membership in all private clubs, including two in Atlanta that have no black and few, if any, Jewish members, and one in Savannah reported to have a similar membership.

title: The Now York Times/Paul Hosofros
description: VOWS TO KEEP FIGHTING FOR HIS FREEDOM: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in Paterson, NJ., jail yesterday discussing his murder conviction. Page 24.

title: DR. MN M. BLAIR, 62; U.S. EXECONOMIST
description: Dr. Tohn M. Blair of St. Petersburg, Fla., chief economist of the Subcommittee on Antitrust and Monopoly of the Senate Judiciary Committee from 1957 to 1970, died Tuesday at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: Indictments Charging Cunningham With Selling Judgeship Dismissed
description: A State Supreme Court Justice yesterday dismissed major indictments against Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic County chairman.

title: Times to Introduce Magazine in April
description: After what it considers to be a successful market test, The New York Times Company has decided to introduce its Us magazine nationally on an everyotherweek basis next April.

description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the following reports of changes in shareholdings of officers, directors and large szockholders in companies listed on the exchange. The information, compiled from reports filed with the exchange, included the following:

title: Sax Played By Howard At a Club
description: Noah Howard, who is performing throtgh tonight at Ali's Alley, 77 Greene Street, in SoHo, draws an appealingly fat, warm sound from his alto saxophone. The music he is playing now is more lyrical than the fiercely energetic music he played before leaving New York for Europe in 1972, and it gives his sound plenty of opportunity to shine through.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most business offices and stock exchanges will be closed Christmas Eve, tomorrow, while banks, post offices and stores will remain open. Many municipal workers will have the day off and most state and Federal offices in this state and in New York will be closed.

title: OLIVE DIEFENBAKER
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 22 (Reuters)Olive Diefenbaker, the wife of former Prime Minister John Diefenbaker, died here today at the age of 73.

title: Carter Says He Believes Brezhnev Will Keep Word on No Early Test
description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 22 (AP)Presidentelect Carter said today that he believed the Soviet Leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, when he said the Soviet Union would not try to test his fledgling administration, but Mr. Carter added, I'll be prepared if my belief is illfounded.

title: C.I.A.I.T.T.CONSPIRACY CHARGED AT HEARING
description: Grand Jury Is Told They Fabricated Statements to Senate on Chile

title: December Coffee Futures Hit Peak
description: The current December coffee futures price reached a record of $2.23 a pound yesterday and closed at that level, up 3 cents on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. This came on top of a strong price rise on Tuesday.

title: Dollar Ends Mixed As Trading Eases In Europe's Centers
description: LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP)  The dollar cicsed mixed on European currency exchanges today after a day of lowvolume preChristmas trading.

title: Fewer Brokerage Firms Pay Bonuses This Year
description: For Wall Street the preChristmas period has traditionally meant more than tax selling, partying and extra days off. Perhaps more than any other business, the securities industry has used the yearend bonus as an incentive, an implied promise of better things to come.

title: Barry Manilow Sings Ballads And Pop in 2Week Run at Uris
description: Barry Manilow has a lot of fans these daysenough to sell out his twoweek run at the Uris Theater in advance. And Mr. Manilow's openingnight performance Tuesday showed all the reasons his admirers hold him dear. It also showed once again why others find it so easy to resist him.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said yesterday that it reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission a total of $129,000 in questionable foreign payii ents since Jan. 1, 1971.

title: The Argo Merchant Disaster
description: The biggest oil spill disaster on the American coast in our history is the way Russell E. Train, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has characterized the wreck of the tanker Argo Merchant on the Nantucket shoals. Mr. Train, who is not given to overstatement, was describing the Impact of this wholly preventable catastrophe that threatens incalculable damage to the great fisheries on the Georges Bank and to New England's coastal environment.

title: Lillian Carter Resting in Hospital
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Dec. 22 (AP)Lillian Carter, the 78yearold mother of Presidentelect Carter, was admitted to a hospital here today for few days of examination and rest after complaining that she did not feel well.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Even the Knicks could have relaxed. They were leading the Detroit Pistons, 9163, in the third quarter Tuesday night and they would win; 133103, for their third triumph since Bob McAdoo arrived. But with a 28point lead, Walt Frazier was having too much fun to relax. In the backcourt, his hands faster than a pickpocket's, he nearly stole the ball twice. And now, after the Pistons had moved across midcourt, Walt Frazier did steal the ball, but accidentally knocked it out of bounds. Walt Frazier was having fun again. For his hustle with a 28point lead, Sports of The Times he received an appreciative Burst of ap plause from the 14,794 spectators at Madison Square Garden, who also were having fun again. And that is what the Knicks revival is all. about. Suddenly, with Bob McAdoo representing the missing link, the Knicks feel they can Win every game. Not that they will win every game, but they're capable of it. Suddenly they're as good as any team in the balanced National Basketball Association, and in that atmosphere basketball is always fun.

title: DEATHS ARE FEARED IN FIRE IN BROOKLYN
description: A threealarm fire swept through a five story building in the shopping center of downtown Brooklyn yesterday, and fire officials said that several persons, including a child, might have been trapped and killed.

title: Police Victory
description: The Appeals Court ruling exempting policemen from the municipal pay freeze is a Pyrrhic victory which a large number of employed policemen may soon regret.

title: Wheat Farmers Cut Winter Plantings 3%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)Farmers facing a mounting surplus of wheat after record harvests in 1976 and 1975 have cut plantings of 1977 winter wheat by 3 percent and the crop may fall 8 percent below this year's level, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Swiss Return Art Dealer To Dutch to Face Trial In Wartime Death of Jews
description: GENEVA, Dec. 22The Swiss Cabinet today handed over a 77yearold Dutch art dealer to the authorities of his country to face charges of having participated in the Nazi wartime killing of several hundred Polish Jews.

title: Justice Samuel Welcome Of State Supreme Court Dies at Home in Queens
description: Samuel A. Welcome, a justice of Stater Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died Monday after a fall near his home in Hollis, Queens. He was 50 years old.

title: Reports on Skiing Conditions in Northeast
description: (Reports supplied by resort owners Not all lifts operating)

title: New York Times Co. Appoints Two Lawyers
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday the appointment of Solomon B. Watson 4th as assistant secretary and of Katharine P. Darrow as assistant general attorney. Both are 32 years old.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Associated Press

title: Sniper Kills ExEditor in Durham; Shooting Is 4th There in 5 Days
description: DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 22 (AP)A retired editor of The Durham Morning Herald editorial page was killed by le sniper today in the fourth sniper attack in Durham in five days.

title: Radio
Chief Tamanaco Brings Good Cheer for Iselins
description: Phil Iselin was summoned from a board meeting of the New York Jets yesterday to answer a phone call from his son Jimmy, trainer of Chief Tamanaco, one of four starters in the $36.250 Bold Ruler Handicap at Aqueduct. Dad, the younger Iselin said almost apologetically, we jitst won the Bold Ruler and broke the track record. The elder Iselin runs horses under the nom de course of the Great Wolf Hill Farms. His partner in Chief Tamanaco, a 3yearold son of Jungle Savage  She Devil, by Devil Diver, are Leon Hess and Zachary Fisher. Hess is the largest stockholder in the Jets and Monmouth Park. Phil Iselin, who decided not to attend the races because of the subfreezing cold, is the president of both the Jets and Monmouth.

title: Market Place
description: One of Wall Street's most successful techniques for convincing investors that a stock is cheap is concept selling.

title: Harvard's Coach Gets Bowl Fever
description: Joe Restic Sr. is taking in a bowl game, even though he is Harvard's football coach and a member of the Ivy League, which prohibits postseason, play. But he is going to Monday night's Gator Bowl in Jacksonville, Fla., as a spectator with College Sports Notes paternal interest in the outcome. Joe Restic Jr. is the starting free safety for No tre Dame, which meets Penn State in the Gator Bowl. This will be only the, third time that the coach has seen his son play.

title: Wage Panel. Says Medical Sector Resists Curbs on Health Care Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Ford Administration's inflation monitors said today that the medical establishment was resisting efforts to control the soaring cost of health care and that private industry, labor unions and patients must redouble their efforts to reform the health care system.

title: The New York Times/Ingebore Lippman
description: At a tea plantation north of Umtali, Rhodesia, automatic rifles belie the serenity of an afternoon cocktail party. Weapons belong to border guards assigned to protect area residents from guerrilla raids from Mozambique.

title: Louis H. Boyar Dead at 78; ExReal Estate Developer Raised Funds to Aid Israel
description: Louis H. Boyar, a retired real estate developer and a leading fund raiser for Israeli causes, died Tuesday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 78 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Women Leaders Differ With Carter On the Difficulties of Taking U.S. Jobs
description: Is it really tougher to persuade a woman than a man to pull up stakes to go to Washington to accept a post in Government?

title: Crime Film 'Enforcer' Lacking Ideas
description: There's a basic weakness in the movie business' assumption that if you have a big suspense or action picture with lots of movement and thrills, you don't need writing or acting or character in it.Because what happens? The climax comes. Good and bad are stalking each other around some monstrous hangar, Zoroastrian rest-home or abandoned maple-sugar factory. Music. Suspenseful lighting. Tension. And a face peers around the corner. But by this time, who cares about the face? It might as well be Donald Duck's.Money, the big name of Clint Eastwood, a lot of gore and howling sirens and the urge to rail at various liberal notions are not enough to make even a passable movie out of "The Enforcer."The movie, which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, is the third in the series"Dirty Harry" and "Magnum Force" were the first twoabout a mean though righteous San Francisco cop. It has been billed as "the dirtiest Harry of them all," but it is simply the surliest. It is the same barroom drunk railing at weirdos and pinkos, and four or five glasses farther into his theme.The movie begins with the killing of two gas-company drivers by the Revolutionary Strike Force. The half-dozen young people in the force need the gas truck to break into an arms depot guarded by one (1) old watchman. They kill him and use the arms and detonators to kidnap the mayor, whom they hold for ransom. The killings are unnecessary, but this is explained by the fact that the leaderwho is really in it for the moneyis a homicidal madman. We know this because his jaws quiver when he stabs people.Out comes Harry Callahan (Mr. Eastwood) of the homicide division. That is, he's sometimes of the homicide division. He starts out by driving his car through the window of a liquor store to break up a stickup and kills the three gunmen. He is busted to personnel for roughness, reinstated when the Revolutionary Strike Force begins work, is busted again when he goes after them too vigorously, but manages to get them all anyway when they hole up in what used to be Alcatraz prison.The action is reasonably fast and competently photographed. The picture doesn't exactly drag. But it is maggoty with non-ideas. These non-ideas come in the form of a whole gallery of corrupt or foolish liberal types who interfere with Harry's mission.There is a progressive priest who shelters the assault gang until one of them, dressed as a nun, tries to shoot Harry. There is a weaselly police captain who says Harry's shooting the liquor-store holdup men was offensive to the city's minorities. "The hoods, you mean," Harry says brightly. "They're Americans, too," the captain answers.Thatthe movie tells usis how knee-jerk liberals think. The politicians are corrupt and pathetically eager to appease the thugs/radicals/ pornographers.Feminism is also some kind of conspiracy. Harry is reluctantly saddled with a woman police officer as his partner. Played by Tyne Daly, who is good-hearted and plucky, but she is also a whole shopping list of alleged feminine incompetences.She runs with her arms flapping all anyhow, holds a pistol as if it were a chamberpot, asks stupid questions, goes around with her mouth gaping, and talks in a high-pitched quack. That is Miss Daly peering around a corner in the climactic scene, not Donald Duck. But, as stated earlier, it might as well be.

title: People in Sports
description: Randy Jones says he's a better pitcher than a bargainer, so he hired an agent to do his negotiating with the San Diego Padres.

title: New Towns Future
description: Never have an ideal and a reality been farther apart than in this country's new towns program. The premise that rational, planned development makes more sense than wasteful, chaotic sprawlin terms of money, efficiency, energy and community and natural resourcesremains sound. No one disputes the desirability, and even the necessity, for some order and amenity in this country's growth and landuse patterns. But never has a program of such obvious virtues failed so miserably.

title: 2 Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (UPI)The Philadelphia Eagles today announced the resignations of two assistant coaches, John Idzik and John Mazur.

title: Woman With Hands Tied Is Found Dead in a Fire; Children Describe Attack
description: A 29yearold woman, her hand, tied above her head, was found dead in her burning apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens, early yesterday by firemen who had been summoned by neighbors, the police reported.

title: Sidney Platt, 66, Advocate Of Vocational Education; Helped to Start a School
description: Sidney Platt, a leading advocate of vocational education and the founding principal of the Eli Whitney Vocational High School in Brooklyn, died Tuesday ofa heart ailment at his home in Jamaica, Queens. He was 66 years old.

title: GEORGE B. M'COY DIES; 30'S RADIO HOST WAS 73
description: George Braidwood (The Real) McCoy, a pioneer radio talkshow host in the 1930's, a character actor, and a parttime taxicab driver on the streets of Manhattan, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He would have been 73 years old on Jan. 14.

title: Shelton to Coach Drake
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 22 (UPI)Chuck Shelton, an assistant football coach at Drake University the last two seasons, was named head coach today. He succeeds Jack Wallace. Shelton came to Drake in 1975 from the University of Cincinnati, where he was assistant athletic director.

title: Bridge:
description: The individual championship, the Cinderella of tournament play, may be on its way to a mild renaissance. At the New York Hilton Hotel last Friday, there were 104 contestants in the regional individual, organized in parallel with the mixed pairs.

title: GUERRILLAS BATTLE FOR 2D DAY IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22  Rival Palestinian guerrilla groups clashed here again for the second day in succession, leading to renewed intervention by the Syrian  dominated Arab peacekeeping force.

title: Vance Meets Russian Dissident, Who Asks Tougher Detente Line
description: Secretary of Statedesignate Cyrus R. Vance met today for 90 minutes with Andrei A. Amalrik, the Russian dissident and writer, who urged the incoming Carter administration to develop a toughened, longterm program of accommodation with Moscow that would gradually lead to a more democratic society in the Soviet Union.

title: Admiral Questions Tanker Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  A Coast Guard admiral said today that the master of the Argo Merchant should never have run aground and must have been asleep when the oil tanker hit a shoal off Nantucket a week aeo.

title: Investigation Agency Bids Governor Remove Sheriff In Dutchess TicketFixing
description: ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP)The New York State Commission of Investigation has recommended the dismissal of the Dutchess County sheriff, Lawrence Quinlan, following testimony by sheriff's deputies that he had criminal cases dismissed and traffic tickets fixed for political and personal motives.

title: Blue Chips Lead Stock Advance, Reflecting Optimism on Inflation
description: Stock prices pushed higher across a broad front yesterday, led by sizable gains in many of the blue chips and glamour stocks.

title: Judge's Restraint Fought
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22The president of the New Jersey chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, a journalism organization, today protested to the New Jersey State Supreme Court warnings by Superior Court Judge Bruno L. Leopizzi that he would jail any reporter who tried to talk to jurors in the CarterArtis trial.

title: New York City and State Held Lax On Medicaid Mills
description: A preliminary audit by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare of efforts to root out abuse and fraud in Medicaid mills in New York City accuses both the city and state of laxness, it was learned yesterday. At the same time, a similar report by a joint New York State legislative commission admonishes the state to not interfere with the city's efforts.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: TANKER'S BOW SPLITS, SPILLING LAST OF OIL IN SEA OFF NANTUCKET
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22The bow of the broken Liberianflag tanker Argo Merchant, grounded off Nantucket Island, split in half today and spilled the remainder of the vessel's 7.5 million gallons of thick oil into the sea.

title: 2 Hostages Go Free As a Man in Airliner Surrenders on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22A tense night of radio negotiations between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and an airline employee who had taken two men hostage aboard a parked DC8 airliner here ended quietly before dawn today when the man turned his gun over to a friend and surrendered.

title: Dance: Auslander and Warshaw
description: Marian Sarach was a ray of sunshine in a generally dull evening of dances by Rose Auslander and Roselle Warshaw at the Terra Firma studio Tuesday evening. Their works never ventured beyond the most elementary level and were more like composition exercises than finished works ready for public display.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The easing of inflationary pressures in recent months should permit Jimmy Carter to focus his main effort, when he takes office, on unemployment. That is the issue that, more than any other, put him in the White House. And unemployment is the biggest The concern of his supporters among the leaders of organized labor, rankandfile Scene workers, young people, blacks and others who stand outside the plant and office gates, looking in.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded a 10year, $796 million contract today for a new type of satellite tracking system that will eventually permit the closing of seven ground stations around the world.

title: Deaths
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 5.3311 UNTIL 5:30 P,M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P,M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 34900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 05300; NASSAU CO. (518) 747.0500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 660.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: INTERNATIONAL LOANS UP $17 BILLION IN 76; DEFICITS SPUR RISE
description: The volume of international lending continued at a record pace this year, largely because of the huge and persistent currentaccount deficits of many countries, according to analysts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: HOME HEATING OIL STOCKS DECLINE AGAIN IN WEEK
description: Stocks of home heating oilknown as middle distillates within the petroleum industrycontinued to decline last week, as cold weather again hung over much of the nation, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: And in Westchester Towns, Too
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 22A creche was erected on Boniface Circle in this Westchester County village last week, as it has been at Christmas for two decades.

title: Crown Heights Divided?
description: Given the potential for conflict, there has been remarkably little dispute over proposed lines for the new, Chartermandated coterminous service districts which are designed to give local communities throughout the city greater control over municipal services and policies affecting their neighborhoods.

title: Postal Employees Keep Up Tradition in Gift to Neediest
description: Through the years, the employees of the United States Postal Service have been among the donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. As the 65th annual appeal continued through its third week, members of the Northeast regional headquarters, at the General Post Office, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, gave $384.25 to the fund.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: CALM The homes bordering the 145 year  old, two  square  block Gramercy Park traditionally present Christmas display in a peaceful, oldworld atmosphere. Glows of Christmases past.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1976

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most business offices and stock exchanges will be closed Christmas Eve, tomorrow, while banks, post offices and stores will remain open. Many municipal workers will have the day off and most state and Federal offices in New York and New Jersey will be closed.

title: Mozart Given Due By Greenwich House
description: The Greenwich House Orchestra traveled uptown from its home at the Greenwich House Music School on Barrow Street Monday night for a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. The music was by Mozart and the orchestra made the visit more than worthwhile by playing every item on the program with crackling vitality and polished technical precision under the expert direction of its conductor. Michael Bartos.

title: Companies Report on Profits
Holidays Come To Many Lands
description: Throughout the world, Christmas and the New Year will be observed in various ways. Lebanese Christians in Beirut celebrate in a city devastated by civil war; Muscovites will mark the New Year, substituting Father Frost for Santa Claus. In Northern Ireland, warring religious factions will Worship the same Christchild. In South Africa, the holiday is shadowed by the uneasy political and racial situation; the Japanese look forward to another prosperous New Year.

title: P.B.A. WINS 6% PAY RISE FOR 75 AS COURT BARS POLICE WAGE FREEZE
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday won its long court battle for a 1975 pay increase of 6 percent, or $900 per officer, but the union still must negotiate an agreement covering the current twoyear contract period.

title: Fordham Beats Dartmouth In Defensive Battle, 47 to 39
description: HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 22Stan Ftankoski was the key scorer in two surges that gave Fordham a 4739 triumph over Dartmouth in a defensive basketball game tonight.

title: EAST GERMANS OUST A WESTERN NEWSMAN
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 22The East Ger. man Government, which has been in con. flict with dissident intellectuals since it exiled the poet Wolf Biermann las month, acted today to remove another critical voice. It ordered the expulsior of a West German television correspond. ent who had frequently interviewed dissi. dents.

title: Montgomery Ward Hit By F.T.C. on Credit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)In the first such action under a new law, the Federal Trade Commission today accused Montgomery Ward & Company of failing to tell unsuccessful credit applicants why they were turned down. The company refuses to give credit to 600,000 persons every year, one F.T.C. official said.

title: HEARINGS ARE BEGUN IN PSYCHIATRIST CASE
description: Hearings on the revocation of the medical licenseof Dr. Martin Shepard, a psychiatrist whose books include Games Analysts Plays and The Love Treatment, were begun yesterday by the State Board for Medicine's committee on professional conduct.

title: Ford Said to Plan an Aid Proposal $800 Million Below Israeli Request
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Administration. officials said today that President Ford had decided to propose a $1.5 billion foreign aid package for Israel in the next fiscal year$800 million less than Israel requested and $300 million less than the State Department recommended.

title: Television
description: Doug Henning stars in his World of Magic, live on Channel 4 tonight at 8.

title: Finley Defends His Need to Sell 3 Unsigned Players
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)The Oakland A's owner, Charles O. Finley, testified today that he had received at least six offers for Joe Rudi because other baseball team owners knew I was having a hard time financially.

title: The New York Times/Ira Wyman
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Dec. 22The miracle of Nantucket was always that it survived at all. For all the summertime splendor of Main Street's mansions and shops, for all the pristine perfection of nearly 1,000 town houses of the whaling era and betore, The Talk the island still looks from of the air like a wisp of sand dunes. Herman Melville Nantucket called it an anthill in the sea in Chapter 14 of Moby Dick and marveled: Look at ita mere hillock, an elbow of sand; all beach, without a background. There is more sand there than you would use in 20 years as a substitute for blotting paper. Some gamesome wights will tell that you have to plant weeds there, they don't grow naturally; that they import Canada thistles; that they have to send beyond seas for a spile [a plug] to stop a leak in an oil cast.

title: Stage: Y our Arms Too Short &:
description: The joyous sound of gospel singing filled the Lyceum Theater last night, and should be filling it for some time to come. It was the opening of Vinnette Carroll's Your Arms Too Short to Box With God, and it is a black celebration according to the Book of Matthew.

title: MUNICIPALITIES GIVEN PUBLIC WORKS FUNDS
description: NEWARK, Dec. 22Fortyeight New Jersey municipalities, school boards and local agencies will share $99.9 million in Federal public works funds designed to provide thousands of jobs within 90 days.

title: VINCENT J. VIGOUROUX
description: Vincent Justin Vigouroux, founder of the old Westchester Home Life magazine, died yesterday of cancer at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: TV:
description: Jean Shepherd, the humorist, author and personality in the broadcasting corridors of radio and television, insists that he hates nostalgia. All right, for argument's sake, let's buy that. But his The Phantom of the Open Hearth, which can be seen on Public television's, Visions series tonight at 9 o'clock is a wonderfully offbeat reminiscence of a young man enduring the maturation trials of a junior prom in the industrial Middle West of the 1940's.

title: Bell Will Quit All Private Clubs
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22Griffin B. Bell, the Attorney Generaldesignate, said today that, because he believed that the Attorney General is a symbol of equality before the law, he would resign his membership in all private clubs, including two in Atlanta that have no black and few, if any, Jewish members, and one in Savannah reported to have a similar membership.

title: Sparks Band Now HardRocking
description: The Mael brothers, who are the basis of a band called Sparks, are not trying to hide their current shift of direction. The band first emerged a couple of years ago as one of the cleverest, most febrile of all the British progressive rock bands (even though Ron and Russell Mael come from Los Angeles).

title: A Town in Spain Cries Fraud and Has Its No Vote Declared Void
description: CONSUEGRA, Spain. Dec. 21This charming town, once known for little more than its crumbling ruins of a castle and nine white windmills perched on a high bluff, emerged from obscurity last week.

title: Japan's Ruling Party Picks Fukuda, Making Him Likely Next Premier
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 23The Liberal Democratic Party, which holds a slim majority in Japan's Parliament, officially named Takeo Fukuda today as its new party president.

title: Aim of New EgyptSyria Unity: Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec, 22Egypt and Syria, in deciding to form a united political leadership, are trying to make sure that their newly repaired alliance will not fall apart once more when they enter into expected negotiations in 1977 for an overall Middle East settlement. This, in the view of Arab diplomats, is the meaning of the unity announcement last night in Cairo and Damascus. The

title: Nadjari's Indictment Record
description: One by one, the indictments against prominent political figures and judges have been dismissed or found seriously defective. Few, if any, are expected to survive further judicial scrutiny. Each time, the message has been similar. That in his rush to indict in his last six months in office, News Analysis Maurice H. Nadjari exceeded his authority, that he stretched his jurisdiction, that he engaged in wholesale and unjustified wiretapping and that he and his aides misused grand juries.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions.

title: CANADIANS TIGHTEN ATOM EXPORT CURBS
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 22The Canadian Government today tightened its already tough restrictions on supplying nuclear reactors and fuel to other countries to prevent the use of such items. in weapons development.

title: F.C.C. Halts Fees For Broadcasters, C.B. Users as Well
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday announced that it would suspend on Jan. 1 all fees charged for licensingincluding those for purchasers of citizens band radioswhile it studied the implications of a recent court ruling that the commission's fees imposed since 1970 have been improper.

title: White Named Hawk Coach
description: Bill White, a defenseman, has replaced Billy Reay as coach of the Chicago Black Hawks. In the change announced yesterday, Bobby Orr and Stan Mikita were picked as assistants to White. Page 31.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1976

title: Advertising
description: An interview with Ronald K. Sherman, head of the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, tends to be about Burt Manning.

title: FEIGNED GERM WAR ADMITTED BY ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Army acknowledged today that from 1950 to 1966 it used what it described as nondisease causing biological substances to conduct simulated germ warfare attacks in eight areas of the nation.

title: Kissinger Will Keep Transcripts Of Official Phone Conversations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has refused to include among his official papers for the Library of Congress the stenographic records of his telephone conversations on the ground that these were personal papers.

title: TANKER'S BOW SPLITS, SPILLING LAST OF OIL IN SEA OFF NANTUCKET
description: BOSTON, Dec. 22The bow of the broken Liberianflag tanker Argo Merchant, grounded off Nantucket Island, split in half today and spilled the remainder of the vessel's 7.5 million gallons of thick oil into the sea.

title: Soviet Bank Is Said to Weaken Dollar in Zurich in Half Hour
description: ZURICH, Dec. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)In less than half an hour yesterday, a Soviet bank managed to weaken the American dollar considerably and give impetus to speculation on further rises in the value of the Swiss franc, according to financial sources here.

title: Music: Jim Hall Leads. a Quartet
description: Jazz Guitarist Is at Hopper's With an Understated, Sensitive and Virtuosic Performance

title: Ownership of Spilled Oil Disputed
description: A dispute arose yesterday over the ownership of the 7.5 million gallons of heavy fuel oil in thelanker Argo Merchant at the time the vessel split apart off Nantucket Wednesday morning.

title: Holiday Decor Stirs Dispute in Englewood
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 22A watercolor painting of carolers on a glass office door at City Hail and Mayor Sondra J. Greenberg's interpretation of it as violation of the constitutional separation of church and state have somewhat soured the holiday mood here.

title: Amor Artis Presents Vivaldi With Verve
description: If nothing else, Vivaldi's music has an energy and momentum that give it a lively, celebratory air. It made the program that was devoted to the composer's works in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night decidedly festive and suitable to the Advent season. It was given by the Amor Artis Chorale and Orchestra, under the direction of Johannes Somary, and it was the first of three they will present in the hall this season.

title: Many Reported Dead In Malagasy Rioting
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, D. c. 22 (AP)  Dozens of people have been killed and hundreds wounded in three days of rioting, fires and looting, the Government radio reported today.

title: PAYMENTS BALANCE SWINGS INTO DEFICIT IN THE 3D QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The United States balance of payments on current account swung from a surplus in the first half of this year into a deficit of $1.1 billion in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: New York Gets PublicWorks Aid
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that the city was about to receive a muchneeded Christmas gift$102.2 million in Federal funds for 51 capitalconstruction projects that are expected to create 2.5001 construction jobs.

title: SOVIET JEWS IN SEMINAR REMAIN IN HOUSE ARREST
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (Reuters)Most of the 13 organizers of an unofficial Jewish cultural symposium remained under hcuse arrest today after the gathering went ahead in a severely curtailed form, Jewish sources said.

title: Books of The Times
description: Is it ultimately impossible for a man to understand the existential rage of contemporary women? So one might conclude from this reviewer's failure to completely appreciate these two talented novels, both of whose plots hinge on female rageat fathers and mothers, husbands and lovers, and middleclass, monogamous society in general. ut naturally I prefer to think that the fault lies in the way these stories are constructed. Take Fay Weldon's

title: MICHIGAN WILL FINANCE TESTS FOR PBB POISONING
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 22 (AP)The State of Michigan will reimburse mothers whose breast milk is tested for the toxic chemical PBB, health officials have announced.

title: 30 Loss in Soccer Ends U.S. Cup Bid
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 22 (AP)Canada's national soccer team defeated the United States, 30, tonight and advanced to the second round of the World Cup tournament for the first time. The Americans were eliminated.

description: TARANTO, ItalyYears ago they worried about the lack of industry here in the instep of Italy's boot. Now they Are worried about the impact of it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Edward M. Carey was incorrectly identified in yesterday's Times as the owner of the Northeast Petroleum Cotporation. Mr. Carey, whose company is the New England Petroleum Corpora). Lion, has no connection with Northeast Petroleum. He is Governor Carey's brother.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22An independent insurance agents group said today that it would be a disaster if New Jersey should decide to set up its own automobile insurance company.

title: White Replaces Reay as Coach Of Black Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)Bill White, a veteran defenseman who has been sidelined this season with a back in: jury, was named coach of the Chicago Black Hawks today, replacing Billy Reay. Bobby Orr and Stan Mikita were listed as assistant coaches and will work closely with White, especially with the younger players, the Hawks said.

title: GRAIN CONCERN FACES $24 MILLION U.S. SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Government filed suit today in Federal District Court against Cook Industries Inc., one of the country's largest grain corporations, seeking to recover nearly S24 million in damage claims for misgrading, adulteration and shortweighting of grain shipments.

title: 26.8% INCREASE SET IN 1916'S CAR OUTPUT
description: DETROIT, Dec. 22The American auto industry, recovering from a twoyear slump, is scheduled to produce about 8.53 million cars in 1976, up 26.8 percent from 6.72 million in 1975.

title: Plan to Reopen the Tombs Rejected by Federal Judge
description: A plan to reopen the Manhattan jail known as the Tombs was rejected yesterday by a Federal judge who said the city's plan failed to eliminate some of the conditions that resulted in the jail's closing two years ago.

title: 4 Cities Will Get $220 Million for People Movers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman Jr. announced today that four large cities would receive $220 million in Government mass transit funds to build futuristic automated people movers that would transport shoppers and downtown workers.

title: Candidates Without Opposition of Major Party in '76
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Following is a list of the Senate and House candidates without major party opposition in 1976, many of whom enjoyed substantial surpluses 20 days after the election. (Minor errors in the totals result from mistakes in data submitted by the members of Congress):

title: Douglas Fraser, Top U.A.W. Aide, Held Likely to Succeed Woodcock
description: DETROIT, Dec. 22Douglas A. Fraser, a follower in the liberalprogressive footsteps of the late Walter P. Reuther, appears likely to emerge in the next .three weeks as the successor to Leonard Woodcock as president of the United Automobile Workers. Mr. Woodcock, at 65 years old. must retire in 1977.

title: Briton Lists Rhodesia Alternatives
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters)Britain is considering four possible methods of administering Rhodesia's defense and justice ministries as the country moves toward blackmajority rule, the British chairman of the Geneva peace negotiations said today.

title: SATRA CORP. SIGNS ACCORD FOR MOSCOW OLYMPIC TV
description: The Satra Corporation, which has apparently won the rights to televise the 1980 Olympics from Moscow to American audiences, confirmed yesterday that had signed a protocol calling for longterm cooperation with the U.S.S.R. Olympic Organizing Committee.

title: Music and Films by Phil Niblock
description: Phill Niblock's music and films are concerned with detail and simplicity. In the music, adjacent tones are amplified and extended in time, so that the acoustical phenomenon of their beat frequencies, heard as a kind of pulsing or flutter, captures the attention. In the films, farmers work their land, suns rise and set, Mexican Indians weave and harvest and wash their clothes in rivers, and bees dance atop flowers. The pace of the images seems to move in rhythmic cycles, and again a pulsing phenomenon becomes the focus of attention.

title: Nonsmoker Honored for Efforts
description: Donna Shimp of Salem yesterday re ceived the American Lung Association's outstanding achievement award for her court victory in achieving a work environment free of the tobacco smoke that she said had frequently made her ill.

title: American Enka Lifts Yarn Price
description: The American Enka Company, a subsidiary of Akzona Inc., announced yesterday price increase of 5 to 10 cents a pound on textured polyester yarns, effective Feb. 7. Critical dyeing yarns will go up 5 cents and noncritical and whites only yarns will be raised as much as 10 cents.

title: A Democratic Objective
description: A meeting.. of the House Democratic leaders, Carter advisers and business executives shows that the Carter administration seeks to win the confidence of the business community. Page 40.

title: CAMDEN AND THE U.S. IN ACCORD ON SLUDGE
description: PHILADELPHIA, DEC. 22Camden's City Attorney, Martin F. ??cKernan and officials of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency agreed today to the terms for a $1.289 million Federal grant for a composting plant that will convert Camden's sewage sludge into a soil conditioner.

description: It's a fur rock, a woman said, looking into one of the wood and clear plastic cages at Abraham & Straus the other day.

title: Saudi Denies Aim Of Limited Oil Rise Was to Aid Carter
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22 (AP)Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia said in an interview published today that his Government's decision to limit its increase in the price of oil to 5 percent Vas not taken to serve the interests of a certain nation or a certain presidentan apparent reference to the United States and Presidentelect Carter.

title: U.S. Six Defeated, 63
description: PRAGUE, Dec. 22 (AP)Erkki Laine scored three goals in the first period and led Finland to a 63 victory over the United States in the opening game of the under20 world ice hockey championship. Paul Miller tied the game briefly at 11 with the first of his two goals in the opening period, but that was the closest the United States got.

title: Bradley Field People Mover A Casualty of Overoptimism
description: WINDSOR LOCKS. Conn., Dec. 22Cobwebs trail from the locked terminal doors. Dead leaves blow through the end station. Nothing moves on the concrete guideway snaking over the parking lots of Bradley International Airbort.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The googoos are in an uproar about Jimmy Carter's cunning selection of Griffin Bell to be Attorney General. They accuse Mr. Carter's friend of being liar, a bigot, a betrayal, and a throwback to those days when the Department of Justice was under the thumb of the White House. Let's take those charges in order:

description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Dec. 22Sugarplum visions materialized tonight for the New York Nets and 6,209 fans in a 12793 trouncing of the New Orleans Jazz at the Nassau Coliseum.

description: FATAL ACCIDENT IN FRANCE: A school bus in which 17 handicapped children were killed yesterday is hauled out of the Rhone River at Lyon. The bus plunged into the river after failing to negotiate a 90degree turn.

description: PARIS, Dec. 22Western trading partners decided today to mobilize half of. a supplemental world credit facility known as the General Agreement to Borrow to permit the International Monetary Fund to lend $3.9 billion to financially pressed Britain.

title: Suits in Scarsdale and Other Towns Term Creches Unconstitutional
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 22A creche was erected on Boniface Circle in this Westchester County village last week, as it has been at Christmas for two decades.

description: RESULTS

title: PARK REGIME CALLED THREAT TO U.S. IN ASIA
description: WASHINGON, Dec. 22The former station chief of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Korea, Donald Gregg, has asserted that the Government of President Park Chung Hee is inherently unstable and, therefore, jeopardizes American interests there.

title: The Screen: 'Voyage of the Damned'
description: In May 1939 the Hamburg-America liner St. Louis sailed from Hamburg headed for Havana, carrying 937 Jews who had paid Hitler's government dearly in the hope of finding refuge from the Nazis in Cuba. Hitler's strategy was simple: if, indeed, the Cuban Government accepted the refugees (and there was doubt about that, even when they sailed), then Germany was well rid of them and a little bit richer, too.If Cuba did not accept them, and if the United States and other countries followed suit, then Hitler would have proven his point that Jews were unwanted by the very countries that were so loudly criticizing his anti-Semitic policies while proclaiming their own humanitarian principles.The story of that voyage is a harrowing footnote to the history of World War II. As carefully researched by Gordon Thomas and Max Morgan Witts in their book "The Voyage of the Damned," it is, further, a revealing commentary on how opportunism could dictate policies of friendly governments, including that of the United States.It also seems to be excellent source material for a film, though you'd never know it from the alternately sluggish and hysterical movie that opened at three New York theaters yesterday. Stuart Rosenberg, the director, and Steven Shagan and David Butler, who wrote the screenplay, appear to have been attracted to the project because of the almost limitless ways in which they could make history look like a bad, all-star movie, to start with, they use a dozen or so too many stories even to fit conveniently into a running time inflated to 158 minutes.Their touch is so surely banal that they turn potentially moving episodes into second-rate melodrama, while adding some third-rate melodramatics of their own, including a Romeo-and-Juliet suicide pact. It's the kind of movie in which someone says, quite seriously, "Vee Chermans har hallvays hon time" (We Germans are always on time).The cast includes good actors and bad, but even the good actors are inclined to be awful. Faye Dunaway and Oskar Werner are all right as a rather posh Berlin doctor and his wife who are carrying their marital problems into exile intact. They travel first-class. Malcolm McDowell plays the role of a cabin boy who appears to be old enough to qualify for Social Security. When we weren't looking, his youth fled. Max von Sydow survives with his reputation undamaged as the liner's humane skipper, but Katharine Ross, who looks like a Rose Bowl parade queen, is a joke as a humane Havana whore.Orson Welles, James Mason, Denholm Elliott and Jose Ferrer are on and off faster than it takes to type this sentence, while Lee Grant, Julie Harris, Wendy Hiller and Luther Adler might wish they had been so lucky.Movies as clumsy, tasteless and self-righteous as this are worse than merely boring. By exploiting the tragedies of real people, some wildly fictionalized, "The Voyage of the Damned" attempts to turn them to profit without giving them any measure of the respect that is due."Voyage of The Damned," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested", contains nothing of an even mildly suggestive nature except the title, which might mislead children to think they are about to see a disaster filmand a child who wants to see a disaster film and sees this, instead, will be an angry child.

title: 76 Are Introduced At Debutante Ball
description: At the 41st annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the WaldorfAstoria last night 76 young women made their forma lbows to society.

title: CHASE LOWERS RATE ON ITS PRIME LOANS
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday lowered its minimum interest rate on corporate loans to 6 percent and became the third major bank to move its prime rate to that level. Elsewhere in the money and bond markets, most fixedincome security price; held steady in the light tradCredit log activity that is a charMarkets acteristic of the final two weeks of a year. The Chase Manhattan's change in the prime rate, which became effective immediately, followed similar reductions by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the First National Bank of Chicago. Other major banks have kept their prime rates unchanged at 6% percent.

title: F .C. O . Halts Fees For Broadcasters, C .B . Users as Well
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday announced that it would suspend on Jan. 1 all fees charged for licensingincluding those for purchasers of citizens band radioswhile it studied the implications of a recent court ruling that the commission's fees imposed since 1970 have been improper.

title: AirBag Decision
description: The air bag as a safety device in automobiles posed a problem for Secretary of Transportation William T. Coleman Jr. His careful study of the evidence showed that the air bag is technologically feasible, can be massproduced at a reasonable cost and, if used in all cars, would save an estimated 12,000 lives a year and prevent or reduce the severity of 100,000 injuries. It is this same evidence that has prompted safety and consumer groups to press for compulsory installation of air bags in all automobiles by 1980.

title: Holidays Come To Many Lands
description: Throughout the world, Christmas and the New Year will be observed in various ways. Lebanese Christians in Beirut celebrate in a city devastated by civil war; Muscovites will mark the New Year, substituting Father Frost for Santa Claus. In Northern Ireland, warring religious factions will worship the same Christchild. In South Africa, the holiday is shadowed by the uneasy political and racial situation; the Japanese look forward to another prosperous New Year.

title: The Cast
description: YOUR ARMS TOO SHORT TO BOX WITH GOD. Conceived from the Book of Matthew and directed by Vinnette Carroll; music and lyrics by Alox Bradford; additional music and lyrics by Micki Grant; settings and costumes by William Schroder; setting supervisor, Michael J. Hotopp,: lighting be Gilbert V. Hemsley Jr.; orchestrations and dance music by H. B. Barnum; choral arrangements and direction by Chapman Roberts; choreography by Talley Beatty; Production stage manager, Haig Sheoherd. Presented by Frankie Hewitt and the Shubert Organization in association with Theater Now Inc. At the Lyceum Theater, 149 West 45th Street.

title: South Africa Is Condemned by U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22The Security Council condemned South Africa today, accusing it of trying to force Lesotho into recognizing the neighboring Transkei territory as an independent country. The Council acted without a formal vote.

title: Police Act to Avert Breakdown In 911 Due to Civilian Absentees
description: Police officials said yesterday that they had taken steps to avert another breakdown this Christmas and New year's Eve at 911, the city's emergency telephone service, because of civilian employee absenteeism,

title: Rev. Dr. Samuel Cavert Is Dead; Planner of Ecumenical Movement
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, one of the country's foremost ecumenical leaders and a chief architect of the National Council of Churches and the World Council of Churches, died Tuesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 years old and lived at 161 Boulder Trail. Bronxville.

title: 2d Swine Flu Case in Month Found in Wisconsin
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22For the second time this month, the swine flu virus has been found in a farm resident in Wisconsin.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  Although none of them had a majorparty opponent in the November election, 50 members of the new Congress accepted more than $3 million in campaign contributions in 1976 and have nearly $1 million of left, apparently available for any political or perscnal use they choose.

title: U.S. Uncovers a Gun Purchase by Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22Administration officials said today that Iraq, which does not have diplomatic relations with the United States, had arranged for the purchase of 100 submachine guns from an American concern and had managed to smuggle 30 of them out of the country through its mission at the United Nations.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 (UPI) The General Assembly ended deliberations for the year tonight with a warning from its Third World President that economic inequalities are as much a menace to global order as political conflicts.

title: United Press International HILTON PLANNING TO MARRY: Conrad Hilton, of the hotel chain Hiltons, at court in Santa Monica, Calif., Tuesday after he took out a licenie marry Mary Francis Kelly, a saleswoman for an airline. It will be the fourth marriage for Mr. Hilton and the first for Miss Kelly. He is 87, she is 61.
Metropolitan Briefs
description: The first program to aircondition cars of the 72yearold IRT subway lines was begun yesterday when the Transit Authority awarded a $13.7 million contract to refit 400 cars with cooling systems. While more and more airconditioned rolling stock, has been put on the BMT and IND division runs over the last few years, engineers have been having trouble developing equipment that would fit into the smaller IRT cars.

title: Postal Employees Keep Up. Tradition in Gift to Neediest
description: Through the years, the employees of the United States Postal Service have been among the donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. As the 65th annual appeal continued through its third week, members of the Northeast regional headquarters, at the General Post Office, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, gave $384.25 to the fund.

title: Hasidim and Blacks Are Disputing New Community Lines in Brooklyn
description: A tan brick wall on the eastern side of the auditorium of Police, Headquarters became a symbol of angry racial conflict in New York City early yesterday as more than 50 Hasidic Jews lined up to pray for a victory.

title: Ski Resort Creates Program To Develop Toddlers
description: WHITE HAVEN, Pa., Dec. 22Get the small fry out of the nurseries and send them out on the slopes could well be the slogan of many ski area operators across the United States. They have been viewing such a policy with increasing favor in recent years. Holiday Mountain in the southern Catskills, among others, has its Lollipop Ridge and Mount Snow in Vermont has its Kiddy City.

title: EXC.I.A. AGENT SEIZED ON ESPIONAGE CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22A retired employee of the Central Intelligence Agency was arrested late today and charged with violating the espionage laws after he apparently left a package of classified Government documents at a Soviet residence here with a note promising to supply more documents in exchange for $200,000 payment.

title: Notes on People
description: The General Assembly yesterday confirmed the appointment of Marttl Ahtisaari, Finnish Ambassador to Tanzania, as United Nations Commissioner for Namibia. Mr. Ahtisaari, who is 39 years old, had been proposed for a oneyear term in the post by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim. He replaces Sean MacBride, winner of a Nobel Peace Prize in 1974, who wishes to devote his life to the cause of world disarmament.

title: No Pardon From Byrne
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)Governor Byrne of New Jersey said today that Mr. Carter should not look to him for clemency. Asked if he would consider any kind of pardon now, Mr. Byrne replied: I, don't think so. What Carter wanted was a new trial, and he got what he was after.

title: People and Business
description: From Key Biscayne, Fla., where he is vacationing, the Federal Energy Administrator, Frank G. Zarb, sent word yesterday that he would return to Wall Street next month as an executive vice president for corporate finance and investment banking activities and a director of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc.

description: Rita Reif

title: Grand Jury Hears Wall St. Witnesses
description: The first witnesses in an investigation into two aspects of trading at the New York Stock Exchange have testified before a Federal grand jury in New York. Two of the witnesses were partners in the specialist firm of Corroon, LichtenStein & Company: George A. Corroon Jr. and Robert R. Lichtenstein. A thi.ed witness was understood to be an official of the stock exchange.

title: Youth Orchestra Heralds the Holiday
description: By midnight tonight most people will be at hometheir own or somebody else'sawaiting the arrival of Santa Claus. Of those in public places, many will be attending masses and other religious services in churches.

title: FORD WON'T RESCIND CURB ON POISON USE
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 23President Ford has decided not to rescind an Executive order barring the use of poisons to control predators on public lands, a high White House official reported today. The official said that Mr Ford had decided not to revoke the ban because he believed that revocation would make no difference.

description: A state report says the state office Wilding in Harlem has fire hazards that are an obvious threat to the safety and welfare of building tenants.

title: TRADING IN A SLUMP FOR BOND MARKETS
description: Credit markets continued to hold steady yesterday in trading activity that one dealer estimated to be onetwentieth normal volume. For the most part, the fixedincome markets were shut down for Christmas, and not even the release of use reaeral Reserve figures at 4 P.M. stirred up any interest. As Aubrey G. Lanston & Company said, The market for Treasury securties loafed through the week, with prices showing a slightly rising tendency. This upward drift, the firm said, appeared to reflect an expectation  that somehow there will be further easing news out of Washington.

description: BECKENSTEINSamuel. Dec. 24, 1968. In blessed memory of our beloved father, our inspiration, guiding tight. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. HIS LOVING FAMILY.

He and Tito Goya, an actor using the name Andrew Butler, being held on similar charges, were arrested. Wednesday by two police officers as they left a building at 241 Eldridge Street, allegedly carrying two pistols, two fur coats, other property and a substance believed to be heroin.

The scheduled initial attraction due to open next Friday is Chats Chalte, described as a romantic musical with Hindi dialogue and English subtitles.

title: Broadway
description: THE SHUBERT Organization and the Kennedy Center will come together once again next year. They will coproduce The Merchant, the new play by Arnold Wesker, and it will star Zero Mostel and be directed by John Dexter. Mr. Mostel is coming into the Winter Garden on Tuesday in Fiddler on the Roof, and will stay there until May. Then his contract runs out. The Merchant, which shows Shakespeare's Shylock as a gentle intellectual, will to into rehearsal in July and open in either Washington or Boston in September. It will come into New York after that.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Prisoner Exchange . .
description: The exchange of political prisoners between the Soviet Union and Chile creates a welcome precedent that needs to be emulated. Now that Soviet dissident Vladimir Bukovsky and Chilean Communist Party leader Luis Corvalan Lepe are out of Jail, the Chileans are offering to free the only remaining political prisoner they acknowledge, Jorge Montes, for Cuban dissident Hubert Matos who has been imprisoned for 17 years.

title: Film: Gladys Knight And Alaska Pipeline
description: GLADYS KNIGHT, the recording star, makes a nice, low-keyed movie debut in "Pipe Dreams," the first film I've seen that uses the building of the Alaskan pipeline as an essential part of its action. The film, which also stars Miss Knight's real-life husband, Barry Hankerson, as her husband, within-the-film, is set in Valdez, Alaska, effectively portrayed as a frozen frontier community of well-heeled, lonely construction workers and the whores and confidence artists who are after their loot.Stephen Verona, the writer and director of the film, displays little apparent talent in either capacity, but at least he doesn't dwell too long on the foolishness of a plot that includes one plane crash of absolutely no surprise and the inept attempts of a crooked entrepreneur to delay the pipeline's completion. The movie pays no attenkerson, as her husband within-the-fraud involving the pipeline.Mostly it's about Miss Knight's attempts to win back her husband who had earlier left her in Atlanta to make his fortune as an Alaskan bush pilot. Miss Knight and Mr. Hankerson are not great actors by any means, but they play well together, creating some genuinely moving and comic moments of a sort one didn't often see in old-fashioned "B" pictures about lumber camps and gold-strike towns, which "Pipe Dreams" faintly resembles.Miss Knight doesn't sing on screen but, with the Pips, she's never long off the soundtrack. A lot of the movie is used up sightseeing by air, accompanied by Miss Knight and the Pips singing a batch of songs, some of which have more plot relevance than others. The film opened yesterday at four theaters."Pipe Dreams," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), makes no attempt to disguise the fact that all the women in the film, except its star, are whores, though nothing in the way of explicit sex is shown.

title: Books of The Times
description: A Manf 38 revisits his widowed mother after an absence, a nearsilence, of 16 ,Years. When she taxes him with the tone he takes, he says: Don't use this is a chance to get even with me for my life . . . I didn't come here to surrender it. Describing the death of his father, his mother is absolutely deadpan, refusing to share the emotion of the. event: I telephoned the doctor when f couldn't wake him up. I listened to what the doctor said and I called bad shape on this occasion and Claire says please don't die. We'll discuss it on the way, he answers.

title: Glow at the City's Heart
description: THE PRESENCE of what must be the world's most famous Christmas tree would alone make Rockefeller Center the city's symbolic heart at Christmas; the nearness of St. Patrick's Cathedral and the great stores of Fifth Avenue confirms it. Tourists swarm about the center, attracted by the tree and the free show of ice skaters gliding across the sunken plaza. But the thick crowds at this time of year contain a fair share of New Yorkers as well, who come remembering Christmases past at Rockefeller Center and see in the great Christmas tree and decorated plaza a sense of continuity In a changing city.

title: Theodore Chaikin Sorensen
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The new head of the American spy and intelligence community brings no expertise in espionage to his job, but, rather, a keen background in American politics and Presidential loyalty that Presidentelect Carter found attractive. In fact, Theodore C. Sorensen said at a news conference this morning in Plains, Ga., that he had not sought the dual appointment of Director of Central Intelligence and head of the Central Intelligence Agency but, because this assignment is central to the maintenance of a secure peace in the world, I did not feel I could turn him down.
