title: Movies: A French Soap Opera
description: THE PINK TELEPHONE" is a depressing little French soap-opera with various more or less fashionable preoccupations tagged on. It is soft at the center and musty on the surface."Telephone," which opened yesterday at the Fine Arts theater, is about a provincial factory owner who sells his factory to a big, American-controlled enterprise. The owner, who plays rugby with his workers on weekends and personifies the old humanity of France, comes up to Paris to discuss the sale.The purchasers, sleek to a fault and inhabiting a faceless glass building, sweeten the talks by providing a call girl who pretends to be somebody's niece and falls in love with the factory-owner. After their night together, he is smitten, and dreams of a new life, of leaving his wife and setting up with the young woman.He finds out the truth, is disillusioned, the factory sale is put in doubt, the workers protest, he leaves his wife. Meanwhile, he conducts a running argument with the young woman. She asserts the economic advantages of being a call girl. He argues for love. Finally she gets on a plane to meet a client in Italy and then, at the very end, turns back. Presumably they will live somewhere in the country and grow tomatoes.The wildly romantic, implausible ending is reminiscent of "Cousin, Cousine," but nothing else in the film is. Pierre Mondy tries to play the factory owner with the warm impassiveness of the late Jean Gabin; he simply looks sorry for himself. Mireille Darc as the call girl is cool, blonde andjudging by the amount of life she contributeson strike. Michel Lonsdale is sometimes amusing as the American capitalist.

title: Oxford Crew Defeats Harvard In First Race of Regatta in Egypt
description: ISMAILIA, Egypt, Dec. 23  Oxford University made up a deficit and scored a three  quarter  boat  length victory oVer'Harvard today in the opening race of the sixth annual Nile Intercollegiate Rowing Festival. Last year, to commemorate the reopening of the Suez Canal, the first race of this tworace regatta was moved to Ismailia, where the canal flows into Lake Timsah, which in Egyptian means Crocodile Lake. In ancient Egyptian mythology the crocodile represented the evil spirits dwelling in the waters, and although today's conditions were ideal for racing, the Harvard shell seemed to succumb to some supernatural powers In losing to Oxford.

title: CECIL ROBERTS, 84, DIES; JOURNALIST AND AUTHOR
description: ROME, Dec. 23 (Reuters)Cecil Roberts, British journalist, author and poet, died in Rome's Salvator Mundi Hospital at the age of 84, hospital officials said today.

description: An effort has begun to build an econometric model of New York City and its surrounding counties to provide better economic forecasts and as a tool to test policy alternatives.

title: 4 Guilty in Truck Robbery
description: NEWARK, Dec. 23 (AP)Four Essex County men have been convicted of the 1971 robbery of a truck containing $171,1000 in liquid gold and silver. An Essex County Jury yesterday returned guilty verdicts against Frank Batso, 38 years old of Newark, who is serving a Federal prison sentence; Nicholas. Stefanelli, 34, of Belleville; Donald Seritos 40, of Nutley, and Gerald Sperduto, 35, of Bellville.

title: Corporation Affairs

description: The Navy announced yesterday that its Resale System Office, which had been scheduled to be moved to Illinois last March, would stay in New York City.

title: Outlook for 1977: The Danger of Inflation
description: Tls the season to he Jolly, the old song says. And, traditionally, it's the time, too, for looking back on the expiring year and hoping that, no matter how it turned out, the New Year will be better and happier. There are reasons for those sentiments in the business world, as well as in personal relationships, every year at this time during the holidays. Final adjustments are being made, the books are about to be closed and budgets and plans are set for a good start once the calendar turns.

Carloadings in the same period totaled 452,905 cars, 5.2 percent above last year.

title: Salute to Thomson And His 3d Symphony
description: Virgil Thomson has waited nearly half of his 80 years for a New York concert performance of his Third Symphony, so he is not about to complain that Sunday's premiere will arrive a month and a day late for its announced purpose as a birthday salute. The composer, in fact, is delighted at the idea of having the work presented at last, and plans to be on hand at 3 P.M. when it opens the American Symphony Orchestra's Carnegie Hall program, with Kazuyoshi Akiyama conducting.

title: GEORGE W. BAILEY, 89, ELECTRONICS EXPERT
description: George W. Batley, an authority on electrical engineering and an amateur radio operator, died Sunday at his home in Nashville. He was 89 years old.

title: Burroughs, After Resisting Trade, Apparently Accepts
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 23 (UPI)Jeff Burroughs, the baseball slugger traded recently by the Texas Rangers, apparently will drop his contention that he had a notrade contract with the Rangers and join the Atlanta Braves.

description: Music

title: Italy to Trim Currency Tax
description: ROME, Dec. 23 (UPI)The Italian Treasury Minister Gaetano Stammati, announced today that he was cutting in half a 7 percent tax on the purchase of foreign currency by Italian residents on Dec. 27 and abolishing it altogether by Feb. 13. The tax was introduced Oct. 23 to raise the flagging lira. The tax will be cut to 3.5 percent on Dec. 27 and will be reduced a further half of 1 percent every week beginning Jan. 3.

title: Art: Feininger's Visionary Style
description: NOWADAYS, When every campy illustration earns the envy and admiration of experts who are supposed to know something about art and when old cartoon strips are republished and prized as precious artistic finds, we tend to forget the weighty decision it once represented for a serious artist to abandon the quick rewards of commercial art for the more arduous labors of what used to be called fine art, but for which we now have no common word or phrase. What was once regarded as a grave spiritual choice is now put down to a matter of taste, as if in an artistic vocation there was nothing,more serious at stake than ordering a meat in a restaurant.

title: Theodore S. Watson, 87, Founder Of Investment Banking Firm, Dead
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 23kTheodore S. Watson, who organized the investment banking firm of Watson and White with E. Laurence White in 1920, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 87 and lived at 284 Round Hill Road.

It's nice to have your parents nearby, but it's not always going to, be that way. They won't always be around.

J., Dec. 23 (AP)One of the owners of an abandoned Jersey City dump where authorities once believed the body of Jimma Hoffa, the missing Teamsters leader, might be buried has pleaded guilty to incometax evasion. Phillip Moscato, 42 years old, admitted yesterday in Federal District Court that he filed a 1false tax return in 1971.

title: Senate Banking Group Bids Fed Ease Monetary Conditions Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The Senate Banking Committee, in a cautiously worded report, urged today that the Federal Reserve Board make a slight shift toward easing monetary conditions and also raise slightly its targets for growth of the money supply in the year ahead.

title: Wealthy, Intellectual Briton A Key Man in Laborite Rule
description: LONDON, Dec. 23When a policy is immediately disagreeable, the English believe it must produce ultimate and enduring benefit. If it is couched in language they cannot understand, they believe it to be the product of much learning. A conjunction of the unpleasant and the incomprehensible is therefore irresistible to Englishmen.

title: DR. HAROLD C. STEWART, PIONEER IN CHILD HEALTH
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 23 (UPI)Dr. Harold C. Stuart, a pioneer in the field of child health and development, died Tuesday after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: A Neatly Balanced Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23If there a sense of anticlimax at the final unveiling of Presidentelect Carter's Cabinet today, it is because his campaign raised expectations of a fresh, bold break with the past and his Cabinet selection actually turned out to be the traditional balancing off of conNews stituencies. He promised Analysis new generation of leaders, but in the end drew heavily on experience. The Carter Cabinet has no easy hallmark like President Eisenhower's, which someone immediately typed as eigh millionaires and a plumber. It is a largely nonpolitical team without any clear idealogical shading of any towering figurewith the possible exception of James R. Schlesinger, the energy chiefto challenge Mr. Carter as an architect of policy or to compete with him as a political personality.

title: Stockngful of Shows For the Holidays
description: It is a common misconception that hit shows are always sold out. The fact is that only one current show, A Chorus Line, consistently plays to capacity. If you want to see A Chorus Line, you must plan far in advance. But this holiday weekend, it is possible to buy tickets to every other theatrical attraction, including such current successes as Porgy and Bess, Comedians, Sly Fox and For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/ When the Rainbow is Enuf. Last week there were even some seats available to Harold Pinter's No Man's Land during its final performances.

title: New Car Sales Rose 32.5% in MidMonth
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23New car sales climbed 32.5 percent in midDecember and were the second best for the period on record, reports from the four domestic auto companies showed today.

title: Foul by Winner
description: It's too late now for New York's thoroughbred horseplayers to talk of getting even, at least for 1976. The players finally ran out of shopping days at Aqueduct yesterday as the flatracing season limped to a close 2,682 races after it began. OrigiAt the nally, the schedule at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Race Saratoga called for 306 Tracks days of action. That would have given the customers 2,754 chances to find a winner. But seven programs were canceled bg bad weather last winter, and another was knocked out by a strike of maintenance employees. So the season ran  298 days.

title: Wyoming Task In Fiesta Bowl: Avoid Injuries
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 23 (AP)Avoiding injuries on the offensive line and at fullback will be essential for the University of Wyoming if it hopes to beat the highly favored University of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl on Saturday.

title: Red Smith
description: This is a nounay greeting to a friend who is spending Christmas in University Hospital, although he is not the university type. His name is Toots Shor. He is the greatest saloonkeeper in the world and for more than 40 years he has been a major figure in sports on the Big Apple, friend and confessor and counsel to athletes, confidant of the sports hierarchy, fan, authority, raconteur. He ought to be designated a national landmark. These days when he is on his feet he holds forth in 33d Street across from Madison Square Garden in a joint that caters to the Sports hitandrun crowds attending games in the of Garden. In a slightly earlier day, his joint, especially the brick house at 51 West 51st The Times Street, was the mother lodge. Attendance was practically compulsory. If you wanted to see anybody, you went there, and if the guy you sought had stepped out for a moment, you could settle for Ernest Hemingway or Chief Justice Earl Warren or Yogi Berra or Paul Draper or Edward Bennett Williams or Gene Fowler or Billy Conn or Frank Sinatra or Pat O'Brien or Robert Sherwood or Jackie Gleason or Abe Attell.

title: Jazz: Betty Carter, Song Stylist
description: Betty Carter has, in the tradition of the jazz world, paid her dues. For almost 30 years, she has been honing a style that is based on an admiration of Billie Holiday, the influences of three years as a singer with Lionel Hampton's band and, for more than two decades, finding her own highly personal way. For mudh of the time her way has been so prickly, so aberrant that her appeal has been largely limited to hard core of fellow musicians.

title: Bugging Our Wards
description: With the new Administration preparing to take over, the intelligence community has been sending out strong signals that it would like very much to be left alone. The gist of the message is that the intelligence agencies have been hit by such blizzards of directors, charges of wrongdoing and shakeups that peaceful consolidation of all the recent reforms is badly needed.

title: In Rio It's Time When Work Is a Charade With Summer at Peak and Carnival Ahead
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24To be a Carioca a certain indolence is necessary, Carlos Lemos, a Brazilian social commentator, once wrote. It requires a certain capacity to linger on the beach or at the bar, even when it is time to work. The important thing is to work, but always giving the impression that you are doing nothing. The Southern Hemisphere summer is upon Rio, and the Cariocasthat is what residents of the city call themselvesare at their most indolent. If anything, many people strive to give the impression of working while in fact doing nothing.

title: Mary Moore Cross, 92, Dead; Pound Dedicated Poems to Her
description: Mary Moore Cross, to whom the late Ezra Pound in 1908 dedicated his first book of poems, Personae, died Thursday at her home in Montclair, N.J. She was 92 years old and was the widow of Frederick Cross, a New York advertising man who died about 10 years ago.

title: Mexico Increasing Oil Prices 10%; Plans to Quadruple Output by 82
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 24The Mexican Government has announced plans to raise the price of its oil exports by 10 percent and to increase foreign sales of crude oil from 105,000 barrels a day now to at least 400,000 barrels a day by 1982.

title: Population of Elephants in Africa Under Study by Wildlife Groups
description: The status of Africa's elephant populations, widely held to be declining rapidly and possibly approaching extermination in some areas, is being examined in the first continentwide research program attempted on an African animal.

title: HIGH FRENCH AIDE IS KILLED IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Dec. 24Prince Jean de Broglie, a longtime, Deputy Foreign Minister and a prominent political figure in France, was shot and killed here this morning on residential street.

title: For Them It's the Most Special Time of All
description: The visions that dance in their heads may no longer be of sugarplums, but to children, the spirit of innocent joy endures . . . in the tentative first brush with Santa, in the soprano ring of an ancient carol,. or in the sparkle of something very special under all of the trees this Christmas morning.

title: MARGARET DREW NETTINGA
description: Margaret Drew Nettinga, wife of the Rev. Dr. James Z. Nettinga, executive secretary of the American Bible Society, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 58 years old and lived in Haworth, N. J.

title: 150 More Firefighters Restored by O'Hagan
description: Commissioner John T. O'Hagan yes; terday reappointed 150 firefighters who were laid off in July 1975: Family members joined the firemen in the auditorium at the Board of Health building, 125 Worth Street.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Christmas Gift
description: LONDONMrs. Margaret Thatcher's idea of an excellent Christmas gift for busted, badgered and bewildered Britain is a Conservative government in the year 1977. Whether, of course, she is afforded the chance to make this present will depend on what use the Labor incumbents make of their newest injection of foreign help and how successfully they can assure the people that they are moving toward recovery.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Tuesday reported incorrectly that the Nassau County tax rates would be decreased in 1977 by more than 40 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation in the area served by the county police. The 40cent decrease will apply only in those areas served by city or village police departments.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Tuesday reported incorrectly that the Nassau. County tax rates would be decreased in 1977 by more than 40 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation in the area served by the county police. The 40cent decrease will apply only in those areas served by city or village police departments.

title: Weekend Events
description: TODAY

title: Pope's Christmas Mass Televised to 32 Lands
description: ROME, Dec. 24 (AP)Pope Paul VI, at a midnight mass in St. Peter7s Basilica that was beamed live to a worldwide audience of more than a billion people in 32 countries, hailed the birth of Jesus as an event of the greatest humility and magnitude.

title: Nevada Bars Middleton As Opponent for Foreman
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 24 (AP) The Nevada State Athletic Commission has rejected a proposed Jan. 22 heavyweight fight between George Foreman and Larry Middleton because of the condition of Middleton's eyes.

title: Army Asked to Open Case of Pvt. Slovik
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP)A lawyer for the widow of Pvt. Eddie Slovik, the only American soldier to be shot for desertion since the Civil war, has requested that the Army reopen Private Slovik's case and pay military insurance benefits to the widow.

title: Dave Anderson
description: They're not destitute. They won't be on line at the Salvation Army for Christmas dinner. But they are the six baseball free agents still out in the cold today, still unsigned and unemployedDick Allen, Willie McCovey, Nate Colbert, Tito Fuentes, Pauld Dade and Billy Smith.

title: Plan to Burn Spilled Oil Is Rejected
description: NANTUCKET, Mass. Dec. 24The Coast Guard rejected today a plan to reduce the effects of the oil spill from the tanker Argo Merchant by burning off parts of the 100milelong smear of oil in the North Atlantic.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONThe head of a New York research and development company was granted a patent this week for a talking wristwatch. Prototypes are now being made, and commercial production by next Christmas is expected.

title: Cutting the Defense Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The prevailing view among members of the transition team and Congressional budget specialists is that Presidentelect Carter will be unable to carry out his pledge to reduce the defense budget unless he

title: Books of The Times
description: They're so beautiful, it's stupid, Gustave Courbet said of his own paintings, and it is interesting to speculate on what he might have meant. He was probably saying, on a superficial level only, that is was stupid for people to fail to like them. On a deeper, less conscious level, he might also have been observing that these paintings had the brute beauty of life itself, that they transcended the intermediation of theory or intellection, that they were so natural that he could ironically call them stupid. Affectation was such a highly developed art in turnofthecentury Paris that a lack of it might easily have been regarded by the most narrowminded art critics of any age and place as peasant stupidity.

title: CHINA IN MAJOR DRIVE TO MECHANIZE FARMS
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 24In an effort, to speed agricultural production after year of political disruption, China is making a major drive to mechanize its farms by 1980 and improve the performance of flagging local party units.

title: Screen: 'The Monkey Hustle' Tasteless, Brutal
description: "The Monkey Hustle" is a movie of jellied brain and idiot eyes, like the defective product of combining an old Andy Hardy movie and modern black urban life. The result is something that peers through a haze of moral confusion at street kids, pimps, hustlers, hookers, crooked cops, spaghetti-spined politicians and corrupt businessmen and decides they are lollipops.The truth is that most of the principal characters, including many of the youngsters, are dishonest or brutal, and the "heroes" are distinguishable only by being slightly less dishonest or brutal than the villains. Reigning at the summit of "The Monkey Hustle's" distorted hagiocracyapparently by virtue of the fact that he smiles brilliantly and contents himself with small swindles and the immoral upbringing of small childrenis Yaphet Kotto as a petty con man named Daddy Foxx.Aside from concerning itself with the virtues of small-time crime as opposed to numbers and pimping, this movie also busies itself with young love, an expressway that threatens the Chicago neighborhood in which it is set, and an effort to obtain the money for the set of drums to play at the big community block party to oppose the expressway.This movie's major hustle will be to separate from their money and time the adolescents who might logically be "The Monkey Hustle's" audienceif, it merited one.The PG ("parental guidance suggested") rating is presumably attributable to the movie's street language and its recognition that adolescents are sexual explorers.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Albert H. Skean Dies at 86; A Leader of Convention Bureaus
description: Albert H. Skean of Absecon, N.J., who retired in 1955 as manager of the Atlantic City Convention Bureau, died Thursday in Atlantic City Medical Center. His age was 86.

title: NEW DELHI RELINOUISHES ITS CONTROL IN GUJARAT
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 24 (AP)The state of Gujarat, ruled by the federal Government for the last nine months, was turned over today to a new state administration formed by Indies ruling Congress party.

title: Damian Krehel, a Retired Priest Of the Russian Orthodox Church
description: The Right Rev. Damian Krehel, a retired Russian Orthodox priest, died Thursday at J.F.K. Medical Center, Edison, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Warren, N.J.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BROADWAY MELODIES Something new has been addeda minibonus of theater memorabiliato the Front Row, the 15thfloor cocktail lounge of the Act One restaurant, at No. Times Square. The lounge is gaining popularity as a theatergoer's oasis, with a new parquet floor for dancing starting at 7 o'clock to the music of singer and pianist Martin St. Lawrence and, of course, with that awesome view of Times &ware.

title: Leaders in Madrid Confer on Red
description: MADRID, Dec. 24 (AP)King Juan Carlos and Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez conferred today on the furor over the arrest of the leader of Spain's Communist Party. In a Christmas address to the nation, the King pledged to carry out his dales with firmness and prudence.

title: 81 Die as Egypt Jet Crashes Into Plant In Bangkok Suburb
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Saturday, Dec. 25 aAn Egyptair jetliner exploded in midair and crashed in a predawn mist fog five miles north of Bangkok's main international airport today, killing 42 passengers and a crew of nine. The landing gear struck a factory and 30 workers inside were killed.

title: Ballet Theater Nutcracker in Capital Delights
description: WASHINGTONAmerican Ballet Theater clearly has a major hit on its hands with Mikhail Baryshnikov's new staging of The Nutcracker. Even for its second performance at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Wednesday afternoon, when Mr. Baryshnikov himself did not appear, no tickets were available, and crowds of wouldbe buyers, hoping for returns or the steely kindness of scalpers, were disconsolately milling around the entrance and the box office, hoping for the best, fearing the worst.

title: Snow Machines, Route 80 Make Poconos Resorts Prosper
description: STROUDSBURG, Pa.In a season that already has produced financial woes at highelevation resorts in Colorado, Utah, Oregon and other states, the skiing economy in Pennsylvania's hilly Poconos is off to the most pros

title: About New York
description: One of the last good looks Sam Heyman had at anyone was at Te% ye, his grandson who was three months old before the final threads of Sam's eyesight gave way after a gradual and, he still says, unbelievable progression of glaucoma. After that there were some shadows for a while, most memorably, again. Tevye, a hit older as a short friendly ghost passing quietly near to snitch one of grandfather's crackers and feed it to the dog.

title: The first phase of the biggest dollarfordollar confrontation in the history of the National Basketball Association will take place tonight when the Knicks oppose the Philadelphia 76ers at Madison Square Garden. It should give an indication whether F. Eugene Dixon's money did more for the 76ers than the Garden's money did for the Knicks.
description: About two months ago, Dixon, newcomer to pro basketball, parted with a chunk of his personal fortune. He won the sweepstakes for Julius Erving and his 76ers were supposed to bolster the Bicentennial spirit in Philadelphia.

title: Oklahoma Fire Ruins 25 Homes; Petroleum Plant Damage Averted
description: BARTLESV1LLE, Okla., Dec. 24 (AP)A windfed fire swept through a residential section of this eastern Oklahoma city today, leaving more than 100 persons homeless and threatening a nearby petroleum storage plant before firemen brought it under control.

title: Personal Investing
description: Funds That Stress OTC Growth Issues

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Time to Change Sox Again
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Dec. 24 (AP)For the third time in three years, the Boston Red Sox's top farm club here has changed its name. This time, the team is being called the New England Red Sox. Last year, the International League team changed its name from the Pawtucket Red Sox to the Rhode Island Red Sox. Mary Adelson, the team's new owner, said he changed the name to the New England Red Sox in an attempt to draw more fans.

title: The Carter Cabinet
description: In putting together his Cabinet, Presidentelect Carter had a choice to make. He could have symbolized the overthrow of the old Eastern establishmentsthe law firms, foundations, banking houses and universities the BostontoWashington corridorby assembling group without connections to those institutions. He could have looked for outsiders, new to power and unfamiliar with existing networks of influence, men and women with an eagerness for innovation.

title: Satra Corp. Says It Has No Backers for Olympic TV
description: An executive of the Satra Corporation, the company that won an agreement with the Soviet Union to televise the 1980 Olympic Games from Moscow for American audiences, said the concern planned to provide coverage equal to or better than anything done so far and we hope the best ever.

title: Carter's Election Is Raising Hopes in Black Africa
description: LAGOS, NigeriaEven though Jimmy Carter is virtually unknown to black Africa, his election has been widely applauded here and has raised hopes for a new chapter in AmericanAfrican relations.

title: Danica Bruckner Deutsch at 86, Retired Director of Mental Clinic
description: Danica Bruckner Deutsch, who retired in 1973 as executive director of the Alfred Adler Mental Hygiene Clinic here, died, yesterday in a nursing home here after an illness of several months. Her age was 86.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Westchester Premiere Theater Begins Bankruptcy Proceedings
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 24  The Westchester Premiere Theater is filing for reorganization with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. The $6 million theater, a showcase for popular entertainers that attracted such stars as Frank Sinatra and Liza Minnelli, will continue to operate with a full season of spring bookings beginning March 1.

title: Bruce Hooton Weds Betsy Main Babcock
description: Betsy Main Babcock, a granddaughter of the late R. J. Reynolds. the tobacco manufacturer, was married at her apartment here yesterday to Bruce Duff Hooton, editor and publisher of ArtWorld, a monthly newspaper covering the visual arts. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick performed the ceremony. It was the third marriage for both bride and bridegroom. Their previous marriages ended in divorces.

title: Unique Land
description: Federal and state officials have acted just in time save a remarkable parcel of land on the eastern end Long Island from being lost to the public as parkland.

title: LYDIK S. JACOBSEN, 79; VIBRATIONS EXPERT
description: Dr. Lydik S. Jacobsen, a researcher and consultant on the construction of buildings to lessen earthquake damage, died Tuesday at Hoag Hospital in Newport Beach, Calif., after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Huntington Beach, Calif.

title: Tony Bird Appeals as Singer Presenting Sounds of Africa
description: Tony Bird, who is appearing at Reno Sweeney through tonight as the opening act for Cathy Chamberlain, grew up in Malawi, in the Rift Valley of Central Africa. His accent falls strangely on American. ears and the songs he writes and sings are spiced with Africanisms such as interlocking rhythms, melodies that move in short, repeating cycles and a Pygmylike falsetto whooping.

title: In a ModernDay Setting, Old Ceremonies Touch Emotions of Visitors
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 24As darkness engulfed the ocher hills tonight, festive lights blinked on along the road from Jerusalem to Bethlehem. rapea carols resonated through the dusky hillsides. Children scampered near Manger Square. The cool weather braced but did not chill. A taxi full of nuns hurried by; undoubtedly the nuns were fortunate enough to hold tickets for the ceremonies celebrating the birth of Jesus, culminating in midnight mass in the Church of the Nativity and a procession to the Grotto of the Nativity. There, a silver star marks the spot where Jesus is believed to have been born.

title: Comecon Is Seeking More Aid by Soviet To Curb Imbalances
description: VIENNA, Dec. 24Eastern European officials are shuttling between their capitals and Moscow to obtain economic concessions and additional assistance for their countries from the Soviet Union, according to information available here.

title: A $330 Million Loan Is Completed by Sidbec Unit
description: MONTREAL, Dec. 24A $330 million loan, one of the largest negotiated by a Canadian concern on the American market in recent years, has been completed here by a mining subsidiary of Quebec's publicly owned steel company, Sidbec.

title: Califon, Now a Historic District, Is Reconstructing Its Past
description: CALIFON, Dec. 24The unaltered 1760 Georgian Schuyler House on Main Street, with its walkin fireplaces and outside bake oven, is a historic treasure.

title: Notes on People
description: At his holiday retreat in Vail, Colo., President Ford got the white Christmas he wanteda halfinch snowfall Thursday night. But he still won't be able to ski today because an old football knee injury is ailing. On doctor's advice, Mr. Ford planned to spend quiet day today, staying off the slopes until tomorrow at least. By the time the President is able to ski, another couple of inches of snow will have fallen, if predictions hold up. The Fords planned a quiet family Christmas.

title: Dance: Meredith Monk Thinks Big
description: Meredith Monk has never shied from mammoth proportions in designing her pieces, at times using footballsize fields and three separate locations spread over several days. In Quarry, however, she has elected to stay in one room, the wonderfully adaptable Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and to trim her presentation time to an hour and a half. The piece still has the imaginative diversity that characterizes her best work and gains from the compression.

title: The Long Weekend Opens Quietly in New YorkLittle Chance of Snow
description: For many New Yorkers, the Christmas rush was over yesterday. Most offices had closed Thursday afternoon for the holiday weekend, and there was a chance to walk or iceskate in the brisk, bright air and take pictures of the children in front of Christmas decorations.

title: Facing Up to Change
description: Jimmy Carter began his shopping early in November. I want to see something in a nice new face, he said. The clerk smiled and took gentle, yet handsome face from the rack.

title: A. Mervyn Davies, an Author And ExSecretary for Pulitzer
description: A. Mervyn Davies, a freelance writer and for years a confidential secretary to the late Joseph Pulitzer, editor and publisher of The St. Louis PostDispatch, died Thursday in his home at 89 Borglum Road, Wilton, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: VOTING IN 1976 IS PLACED AT 89% OF REGISTRATION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The Census Bureau says 89 percent of registered voters participated in the Nov. election.

title: Rebecca West Still Going Strong
description: LONDONThere is nothing like a Dameespecially if she is Rebecca West, Dame Commander, Order or the British Empire, and uncrowned queen of British letters.

title: Article 7  No Title
Fans, Players Keyed Up for RangerIslander Battle
description: Quickly setting aside the holiday spirit, the Rangers and the Islanders clash tomorrow night for the second time in less than two weeks. The place is Madison Square Garden, which isn't necessarily an advantage for the home team.

title: Spinning Elegantly at the Waldorf at aYouthHelpsYouth Ball
description: The girls were a mlange of every fashion point made in the last 10 years clinging jerseys, filmy chiffons, oneshoulder velvets, handkerchiefpoint scarves, stiff taffetas and tight satin pants. The shy among them plucked at rosebud, orchid and gardenia corsages and puffed intently on cigarettes. The more assured exchanged highpitched greetings and cheek kisses, not quite as smoothly as their mothers do, but not missing the target either.

title: Shift in Membership of Community Boards Expected
description: The composition of most of the city's community boards is expected to undergo substantial change next week when the five, Borough Presidents appoint members of the newly constituted boards that will assume expanded powers under the revised City Charter.

title: Jersey Doctor Loses License
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24 (AP)The license of a Vineland, N.J., physician who was arrested in October on a charge of selling barbiturates to an undercover agent has been temporarily suspended. The physician, Dr. Milton Levin, voluntarily surrendered his license after being charged in an administrative complaint with selling 12,952 barbiturates for $2,900. Dr. Levin denies the charges.

title: Chicago Fire Kills 12 At Christmas Party; 8 Others Are Injured
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP)A fire erupted today in a threestory brick apartment building where a Christmas party was being held and killed 12 persons, includine at least eight children.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A man tentatively identified by the police as 22yearold Eddie Judge of 85 Eighth Avenue, died in St. Clare's hospital after being stabbed in the groin with the jagged edge of a broken liquor bottle. The police said the stabbing had occurred during an argument between two other persons in front of a bar at 46th Street and Eighth Avenue. They said they did not know who had been involved in the fight or what it had been about.

title: Music: Brandenburg Concertos
description: Thursday night's presentation of Bach's six Brandenbrug Concertos at the 92d Street Y was a trial run for prospective chamber orchestra to have headquarters there, beginning next season. Beyond merely justifying such an undertaking, the performances held out the promise of a distinctive and valuable addition to the city's musical life.

title: Christmas Mail Service Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI)Postal workers, with help from the public, have done an outstanding job this Christmas season in handling all the mail and parcels, Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar says. A Postal Service spokesman said that parcel volume was up more than 20 per cent over last year because of the United Parcel Service strike and that other mail was about even at 6.5 billion pieces.

title: College Results
Eurodollar Market Booming in London
description: LONDON, Dec. 24Along the cluttered gray streets of the financial center of London, a district that's as morose as any here over the harsh turns in the British economy, the Eurodollar business is thriving.

title: In a ModernDay Setting, Old Ceremonies Evoke Emotions of Visitors
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Dec. 24As darkness engulfed the ocher hills tonight, festive lights blinked on along the road from Jerusalem to Bethlehem.

title: Poor Feel Pinch In Rich Caracas During Holdays
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 22For the affluent, Venezuela's extravagant Christmas season is an endurance contest in social obligations. For the poor, it shows how inflation can hurt.

title: Military Cuts Jar New England
description: LIMESTONE, Me.The Air Force came to this bleak, remote potato farming country in 1946, bulldozing the forests and fields for runways. The bombers arrived in 1953, first the B36's, then the B52's, and since then people here have been told that Loring Air Force Base, the northeasternmost in the country, the closest to Russia, was the first line of defense and deterrence absolutely indispensable.

title: Duke of Braganza, Claimant to Throne, Is Dead in Portugal
description: LISBON, Dec. 24Dom Duarte Nuno, the Duke of Braganza and claimant to the Portuguese throne, which was abolished in 1910, died in a hospital here today at the age of 69.

title: RIGHTWING RADICALS AROUSE NEW INTEREST
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24The discovery of large stores of weapons and munitions buried on the edge of the Mojave Desert has for the first time in years turned attention to the forgotten man of American politics, the rightwing extremist.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Vermont Governor Will Pardon 71; Drug Agent's Evidence Questioned
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., Dec. 24 (AP)Gov. Thomas P. Salmon will pardon 71 persons convicted of drug charges on the basis of arrests by a discredited undercover agent, Paul Lawrence, gubernatorial aides said today.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reported during the last week in the New York Times.

title: Gottfried and McEnroe In Orange Bowl Semifinals
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 24 (AP)Four American boys, including topseeded Larry Gottfried of Lauderhill, gained the semifinals of the Orange Bowl world junior tennis championships today.

title: Mental Hygiene Agency Is Being Split Up
description: ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP)The Carey administration plans to restructure the Department of Mental Hygiene by dividing it into three nearly autonomous agencies and reducing the power of the current Commissioner.

title: NOMINEES OF CARTER DIFFER ON CLUB ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)Two top level Carter administration appointees say they will quit private clubs that have no black members and do not routinely accept women, but the membership status of two other Carter nominees in similar organizations remains unchanged.

title: Bridge:
description: In keeping with the season, there were many generous players distributing presents to their opponents at the winter regionals here last weekend. Two of the beneficiaries were Bill Ericksen of Port Washington, L.I., and Gary Hann of New York, who sat South and North, respectively, on the diagramed deal. They received one Christmas present from their opponents in the bidding, and another from the fates.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1976

title: Anniversaries
description: MARIA AND RAMON. All our lave and best wishes on your first wedding anniversary. The Morales and the Paner families.

title: In Southern and East Africa, U.S. Is Facing Challenges Almost as Volatile as in Mideast
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 20In terms of American foreign policies, the problems of southern and eastern Africa have in the last year proven to be like the unexpected arrival of quintuplets. They may not be manageable but they cannot be ignored.

title: Polish Church Recalls a Midnight Mass on Christmas Eve
description: SCRANTON, Pa.On Christmas Eve in 1900, a young, intrepid priest named Francis Hodur broke with tradition by chanting midnight mass to his Polish congregation here in St. Stanislaus Church in their native language.

title: VIKTOR Y. STANITSYN
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (UPI)Viktor Y. Stanitsyn, for four decades a leading actor, producer and art director of the Moscow Arts Theater, has died at the age of 79, the Tass press agency said Friday.

title: Lawless Taxis
description: The times shortly after 5 P.M. The place: midtown on New York's West Side. The problem: getting a taxi to La Cuardia Airport.

title: I.B.M. Now Frowns On Civic Activities
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 24 (AP)  The International Business Machines Corporation, which traditionally has encouraged its employees to be active in government affairs, has begun to discourage such activity, saying it wishes to avoid charges of conflict of interest.

title: Seaway Section Closes Late
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (AP)The MontrealLake Ontario section of the St. Lawrence Seaway was closed for the winter last night, five days after it had been scheduled to close, the Transportation Department announced. A spokesman said the closing was delayed because severe weather slowed vessels trying to get through.

title: Pound Up in Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The pound gained strength today on European markets, while the dollar had a mixed day. Gold rose slightly.

title: By Paul Engle
description: Every Christmas should begin with the sound of bells, and when I was a child, mine always did. But they were sleigh bells, not church bells, for we lived in part of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, where there were no churches. My bells were on my father's team of horses as he drove up to our horseheaded hitching post with the bobsled that would take us to celebrate Christmas on the family farm 10 miles out in the country, near Marion.

title: An Endless Christmas Party for 5 Inch Guests
description: There's a Christmas party in progress at the Museum of the City of New York. A lobster, ham and sturgeonall plasterare laid out In a miniature dining room. In the ballroom, guests sip champagne from goblets smaller than thimbles. The guests themselves, in fact, are only five and a half inches tall, and what guests they are.

title: Donor to Fund For the Neediest Once Got Its Aid
description: A grandmother who lost her husband in the closing days of World War II and was helped at that time by the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was among the donors yesterday to the 65th annual appeal.

title: CITIBANK PLANS TO LEAVE PRIME RATE AT 61/4% LEVEL
description: Citibank yesterday decided to leave its prime lending rate at 614 percent although some major banks recently have lowered their rate to 6 percent.

title: For Them It's the Most Special Time of All
description: The visions that dance in their heads may no longer be of sugarplums, but to children, the spirit of innocent joy endures . . . in the tentative first brush with Santa, in the soprano ring of an ancient carol, or in the sparkle of something very special under all of the trees this Christmas morning.

title: Rams Warming to the Task Of Facing Cold and Vikings
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec 24 (UPI)The Los Angeles Rams, healthy and warmly confident of reaching the Super Bowl for the first time, left today for frigid Minnesota and Sunday's National Football Conference title clash with the Vikings. The winner advances to the Super Bowl Jan. 9.

title: NEW PRIME MINISTER IS SELECTED IN JAPAN BY A NARROW MARGIN
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24Takeo Fukuda was elected Prime Minister of Japan today in a narrow parliamentary vote that presaged a new era of tough legislative politics for the United States chief Asian ally.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All United States stock exchanges and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Christmas.

title: Group Provides LowCost Transit So Families Can Visit Prison Inmates
description: NEWARK, Dec. 24The Joint Connection, a nonprofit group that provides direct, lowcost transportation for prisoners families, has a special gift for them this holiday season.

title: Manila Halts AntiMoslem Drive
description: MANILA, Dec. 24 (Reuters)President Ferdinand E. Marcos ordered his military forces to halt operations in the southern Philippines today following a ceasefire agreement reached with Moslem separatists who have been in rebellion there for four years.

title: $20,000 and $20,800 Fines Levied Against 2 Detectives for Corruption
description: Record fines of $20,000 and $20,800 have been levied by the Police Department against two detectives who were accused of pocketing $3,500 during a narcotics raid in a Manhatttan apartment more than six years ago.

title: Train Derailment On Potomac Bridge Delays Travelers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)Christmas travelers passing through here today encountered delays and a short bus trip after a freight train derailed, blocking the only rail bridge linking the nation's capital and Virginia.

title: CONSPIRATOR HINTED IN DR. KING SLAYING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24A report by the House Committee on Assassinations says that its investigators have obtained uncorroborated testimony that James Earl Ray received instructions from a secret conspirator in his flight after the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: People in Sports
description: If the New York Jets intend to do thorough housecleaning after this season's record of 3 victories and 11 losses, the man with the most legendary broom in pro football is now officially available. Joe Thomas, the controversial general manager of the Baltimore Colts, has been given permission to negotiate with all the other National Football League teams.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1976

title: Gunman Loses His Hostages and Surrenders
description: Three of 13 persons being held in a storage room of a Los Angeles supermarket escaped through the roof. A gunman had held up the store and locked them there, but all were freed by police officers who rushed to the scene. The gunman, surrounded, hid in a refrigerator.

title: Miss Allen Wed To Bryan Cary

title: People and Business
description: In the financial world and in the economy generally, 1976 was a year of excessive expectations. The stock market scored a sizzling gain in January, then backed and filled for the rest of the year. Similarly, the economy, after a robust first quarter, lapsed into a long pause. It was a year of controversy over problem loans, accounting standards and the national market system. But it was also a year of real accomplishment in reducing inflation, restoring liquidity and rebuilding profits. Here are four people who made news in finance and economics. A selection from business and industry will appear next week.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners forget that there is an ash pit under each fireplace and another at the base of the flue to which the furnace is connected. These ash pits, usually in the basement, accumulate soot (from the furnace) or ashes (from the fireplace), and each has a small metal door that provides access for cleaning at the bottom. If the ash pit at the bottom of a fireplace is neglected for long periods, allowing accumulations to build up, a damp, Musty or smoky smellsimilar to burnt goodmay develop. And if soot builds up excessively in the cleanout pit under a furnace flue, it can interfere with proper draft and even pose a fire hazard. Cleaning out the ash pit is simply a matter of opening the door and brushing, scooping or vacuuming out the soot, ashes or both.

title: State Prison: No Community Wants It
description: NY community would be expected to resist the intrusion of anything that would threaten to tear down the neighborhood, and the state has just run into that obstacle in trying to find site for a prison in one of New Jersey's I northern cities.

title: :Ballet: 2 Classics From Joffrey

Thursday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, during the Joffrey Ballet's special Christmas season, it was the turn of William Whitener to make his debut in this 75yearold ballet.

title: Giving big business the business
description: Practically nobody loves a large corporation. Such at least, Ralph Nader and his associates happily report in Taming the Giant Corporation, is the general conclusion of the pollsters. According to Louis Harris only 18 percent of Americans in 1979 had great confidence in big business, a sad drop from 55 percent in 1966. In September 1975, 49 percent of Peter Hart's sample agreed that big business is the source of most of what's wrong in this country today, slightly more than the 45 percent who rejected the harsh verdict. And in 1973, 53 percent of Opinion Research Corporation's respondents favored the fragmentation of large American corporate entities, up from 37 percent in 1965.

title: TimeWasting on Rise at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP) Figures show that the General Assembly and its seven committees wasted 263 hours by starting meetings late during the threemonth annual session just ended, compared with 224 hours last year and 199 hours in 1974.

description: Fragmented politically and socially, ItalianAmericanswho, according to new statistics, are on a par with blacks as the biggest ethnic groups in New York City are shaping up as an unpredictable but potentially important element in the mayoral election.

title: Finding the Beat
description: Following is a partial listing of discotheques on the Island. The clubs set age restrictions and dress codes, but many are lax in enforcement of the regulations. It is a good idea to call first, because the days and hours they are open are subject,to change. Many of the discos have special New Year parties this Friday night, for which there is an additional charge.

title: Purged, imprisoned, rehabilitated, exiled
description: Eugen Loebl was one of Communist Czechoslovakia's highest and most highly decorated Government officials when, in 1949, he was swept up in the postwar purge trials. He spent several years in brutal solitary confinement and then in concentration camps, was only rehabilitated in 1963, and was about to join the Dubcek Government in 1968when in August of that year the Russians invaded the country, whereupon he went into exile. Eight years later, we have two remarkable books from himthe first looking back to one of the great horrors of the 20th century; the second looking forward, perhaps presenting a new way to regard economic society.

title: Cornell Wins in Japan

title: The Destructive Island of Oil
description: Crude oil, some of it as thick as pudding and polluting 2,850 square miles, has been set loose off the shore of Nantucket by a grounded tanker, and it has a destructive capacity that is essentially Immune to human alteration.

title: Christine Estabrook and Jerry Zaks in Marco Polo, a play for children, which opens today at Marymount Manhattan Theater
Family Trek Across Asia: 3 Months on $20 a Day
description: Every year thousands of young Americans, Australians and Europeans travel the overland route across Asia, and most of them fall into two categories. They are either ascetic spiritualists, seeking enlightenment in India, or gloriously muscular bank clerks, in search of adventure in the Afghan mountains. We fit neither category, Just a family of four returning to the States after a stay in the Orient, with the time and inclination to see a bit of the world along the way.

title: In the U.S., an Erratic Year Ends on an Upbeat Note
description: In what was certainly a gross understatement, one of the nation's top industrialists last week described 1976 as a mixedup year for the American economy. That was an accurate assessment up to a point, but it doesn't delve deeply enough. Economic events and political developments of the last 12 months have made 1976 even more dramatic and traumatic than such a relatively mild characterization suggests. In many ways, the year now ending has been a truly epochal and schizophrenic period.

title: Amtrak and Conrail
description: Conrail is a federally sponsored, private railroad corporation formed from six bankrupt lines in the Northeast and Midwest. It carries 13 percent of the nation's freight and 370,000 commuter passengers daily. Amtrak is a Governmentsupported, quasipublic railroad corporation set up in 1971 to assume the costly burden of intercity passenger service. Trains traveling its routes, encompassing 46 states, carried 18 million passengers last year. There are also 55 private railroads with no Government connection, carrying 87 percent of the nation's freight and a minuscule number of passengers.

So begins this novel, in the manner of a fairy tale; and so it continues, sustained by the author's delight in the Canadian outdoors and uncomplicated characters. Pierre is the son of a white trapper and an Indian woman who disappeared into the Gulf of St. Lawrence one treacherous winter, leaving the boy to fend for himself.

title: Oral nightmares
description: Flying from the griefs of her ruined marriage, her lost child and her mutilated self, the nameless narrator of Mai Zetterling's fourth hook, nouvelle, pours out her lament in a single long drawn out wail. Not one conversation mars the internal monologue of her pain. She has packed a few remnants of her Nordic past into a Volkswagen. fleeing the

title: Jason Zeides Is Fiance Of Lisbeth J. Mackler
description: The engagement of Lisbeth J. Madder to Jason M. Zeides, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Zeldes of Spring Valley, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David C. Mackler of East Norwalk, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: CHESS
description: How do you distinguish between fantasy and reality in the heat of a struggle? Whatever it takes seems to elude the vast majority of players all too often, for everywhere you see decisions made emotionally without regard for the logic of the situation.

title: The New Arab Expressions of Moderation Lend Urgency to Discussion
description: JERUSALEMThe terms for a Middle East peace settlementwhat if any concessions Israel can afford to make to end its prolonged state of hostility with its Arab neighborshave been the subject of debate for years. The discussion has assumed new urgency because the Arabs are expressing (1) a new moderation, and (2) a desire to resume peace talks in Geneva.

title: From the Bowery to Westchester, a Day of Giving and of Receiving
description: Amid the aromas of roast goose and turkey, and the clutter of colorful ribbons and wrappings, people throughout the New York City area marked Christmas yesterday with traditional family gatherings, hearty feasts and the joys of giving and receiving gifts.

title: On the. Proper Education Of the Green Thumb
description: Recent survey's among professionals have pointed out what many homeowners already know: large percentage of house plants bought at greenhouses, florists and garden centers do not survive their first year in the home. This stirs the old brown thumb versus green thumb debate and too often the brown thumb side wins.

title: Julianna E. Roosevelt Engaged To Stephen MacDonell Hargrove
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marion Hargrove of Santa Monica, Calif., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hargrove's daughter, Julianna Edwards Roosevelt, to Mr. Hargrove's son, Stephen MacDonell Hargrove of Berkeley, Calif.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Virgil Scott and Dominic Koski first collaborated on The Kreutzman Formula about two years ago. It was a rather conventional espionage book, but it was well written and also had authenticsounding details that suggested the authors were drawing upon their own professional experience. That kind of authentic background is also found in their new book, WALKIN (Simon and Schuster, S7.95).

title: What's Doing in PUERTO RICO
description: INAUGURATIONAt 10 A.M. on Jan. 2 on the steps of the Capitol overlooking the Atlantic Ocean in San Juan, Carlos Romero Barcelo, now Mayor of that city, will be sworn in as the sixth Governor of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. His New Progressive Party, which favors statehood, won an upset victory last month including control of both houses of the Legislature. Mr. Romero Barcelo promised that he would not push for statehood during his first term, but if he wins reelection in 1980, he is expected to call for a referendum on statehood.

title: E.C.A.C. Tourney Begins Tomorrow
description: The opening round of the 25th annual Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival will get under way tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, with the basketball tournament's cofavorites watching the action from the stands.

title: Bladderball Bursts For 14 Y ale Students
description: NEW HAVEN (AP)Fourteen Yale University students have been disciplined for taking part in pranks on the day of last month's bladderball game.

title: Curtis Oberlander, an Executive Of Harry Winston Inc., Dies at 77
description: Curtis Oberlander, a vice president of Harry Winston Inc., the jewelry concern at 718 Fifth Avenue, died Friday night of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived at 955 Fifth Avenue.

title: Hardy Birds Brighten Winter
description: WHILL New Jersey's ski  slopes and skating ponds beckon outdoor sports lovers, . others  the very young, the old, the sufferers from a bug' and those people who just plain hate cold weathercan enjoy a popular indoor sport: backyard birding. It's true, of course, that some contact with the outdoors is necessary to stock the feeding station with seeds, suet and fruit. But once that's done, the family can rather at the windows of a warm room to watch the antics of the birds.

title: A Quick Look Backward
description: WALL STREETAfter an explosive first quarter, stock prices stagnated. In April, a leadership crisis developed as James J. Needham was forced out as chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. Negotiated commission rates slashed profits and caused a wave of mergers.

title: School Holidays And Why They Aren't
description: OUR New Jersey local school calendar is a device ingeniously designed to foster loneliness, discourage patriotism, divide families and provoke enormous historical confusion.

title: Vanessa With Two Heads
description: Red Smith

title: New YorkArea Pricing
description: Michael Roth, chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority, said that under the law in effect now the minimum price at which liquor could be sold was set by the wholesaler, and to which there was added a 12 percent markup for the retailer.

title: LibyaBulgaria Pact Signed
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)Libya and Bulgaria today signed five agreements on trade, economic, scientific and political cooperation at the end of a fourday visit by Todor ZhIvkov, the Communist leader. The Libyan radio reported.

title: Dutch Queen Offers Grim View of World
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 25 (UPI) Queen Juliana of the Netherlands presented a pessimistic view of the world in her annual broadcast to the nation today, describing mankind as 4 billion egoists.

title: Up From Nigger
description: Over the last 15 years, as he has shuttled between the two worlds of nightclub comedy and social protest. Dick Gregory has put together an often exhilarating, sometimes exemplary, occasionally baffling, and almost always hectic public performance. He told part of the story in Nigger, where he sketched his climb to stardom from a St. Louis ghetto and his active duty in the civil rights battles of the early 1960's. Now, in this slight and selfadmiring memoir, he brings us up to date,, devoting himself mostly to a desultory mix of public events and encounters, from J.F.K.'s assassination, which he was convinced was a Government conspiracy, to meeting Haile Selassie, who he decided was chump. So much of the book consists of his comedy routines, speeches, telegrams, press statements, political programs, and pages of praises received and sedulously reftoduced that it resembles a scrapbook more than an autobiography.

title: Massacre at Mountain Meadows
description: Seventy years ago, in his presidential address to the members of the American Historical Association, the noted scholar J. Franklin Jameson pointed out that religious history often taught more than just the history of religions. The early story of Mormonism, he suggested, provided a prime source of illumination upon the actual mentality of the obscure villagers who converted to the new religion.

title: ECONOMIC BULLETIN ISSUED ON NEW YORK
description: The first issue of a quarterly bulletin on New York City economic trends was Published yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

title: PEOPLE
description: THE Dalton High School's loss is Woodmere Academy's gain. Come next July, Peter M. Branch, who has spent the last four years as director of the Dalton High School in Manhattan, will become Woodmere's headmaster. The 33yearold Mr. Branch, who lives now in Dobbs Ferry, will be moving into a house a mile from the academy with his wife, Susan, his son, 5, his daughter. 3, and  if all goes according to schedule another Branch of the family tree, too.

title: A New Beginning: The Economy
description: The task facing the Carter Administration on the economic front is as complex as it is critical to this nation and to the world economy.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Bye, bye, Bicentennial.

title: CHICAGO FIRE TRACED TO COOKING MISHAP

title: Paperbacks

title: Texas Legislator Seeking To Reduce the Incentives For Operating Speed Trap
description: AUSTIN, Ter., Dec. 25 (UPI)A state legislator will try next year for the third time to put some restraints on patrolmen in a south Texas community known to CB radio users as the valley of the bears.

title: When Bars Close, Night Is Young At Illegitimate but Abundant Clubs
description: At 4 A.M., when New York Citys legitimate bars have given the last call for drinks and the few remaining customers are getting ready to shuffle home, hundreds of unlicensed clubs in Hispanic areas are in full swing, selling liquor until the sun comes up and, in some cases, going around the clock.

title: Deaths
G. R. Parkins to Wed Jamie W. Bergford
description: Mr, and Mrs. James Walker Bergford of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jamie Walker Bergford, to Geoffrey Richard Parkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril James Parkins of Katonah, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September.

title: John Opalacz to Wed Linda Susan Durhan
description: Linda Susan Durban and John Paul Opalacz, who are in their fourth year at the St. Louis University School of Medicine, plan to be married in May, when they expect to receive their medical degrees.

title: ARAFAT SAID TO GET SYRIAN ASSURANCES
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, Dec. 25In a switch of policy, Syria has assured Yasir Arafat and other leaders of Al Fatah, the major Palestinian guerrilla group, that it has no intention of ousting them from the leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Ford Receives Something Special for Christmas Snow on the Ski Slopes
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec 25This was not very good yea rfor Gerald R. Ford, but there was fresh powder on the slopes of Vail today, and the President was looking forward, not backward, as he celebrated Christmas with his family and on the ski slopes.

title: Miss Schultz To Be Bride
description: Miss Schultz To Be Bride

title: Angst in the Ibid and the Odyssey:
description: HONOLULUIn these fading moments of our crowded 1976, it is well to remind ourselves of one anniversary that has almost eluded us: the 75th year of The Tale of Peter Rabbit.

title: Music: A Christmas Concert
description: The night before Christmas, Carnegie Hall is invariably astir, and Santa Claus is always Alexander Schneider. As in seven seasons past, Mr. Schneider and his New York String Orchestra celebrated by treating large audience to a midnight concert.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bird'sEye View Bags Buck New Guidelines Aimed
description: EAGLE PASS, Tex.Seeming to writhe through the dense mist rising from the water before us, the skeletons of drowned, stunted oaks were the first objects to materialize as the day grew brighter.

title: Reflections on Suffolk History
description: ABOUT 10,000 years ago the first human beings came to the land we call Suffolk. They were nomadic hunters who followed the caribou herds to this area. The land then had many similarities to our own terrain. Our hills existed then. Where we have flat areas, it was flat then. But the vegetation was that of a tundra and the weather was colderthe edge of the receding continental glacier was just a few hundred miles to the north.

title: NEW YORK'S COUNCIL ACTS ON DISTRICTING
description: After a twomonth search for candi dates for an independent, nonpartisan commission to redistrict councilmanic lines for the next election, the New York City Council is expected to give final approval to a nineman committee no later than their next regular meeting, on Jan. 5.

title: Ends and Means
description: Does the end justify the means, or are there means that are unjustifiable no matter how important, and good an objective may be? This philosophic question as old as man, but it arises constantly in new situations. Two developments concerning Africa these past few days illustrate its poignancy.

title: Soviet Six's Latest Victory a HardFought One
description: MOSCOWIn a game as rugged and nasty as any contest one might see in the National Hockey League, the Soviet Union's national team defeated the national team from Czechoslovakia last week, 32, ending the Izvestia Cup tournament with yet another victory for the powerful hosts.

title: Murphy: A David and the N.B.A. Goliaths
description: A young man named Calvin Murphy has gained quite a bit of notoriety lately with his fistic exploits. The most often heard question is, How does he do it?

title: A Thinking Man's Blue Collar Journal
description: In February 1973, John R. Coleman, a 51yearold labor economist, president of Haverford College and chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, took off on a twomonth searoh to find out what it was like in the world where people worked with their hands instead of their mouths. He was variously ditchdigger in Atlanta, Ga., a sandwichandsaladman in Boston, Mass., and a garbage collector in a Washington, D.C., suburb. He also kept a diary, which was published in 1974 as Blue Collar Journal: A College President's Salibatical. According to Blue Collar Journal, a sincere if somewhat pious account, manual labor is good for the soul.

title: Voyage
description: These were strange times indeed, thinks Banning Butler Blanchard, master shipbuilder from Maine, as he contcmpla tes the 1896 Democratic convention in Chicago, where bimetallic brouhaha is breaking loose with Altgeld, Bryan. Debs and the Populists. He would be even more bewildered he knew what was happening aboard h:s newest ship, Neptune's Car, steel fourmasted barque now floundering off Cape Horn with 5.000 tons of coal (some of it afire) hound for San Francisco: sadism, nearmutiny,

title: Shortages of Money and Teachers Impair Egypt's Literacy Campaign
description: CAIRO, Dec. 25 My darling whom I love, the scribe writes on behalf of any of Egypt's illiterate majority who is separated from a loved one and seeks his help.

title: MOZAMBIQUE SYSTEM OF LAW CAPRICIOUS
description: MAPUTO, MozambiqueIn the police headquarters here, criminal cases are pre1 pared by a twofinger typist. A young man in tight jeans and a clinging sports shirt, he works his way laboriously through the cases, finishing perhaps three or four a day. On a recent afternoon, he had scores that he had not yet tackled.

title: To Silence the Aerial Din
description: NOISE: an unwanted discordant sound disturbing to the car. According to the Department of Transportation, seven million Americans are subjected to noise caused by jet aircraft, every day. The threequarters of a million residents around Kennedy International Airport are jarred out of their normal routines as frequently as every 90 seconds, for hours on end, seven days a week, night and day.

title: A Very Young Dancer
description: There are two reasonsor if one is counting scrupulously, perhaps threefor the initial prospect of Jill Krementz's book A Very Young Dancer to me with misgivings. First, following an overdose of seasonal exposure to The New York City Ballet's The Nutcracker has left me perceptibly cool anything to do with that ballet. A Very Young Dancer is about a girl dancing Mary in The Nutcracker. Second, I am antipathetic to dance books children. This is merely a blind prejudice, Finally, I am not all that keen ballet students.

description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Dec. 25 (AP) The Coast Guard, weary from 11 days of fighting winds and seas around the wrecked Argo Merchant, will monitor the tanker's oil spill until it disperses somewhere in the Atlantic.

title: With Carter, Public Jobs Have New Importance
description: Through most of the recent recession, bills designed combat unemployment by creating emergency jobs bounced between Capitol Hill and the White House. The Democratic Congress would pass multibilliondollar measures calling for expanded programs of public service employment and public works; President Ford would veto them on fiscal and philosophic grounds, and ultimately scaleddown versions would become law.

title: The 56th at 91
description: Now 91, Frank Swinnerton has written 56 novels, slices of English life steeped in seething passions, romantic contretemps, a whole range of the baser human impulses, that somehow never really betrayor transcendthe essential gentility of the author himself. This latest novel gives us Florence Marvell, a middleaged spinster spinning out her days in the

title: Edison Uno, 47, Who Led Drive To Repeal Internment Camp Act
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (UPI) Edison Uno, 47 years old, who led the drive to repeal an Internal Security Act section that authorized retention camps, died of a stroke yesterday at the University of California Hospital.

title: BILL SKIFF DIES AT 81; EXSCOUT FOR YANKS
description: Bill Skiff, a lonkthne New York Yankee scout who spent 55 years in organized baseball, died yesterday morning. He was 81 years old.

description: DES MOINES, IowaWithin the next eighteen months this prosperous and comfortably busy capital of Iowa will be forced to close at least six of its 50 elementary schools and three of its 12 junior highs.

description: This is the story of a house, a small brownstone rowhouse off Central Park West at 69 West 83d Street. It is also the story of the neighborhood around the house, and for that matter of the city around the neighborhood.

title: Beverly Sills In First Lucia At Met Opera
description: Repertory opera companies like the Metropolitan have a problem when Christmas Eve rolls aroundthere just are not many operas that might be considered appropriate to the season. In the past the Met has had to settle for such unlikely Yuletide offerings as Fedora, Tannhauser, La Gioconda and, of all things, Halevy's La Juive, which marked Enrico Caruso's 607th and last performance with the company on Dec. 24, 1920.

description: Amy Ellen Jaroslow, candidate for a master's degree at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeohs, and Richard Gallagher, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Temple University, plan to be married in August.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HAT'S old to yours is new to mine, a friend once said as we exchanged a parcel of clothes from our children. And now four enterprising young women have established a business based on that premise. The shop, Money In Your Pocket, at 570B Peninsula Boulevard In Cedarhurst, specializes in children's outgrown quality clothing, from infant size to early teens, offered at a small fraction of their original retail price.

title: The Goalie's in First Grade

There is nothing like ittake away anything but not my hockey, says the 17yearold Syosset athlete. Threatened with losing hockey privileges two years ago, he improved his school grades to a average in one term and has kept it there since.

description: Baseball cards were the dog tags of our early youth  you were what you carried in your hip pocket. With my Johnny Mize (Bats LeftThrows Right .349) I was the equal of any boy on Wallace Street, and if Bobby Osternueller seriously thought he could equate his Bruce Edwards (BRTR .267) with my Walker Cooper (BRTR .305) then that just showed what a creep he really was. later learned humility when we moved to Washington and I had to carry the burden of Gil Torres (BRTR .237) and Sherry Robertson (BLTR .200), but that's another

title: Letter from London:
description: LONDON.

title: Never Mind the P'sIt's Those Queues
description: IN photographs from World War II, the women queue up, stoic, unsmiling, patiently resigned, the wicker basket under the arm, the kerchief around the head, waiting, waiting, in the English city or the French town, in the Italian or Russian or German village. The piece of rationed meat bought, they hurry to the next queue, the figures shapeless under the bulky sweaters and worn coats, gathering a meal, waiting and watching the endless days for it to end. The queue became a visible symbol of endurance and stubborn courage.

title: Jeanne Johnson Fiancee of Robert Thompson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Ford Moreland of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of Mrs. Moreland's daughte, Jeanne Susan Johnson, to Robert Reade Thompson of Washington, Congressional liaison officer with the Environmental Protection Agency. He is son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Edward Thompson of Wallingford and Madison, Conn.

title: Death Penalty: One Man's View
description: DEBATING the restoration of the death penalty in our state seems such a minute undertaking in proportion to dealing with crime on the streets. It is easy to stateand I prefer to take the easy waythat capital punishment is a form of legal murder that will do little to ease the No. 1 problem in our country: crime and how to deal with the criminal.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Any film year is more than simply the best films of the year. It's also people, events, trends, affirmations of old truths, exceptions to rules. Now, boys, he said, lifting his head higher from the water, you've done a good job. Everyone at the dinner had heard of Herrera and his super football statistics at Southern Illinois University this season, but what really grabbed the audience was one of Andre's opening lines: Hey, I'm just like one of you guys.

description: CALABOZO, Venezuela  Ravenous field rats are consuming as much of this year's Venezuelan rice crop as will reach the tables of consumers, according to farmers here.

title: Youth Killed in Auto Accident
description: RAMAPO, N.Y., Dec. 25 (UPI)  One youth was killed and three were injured early today in a onecar, Accident in Monsey the police here reported. They said Roy Hansen, 19 years old, of Chestnut Street, Greenwood Lake, N.Y., was killed when the car he was driving hit a utility pole along Saddle River Road. Two passengers in the car, oJhn Hendrickson, 20, and Gerald Lyons, 18, were reported in critical condition at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern. A fourth passenger, Raymond Osborne, 19, was treated and released from the hospital.

title: Rent Default by Welfare Tenants Called Factor in Suspicious Fires
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt asserted yesterday that nonpayment of rent by welfare tenants might be an increasingly significant factor in suspicious fires in New York City. He proposed a special commission of members from state and city government, the housing industry and other groups to investigate.

title: Why nothing works the way it's supposed to
description: A colleague of the author (let us call him Jones), considered himself fortunate to be employed as research associate at a small state home for retarded children. In this humble, even despised, position he was too low on the Civil Service scale to merit the attention of administrators, and he was therefore left alone to tinker with ideas in his chosen field. He was happily pursuing his own research interest when, following Presidential interest and national publicity, mental retardation suddenly became a fashionable subject. Jones received an urgent invitation to join an ambitious Federally funded project for a systematic attack upon the problem of mental retardation.

He doesn't know how to go about making the one that he thinks the British economy could use today, so, like number of other British businessmen, especially young unfettered ones, Mr. Cross wants out.

CASO, the Nassau County Executive, appears to have resigned himself to the inevitability of oil drilling off the Island while simultaneously continuing involvement in a lawsuit to block such plans and to nullify a $1.1 billion sale of drilling rights from the Island to Virginia.
