But a small number of skilled artisans, some of whom brought their techniques from Europe, have in the last two decades been teaching others. Today their stu dents, now themselves professionals, are experimenting in increasing numbers with that demanding, jewellike craft.

title: Electric Rate Reduction Ordered by the P.S.C. Is Invalidated by Court
description: A temporary oneyear reduction in electric rates for 45,000 customers who use electricity to heat their homes was invalidated yesterday by New York State's highest court. As a result, these customers may have to pay higher rates in a subsequent year and other electricity users, who had been assessed slightly more for the year, may be charged less.

title: How to Byu a Pennant, Maybe
description: Sportswriters and sportscasters blessed with more sensi tive antennae than some of the rest of us have been assuring us for years that the fans are fed up with the financial demands of greedy athletes and the public is sick and tired of complaints from spoiled brats crying for their freedom. Since the authorities who give us this information never reveal their sources, it has not been clear how they could be so sure about public attitudes. Now, for the first time, comes a more or less reliable sampling of opinion na tionwide. A Harris poll has ascertained that a substantial majority of baseball fans approve the players newly won right to work out their contractual obligations and then sell their services on a fairly open market. The margin was 54 percent in favor of the free agents, 32 percent opposed and 14 per cent undecided. Thus even if all the fencestraddlers were to fall off on the side of the opposition, freedom would still get a fatter slice of the popular vote than Jimmy Carter did.

title: Philip Iselin Dead at 74
description: Philip Iselin, president of the New York Jets and Monmouth Park race track, died yesterday at the age of 74. Obituary on Page 28.

title: Alex Rose of Liberal Party, A Power in Politics, Is Dead
description: Alex Rose, leader of a tiny millinery union, who built the Liberal Party into a significant and oftendecisive force in New York City, State and national politics, died yesterday at his home in Washington Heights. The 78yearold confidant of Presidents, governors and mayors had been ill for nearly a year, first with septicemia, a blood infection, and in recent weeks with vim] bronchitis, but cancer was the cause of death.

title: Spreading the Word Via Magazine Ads
description: Do you want to meet a man with a tremendous faith in the power of advertising? Then meet the Rev. Joseph F. Lupo, just Father Joe to his friends and contributors.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ONE AND ONLY Pablo Casals would have been 100 years old today. A centenary tribute to the great cellist and, conductor takes place tonight at Carnegie Hall. Participating are three of the musician's closest friends and colleagues, Isaac Stern, Eugene Istomin and Alexander Schneider; the 60member New York String Orchestra, ranging in age from 15 to 22 and three young soloists, the pianist Yefim Bronfman, the violinist Shlomo Mintz and the cellist YoYo Ma.

title: 86th St. Group and Mental Agency Fail on an Accord
description: Efforts to draft a moratorium agreetrient between Bridge Inc. and the Committee to Preserve West 86th Street broke, down yesterday amid charges of doubleCross made by the neighborhood group and of bad faith by the mentalhealth agency.

title: President Giscard's Middle East Bet
description: PARISFrench President Giscard d'Estaing is convinced that 1977 must be the year in which peace is at last established in the Middle East; that there can be no advantage to any party in postponing a settlement until later; and that, apart from the nations directly involved in the ArabIsraeli cuspate, the entire world would benefit.

title: Current Strike At City Ballet Perils Season
description: Sources on both sides felt last night that the walkout by the 62 members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians might lead to a cancelation of the remaining eight weeks of the New York City Ballet's season. The musicians strike that shut down the company went through its 16th day yesterday with no settlement in sight.

title: TV: Julie Harris Tour de Force
description: The Belle of Amherst offers Julie Harris in a onewoman show, a celebration of Emily Dickinson. William Luce culled this ingenious theatrical portrait from the writer's notes, letters and poetry. Successful on Broadway and on tour across the country, the play has now been produced for television, before an audience in a studio of Los Angeles station KCET. and can be seen on public television tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Mediators to Seek to Settle Newark Sanitation Strike
description: NEWARK, Dec. 28Because of the health threat posed by growing piles of uncollected garbage, state mediators said today they would attempt to settle a twoday old strike by city sanitation workers.

title: Politics, Budgets and Public Relations at City U.
description: Politics is no stranger to the groves of academe, and on the 19 campuses of the City University the atmosphere these days is increasingly political.

title: New York Thruway Employees Vote Against Staging a Walkout
description: Employees of the New York Thruway Authority have voted 526 to 516, against striking next Saturday for an improved contract.

title: CARTER GIVES PLEDGE TO BEAME AND CAREY TO BAR BANKRUPTCY
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 28Presidentelect Carter pledged to Mayor Beame and Governor Carey today to work to keep New York City out of bankruptcy, to assure that all its borrowing needs were met in the future and to review systematically the actions he could take by himself to help the city overcome its budget deficit next year.

title: Today's Events
description: 10 A.M.5 P.M.: Bicentennial exhibitsWar Memorial Visitors Center, New Jersey State Museum, State Library Archives Room and State House Rotunda. Minary encampments, Washington Crossing State Park.

title: About Education
description: It is not widely known that the source of the largest amount of Federal aid for the nation's college students is not the Office of Education, but the Veterans Administration.

title: Associated Press
description: ICY RESCUE: As Robert Golden sat in his living room Monday in Mount Clemens, Mich., near Detroit, he heard cries for help coming from Metropolitan Beach. Glenn J. Adamek, 16, had plunged through the ice there in a snowmobile. At left, Mr. Golden is seen sliding an aluminum boat to Glenn, who is wearing a helmet. Having grasped the boat, the young man was pulled to

title: Suffern Family Gives Some Savings For Christmas to the Neediest Cases
description: The Christmas shopping had been done and the Gilbert W, Hales family of Suffern, N.Y., was sitting down to dinner when someone brought up the 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 20 in New Orleans Are Indicted by U.S. In Dock Union Fraud
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28Two dentists and a physician were among 20 persons indicted by a Federal grand jury here today for allegedly taking part in a conspiracy to embezzle more than $1 million from a waterfront union welfare fund through false medical claims.

title: Ford Reiterates Plan For Study of Amnesty
description: VAIL, Colo.Dec. 28President Ford reiterated today that he intended to examine the possibility of a general amnesty for all Vietnam war deserters and draft resisters and said that he had already started the process.

title: Business Records
description: ERNEST A. MAURER, Jr. Martin's Trailer Park, Lot 19, Coxsackie, N. Y.Liabilities, $18,778.28; assets $7,030 JOSEPHINE A. MAURER Martin's Trailer Park, Lot 19, Coxsackie, N. Y.Liabilities, $14,320.60; assets, $4,730.00 KENNETH LAITMAN, a/k/a KENNETH JAY LAITMAN, Chimney Ridge Drive, Nanuet, N, Y.Liabilities, 579, 201.36; assets, $550.00

title: A New Beginning: Foreign Policy
description: Jimmy Carter will inherit a world situation not free of crisis but one that is not likely to demand immediate agonizing decisionsno burgeoning Vietnam war, no ongoing Bay of Pigs invasion scheme, no Berlin blockade. Intractable problems fester on several continents and some will demand action by the United States; but with luck, Mr. Carter will have time to play himself gradually into his selfappointed role as the spokesman for the nation in the area of foreign affairs.

title: Hospital Supply Paid Saudi Fees; Flying Tiger Impropriety Charged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the American Hospital Supply Corporation submitted to Saudi Arabian demands that it pay millions of dollars in questionable fees for contracts to equip the ultramodern King Faisal Specialist Hospital in Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

title: American Jewish Leaders Are Split Over Issue of Meeting With P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A bitter dispute has broken out among the leaders of American Jewish organizations over whether American Jews should have any contact with representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization, given the Israeli Government's refusal to deal with that group.

title: Bridge:
description: The World Bridge Federation regards the Far East and Australasia as separate zones, each entitled to send a team to compete in the Bermuda Bowl for the world team title. Nevertheless Australia and New Zealand; eager for international competition, compete in the Far East Championship and serve in turn as host to the tournament, slightly stretching the realities of geography.

title: LENDERS STAY WARY ABOUT NEVI YORK CITY
description: LENDERS STAY WARY ABOUT NEVI YORK CITY raised a number of objections to going along with the notepayment plan. One of their key demands was that they wanted an accord placed in the context of certain guarantees of assistance from the state and the Federal Government.

title: Safeguards Written into Gas Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29To make Mr. Ford's proposal more politically palatable to Congress, the Federal Energy Administration plans to write in three safeguardtype provisions, officials said.

title: Tanner and Stockton Reach Quarterfinals
description: SYDNEY. Australia, Dec. 29 (UPI)Three Americans, including Hank Pfister of California, reached the quarterfinals of the $100,000 New South Wales grass tennis championships today.

title: A Mostel Mazeltovr! for Fiddler
description: On opening night at Fiddler on the Roof Tuesday, there was no mistaking the billing: It was Zero Mostel above and beyond the title. The evening was, first of all, a celebration for the actor. And when the curtain fell, it was Mostel, solo, who received a standing ovation.

title: Ford Likely to Request Gasoline Price Decontrol
description: VAIL, Colo. Dec. 29President Ford said today it was highly likely that he would recommend the elimination of price controls on gasoline when he returns to Washington next week.

title: CHARGE IS REDUCED FOR BLACK MARINE
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP)  The first of several black marines charged in a commandostyle attack on white marines they allegedly thought were Ku Klux Klan members pleaded guilty today to rduced charges of assault.

title: A Program for Men Facing the Traumas Of Marriage's End
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 28The breakup of marriage is often depicted as a traumatic experience for the wife and as a release for the husband, who supposedly longs for the freedom of his bachelor days.

title: Carter's Pledge to New  York Leaves Banks and Union Heads Still Wary
description: Labor leaders and bankers said yesterday that they were pleased with Presidentelect Carter's new assurances about New York City, but that many additional questions had to be answered before they could agree to a plan to redeem nearly $1 billion in city shortterm notes.

title: ARTHUR G. REICHERT
description: Arthur G. Reichert of 32 Harriet Lane, Huntington, L. I., who retired in 1974 as a partner in Quigley & Reichert, a real estate and general insurance firm in Northport, died yesterday morning in Huntington Hospital after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Writs Filed for 3d CarterArtis Trial
description: PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29Motions for a third trial for Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Arts were filed today at the Passaic County Courthouse here.

title: JERSEY WINS ITS SUIT ON ROAD BIDRIGGING
description: TRENTON, DEC. 29The state today settled out of court a $61.7 million, antitrust suit it had brought against 15, individuals, including Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel, and 12 companies accused of conspiring to rig highway bids in New Jersey from 1957 to 1970.

title: Van Damme, Belgian Track Star,  Dies   After Car Crash in France
description: ORANGE, France, Dec. 29 (AP)  Ivo Van Darnme of Belgium, winner of two silver medals in track at the recent Olympics, was fatally injured today in a car crash while traveling from the Riviera to Paris.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCCOW, Dec. 29 (AP)The Soviet President, Nikolai V. Podgorny, is expected to visit Zambia, Mozambique and Tanzania in March, apparently in an attempt by Moscow to play a bigger role in southern Africa. The visit, reported by African diplomatic sources here, has not been offiically announced in the Soviet Union.

title: Dance: A Treat
description: About 150 young women are likely to dance the Sugarplum Fairy in various productions of The Nutcracker this season, but one must count Martine van Hamel's as a special treat. She appeared with Adam Luders as her cavalier in the Eglevsky Ballet's production Tuesday evening at the Nassau Coliseum. The arena is scarcely the ideal setting for the ballet, but judicious curtains and lighting framed the production warmly, and the company did the rest.

title: Carter Jobs Filled But Only for a Day
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  The Carter camp found itself in a minor todo tonight over what various spokesmen sought to treat as a premature and possibly, though not necessarily, inaccurate disclosure of several major White House staff appointments by a senior transition aide.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: 1976 Giant Coaching Staff Bil Arnsparger, head coach.

title: Vatican Programs in Chinese
description: ROME, Dec. 28 (UPI)The Vatican Radio has said it will start daily programs in Chinese Jan. 1. The Vatican Radio broadcasts in 32 languages. The number of programs in Chinese has increased from two a week a few years ago to five a week this year.

title: Atlantic City Convention Bookings Blossom After the Vote on Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITYThe adoption of the casino gambling referendum on Nov. 2 has stimulated the best two months of convention bookings in the history of the 68yearold Atlantic City Convention Bureau.

title: W.H.A. Stars Are Hopeful Of Testing Skills in N.H.L.
description: In naming its allstar teams for the annual contest Jan. 18 in Hartford, the World Hockey Association in a sense has pinpointed the players whom the league was most likely to lose if a merger with the National Hockey League did not materialize in the near future. Anders Hedberg, the Swedish right wing, who was the only unanimous choice in the balloting, has vowed that some time in his career he would match his skills against those of the N.H.L.'s top players.

title: Perfect Walnut Tree Is Among 18 Sold for $80,000
description: PIONEER, Ohio  Roger Herrett, a state forest service officer in the northwestern part of Ohio for some 17 years, is not one who gets easily excited over a new tree story. He thought he had heard them all.

title: Sonics Late Surge eats Nets, 10296
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., bee. 29Fred Brown, who looks sleepy, and Slick Watts, who looks innocent, stole a game for the Seattle Super Sonics against the Nets last night at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Andrew Besch Weds Jenny C. Maybruck
description: Jenny Charnay Maybruck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Maybruck of New York, was married in Stamford, Conn., yesterday to Andrew Francis Besch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Besch of Bedford Hills, N. Y. Rabbi Philip Schecter performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger. Their daughter, CathySulzberger, was matron of honor. Jeff Lieberman was best man.

title: WALTER YOUNG
description: Walter Young, a painter and art teacher, died Saturday at his Lake Katonah home in Golden's Bridge, N.Y., after sufferine a stroke. He was 70 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A state appeals court ruled in Trenton yesterday that teacher federations had a right to inspect public records kept by boards of education.

title: Music: Homage to Pablo Casals
description: Alexander Schneider and his New York String Orchestra paid homage last night to Pablo Casals, who was born Dec. 29 a century ago, and whose postWorld War II career in Prades and Puerto Rico was intimately linked with that of Mr. Schneider.

title: United Press International
description: United Press International

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attdrney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County announced that a $21,000 grant from the State Division of Criminal Justice Services would enable him to keep for another month eight assistant district attorneys he had planned to dismiss this week because of a cut in his 1977 budget.

title: Providence Upsets Michigan In Double Overtime, 8281
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 19Loyalists, who follow Providence College's basketball teams, have enjoyed a lot of euphoric moments, but none so delirious as the one that occurred here tonight in the final of the Industrial National Classic.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29New Yorkers who, as guests of Miami Beach hotels affected by a strike of employees, are receiving fewer services are entitled to a compensation from these hotels, Louis J. Lefkowitz, the New York Attorney General, said today.

title: Suspect Is Charged With Kidnapping In Rape of Girl, 14
description: A 32yearold convicted felon was being held yesterday following his indictment on charges that he had abducted a 14yearold Long Island girl, raped and otherwise sexually abused her in a midtown hotel over a period of three days, and had then attemped to turn her into a prostitute.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONWin Frank G. Zarb punt? With only two weeks and three days to the Jan. 15 effective date of his resignation, Mr. Zarb has the oil industry and his own staff wondering whether he will follow through on a major regulatory idea he floated or whether he will play it safe and turn the ball over to the Carter administration.

title: Manhattan and Purdue Reach Final of Festival
description: Darryl Eady, Dino Larry and 32 free throws put Manhattan College into the final round of the Holiday Festival basketball tournament last night before a disappointing Madison Square Garden crowd of 7,102.

title: Perpich Sworn in as Governor of Minnesota
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 29 (AP) Rudolph George Perpich became Governor of Minnesota today when Gov. Wendell R. Anderson stepped down to take the Senate seat being vacated by Vice Presidentelect Walter F. Mondale.

title: POUND UP HALFCENT IN LONDON TRADING
description: LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP)The pound gained more than a half cent to $1.7065 on the London foreign exchange market yesterday, reaching its highest level since late September.

title: Ruins Show Urban Rival to Mesopotamia
description: The discovery of a major urban civilization that rose in northern Syria 4,400 years ago and rivaled its only contemporaries, Mesopotamia and Egypt, is being acclaimed as one of the most significant archeological advances of the century.

title: Sports Today
description: E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7 P.M.

title: DEPUTY CHANCELLOR CRITICIZED BY GOLDIN
description: In a stinging fourpage letter, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday accused the deputy schools chancellor, Bernard R. Gifford, of dishonesty, demagoguery and bad faith for his questioning of the accuracy of the Comptroller's figures for layoffs at the Board of Education.

title: North Shore Acres:
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I.All last week, while many students at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn were planning trips to beach and ski resorts for their Christmas holiday, Nancy Manzlone simply wanted to go home.

title: ANTIWAR ACTIVISTS CITE HANOI REBUFF
description: A group of American antiwar activists said yesterday that they had been rebuffed by Vietnamese authorities after months of efforts to persuade Hanoi to release political prisoners and to accept an impartial inquiry into charges of violations of human rights.

title: Kissinger's Phone Transcripts Moved From Rockefeller Estate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  The State Department said today that Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger had stored the transcripts of his telephone conversations while in office at the private New York estate of Vice President Rockefeller.

title: NeighborhoodSaving
description: BOSTONTom Kelly has been believer in ColumbiaSavin Hill, neighborhood in Boston's Dorchester section. But now he says his faith is shaky. After sinking $17,000 into improvements in his threefamily house over the last two years, he is having second thoughts about his investment.

title: March Cocoa Futures Climb on News of Drop in Purchases From Ghana
description: Cocoa futures prices moved up yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, Wirth the March delivery closing at $1.39 65/100 up from $1.38 55/100.

title: Sharon Halsey Wed to George R Stiteler
description: Sharon Louise Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheffield J. Halsey of Ossining, N. Y., and Sea Island, Ga., was married yesterday evening to George Robert Stiteler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. N. Stiteier of Broomall, Pa.

title: Maple Leafs 6, Barons 2
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (AP)Darryl Sittler rammed in two goals and a defenseman, Borje Salming, got a goal and three assists as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Cleveland Barons, 62, in an N.H.L. game tonight.

title: SENTENCES REDUCED FOR KOREA DISSIDENTS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 29The South Korean Court of Appeals ruled today that a former opposition presidential candidate had properly been convict, ed of antiGovernment activities for demanding the resignation of President Park Chung Hee, but it reduced the dependant's sentence from eight years to five.

title: ImportedCommodity Supply Mostly Stable, Study Finds
description: An independent study of the international supply situation in seven critical commodities, for which the United States depends heavily on foreign sources, finds optimistically that the likelihood of damage from supply interruptions in all but onechromiteis small.

title: American Jewish Leaders Are Split Over Issue of Meeting With P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A bitter dispute has broken out among the leaders of American Jewish organizations over whether American Jews should have any contact with representatives of the Palestine Liberation Organization, given the israeli Government's refusal to deal with that group.

title: Solomon Zeitlin, Long a Professor Of History and Rabbinics, Dies
description: Solomon Zeitlin, a scholar who found himself uncomfortable in majorities and immovable as a party of one, died in Philadelphia Tuesday of heart failure. He was 84 by his count, 88 or 91 by the count of Dropsie University, where he taught.

title: Suit Against Panovs Is Dismissed
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a twoyearold suit for breach of contract against Valery and Galina Panov by their first American manager, and also denied their countersuit for punitive damages.

title: Some Regret Change in may Area's North Beach
description: SAN FRANCISCOJoseph Malandra stood on the corner of Vallejo Street and pointed up Grant Street to the big neon signs dominating the busy avenue of small shops. That's what I object to, neon signs with block lettering that are completely out of Talk character with the OldWorld feeling of this neighborhood, said Mr. Malandra, a young lawyer with offices above a nearby saloon.

title: Parking Rules Eased
description: Alternate side of the street parking regulations will continue to be suspended today because of the snow, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff announced. All other parking and standing regulations remain in effect.

title: Penguins Tie Canadiens On Goal by chock, 33
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP)Ron Schock's sixth goal of the season, scored from the edge of the crease early in the final period, gave the Pittsburgh Penguins a 33 tie with the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: COMPOSITE INDEXES INDICATE ECONOMY IS EXPANDING AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Government's composite indexes of leading indicators and coincident indicators of the economy both rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, giving a further signal that the summer and early autumn pause in the economy has given way to renewed expansion.

title: DEMOCRATS IN BROOKLYN GIVE BACKING TO GOLDEN
description: The Brooklyn Democratic organization has endorsed former City Councilman Howard Golden for Brooklyn Borbugh President to succeed Sebastian Leone, who resigned to become a State Supreme Court. Justice.

title: Advertising
FED COMPLETES BAN ON BIAS IN LENDING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)  Final regulations were issued today by the Federal Reserve Board banning credit discrimination for reasons of race, color, religion and age, and including the right for people to know why they were denied credit.

title: Dominick J. DeLucco, 81; Hartford ExMayor Tried To Listen to Everyone
description: HARTFORD, Dec. 29Dominick J. DeLucco, who rose from newspaper boy and dumpcart driver to election as the first ItalianAmerican Mayor of Hartford, died yesterday at the State Veterans Home and Hospital in Rocky Hill, where he had lived for eight months. He was 81 years old.

title: REV. FRANCIS X. DESMOND
description: The Rev. Francis X. Desmond, former rector of Our Lady of Angels Seminary, which is part of Niagara University, Niagara, N.Y., and Mount St. Mary's Seminary, Emmitsburg, Md., died Monday in Jordan Hospital, Plymouth, Mass., after suffering a stroke Christmas Eve. His age was 75.

title: Office Pool, 1977
description: WASHINGTONThe Fourth Annual Office Pool, pitting reader against pundit, is offered herewith.

title: U. S. Attorney Beeins Inquiry
description: NEWYORK, Dec. 29 (UPI)United States Attorney Jonathan L. Goldstein said today that his office had begun an investigation into the cause of the grounding of the Olympic Games in the Delaware River.

title: Big Board Seat Up $3,000
description: A membership on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $75,000, pup $3,000 from the previous sale of Dec. 17, the exchange reported.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec. 29The State Supreme Court indicated today by an unusual request that it might be nearing a ruling on whether State Senator Stephen B. Wiley of Morris Township might take his place on the court.

title: George Dunne, Aide to Daley, Named His Succesor As Chairman of Cook County Democratic Committee
description: CHICAGO Dec. 29George W. Dunne, long a member of Richard J, Daley's inner circle, was chosen today to succeed the late Mayor as chairman of the Cook Ccunty Democratic Central Committee, the organization through which the Daley machine functioned.

title: Griffin Bell's Record
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29In 1966 the Georgia House of Representatives refused to seat Julian Bond, a newly elected black member. The reason was his endorsement of a statement by the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee criticizing the war in Vietnam and sympathizing with men who resisted the draft for service there.

title: Holography Museum to Reopen
description: The Museum of Holography, at 11 Mercer Street, the subject of an article in yesterday's New York Times, has shutdown for the holidays and will reopen next Wednesday.

title: Solar Heat Competitive With Electric, Agency Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 29The Federal energy research agency said today that solar heating can now compete economically with electricity in the heating of newly built, wellinsulated, onefamily houses in New York and at least 12 other cities.

title: Contributions to the Neediest Go Past the $600,000 Mark
description: The 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $11,698.14 from 200 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which is in its fourth week and will continue through February, now stands at $609,613.32.

title: FLU EXPERTS OPPOSE ENDING VACCINE BAN
description: ATLANTA. Dec. 29A group of expert advisers to the Federal Government today recommended continuing the present moratorium on influenza vaccinations because of the possible risk of a rare form of paralysis called GuillainBarrd Syndrome.

title: Riegle Named to Fill Hart's Term
description: LANSING, Mich., Dec. 29 (AP)United States Senatorelect Donald W. Riegle Jr. was appointed today by Governor William Milliken to finish the term of the late) Senator Philip A. Hart, who died Sunday of cancer. Senator Hart, an 18year veteran of the Senate, had not sought reelection. Mr. Riegle, a member of the House of Representatives, was elected to succeed him.

title: Homage Paid Casals In Native Catalonia
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 29Three years after his death in selfimposed exile in Puerto Rico, the memory of Pablo Casals was honored today in his beloved Catalonia.

title: Mystery Deepens in France Over Defrauding of Libyans
description: PARIS. Dec. 29A mystery involving the sale of fraudulent military equipment to Libya deepened today with evidence that the French Government, and apparently the Libyan Government as well, knew in advance that a fake deal was in the works.

title: Soviet Dissident Activity Is Rising
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 29Soviet dissident activity has risen in recent months, bringing a series of government countermeasures.

title: Quickwitted Illusionist is at Gate
description: Charles Pierce is, as he points out, an illusionist. With a variety of wigs and gowns, he creates the illusion of a brash and bawdy woman, who, in turn, gives the illusion of being an extraordinary, constantly changing room full of people, ranging from Shirley Temple to Eleanor Roosevelt.

title: CARTER TO CONTINUE TALKS ON ECONOMY
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., Dec. 29Presidentelect Carter concluded a series of meetings with his future Cabinet and other major advisers today, announced more meetings for next week to fashion the outlines of an economic recovery program and, in effect, confirmed that it was uncertain that his administration would seek a reduction in defense spending.

title: Tanker Captain Says He Had Wrong Nantucket Chart
description: Capt. Georgios Papadopoulos testified yesterday that his oil tanker, the Argo Merchant, lacked an uptodate chart for the currents near Nantucket Island when the ship ran aground and poured 7.5 million gallons of oil into the Atlantic.

title: 86th St. Group Advised on How to Eject Mental Agency
description: Picketing and demonstrations, political pressure and the raising of money from West 86th Street landlords to press lawsuits will be required to reverse the move by Bridge Inc. into the Brewster Hotel, but what is done can be undone, nearly 200 residents of the street were told at a meeting last night.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: China Reported Stepping Into Halt Fighting in a City South of Pering
description: China Reported Stepping Into Halt Fighting in a City South of Pering

title: NEWARK EMPLOYEES GOING BACK TO WORK
description: NEWARK, Dec. 29Although no garbage was collected in residential neighborhoods for the fourth straight day today, some of the striking public works employees began going back to their jobs in response to calls from their union leaders.

title: Senator Hart Buried On Mackinac Island
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Dec. 29 (AP)The burial of Senator Philip A. Hart took place at noon today in a snowy, wooded cemetery on this tiny island, which he called home.

title: Books of The Times
description: VOYAGE. By Sterling Hayden. 700 pages. Putnam. $12.95.

title: Railroad Properties Are Put Up for Sale
description: TRENTON, (UPI)Dec. 29  The State Department of Community Affairs is attempting to find buyers for abandoned railroad properties. Federal law gives governmental agencies preference on the properties.

title: The West German Leonberger: A Princely Choice Indeed
description: Prince Alexander Ratibor lives in 746yearold, 35room castle in Stuttgart, West Germany. His dual professional career as a veterinarian and agricultural engineer blends with his avocation for breeding Leonbergers, and showing French bulldogs on the continent. Whether he's participating as a judge or exhibitor or spectator, the prince is at home in any country as long as he's at a dog show.

title: Wild Horses Are Still Unclaimed
description: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., Dec. 29 (UPI)Nine wild horses captured in an October roundup south of Little America, Wyo., have not been claimed under the Bureau of Land Management's adopt a horse program. The agency said yesterday the horses may have to be destroyed if not adopted. Persons wanting to get the horses must agree to treat them humanely and not exploit them commercially.

title: Supreme Court Grants Extension To Two Watergate Defendants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) Chief, Justice Warren E. Burger today gave John N. Mitchell and H. R. Haldeman 29 extra days to appeal to the Supreme Court their convictions for conspiracy, obstruction of justice and perjury in the Watergate case.

title: Market's Best and Worst in 76
description: Some investors who favor dark horses, or secondary issues, did very well in the stock market this year.

title: DR. EUGENE F. RUSSELL
description: Dr. Eugene F. Russell, who retired in 1942 as a vice president of Mutual Life Insurance Company in New York City, died yesterday in Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 91 years old.

title: Yonkers Trot Feature: Arrivederci, Bandinelli
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 29The feature trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway was named La Festa Italiana Invernale (The Italian Winter Festival) in honor of the guest driving star, Dino Bandinelli, the campion reinsman of Sicily.

title: Brazilian Politicians Protest
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 29The publication of documents relating to the role of the United States Government before the 1964 rightwing military coup in Brazil has led to a flurry of protests by Brazilian politicians who were unfavorably protrayed.

title: Manila strip on Ninth Ave. Is Bit of Home for Filipinos
Dyce Is Easy Victor In 1:53.8 for HalfMile
description: Byron Dyce, home on vacation from his doctoral studies at the University of Florida, ran his first competitive race of the indoor season last night and won the halfmile event in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's development meet.

title: A Hostel Mazel Toy! for Fiddler
description: On opening night at Fiddler on the Roof Tuesday, there was no mistaking the billing: It was Zero Mostel above and beyond the title.The.evening was, first of all, a celebration fcir the actor. And when the curtain fell it was Mostel solo, who received a standing ovaLion.

title: Ties That Bind Soviet Bloc More Economic Than Political
description: BUCHAREST, RumaniaJust a few hours before he greeted Leonid I. Brezhnev at Bucharest's airport, President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania made time to see another visitor, Secretary of Commerce Elliot L. Richardson.

title: Salzburg Marionettes Present Magic Flute
description: In its weeklong engagement at Alice Tully Hall, the Salzburg Marionettes have been concentrating on the presentation of fairy tales, ideal holiday fare for children. On Tuesday night, they gave the first of the three opera performances that were scheduled and ended up with another fairy tale. This was The Magic Flute, raised by Mozart's music to the realm of high art, but still filled with the fantasy and illusion that appeal to the young.

title: New Freestyle Skiing Clinics Reflect the Sport's Growing Acceptance
description: HUNTER, N.Y., Dec. 29  Freestyle skiing has come a long way since such internationalists as Stein Ericksen, Herman Goellner and Arthur Furrer used to do somersaults off bumps at Sugarbush, Killington and Bolton Valley, respectively. In those days, about 10 years ago, flipping on skis was an oddity. Today, freestyling pros are doing everything from the moebius flip (a full twisting back layout) to double and triple heliocoptors (airborne vertical revolutions with the body). Such potentially dangerous routines have caused skiarea operators across the United States to months of reevaluating.

title: About New York
description: As Alex Rcse lay dying Monday night, his secretary of 25 years, Florence Erdel, visited his bedside, not for a sad farewell, but to bring him up to date on who called that day and what they wanted. This was the essential Alex Rose tracking his communicants to the end, studying the thoughts and people of politics that clustered to him each day as if the telephone itself were patronage.

title: Engine Fire Forces Jet Back
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 29 (UPI) A Delta DC9 jet, bound from Atlanta to Chicago with several stops, caught fire shortly after takeoff from Chattanooga's Lovell Field today, forcing it to return for an emergency landing. The plane, flight No. 694, carrying 44 persons, made it in safely and there were no injuries. The fire, in the engine, went out before the plane landed.

title: Rescue Operation Set Up for Birds Crippled by Oil in the Delaware
description: GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Dec. 29A threestate bird rescue operation was set up today by Federal wildlife officials to save hundreds of ducks and goese covered with oil from a tanker spill in the Delaware River two days ago.

title: Ruins Show Urban Life Rivaling Egypt's
description: The discovery of a major urban civilization that rose in northern Syria 4,400 years ago and rivaled its only contemporaries, Mesopotamia and Egypt, is being acclaimed as one one of the most significant archeological advances of the century.

title: 3 Repairmen on Board
description: BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP)The Argo Merchant carried an unusual complement of three portbased repairmen when she ran aground two weeks ago off Nantucket, attorneys for Cape Cod fishermen said yesterday.

title: Rebound Linked to Reactivation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Continental Bank of Chicago, in a recent commentary on housing markets, said the rebound in multifamily housing in part reflects the reactivation of governmentsubsidized housing programs, which have remained virtually dormant for at least two years.

title: Majors Plays QuickChange Artist at Sugar Bowl
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29Johnny Majors, who has three days to go as the University of Pittsburgh head football coach, returned to the scene of his best known mistake and found himself the center of a socialprofessional situation that he admitted was a little bit bizarre.

title: Marion Rombauer Becker, 73, Dies; Coauthor of The Joy of Cooking
description: Marion Rombauer Becker, coauthor of the bestselling The Joy of Cooking, died Tuesday night of cancer at Holmes Hospital in Cincinnati, where she lived. She would have been 74 years old next Sunday.

title: SCOPPETTA PROPOSES A POLICE EVALUATION
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, proposed yesterday a system of evaluating individual police officers that would include such data as how many of their arrests ultimately resulted in convictions.

title: Carter's Pledge to New York Leaves Banks and Union Heads Still Wary
description: Labor leaders and bankers said yesterday that they were pleased with Presidentelect Carter's new assurances about New York City, but that many additional questions had to be answered before they could agree to a plan to redeem nearly $1 billion in city shortterm notes.

title: Green, Baylor Star, Unsure of Pro  status Without Draft
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 29Perhaps Gary Green is one of the best college football players in America and one who might play professionally for 15 years, like Mel Renfro of the Dallas Cowboys or Pat Fischer of the Washington Redskins. Perhaps. Green has no idea how good he is or isn't. Inasmuch as there are no plans, as of this moment, for a draft of the college players by the pros early next year the Class of 77 lacks any sense of Its worth in terms of dollars.

title: 5,200 Fled East Germany in 76
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 29 (Reuters)About 5,200 East Germans fled to the West during 1976 and 9,900 emigrated legally, it was announced today by the refugee group known as the Aug. 13 Association, named for the date of the build:ing of the Berlin Wall in 1961. Most of the fugitives fled by way of third countries, but 620 risked their lives by directly crossing the ruined and heavily guarded border, the association said.

title: Mexico Seizes Marijuana
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec 29 (Reuters)The police said today they had seized 10 tons of marijuana valued at $5 million after an American plane crashed and was abandoned at a smugglers airstrip near Culiacn in northwest Mexico. No arrests were made.

title: Constitution Passes Test of Time And Scrutiny of 200 Teenagers
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Dec. 29Two hundred high school students have spent the last three days analyzing the United States Constitution at a Youth Constitutional Convention here, and the teenage delegates seem agreed that the document needs no drastic changes.

title: Moods of Oriental Dance, Offbeat Event, Stars Navida
description: Belly dancing would be one name for most of what was on view Tuesday night in an offbeat program at the Hudson Guild Theater, 441 West 26th Street.

title: 4 WOMAN, 82, IS MUGGED IN EAST SIDE APARTMENT
description: An 82yearold woman was shoved into her lower East Side apartment as she turned her key in the lock early yesterday afternoon, punched in the face, threatened with a knife and robbed of more than $350 by a man the police believe had also attacked two women in their 80's early asl week.

title: P.G.A. Suit Withdrawn
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 29 (AP)Jack Spradlin says he has withdrawn a Federal antitrust suit against the Professional Golfers Association for dropping him from membership in 1975. Spiadlin's suit asked for reinstatement of his P.G.A. tour eligibility and cash damages.

title: French Say Politician Was Slain For Life Insurance, Not Politics
description: PARIS. Dec. 29The bizarre assassination on Friday of Prince Jean de Broglie, a prominent politician, took an even more curious turn today as officials said that the motive for the killing was not political retribution, as earlier believed, but money.

title: C.A.B. Accusation Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29A lawyer for the Civil Aeronautics Board charged today that Flying Tiger Line Inc., a Los Angelesbased cargo carrier, gave money and corporate gifts to American politicians and foreign dignitaries and then improperly listed them as operating expenses.

title: Manhattan, Purdue Reach Final By Defeating Penn, Georgetown
description: limited McDonald to 4 points in the first half, denying him the ball, forcing rush his shots and boxing, him off the boards. McDonald was 1 for 9. In the second half McDonald did better and finished with 14 points. He fouled out with 58 seconds left. Penn started the season as the favorite to regain the Ivy League title it lost to Princeton last season. The Quakers were accorded the high ranking because they had an outstanding freshman team last season. But amid all the glowing predictions, Coach Chuck Daly had warned that his players had big high school reputations and little experience.

title: Rescue Operation Set Up for Birds Crippled by Oil in the Delaware
description: GLOUCESTER CITY, N.J., Dec. 29A threestate bird rescue operation was set up today by Federal wildlife officials to save hundreds of ducks and geese covered with oil from a tanker spill in the Delaware River two days ago.

title: Gunman Holding Seven Hostages Shot and Killed by Kansas Police
description: FLAYSVILLE, Kan., Dec. 29 (AP)Police marksmen shot and killed ?? on?? mental patient tonight, ending an eighthour ordeal that began when he took a woman and (cur children hostage at gunpoint in their home in this suburb of Wichita.

title: ..And at a West Side Deli, There Was Caviar For the Employees, at a Party in Their Honor
description: For 364 days a year, the employees of Zabar's serve the customers of the West Side delicatessen, but once a year they are the guests at a party in their honor.

title: Contributions to the Neediest Go Past the $600,000 Mark
description: The 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund passed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $11,698.14 from 200 donors, The overall figure for the campaign, which is in its fourth week and will continue through February, now stands at $609,613.32.

title: James F. Ryan Marries Anne van Munching Johnson
description: Anne van Munching Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo van Munching of Greenwich, Conn., and Bal Harbour, Fla., was married yesterday evening to James F. Ryan, a widower of Old Greenwich, Conn. He is the son of the late Dr. Joseph P. Ryan, a physician, of Hartford, and the late Mrs. Chester M. Curry of New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The massive oil spill from the grounding and the breakup of the tanker Argo Merchant provides another grim example of the lack of competence in and regulation of merchant marine activities. That the ship owners U.S. representative himself attributes the vessel's grounding to erratic currents merely underlines the fact that many ships are captained, navigated and manned by less than competent personnel.

title: Market Place
description: Some astute individuals are earning extra income by paying large bills with checks written against their interestbearing moneymarket fund investments.

title: MOBILE SILVERSTEIN
description: Mollie Silverstein, a former high school teacher of business courses, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. She was 69 years old and lived at 22614 137th Avenue, Quens.

title: Parking Rules Eased
description: Alternate side of the street parking regulations will continue to be suspended today because of the snow, Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff announced. All other parking and standing regulations remain in effect.

title: C.A.B. WILL CONSIDER BIDS TO SERVE CHICAGO AIRPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  The Civil Aeronautics Board said today it was proceeding to consider applications by two corporations to offer lowcost service to and from Chicago's Midway Airport in case the board says is unique and could have farreaching consequences for both domestic air transportation and the problem of service at Midway.

title: Yonkers Budget Power Is Switched
description: YONKERS, Dec. 29The City Council regained control of the Yonkers budget last night by removing from the City Manager the power to create and eliminate jobs and set salariesa role that had been given to him in a 1970 law.

title: Hearings Will Open March 20 on OilGas Accounting
description: Working under a Congressional deadline, the Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday set next March 20 for public hearings to begin on accounting standards for oil and gas producers and other extractive industries.

title: Carey Warns City University on Campaign to Prevent Cuts in Its Budget
description: ALBANY, Dec. 29Governor Carey warned today that the City University's Mobilization, the public relations effort designed to forestall budget cuts, shouldn't develop into a resistance movement to jar the city out of a balanced budget.

title: Solar Heat Competitive With Electric, Agency Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 29The Federal energy research agency said today that solar heating can now compete economically with electricity in the heating of newly built, wellinsulated, onefamily houses in New York and at least 12 other cities.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FIRE flours 119 GUESTS IN SNOWSTORM: An elderly resident being carried by a fireman yesterday after an early morning blaze forced evacuation of the Copley Square Hotel in Boston. At least 13, including two firemen, were treated for smoke inhalation, cuts and bruises. Damage to hotel was estimated at $50,000. One guest was hospitalized.

title: News Summary
description: Political unrest in Paoting, about 100 miles south of Peking, is reported to have erupted into conflict requiring intervention from the Chinese capital to quell it. The reports from reliable sources in Peking said that raiding of arsenals, blowing up of factories, looting, murder and rape in Paoting were linked with supporters of the discredited Chiang Ching, widow of Mao Tsetung, and the three other radicals accused of plotting to seize pciwer. [Page 1, Columns 45.]

title: Homage Paid Casals In Native Catalonia
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 29Three years after his death in selfimposed exile in Puerto Rico, the memory of Pablo Casals was honored today in his beloved Catalonia.

title: STATE WILL ACQUIRE A DUNES AREA ON L I.
description: PORT JEFFERSON L.I., Dec. 29New York State will soon acquire a 1,300acre area of beaches, dunes and rare wetlands on Long Island's South Fork.

title: Pamela Gridley Is Married
description: The marriage of Pamela West Gridley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Craig West Gridley, to Carlo Cattermole McGinnis son, of Mr., and Mrs. Edward Clair McGinnis; took place yesterday afternoon. Both families live in Dayton, Ohio, where the Rev. Robert D. Fenwick and the Rev. James Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: BUILDING CONTRACTS ROSE 37% IN MONTH ON RESIDENTIAL GAIN
description: With November residential construction contracts running 50 percent ahead of the November 1975 level, the total of construction contracts last month at $7.69 billion showed an increase of 37 percent over the level of the corresponding month of 1975, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: COMPOSITE INDEXES INDICATE ECONOMY IS EXPANDING AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Government's composite indexes of leading indicators and coincident indicators of the economy both rose in November, the Commerce Department reported today, giving a further signal that the summer and early autumn pause in the economy has given way to renewed expansion.

title: Sports Today
description: E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7 P.M.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: High inventories indicative of the slackened demand for its products has prompted temporary closedown at a textile fiber plant, an iron ore mine and 11 plants of a major textile producer in Canada. All of them were announced yesterday.

title: United Press International
description: PROTEST IMPRISONMENT OF COMMUNISTS:

title: Mental Patient Transfer Sought in Nurses Strike
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 29 (AP)The State Commissioner of Human Services today was ordered to show cause why patients at Meadowview Hospital should not be transferred to staterun psychiatric treatwent centers.

title: Sabres 6, Flames 3
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Jim Schoenfeld scored a goal and set up another to propel the Buffalo Sabres to a 6.3 victory over the Atlanta Flames at the Omni tonight. The triumph was Buffalo's ninth straight.

title: People and Business
description: A 50cent service charge on creditcard users, imposed earlier this year by Citibank has come under attack by Leonard Lapidus, acting New York State Superintendent of Banks.

title: Brazil's Hopes Falter in Coping With Oil Rises
description: RIO DE JANEIROIn Braziland throughout the developing worlda growing discontent and sense of crisis have emerged over the sharp oil price increases decreed by the Organization of Oil Exporting Countries.

title: U.S. Assembled a Force in 1964 For Possible Use in Brazil Coup
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29The Administation of President Lyndon B. Johnson prepared briefly to intervene in Brazil with naval and airborne units in 1964 to prevent leftist forces from seizing power in the wake of an expected millary coup, according to recently released documents and to the former United States Ambassador, Lincoln Gordon.

title: In SoHo, King Kong Cookies And may Wray Punch
description: They came to the party to see a gorilla grab at airplanes from his perch atop the 12foot Christmas tree. Or was it the Empire State Building?

title: Spark of Religious Fervor Still Strong in Turkey
description: KONYA, TurkeyThe pilgrims shuffle slowly into the greendomed mausoleum, the mud of their fields still clinging to their plastic shoes. When they reach the sarcophagus, they raise their hands chest high, palms up, and begin to murmur the old prayers. Sonic try to kneel on the brightly patterned prayer rugs, but the guard usually stops them. Officially, the building is now museum, and devotion cannot be too obvious.

title: Albany Consumer Unit Calls Sealant a Health Peril
description: New Yorkers were warned yesterday not to purchase or use for any purpose a silicone caulking sealant made by General Electric, because of possible hazards from the arsenic compound it contained.

title: FIRM TONE CONTINUES ON CREDIT MARKETS
description: Credit markets continued to show a firm tone in quiet trading yesterday. The Government securities sector was buoyed during the afternoon after the Federal Reserve injected permanent reserves into the banking system by purchasing Treasury coupons. This move, which could be a hint of further slight easing of credit conditions by the nation's money manager, came as a surprise to some traders.

title: Secret C. I. A. Data Are Found in Home Of ExAgency Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation found hundreds of secret Central Intelligence Agency documents in the home of a retired C.I.A. employee charged with trying to sell documents to the Soviet Union, according to an inventory, the bureau filed with a Federal maaistrate.

title: DiBrito 62, 75 Victor; Powers Wins at State Net
description: GEEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 29Topseeded Carlos DiBrito of Brazil led the way into the semifinals of the New York state men's indoor tennis championship today at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: Britain Prepares to Use Warships To Protect Oil Fields in North Sea
description: Early in 1977, Britain's Royal Navy will deploy five small warships as the first step toward military protection of the North Sea oil and gas fields.

title: Ella Dutcher Romig, 84, Is Dead; Led a Board of Reformed Church
description: Ella Dutcher Romig of Washington, former president of the Women's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America, died Monday whilo visiting a son, the Rev. David W. Romig, pastor of the Downtown United Presbyterian Church in Rochester. She was 84 years old.

title: PRINCESS ANDREE
description: CANNES, France, Dec. 29 (UPI) Princess Andree, a former wife of the late Aga Khan, died today in Cannes, gamily sources said. She was 70 years old.

title: Profit Taking in Stock Market Sends Dow Average Below 1,000
description: The stock market ignored some favorable economic news yesterday as profit taking weakened the list and sent the Dow Jones industrial average below the 1,000 level at the close.

title: A Bowl Warm up for Hayes: Some New Targets to Attack
description: MIAMI, Dec. 29Having said earlier this week that he could live with Jimmy Caster and without girlie magazines, Woody Hayes found another target for his verbal punches todayathletic scholarships based on need.

title: Gibson Joins Reshuffled Giants Staff
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 29Bob Gibson, not the former St. Louis Cardinal pitcher but the former Youngstown University quarterback, was the only newcomer announced today by Coach John McVay to the Giants reshuffled coaching staff.

title: Combating PoliceState Tendencies
description: WASHINGTON  The coming to power of an elected President with Congress controlled by his own political party offers an unparalleled opportunity to bring an end to lawbreaking by the intelligence and police agencies of the Federal Government.

title: Storm Blocks Coast Guard
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Dec. 29 (AP)A winter storm today stalled the Coast Guard's efforts to map the movements of the oil slick off Nantucket because oceanographers were unable to fly over the 130mile long spill.

title: News Summary
description: Political unrest in Paoting, about 100 miles south of Peking, is reported to have erupted into conflict requiring intervention from the Chinese capital to quell it. The reports from reliable sources in Peking said that raiding of arsenals, blowing up of factories, looting, murder and rape in Paoting were linked with supporters of the discredited Chiang Ching, widow of Mao Tsetung, and the three other radicals accused of plotting to seize power. [Page 1, Columns 45]

title: Shipping/Mails
description: DART ATLANTIC (Dart). Antwerp Jan. (, Southampton 10, Copenhagen 11 and Dublin 12; sails from Global Marine Terminal, N.J.

title: and the Defense Budget
description: During the campaign, Presidentelect Carter seemed to indicate that his intention was not to reduce, military spending but only the rate of growth. Even this will not be easily done, as Defense Secretarydesignate Harold Brown has now affirmed. Any proposed cutback undoubtedly will run into resistance from the militaryindustrialCongressional complex, reinforced by upward revisions recently in intelligence estimates of the Soviet Union's capabilities and intentions. It is vital, nevertheless, to recognize that the problem is political more than military. The nation's military capability could be maintained and even improved at significantly lower cost. The catalogue of potential savings is long.

title: Gold Bars Stolen in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 29 (Reuters)Three men using false documents stole a consignment of gold bars, diamonds and coins worth 4 million Hong Kong dollars ($858,000) from the international airport over Christmas, the police said today. A cargo terminal spokesman said the consignment had been flown here from Zurich by Swissair.

title: Controls for Large Oil Spills Lag
description: Coast Guard pollutioncontrol officers said yesterday that no capability existed in the technology for control of oil spill that could cope with a calamitous spill in a storm. They cited the discharge of 7.5 million gallons of oil from the Argo Merchant, which broke up last week off Nantucket, Mass.

title: Today's Events
description: 10 A.M.5 P.M.: Bicentennial exhibltsWar Memorial Visitors Center, New Jersey Stale Museum, State Libryte Archives Room, State House Rotunda. Military encampmenWashington Crossing State Park, Admission free.

title: New York Council Expected to Clear New District Lines
description: The New York City Council is expected to approve next Wednesday nine nominees for an independent, nonpartisan commission to draw new Council lines for the 1977 elections.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GINGER'S OWN Television viewers enjoying this week's festival of Fred AstaireGinger Rogers musical movies have a bonus in store in the form of a rare theatrical revival of Kitty Foyle (1940) coupled with Roxie Hart (1942) tomorrow through Sunday at the Theater SO St. Marks (2547400).

title: HAZEL HARDY OF ABC DIES OF CANCER AT AGE OF 32
description: Hazel Hardy, a publications executive with the American Broadcasting Companies Inc., died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 32. Mrs. Hardy, whose home was in Ossining, N.Y., had been ill for several months with cancer.

title: Scoppetta Proposes an Evaluation Of Police, Including Arrest Record
description: Nicholas Scoppetta, the city's new Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, proposed yesterday a system of evaluating individual police officers, that would include such data as how many of their arrests ultimately resulted in convictions.

title: Congress Panel Critical of Army's ShortWar Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Congres sional Budget Office suggested today that the Army was buying the wrong type of helicopter and planning to form the wrong kind of division if it is expected to fight a short, intense war in Europe.

title: TopRanked Michigan Upset By Providence
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 29Unranked Providence College scored a stunning, doubleovertime upset over topranked Michigan tonight in the final of the first Industrial National Classic.

title: Abel Scores Steel Union Insurgent
description: I. W. Abel, the retiring president of the United Steelworkers of America, pledged yesterday to campaign in the Ants, the mines, the mills, the factories and the shops for Lloyd McBride as his successor against the insurgent challenger Ed Sadlowski, who, he said, was the cocktail party candidate for president of our union.

title: Unification Church Denies Bigotry Is a Part of Its Basic Philosophy
description: Spokesmen for the Unification Church yesterday described as hysterical and malicious criticisms made Tuesday by Christian and Jewish leaders of the movement, which is led by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: China Reported Stepping Into Halt Fighting in a City South of Peking
description: PEKING, Dec. 29  Longsmoldering political unrest in a city about 100 miles south of here has reportedly erupted into armed conflict, forcing Peking to intervene to quell it.

title: GRACE H. TURNBULL
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 (UPI)  Funeral services will be held tomorrow for Grace H. Turnbull, noted Maryland sculptor, painter, author and temperance advocate. She died yesterday at Union Memorial Hospital at the age of 96.

title: Dave Anderson
description: He had enough problems of his owna heart attack in September, another bad season for the New York Jets, the sudden resignation of Lou Holtz as coach, the selection of a new coach. But on Tuesday at lunch Phil Iselin was telling others in the Jets front office about what a difficult year it had been for his wife. Poor Betty, he said. Between her mother and me, she's been in hospitals all year. That afternoon Phil Iselin died. Almost as if to spare Betty any more hospital visits, he was stricken by a heart attack as he sat at his desk in the Madison Avenue office he occupied as the Jets president. He also was the president and chairman of Monmouth Park race track. Pleasant, friendly, thoughtful, Philip H. Iselin was one of nice people. But he always appeared more comfortable and more knowledgeable at his race track Than with his football team. Perhaps that's why Monmouth Park always was more successful under his direction than the Jets were. As a modest millionaire in the women's dress business, lie had been involved in the syndicate of New Jersey sportsmen who built the race track in 1944. And he was proud to have been the chairman of the construction committee.

title: Books of The Times
description: Sterling Hayden's Voyage is the sort of book some critic is certain to call a blockbuster, but I believe that this particular block has already been busted beyond repair. Epic novels of the sea are generally foul weather in fiction, and Voyage is not responsive to the helm. I always liked Mr. Hayden as an understated actor, but as a writer he is a terrible ham.

title: Notes on People
description: Two United States Senators, Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia and Lowell P. 1,Veicker of Connecticut, are separating from their wives. Marie Louise Weicker yesterday asked Superior Court in Stamford for a divorce, saying in her complaint, filed under the state's nofault law, that her 23yearold marriage to the Republican Senator was irretrievably broken. And in McDonough, Ga., it was Mr. Talmadge who yesterday filed a petition for divorce from his wife of 35 years, Betty Talmadge. Under Georgia's nofault divorce law, the Democrat stated only that he and his wife had been living apart, and their marriage was irretrievably broken. In the case .of the Weicker divorce, Mrs. Weicker asked for custody of the couple's 16yearold son, Gray G. Weicker. Another son, Scot B. Veicker, is /8 years old. The Talmadges only living son, Herman Jr., is 34 years old.

title: Funeral Services for Iselin Set For Tomorrow in New Jersey
description: The funeral for Philip H. Iselin, president of the New York Jets football team and of Monmouth Park race track, will be held tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock at Temple Beth Miriam, Elberon, N. J. Mr. Iselin died Tuesday.

title: Carter Jobs Filled But Only for a Day
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29  The Carter camp found itself in a minor todo tonight over what various spokesmen sought to treat as a premature and possibly, though not necessarily, inaccurate disclosure of several major White House staff appointments by a senior transition aide.

title: VANCE FORMS STAFF OF OLD AND NEW AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29Cyrus R. Vance, the Secretary of Statedesignate, has virtually assembled his highlevel staff, combining some new faces, former and present Foreign Service officers and at least four key aides to Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger.

title: Tanker Aground in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 29 (UPI)The Liberian tanker Daphne carrying 14 million gallons of oil ran aground off Puerto Rico's southern shore yesterday. A Coast Guard crew boarded the ship today to make certain the captain dumped none of his cargo.

title: RCA REDUCES ITS PRICES FOR FACTORY COLOR TV'S
description: The RCA Corporation's consumer electronics division announced yesterday factory price reductions on color television that should make possible optional retail price cuts of from $20 to $40 a unit.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 23.3%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 12.1 billion tonmiles, 23.3 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 346,560 cars, 18.9 percent above last year.

title: Pro Transactions
description: WASHINGION (NHL)Recalied Mike Marson. ?? wing, from Springfield of the American League and Bill Pilcy, right wing, from Dayton of rho international League; Sent Tom Rowe, right wing, to Springfild, and Paul Nicholson, left Wing, to Dayton.

title: TANKER MATE LOOKED FOR LIGHTSHIP IN VAIN
description: Top officers of the oil tanker Argo Merchant remained on the bridge for several hours to see the Nantucket Lightship before the tanker ran aground, according to testimony yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Ray Asserts He Is Willing To Give the House Inquiry Facts in Dr. King Slaying
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30James Earl Ray has made an apparently conditional offer to testify before the House Select Committee on Assassinations about the 1968 killing of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Publishing: The Holocaust
description: UDDENLY, it looks as if this is the season of new books and films about the Holocaust and its aftermath. The Holocaust is neither a trend nor trendy; it has become a recognized discipline.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: It isn't only the champagne that will go pop tonight. Over at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the Joffrey Ballet will present three ballets to rock music as its own New Year Eve's celebration, beginning at 8 P.M.

description: Article 10  No Title

title: Variety is the Norm For Elizabeth Keen
description: Choreography has no boundaries for Elizabeth Keen, whose dance company opens a weeklong run Sunday at P.M. at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.
